{"uri": "8148534363", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "17:30:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T17:30:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T17:29:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.cbssports.com/tennis/news/2024-french-open-rafael-nadal-loses-to-alexander-zverev-in-his-potentially-final-appearance-at-roland-garros/", "title": "2024 French Open: Rafael Nadal loses to Alexander Zverev in his potentially final appearance at Roland Garros - CBSSports.com", "body": "Getty Images\n\nRafael Nadal has been eliminated from the 2024 French Open in the first round of the Grand Slam tournament. Nadal, who is a 14-time French Open champion, lost to No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev 6-3, 7-6, 6-3 on Monday.\n\nIn a match that lasted just over three hours, Zverev was victorious in what could be Nadal's final appearance at Roland Garros. Following the match, Nadal left the clay courts and received a rousing ovation from the fans in attendance.\n\n\"As I said, it's a big, big chance that it's going to be my last Roland Garros, but if I have to tell you it's 100 percent my last Roland Garros, sorry, but I will not, because I cannot predict what's going on. I hope you understand,\" Nadal said following Monday's loss.\n\nSome of the sport's biggest stars -- including Novak Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz and Iga Swiatek -- were looking on as Nadal exited the court for perhaps the final time.\n\nNadal came into this year's French Open unseeded after battling through injuries in recent years. On the other hand, Zverev entered the Grand Slam tournament after recently winning the Italian Open, and he is likely viewed as one of the favorites to win the French Open.\n\nDefeating Nadal is quite a remarkable feat as Zverev becomes just the third player to beat Nadal in the French Open. Djokovic and Robin Soderling are the only other players who took down Nadal on the clay courts of Roland Garros.\n\nIf this was Nadal's final match at the French Open, he would finish with a 112-4 career record at the Grand Slam tournament. Nadal last won the French Open in 2022, which is his last major title.", "source": {"uri": "cbssports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBS Sports"}, "authors": [{"uri": AP\n\nIn what could be his last French Open, 14-times champion Rafael Nadal faces a tough task to avoid it all ending in a first-round exit when he plays Alexander Zverev on Monday. Nadal had already announced that this could be the final season of his career but on his arrival in Paris the Spaniard said he could not yet be sure that he was ready to close the door on Roland Garros.\n\nAfter missing last year's tournament through injury, Nadal will be keen to make the most of his return, as will his fans, but standing in his way is fourth-seeded German Zverev, fresh from his triumph at the Italian Open.\n\n\"It's not ideal the first match, because I feel competitive to have this match later in the tournament, but it's how it is,\" Nadal said.\n\n\"I need to be ready since the beginning. Let's see.\"\n\nThe meeting will bring back contrasting memories for both players of the last time they met, in a French Open semi-final in 2022, when Nadal went on to win yet another title in Paris, the last of his 22 Grand Slam victories.\n\nZverev was forced to retire from that match with an ankle injury. He underwent surgery and ended up missing the rest of the season with another injury, but he returned last year to reach his third consecutive French Open semi-final.\n\nWith some of the other top players such as Novak Djokovic, Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz, struggling with injuries of late, this could be Zverev's chance to finally win a Grand Slam.\n\nThe German might not have wanted to meet Nadal so early in the tournament but he was happy to have the chance to take him on again.\n\n\"I really wanted to play him here. I did not want to play him in the first round. {"uri": "2024-05-370730607", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "10:56:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T10:56:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T10:56:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://gulftoday.ae/sport/2024/05/28/zverev-defeats-nadal-in-roland-garros-blockbuster", "title": "Zverev defeats Nadal in Roland Garros blockbuster", "body": "Germany's Alexander Zverev reacts after defeating Spain's Rafael Nadal during their first round match of the French Open tennis tournament at the Roland Garros stadium in Paris on Monday. AP\n\nRafael Nadal's illustrious French Open career came to a likely end with his first ever defeat in the opening round by Alexander Zverev on Monday, after Iga Swiatek made a winning start in her bid for a fourth title.\n\nNadal matched world number four Zverev for long periods on a packed Court Philippe Chatrier, but slipped to a 6-3, 7-6 (7/5), 6-3 loss as he was beaten for just the fourth time in 116 matches at the tournament.\n\nThis year's event was expected to be the 14-time champion's farewell to Roland Garros, but he had since insisted he could not confirm \"100 per cent\" it would be his last appearance.\n\n\"If it is (the last time), then you have been amazing,\" Nadal told an adoring crowd under the Chatrier roof.\n\n\"The feelings I have today are difficult to describe in words. It is the place I love the most.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 next week, showed all his trademark fighting qualities in a gripping match, but only managed to convert two of 11 break points against an inspired opponent.\n\n\"The first round wasn't ideal,\" he admitted, before saying he \"hoped\" to be back at Roland Garros later this summer for the Paris Olympics but would almost certainly skip Wimbledon.\n\n\"It will be difficult playing on grass considering that right after Wimbledon are the Olympic Games.\"\n\nRafael Nadal reacts as he plays against Alexander Zverev at the Roland Garros stadium in Paris, on Monday. AP\n\nIt was only Nadal's fifth tournament since January 2023 after suffering a hip injury and then a muscle tear, arriving in Paris a lowly 275th in the world rankings.\n\n\"It's hard to say about the future,\" he added. \"I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. The body is feeling better than it did two months ago.\"\n\nNadal was unseeded for the draw and vulnerable to a difficult opening round.\n\nGerman Zverev, who lifted the Rome Open title last month, proved too strong despite the fans desperately attempting to raise Nadal to past glories.\n\nThe 27-year-old banished the memories of the duo's last meeting, when he left Chatrier court on a wheelchair after injuring his ankle during their 2022 French Open semi-final.\n\nHis reward for becoming just the third player to defeat Nadal at Roland Garros -- after Novak Djokovic and Robin Soderling -- is a match against either David Goffin or home wildcard Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard.\n\nZverev's fast start\n\nZverev started the match strongly with a break to love in the opening game, going on to wrap up the first set with relative ease.\n\nRafael Nadal (right) checks hands with the winner Alexander Zverev at the Roland Garros Complex in Paris. AFP\n\nNadal was much improved from his most recent outing, when he was well beaten by Hubert Hurkacz in the Rome second round, but failed to serve out the second set when leading 5-4.\n\nZverev then came out on top in a tense tie-break as a Nadal return found the net.\n\nThe Spaniard again broke first in the third set to lead 2-0, much to the delight of the 15,000 spectators in attendance, including Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz, Swiatek and Manchester City footballer Rodri.\n\nBut Zverev quickly hit back once more, before breaking for a 4-3 lead with a wonderful passing winner.\n\nHe secured victory on his first match point as Nadal blazed a forehand off target, potentially ending the most dominant career at a single event in Grand Slam history.", "source": {"uri": "gulftoday.ae", {"uri": "8149217890", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "06:11:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T06:11:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T06:11:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://newsable.asianetnews.com/sports/french-open-2024-nadal-eyes-olympics-but-not-wimbledon-after-exit-says-body-has-been-a-jungle-for-2-years-snt-se6m4k", "title": "French Open 2024: Nadal eyes Olympics but not Wimbledon after exit, says 'body has been a jungle for 2 years'", "body": "Rafael Nadal's legendary French Open career likely reached its conclusion on Monday when the 14-time champion suffered a demoralizing defeat against Alexander Zverev.\n\nRafael Nadal's legendary French Open career likely reached its conclusion on Monday when the 14-time champion suffered a demoralizing defeat against Alexander Zverev. Following the match, Nadal disclosed that his path to the Paris Olympics in July would bypass Wimbledon.\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3, lost 6-3, 7-6 (7/5), 6-3 in the first round to world number four Zverev, marking only his fourth defeat in 116 matches at Roland Garros since his debut title in 2005.\n\nThis first-round exit, his first-ever at Roland Garros, raises further questions about his future in the sport.\n\n\"I don't know if it's the last time I'll be here in front of all of you,\" he said.\n\n\"If it is, then you have been amazing. The feelings I have today are difficult to describe in words. It is the place I love the most,\" the Spanish ace added.\n\n\"It's hard to say about the future. I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. The body is feeling better than it did two months ago. Maybe in two months I say it's enough. That is something I don't feel yet,\" Nadal stated.\n\nRafael Nadal may not return for the 2025 French Open, but he still plans to compete in the Olympics at Roland Garros in July.\n\nNadal, who won Olympic singles gold in Beijing in 2008 and doubles gold at the Rio Games, told reporters, \"That's my main goal now. I need to prepare myself the proper way to try to arrive healthy and well-prepared.\"\n\nAlthough Rafael Nadal won't meet the rankings cut for the Olympics, he would still be eligible for a spot reserved for Grand Slam winners.\n\nPlagued by injuries that have limited him to just four events since January last year, the former world number one is now ranked 275 and was unseeded in Paris.\n\n\"My body has been a jungle for two years. You don't know what to expect. You know, I wake up one day and I found a snake biting me. Another day a tiger,\" said Nadal of his recent battles with a hip injury.\n\nIn his career, Rafael Nadal has had to skip 11 Grand Slams. This number is set to become 12 next month, as he is likely to skip Wimbledon, where he was the champion in 2008 and 2010.\n\n\"It looks difficult to make a transition to grass, having the Olympics again on clay,\" he said.\n\n\"I don't think it's going to be smart after all the things that happened to my body now make a big transition to a completely different surface and then come back immediately to clay. I don't think it's a positive idea right now,\" Nadal concluded.\n\nAlexander Zverev expressed that it had been \"a great honour\" to play Rafael Nadal 11 times in their careers.\n\n\"I've watched Rafa play all my childhood, and I was lucky enough to play him two times on this beautiful court. Today is not my moment, it is Rafa's moment,\" said the German star.\n\nIn a rematch of the 2022 semi-final, which Nadal won when Zverev withdrew due to ankle ligament damage, the Spaniard had his chances. He was a break of serve up in the second and third sets, only to be reeled back in both times by his in-form 27-year-old opponent.\n\nHowever, a relentless Zverev broke Nadal's serve six times from 18 opportunities and fired 44 winners to Nadal's 34.\n\nChants of \"Rafa, Rafa\" echoed loudly under the roof of Court Philippe Chatrier, shut tight against the torrential rain wreaking havoc on the schedule.\n\nThe cheers subsided to silence when Nadal was broken to love in his opening service game, regretting his inability to convert two break points in the fourth game.\n\nNadal saved two set points in the ninth game but lost the opener after 50 minutes, burying a loose forehand into the net. It was only the fourth opening set he had lost at Roland Garros.\n\nNadal broke for the first time in the match to lead 3-2 in the second set but couldn't consolidate the advantage, handing the break back to three-time semi-finalist Zverev as he served for the set.\n\nA tense tiebreak followed, claimed by the German who stretched to 5/3 after a grueling 19-shot rally.\n\nNadal dug deep, breaking and holding for 2-0 in the third set, with Novak Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz, and Iga Swiatek watching from the packed stands.\n\nHowever, Zverev roared back to level at 2-2, putting immense pressure on Nadal. In a grueling 13-minute fifth game, Nadal had to save four break points to stay in contention.\n\nThe effort proved too much, and a composed Zverev soon moved ahead 4-3. The match concluded when Nadal fired a forehand wide and long.", "source": {"uri": "newsable.asianetnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Asianet News Network Pvt Ltd"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "2024-05-370086046", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "19:54:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T19:54:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T16:42:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/sports/14-time-champion-rafael-nadal-knocked-out-in-first-round-of-likely-last-french-open-1.6902171", "title": "14-time champion Rafael Nadal knocked out in first round of likely last French Open", "body": "The noise was loud and relentless, a chorus of thousands of belting out \" Ra-fa! Ra-fa! \" whenever their guy found the occasional moment of brilliance of the sort he has conjured up so often at the French Open and elsewhere through the years.\n\nThe 15,000 or so on hand roared their support when Rafael Nadal stepped out into Court Philippe Chatrier on Monday, voices echoing under the closed roof of a place he called \"magical for me.\" When the 14-time champion at Roland Garros approached the net for the prematch coin toss. When he took his swings during the warmup. And, especially, when he whipped his trademark topspin lefty forehand or chopped his two-fisted cross-court backhand or placed a volley perfectly to claim a point.\n\nThe problem for Nadal, and for his fans, is that there were not nearly enough such points for him against Alexander Zverev. Not enough vintage play to allow his nearly 38-year-old, oft-injured body to claim one more victory, no matter how much the folks in the stands tried to will that to happen. And so he lost 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3 in the first round of the French Open to Zverev in what might turn out to be Nadal's last match at the clay-court tournament he dominated for so long.\n\n\"If it's the last time that I played here,\" Nadal said, \"I am at peace with myself.\"\n\nIt is the first time in his long and illustrious career that Nadal has been beaten in two consecutive matches on clay courts -- he lost to Hubert Hurkacz at the Italian Open on May 11 -- and the first time he has dropped a match earlier than the fourth round at the French Open.\n\n\"The last two years, I have been working and going through probably the toughest process in my tennis career with the dream to come back here. At least I did,\" Nadal said. \"I mean, I lost, but that's part of the business.\"\n\nHe had indicated 2024 likely would be his last season, but he said Saturday he is not absolutely certain he be at the French Open again. He reiterated that after only his fourth defeat in 116 career matches at the place.\n\n\"I am not saying I am retiring today,\" said the Spaniard, whose 1 1/2-year-old son, Rafael Jr., sat on his mother's lap in the stands.\n\nWhile Nadal said it's doubtful he'll enter Wimbledon, which he won twice and starts on July 1, he did note he hopes to return to Roland Garros later that month, when the Olympics' tennis competition will be at the French Open site.\n\nMonday's match ended in anticlimactic fashion, with the 22-time Grand Slam champion unable to play his customary way after 1 1/2 years of hip and abdominal injuries. He had hip surgery during the 2023 French Open, the first time he missed it since winning his debut there as a teenager.\n\n\"My body has been a jungle for two years. You don't know what to expect,\" Nadal said. \"I wake up one day and I (felt like I had) a snake biting me. Another day, a tiger.\"\n\nSpain's Rafael Nadal reacts as he plays against Germany's Alexander Zverev during their first round match of the French Open tennis tournament at the Roland Garros stadium in Paris, Monday, May 27, 2024. (Jean-Francois Badias / AP Photo)\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3, has been limited to 16 matches and an 8-8 record since the start of last year. His infrequent play dropped his ranking to No. 275, and he was unseeded for the French Open for the first time; he'd never been anything worse than the No. 6 seed in 18 previous appearances.\n\nThat is why Nadal ended up facing the No. 4-seeded Zverev, the runner-up at the 2020 U.S. Open, a gold medalist at the Tokyo Olympics and the only man to reach the semifinals in Paris each of the past three years.\n\nNadal's other losses at Roland Garros came against Robin Soderling in 2009, and against Novak Djokovic in 2015 and 2021.\n\nDjokovic, owner of 24 major championships and the man Nadal played against more than any other, sat in the stands Monday, as did younger stars Iga Swiatek and Carlos Alcaraz. Also there: Nadal's uncle, Toni, who used to be his coach. Not surprisingly, it was difficult to spot so much as a single empty chair anywhere in the arena on what many realized could be a historic occasion.\n\nHere and there, when Nadal was able to come up with the goods and get the better of his opponent, he would yell \"Vamos!\" and throw that celebratory uppercut that became so familiar, from the days of muscle shirts and Capri pants to Monday's look of sky-blue sleeves and standard-length white shorts. His numerous and vocal supporters would respond in kind, thrusting their fists in the air right along with him or shaking their red-and-yellow Spanish flags or clapping to the beat of a drum.\n\nIf Nadal put a ball into the net, or sailed one wide or long, the groans of disappointment filled the chilly air. Between points, especially when he was trying to navigate a difficult spot, it was so quiet that a pigeon's coos were audible from a corner of the stadium.\n\nNadal began shakily, with a misplayed drop shot and a double-fault contributing to getting broken at love. He got broken again to end the first set.\n\nThe 6-foot-6 (1.98-metre) Zverev is a talented player coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open. The 27-year-old German leverages every bit of his long legs and considerable wingspan to cover the court well and unleash tough-to-corral groundstrokes.\n\nAs he plays in Paris, he is awaiting Friday's start of a trial in a Berlin court related to accusations of domestic abuse made by an ex-girlfriend. Zverev does not need to be present at the court and has said he won't be there.\n\nOn Monday, there were two stretches, albeit brief, where Nadal looked as though he might be able to find enough muscle memory to make this a close contest.\n\nIn the second set, right after he flubbed a backhand and hung his head, Nadal faced a pair of break points that would have put Zverev up 3-1. Nadal escaped, using a 116 m.p.h. (187 km/h) ace and a 117 m.p.h. (188 km/h) service winner to hold, before breaking for a 3-2 lead.\n\nRoars.\n\nNot so fast. Nadal served for that set at 5-4, but Zverev broke at love, then was superior in the ensuing tiebreaker.\n\nAt the start of the third set, Nadal again erased a pair of break points, then broke for a 2-0 lead with an on-the-run forehand. He pumped his fists, gritted his teeth and screamed, \"Vamos!\"\n\nMore roars.\n\nSpain's Rafael Nadal leaves the court after losing against Germany's Alexander Zverev at the 2024 French Open. (Thibault Camus/AP Photo)\n\nOnce more, though, Nadal failed to sustain it and soon was back at 2-all. Zverev broke to lead 5-3, and that essentially was that. Nadal said his body felt as well as it has in a while during practice, and he finally could move without limitations, but he hasn't been competing enough lately.\n\n\"To hold your level (with) this amount of energy, this amount of concentration,\" he explained, \"you need to be playing often.\"\n\nAddressing the fans directly, Nadal said: \"The feelings that you made me feel here are unbelievable. I really hope to see you again, but I don't know. Merci beaucoup.\"\n\nAnd with that, he gathered his bags and headed to the locker room, but not before stopping to look around. He applauded right back at those applauding him and saluting him with one final chant.", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The feelings I have today are difficult to describe in words. It is the place I love the most.\"\n\nALSO READ: Nadal defeated in likely French Open farewell\n\nHe added: \"It's hard to say about the future. I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. The body is feeling better than it did two months ago.\n\n\"Maybe in two months I say it's enough. That is something I don't feel yet.\"\n\nNadal may not return for the 2025 French Open but he still plans to play the Olympics at Roland Garros in July.\n\nNadal, an Olympic singles gold medallist in Beijing in 2008 and doubles champion at the Rio Games, later told reporters: \"That's my main goal now.\n\n\"I need to prepare myself the proper way to try to arrive healthy and well-prepared.\"\n\nHe won't make the rankings cut for the Olympics, but as a Grand Slam winner he would be eligible for a spot reserved for major winners.\n\nPlagued by injuries, which had limited him to just four events since January last year, former world number one Nadal is now 275 in the rankings and was unseeded in Paris.\n\nALSO READ: Nadal puts return on ice, admits 'not ready to compete'\n\n\"My body has been a jungle for two years. You don't know what to expect. You know, I wake up one day and I found a snake biting me. Another day a tiger,\" said Nadal of his recent battles with a hip injury.\n\nIn his career, he has had to skip 11 Grand Slams. That is certain to become 12 next month when he is likely to skip Wimbledon where he was champion in 2008 and 2010.\n\n\"It looks difficult to make a transition to grass, having the Olympics again on clay,\" he said.\n\n\"I don't think it's going to be smart after all the things that happened to my body now make a big transition to a completely different surface and then come back immediately to clay. I don't think it's a positive idea right now.\"\n\n- 'Thank you Rafa' -\n\nZverev said it had been \"a great honour\" to play Nadal on 11 occasions in their careers.\n\n\"I've watched Rafa play all my childhood and I was lucky enough to play him two times on this beautiful court. Today is not my moment, it is Rafa's moment,\" said the German star.\n\nIn a repeat of the 2022 semi-final, which Nadal won when Zverev quit with ankle ligament damage, the Spaniard had his chances.\n\nHe was a break of serve up in the second and third sets, only to be pinned back on both occasions by his in-form 27-year-old opponent.\n\nHowever, a relentless Zverev broke six times from 18 opportunities and fired 44 winners to Nadal's 34.\n\nChants of \"Rafa, Rafa\" had loudly echoed under the roof of Court Philippe Chatrier which was shut tight against the torrential rain sweeping across the grounds and bringing havoc to the schedule.\n\nALSO READ: Fans' tears flow as 'legend' Nadal bows out at French Open\n\nThey subsided to silence when Nadal was broken to love in his opening service game and he was left to regret his inability to convert two break points in the fourth game.\n\nNadal saved two set points in the ninth game but surrendered the opener after 50 minutes when he buried a loose forehand into the net.\n\nIt was only the fourth opening set he had lost at Roland Garros.\n\nNadal broke for the first time in the match to lead 3-2 in the second set but couldn't back up the advantage and handed the break back to three-time semi-finalist Zverev as he served for the set.\n\nA tense tie-breaker followed which the German claimed, buoyed by stretching to 5/3 on the back of a gruelling 19-shot rally.\n\nNadal dug deep and with the likes of Novak Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz and Iga Swiatek having watched from the packed stands, he broke and held for 2-0 in the third set.\n\nHowever, Zverev again roared back to level at 2-2 before a besieged Nadal had to save four break points in a 13-minute fifth game to stay in contention.\n\nThe effort was too much and a {"uri": "8149662659", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "10:58:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T10:58:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T10:57:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://gulftoday.ae:443/sport/2024/05/28/zverev-defeats-nadal-in-roland-garros-blockbuster", "title": "Zverev defeats Nadal in Roland Garros blockbuster", "body": "Rafael Nadal's illustrious French Open career came to a likely end with his first ever defeat in the opening round by Alexander Zverev on Monday, after Iga Swiatek made a winning start in her bid for a fourth title.\n\nNadal matched world number four Zverev for long periods on a packed Court Philippe Chatrier, but slipped to a 6-3, 7-6 (7/5), 6-3 loss as he was beaten for just the fourth time in 116 matches at the tournament.\n\nThis year's event was expected to be the 14-time champion's farewell to Roland Garros, but he had since insisted he could not confirm \"100 per cent\" it would be his last appearance.\n\n\"If it is (the last time), then you have been amazing,\" Nadal told an adoring crowd under the Chatrier roof.\n\n\"The feelings I have today are difficult to describe in words. It is the place I love the most.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 next week, showed all his trademark fighting qualities in a gripping match, but only managed to convert two of 11 break points against an inspired opponent.\n\n\"The first round wasn't ideal,\" he admitted, before saying he \"hoped\" to be back at Roland Garros later this summer for the Paris Olympics but would almost certainly skip Wimbledon.\n\n\"It will be difficult playing on grass considering that right after Wimbledon are the Olympic Games.\"\n\nRafael Nadal reacts as he plays against Alexander Zverev at the Roland Garros stadium in Paris, on Monday. AP\n\nIt was only Nadal's fifth tournament since January 2023 after suffering a hip injury and then a muscle tear, arriving in Paris a lowly 275th in the world rankings.\n\n\"It's hard to say about the future,\" he added. \"I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. The body is feeling better than it did two months ago.\"\n\nNadal was unseeded for the draw and vulnerable to a difficult opening round.\n\nGerman Zverev, who lifted the Rome Open title last month, proved too strong despite the fans desperately attempting to raise Nadal to past glories.\n\nThe 27-year-old banished the memories of the duo's last meeting, when he left Chatrier court on a wheelchair after injuring his ankle during their 2022 French Open semi-final.\n\nHis reward for becoming just the third player to defeat Nadal at Roland Garros -- after Novak Djokovic and Robin Soderling -- is a match against either David Goffin or home wildcard Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard.\n\nZverev's fast start\n\nZverev started the match strongly with a break to love in the opening game, going on to wrap up the first set with relative ease.\n\nRafael Nadal (right) checks hands with the winner Alexander Zverev at the Roland Garros Complex in Paris. AFP\n\nNadal was much improved from his most recent outing, when he was well beaten by Hubert Hurkacz in the Rome second round, but failed to serve out the second set when leading 5-4.\n\nZverev then {"uri": "8149999772", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "14:23:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T14:23:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T14:23:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.nj.com/sports/2024/05/how-to-watch-french-open-2024-free-live-streams-dates-times-usa-tv-channels-for-day-3-at-roland-garros.html", "title": "How to watch French Open 2024 | FREE live streams, dates, times, USA TV, channels for Day 3 at Roland Garros", "body": "The 2024 French Open continues on Tuesday, May 28, 2024 (5/28/24) with the first round of the competition at Roland Garros in Paris, France. The tournament concludes on Sunday, June 9, 2024 (6/9/24).\n\nPARIS (AP) -- The noise was loud and relentless, a chorus of thousands of belting out \" Ra-fa! Ra-fa! \" whenever their guy found the occasional moment of brilliance of the sort he has conjured up so often at the French Open and elsewhere through the years.\n\nThe 15,000 or so on hand roared their support when Rafael Nadal stepped out into Court Philippe Chatrier on Monday, voices echoing under the closed roof of a place he called \"magical for me.\" When the 14-time champion at Roland Garros approached the net for the prematch coin toss. When he took his swings during the warmup. And, especially, when he whipped his trademark topspin lefty forehand or chopped his two-fisted cross-court backhand or placed a volley perfectly to claim a point.\n\nThe problem for Nadal, and for his fans, is that there were not nearly enough such points for him against Alexander Zverev. Not enough vintage play to allow his nearly 38-year-old, oft-injured body to claim one more victory, no matter how much the folks in the stands tried to will that to happen. And so he lost 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3 in the first round of the French Open to Zverev in what might turn out to be Nadal's last match at the clay-court tournament he dominated for so long.\n\n\"If it's the last time that I played here,\" Nadal said, \"I am at peace with myself.\"\n\nIt is the first time in his long and illustrious career that Nadal has been beaten in two consecutive matches on clay courts -- he lost to Hubert Hurkacz at the Italian Open on May 11 -- and the first time he has dropped a match earlier than the fourth round at the French Open.\n\n\"The last two years, I have been working and going through probably the toughest process in my tennis career with the dream to come back here. At least I did,\" Nadal said. \"I mean, I lost, but that's part of the business.\"\n\nHe had indicated 2024 likely would be his last season, but he said Saturday he is not absolutely certain he be at the French Open again. He reiterated that after only his fourth defeat in 116 career matches at the place.\n\n\"I am not saying I am retiring today,\" said the Spaniard, whose 1 1/2-year-old son, Rafael Jr., sat on his mother's lap in the stands.\n\nWhile Nadal said it's doubtful he'll enter Wimbledon, which he won twice and starts on July 1, he did note he hopes to return to Roland Garros later that month, when the Olympics' tennis competition will be at the French Open site.\n\nMonday's match ended in anticlimactic fashion, with the 22-time Grand Slam champion unable to play his customary way after 1 1/2 years of hip and abdominal injuries. He had hip surgery during the 2023 French Open, the first time he missed it since winning his debut there as a teenager.\n\n\"My body has been a jungle for two years. You don't know what to expect,\" Nadal said. \"I wake up one day and I (felt like I had) a snake biting me. Another day, a tiger.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3, has been limited to 16 matches and an 8-8 record since the start of last year. His infrequent play dropped his ranking to No. 275, and he was unseeded for the French Open for the first time; he'd never been anything worse than the No. 6 seed in 18 previous appearances.\n\nThat is why Nadal ended up facing the No. 4-seeded Zverev, the runner-up at the 2020 U.S. Open, a gold medalist at the Tokyo Olympics and the only man to reach the semifinals in Paris each of the past three years.\n\nNadal's other losses at Roland Garros came against Robin Soderling in 2009, and against Novak Djokovic in 2015 and 2021.\n\nDjokovic, owner of 24 major championships and the man Nadal played against more than any other, sat in the stands Monday, as did younger stars Iga Swiatek and Carlos Alcaraz. Also there: Nadal's uncle, Toni, who used to be his coach. Not surprisingly, it was difficult to spot so much as a single empty chair anywhere in the arena on what many realized could be a historic occasion.\n\nHere and there, when Nadal was able to come up with the goods and get the better of his opponent, he would yell \"Vamos!\" and throw that celebratory uppercut that became so familiar, from the days of muscle shirts and Capri pants to Monday's look of sky-blue sleeves and standard-length white shorts. His numerous and vocal supporters would respond in kind, thrusting their fists in the air right along with him or shaking their red-and-yellow Spanish flags or clapping to the beat of a drum.\n\nIf Nadal put a ball into the net, or sailed one wide or long, the groans of disappointment filled the chilly air. Between points, especially when he was trying to navigate a difficult spot, it was so quiet that a pigeon's coos were audible from a corner of the stadium.\n\nNadal began shakily, with a misplayed drop shot and a double-fault contributing to getting broken at love. He got broken again to end the first set.\n\nThe 6-foot-6 (1.98-meter) Zverev is a talented player coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open. The 27-year-old German leverages every bit of his long legs and considerable wingspan to cover the court well and unleash tough-to-corral groundstrokes.\n\nAs he plays in Paris, he is awaiting Friday's start of a trial in a Berlin court related to accusations of domestic abuse made by an ex-girlfriend. Zverev does not need to be present at the court and has said he won't be there.\n\nOn Monday, there were two stretches, albeit brief, where Nadal looked as though he might be able to find enough muscle memory to make this a close contest.\n\nIn the second set, right after he flubbed a backhand and hung his head, Nadal faced a pair of break points that would have put Zverev up 3-1. Nadal escaped, using a 116 mph (187 kph) ace and a 117 mph (188 kph) service winner to hold, before breaking for a 3-2 lead.\n\nRoars.\n\nNot so fast. Nadal served for that set at 5-4, but Zverev broke at love, then was superior in the ensuing tiebreaker.\n\nAt the start of the third set, Nadal again erased a pair of break points, then broke for a 2-0 lead with an on-the-run forehand. He pumped his fists, gritted his teeth and screamed, \"Vamos!\"\n\nMore roars.\n\nOnce more, though, Nadal failed to sustain it and soon was back at 2-all. Zverev broke to lead 5-3, and that essentially was that. Nadal said his body felt as well as it has in a while during practice, and he finally could move without limitations, but he hasn't been competing enough lately.\n\n\"To hold your level (with) this amount of energy, this amount of concentration,\" he explained, \"you need to be playing often.\"\n\nAddressing the fans directly, Nadal said: \"The feelings that you made me feel here are unbelievable. I really hope to see you again, but I don't know. Merci beaucoup.\"\n\nAnd with that, he gathered his bags and headed to the locker room, but not before stopping to look around. He applauded right back at those applauding him and saluting him with one final chant.\n\n\"Ra-fa! Ra-fa!\"\n\n(The Associated Press contributed to this report.)", "source": {"uri": "nj.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NJ.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": If it is, then you have been amazing. The feelings I have today are difficult to describe in words. It is the place I love the most.\"\n\nALSO READ: Returning Nadal wants to enjoy comeback 'gift'\n\nHe added: \"It's hard to say about the future. I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. The body is feeling better than it did two months ago.\n\n\"Maybe in two months I say it's enough. That is something I don't feel yet.\"\n\nNadal may not return for the 2025 French Open but he still plans to play the Olympics in the city in July.\n\n\"I hope to be back here for the Olympics, that motivates me. I really hope to be well prepared,\" he said to loud cheers.\n\nPlagued by injuries, which had limited him to just four events since January last year, former world number one Nadal is now 275 in the rankings and was unseeded in Paris.\n\nHowever, he insisted on the eve of the tournament that he was \"100% keeping the door open\" on his future in a sport which has brought him 22 Grand Slam titles.\n\n- 'Thank you Rafa' -\n\n\"I don't know what to say. Thank you Rafa from all of the tennis world. It is such a great honour,\" said Zverev.\n\n\"I've watched Rafa play all my childhood and I was lucky enough to play him two times on this beautiful court. Today is not my moment, it is Rafa's moment.\"\n\nIn a repeat of the 2022 semi-final, which Nadal won when Zverev quit with ankle ligament damage, the Spaniard had his chances.\n\nHe was a break of serve up in the second and third sets, only to be pinned back on both occasions by his in-form 27-year-old opponent.\n\nHowever, a relentless Zverev broke six times from 18 opportunities and fired 44 winners to Nadal's 34.\n\nALSO READ: Nadal keeps his clay dream alive as he battles past Cachin\n\nChants of \"Rafa, Rafa\" had loudly echoed under the roof of Court Philippe Chatrier which was shut tight against the torrential rain sweeping across the grounds and bringing havoc to the schedule.\n\nThey subsided to silence when Nadal was broken to love in his opening service game and he was left to regret his inability to convert two break points in the fourth game.\n\nNadal saved two set points in the ninth game but surrendered the opener after 50 minutes when he buried a loose forehand into the net.\n\nIt was only the fourth opening set he had lost at Roland Garros.\n\nNadal broke for the first time in the match to lead 3-2 in the second set but couldn't back up the advantage and handed the break back to three-time semi-finalist Zverev as he served for the set.\n\n- 'Beautiful process' -\n\nA tense tie-breaker followed which the German claimed, buoyed by stretching to 5/3 on the back of a gruelling 19-shot rally.\n\nNadal dug deep and with the likes of Novak Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz and Iga Swiatek having watched from the packed stands, he broke and held for 2-0 in the third set.\n\nHowever, Zverev again roared back to level at 2-2 before a besieged Nadal had to save four break points in a 13-minute fifth game to stay in contention.\n\nALSO READ: Nadal progresses in Madrid to set up De Minaur rematch in Madrid Open\n\nThe effort was too much and a composed Zverev was soon 4-3 up and the match was over when Nadal fired a forehand wide and long.\n\n\"The amount of feelings I had on this court throughout my career, I didn't think I would be here almost 38 with all of the success. Five previous meetings between Nadal and Zverev", "body": "The 14-time Roland Garros champion has only played four tournaments since January 2023 due to injuries but holds a 7-3 winning record over Zverev\n\nRafael Nadal faces Alexander Zverev on Monday as he opens what is likely to be his final French Open campaign with a tough assignment against the world number four. The 14-time Roland Garros champion has only played four tournaments since January 2023 due to injuries but holds a 7-3 winning record over Zverev. Mid-Day takes a look at five previous meetings between Nadal and Zverev ahead of their French Open encounter:\n\n2016 Indian Wells last 16 Nadal 6-7 (8/10), 6-0 7-5 -- A teenage Zverev enjoyed a breakthrough tournament at Indian Wells, knocking out seeds Grigor Dimitrov and Gilles Simon to reach the fourth round of a Masters event for the first time. The German made a mark in his maiden match against Nadal, saving two set points before taking the first set in a tie-break. Nadal fought back to force a decider, but Zverev created the chance to serve for victory when leading 5-3, only to miss a match point and lose five straight games as he tumbled to defeat.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\n2017 Australian Open 3rd rd Nadal 4-6, 6-3, 6-7 (5/7), 6-3, 6-2 -- The pair's second meeting was their first at a Grand Slam tournament. Zverev took control of the match early on, building a two-sets-to-one lead. But again Nadal battled back in trademark fashion, eventually securing victory after more than four hours on court. Nadal went on to lose a memorable final against Roger Federer.\n\nAlso Read: Age barrier for Rafael Nadal? Not quite! Here's three 40-something trailblazers\n\n2018 Rome Open final Nadal 6-1, 1-6, 6-3 -- Zverev's first defence of a Masters 1000 title was a strong one in Rome six years ago, as he set up his only meeting with Nadal in a final to date. The Spaniard, though, was too strong for his young rival once more, clinching his eighth of 10 Rome triumphs with his fifth win against Zverev in as many matches.\n\n2019 ATP Finals round robin Zverev 6-2, 6-4 -- Zverev finally got the better of Nadal at the 2019 season-ending Finals in London during the group phase. The German dominated on the indoor hard court and eventually finished second in the group ahead of Nadal on set difference. But Zverev's title defence ended in the semi-finals with defeat by Dominic Thiem.\n\n2022 French Open semi-finals Nadal 7-6 (10/8), 6-6 -- retired -- Nadal and Zverev's most recent meeting was their most memorable. Ahead of the second time they had played each other at a Grand Slam and the first time in the second week, Zverev had high hopes of becoming only the third player to ever defeat Nadal at Roland Garros. Nadal won a marathon first set after Zverev blew a 6-2 lead in the tie-break. After more than three hours on court, Zverev suffered a nasty ankle injury while hitting a forehand wide which levelled the second set at 6-6, leaving the court in a wheelchair before confirming he could not continue. Nadal beat Casper Ruud in the final to win his 14th French Open. {"uri": "8149212085", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "06:07:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T06:07:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T06:07:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.citizen.co.za/sport/nadal-olympics-first-round-french-open-exit/", "title": "Nadal sets sights on Olympics after first-round French Open exit | The Citizen", "body": "Rafael Nadal during his first-round match at the French Open on Monday. Picture: Richard Callis/Eurasia Sport Images/Getty Images\n\nRafael Nadal's record-breaking French Open career came to its likely end on Monday when the 14-time champion slumped to a demoralising defeat against Alexander Zverev before he revealed his journey to the Paris Olympics in July will not take a detour to Wimbledon.\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3, went down 6-3, 7-6 (7/5), 6-3 in the first round to world number four Zverev, suffering only his fourth loss in 116 matches at Roland Garros since his 2005 title-winning debut.\n\nIt was the first time he had been defeated in Paris in the opening round and will again lead to questions over his long-term future in the sport.\n\n\"I don't know if it's the last time I'll be here in front of all of you,\" he said.\n\n\"If it is, then you have been amazing. The feelings I have today are difficult to describe in words. It is the place I love the most.\"\n\nHe added: \"It's hard to say about the future. I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. The body is feeling better than it did two months ago.\n\n\"Maybe in two months I say it's enough. That is something I don't feel yet.\"\n\nNadal may not return for the 2025 French Open but he still plans to play the Olympics at Roland Garros in July.\n\nNadal, an Olympic singles gold medallist in Beijing in 2008 and doubles champion at the Rio Games, later told reporters: \"That's my main goal now.\n\n\"I need to prepare myself the proper way to try to arrive healthy and well-prepared.\"\n\nHe won't make the rankings cut for the Olympics, but as a Grand Slam winner he would be eligible for a spot reserved for major winners.\n\nPlagued by injuries, which had limited him to just four events since January last year, former world number one Nadal is now 275 in the rankings and was unseeded in Paris.\n\n\"My body has been a jungle for two years. You don't know what to expect. You know, I wake up one day and I found a snake biting me. Another day a tiger,\" said Nadal of his recent battles with a hip injury.\n\nIn his career, he has had to skip 11 Grand Slams. That is certain to become 12 next month when he is likely to skip the prestigious Wimbledon tournament where he was champion in 2008 and 2010.\n\n\"It looks difficult to make a transition to grass, having the Olympics again on clay,\" he said.\n\n\"I don't think it's going to be smart after all the things that happened to my body now make a big transition to a completely different surface and then come back immediately to clay. I don't think it's a positive idea right now.\"\n\nZverev said it had been \"a great honour\" to play Nadal on 11 occasions in their careers.\n\n\"I've watched Rafa play all my childhood and I was lucky enough to play him two times on this beautiful court. Today is not my moment, it is Rafa's moment,\" said the German star.\n\nIn a repeat of the 2022 semi-final, which Nadal won when Zverev quit with ankle ligament damage, the Spaniard had his chances.\n\nHe was a break of serve up in the second and third sets, only to be pinned back on both occasions by his in-form 27-year-old opponent.\n\nHowever, a relentless Zverev broke six times from 18 opportunities and fired 44 winners to Nadal's 34.\n\nChants of \"Rafa, Rafa\" had loudly echoed under the roof of Court Philippe Chatrier which was shut tight against the torrential rain sweeping across the grounds and bringing havoc to the schedule.\n\nThey subsided to silence when Nadal was broken to love in his opening service game and he was left to regret his inability to convert two break points in the fourth game.\n\nNadal saved two set points in the ninth game but surrendered the opener after 50 minutes when he buried a loose forehand into the net.\n\nIt was only the fourth opening set he had lost at Roland Garros.\n\nNadal broke for the first time in the match to lead 3-2 in the second set but couldn't back up the advantage and handed the break back to three-time semi-finalist Zverev as he served for the set.\n\nA tense tie-breaker followed which the German claimed, buoyed by stretching to 5/3 on the back of a gruelling 19-shot rally.\n\nNadal dug deep and with the likes of Novak Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz and Iga Swiatek having watched from the packed stands, he broke and held for 2-0 in the third set.\n\nHowever, Zverev again roared back to level at 2-2 before a besieged Nadal had to save four break points in a 13-minute fifth game to stay in contention.\n\nThe effort was too much and a composed Zverev was soon 4-3 up and the match was over when {"uri": "8148579346", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "18:11:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T18:11:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T18:10:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/news/sports/rafael-nadal-loses-zverev-french-open-rcna154189", "title": "Nadal loses to Zverev in the first round of what could be his final French Open", "body": "Rafael Nadal after losing against Alexander Zverev during the French Open at the Roland Garros stadium in Paris on Monday.Thibault Camus / AP\n\nRafael Nadal is out after the first round of what could be his last French Open -- a tournament he has dominated since he was a teenager.\n\nNadal, 37, has won a record 14 French Open championships during his career. A 15th win proved far out of reach Monday: He lost in straight sets to Alexander Zverev.\n\nThe 3-6, 6-7, 3-6 loss for Nadal, who has been struggling with hip and abdominal injuries, came as the crowd in Paris cheered him on with chants of \"Ra-fa!\"\n\nIn a rare post-defeat interview on the court, the 22-time Grand Slam champion said that while he wasn't 100% sure that this would be his final French Open, \"if it's the last time, I enjoyed it.\"\n\n\"The crowd have been amazing,\" the Spanish player said. \"The feelings that I have today are difficult to describe in words, but for me, so special to feel the love of the people the way that I felt in the place that I love the most.\"\n\nHe added that while it would be \"difficult\" to play on the grass courts at Wimbledon this summer, he was hopeful about coming back to Roland Garros' clay courts for the Olympics.\n\n\"That motivates me. That's going to be another chance, and I hope to be well-prepared,\" he said before the crowd gave him a standing ovation.\n\nZverev is only the third player to beat Nadal at Roland Garros, and it's only Nadal's fourth defeat in 116 matches at the French Open.\n\nHip surgery forced him to sit out the French Open last year.\n\nNadal's hip and abdominal injuries have severely limited his court time in the last year and a half, leaving him unseeded for the French Open for the first time.\n\nNo. 4 seed Zverev, a 27-year-old from Germany, was the runner-up at the 2020 U.S. Open and a gold medalist at the Tokyo Olympics the same year.\n\nFollowing his victory Monday, Zverev told Nadal that playing against him was \"such a great honor.\"\n\n\"Thank you, Rafa, from all of the tennis world,\" he said.\n\nZverev then handed the microphone to Nadal, adding: \"Today is not my moment. {"uri": "8148721326", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "20:39:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T20:39:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T20:37:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.gulf-times.com/article/683485/sports/nadal-eyes-olympics-after-likely-french-open-farewell", "title": "Nadal eyes Olympics after likely French Open farewell", "body": "Rafael Nadal and Alexander Zverev embrace after their match. (AFP) Rafael Nadal's record-breaking French Open career came to its likely end on Monday when the 14-time champion slumped to a demoralising defeat against Alexander Zverev before he revealed his journey to the Paris Olympics in July will not take a detour to Wimbledon.\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3, went down 6-3, 7-6 (7/5), 6-3 in the first round to world number four Zverev, suffering only his fourth loss in 116 matches at Roland Garros since his 2005 title-winning debut. It was the first time he had been defeated in Paris in the opening round and will again lead to questions over his long-term future in the sport.\n\n\"I don't know if it's the last time I'll be here in front of all of you,\" he said. \"If it is, then you have been amazing. The feelings I have today are difficult to describe in words. It is the place I love the most.\"\n\nHe added: \"It's hard to say about the future. I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. The body is feeling better than it did two months ago. Maybe in two months I say it's enough. That is something I don't feel yet.\"\n\nNadal may not return for the 2025 French Open but he still plans to play the Olympics at Roland Garros in July. Nadal, an Olympic singles gold medallist in Beijing in 2008 and doubles champion at the Rio Games, later told reporters: \"That's my main goal now. I need to prepare myself the proper way to try to arrive healthy and well-prepared.\"\n\nHe won't make the rankings cut for the Olympics, but as a Grand Slam winner he would be eligible for a spot reserved for major winners. Plagued by injuries, which had limited him to just four events since January last year, former world number one Nadal is now 275 in the rankings and was unseeded in Paris.\n\n\"My body has been a jungle for two years. You don't know what to expect. You know, I wake up one day and I found a snake biting me. Another day a tiger,\" said Nadal of his recent battles with a hip injury.\n\nIn his career, he has had to skip 11 Grand Slams. That is certain to become 12 next month when he is likely to skip Wimbledon where he was champion in 2008 and 2010. \"It looks difficult to make a transition to grass, having the Olympics again on clay,\" he said. \"I don't think it's going to be smart after all the things that happened to my body now make a big transition to a completely different surface and then come back immediately to clay. I don't think it's a positive idea right now.\"\n\nZverev said it had been \"a great honour\" to play Nadal on 11 occasions in their careers. \"I've watched Rafa play all my childhood and I was lucky enough to play him two times on this beautiful court. Today is not my moment, it is Rafa's moment,\" said the German star.\n\nIn a repeat of the 2022 semi-final, which Nadal won when Zverev quit with ankle ligament damage, the Spaniard had his chances. He was a break of serve up in the second and third sets, only to be pinned back on both occasions by his in-form 27-year-old opponent.\n\nHowever, a relentless Zverev broke six times from 18 opportunities and fired 44 winners to Nadal's 34. Chants of \"Rafa, Rafa\" had loudly echoed under the roof of Court Philippe Chatrier which was shut tight against the torrential rain sweeping across the grounds and bringing havoc to the schedule.\n\nThey subsided to silence when Nadal was broken to love in his opening service game and he was left to regret his inability to convert two break points in the fourth game. Nadal saved two set points in the ninth game but surrendered the opener after 50 minutes when he buried a loose forehand into the net. It was only the fourth opening set he had lost at Roland Garros.\n\nNadal broke for the first time in the match to lead 3-2 in the second set but couldn't back up the advantage and handed the break back to three-time semi-finalist Zverev as he served for the set. A tense tie-breaker followed which the German claimed, buoyed by stretching to 5/3 on the back of a gruelling 19-shot rally. Nadal dug deep and with the likes of Novak Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz and Iga Swiatek having watched from the packed stands, he broke and held for 2-0 in the third set.\n\nHowever, Zverev again roared back to level at 2-2 before a besieged Nadal had to save four break points in a 13-minute fifth game to stay in contention. The effort was too much and a composed Zverev was soon 4-3 up and the match was over when Nadal fired a forehand wide and long.", "source": {"uri": "gulf-times.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8148465550", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "16:35:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T16:35:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T16:34:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.newsbytesapp.com/news/sports/french-open-2024-zverev-vs-nadal-key-stats/story", "title": "Alexander Zverev claims first-ever French Open win over Rafael Nadal", "body": "Alexander Zverev scripted history at the Philippe-Chatrier Court after beating Spanish ace Rafael Nadal at the French Open. The German star claimed a 6-3, 7-6(5), 6-3 victory in the first round to knock out Nadal. Notably, Zverev has become only the third man to beat Nadal at Roland Garros. The latter bids adieu after claiming 14 Roland Garros title.\n\nZverev won a total of 112 points and 44 winners throughout the match. He served eight aces compared to Zverev's two. The German had a win percentage of 58 and 48 in the first and second serves, respectively. Nadal won 19 of his 21 net points. Both Nadal and Zverev recorded 30 unforced errors. They registered three double-faults each.\n\nBefore this match, Nadal had only lost to Robin Soderling and Novak Djokovic at the French Open. Soderling defeated him in the fourth round in 2009, while Djokovic remains the only player to defeat Nadal twice in the tournament (quarter-finals, 2015 and semi-finals, 2021). Between 2015 and 2021, Nadal was unbeaten in as many as 35 matches at the French Open.\n\nNadal now has a win-loss record of 112-4 at Roland Garros. He has been knocked out for the first time before the fourth round. Notably, the Spaniard also holds the record for winning 39 consecutive French Open matches. It is worth noting that Nadal won four French Open titles without losing a set (2008, 2010, 2017, and 2020), the most for a player.\n\nNearly two decades after winning his maiden Grand Slam title, Nadal owns a total of 14 French Open honors (2005-2008, 2010-2014, 2017-2020, and 2022). The Spaniard has won eight more Roland Garros titles than Bjorn Borg, who owns six titles (second-most). Nadal also holds the record for winning most titles at a Grand Slam and on a single surface (clay).", "source": {"uri": "newsbytesapp.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NewsBytes"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8149277590", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "06:56:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T06:56:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T06:55:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/may/28/nadal-shows-flashes-but-zverev-prevails/", "title": "Nadal shows flashes, but Zverev prevails", "body": "PARIS -- The noise was loud and relentless, a chorus of thousands belting out \"Ra-fa! Ra-fa!\" whenever their guy found the occasional moment of brilliance of the sort he has conjured up so often at the French Open and elsewhere through the years.\n\nThe 15,000 or so on hand roared their support when Rafael Nadal stepped out into Court Philippe Chatrier on Monday, voices echoing under the closed roof of a place he called \"magical for me.\" When the 14-time champion at Roland Garros approached the net for the prematch coin toss. When he took his swings during the warmup. And, especially, when he whipped his trademark topspin lefty forehand or chopped his two-fisted cross-court backhand or placed a volley perfectly to claim a point.\n\nThe problem for Nadal, and for his fans, is that there were not nearly enough such points for him against Alexander Zverev. Not enough vintage play to allow his nearly 38-year-old, oft-injured body to claim one more victory, no matter how much the folks in the stands tried to will that to happen. And so he lost 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3 in the first round of the French Open to Zverev in what might turn out to be Nadal's last match at the clay-court tournament he dominated for so long.\n\n\"If it's the last time that I played here,\" Nadal said, \"I am at peace with myself.\"\n\nIt is the first time in his long and illustrious career that Nadal has been beaten in two consecutive matches on clay courts -- he lost to Hubert Hurkacz at the Italian Open on May 11 -- and the first time he has dropped a match earlier than the fourth round at the French Open.\n\n\"The last two years, I have been working and going through probably the toughest process in my tennis career with the dream to come back here. At least I did,\" Nadal said. \"I mean, I lost, but that's part of the business.\"\n\nHe had indicated 2024 likely would be his last season, but he said Saturday he is not absolutely certain he be at the French Open again. He reiterated that after only his fourth defeat in 116 career matches at the place.\n\n\"I am not saying I am retiring today,\" said the Spaniard, whose 1 1/2-year-old son, Rafael Jr., sat on his mother's lap in the stands.\n\nWhile Nadal said it's doubtful he'll enter Wimbledon, which he won twice and starts on July 1, he did note he hopes to return to Roland Garros later that month when the Olympics' tennis competition will be at the French Open site.\n\nMonday's match ended in anticlimactic fashion, with the 22-time Grand Slam champion unable to play his customary way after 1 1/2 years of hip and abdominal injuries. He had hip surgery during the 2023 French Open, the first time he missed it since winning his debut there as a teenager.\n\n\"My body has been a jungle for two years. You don't know what to expect,\" Nadal said. \"I wake up one day and I (felt like I had) a snake biting me. Another day, a tiger.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3, has been limited to 16 matches and an 8-8 record since the start of last year. His infrequent play dropped his ranking to No. 275, and he was unseeded for the French Open for the first time; he'd never been anything worse than the No. 6 seed in 18 previous appearances.\n\nThat is why Nadal ended up facing the No. 4-seeded Zverev, the runner-up at the 2020 U.S. Open, a gold medalist at the Tokyo Olympics and the only man to reach the semifinals in Paris each of the past three years.\n\nNadal's other losses at Roland Garros came against Robin Soderling in 2009 and Novak Djokovic in 2015 and 2021.\n\nDjokovic, owner of 24 major championships and the man Nadal played against more than any other, sat in the stands Monday, as did younger stars Iga Swiatek and Carlos Alcaraz. Also there: Nadal's uncle, Toni, who used to be his coach. Not surprisingly, it was difficult to spot so much as a single empty chair anywhere in the arena on what many realized could be a historic occasion.\n\nHere and there, when Nadal was able to come up with the goods and get the better of his opponent, he would yell \"Vamos!\" and throw that celebratory uppercut that became so familiar, from the days of muscle shirts and Capri pants to Monday's look of sky-blue sleeves and standard-length white shorts. His numerous and vocal supporters would respond in kind, thrusting their fists in the air right along with him or shaking their red-and-yellow Spanish flags or clapping to the beat of a drum.\n\nIf Nadal put a ball into the net, or sailed one wide or long, the groans of disappointment filled the chilly air. Between points, especially when he was trying to navigate a difficult spot, it was so quiet that a pigeon's coos were audible from a corner of the stadium.\n\nNadal began shakily, with a misplayed drop shot and a double-fault contributing to getting broken at love. He got broken again to end the first set.\n\nThe 6-6 Zverev is a talented player coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open. The 27-year-old German leverages every bit of his long legs and considerable wingspan to cover the court well and unleash tough-to-corral groundstrokes.\n\nAs he plays in Paris, he is awaiting Friday's start of a trial in a Berlin court related to accusations of domestic abuse made by an ex-girlfriend. Zverev does not need to be present at the court and has said he won't be there.\n\nOn Monday, there were two stretches, albeit brief, where Nadal looked as though he might be able to find enough muscle memory to make this a close contest.\n\nIn the second set, right after he flubbed a backhand and hung his head, Nadal faced a pair of break points that would have put Zverev up 3-1. Nadal escaped, using a 116 mph ace and a 117 mph service winner to hold, before breaking for a 3-2 lead.\n\nRoars.\n\nNot so fast. Nadal served for that set at 5-4, but Zverev broke at love, then was superior in the ensuing tiebreaker.\n\nAt the start of the third set, Nadal again erased a pair of break points, then broke for a 2-0 lead with an on-the-run forehand. He pumped his fists, gritted his teeth and screamed, \"Vamos!\"\n\nMore roars.\n\nOnce more, though, Nadal failed to sustain it and soon was back at 2-2. Zverev broke to lead 5-3, and that essentially was that. Nadal said his body felt as well as it has in a while during practice, and he finally could move without limitations, but he hasn't been competing enough lately.\n\n\"To hold your level (with) this amount of energy, this amount of concentration,\" he explained, \"you need to be playing often.\"\n\nAddressing the fans directly, Nadal said: \"The feelings that you made me feel here are unbelievable. I really hope to see you again, but I don't know. Merci beaucoup.\"\n\nAnd with that, he gathered his bags and headed to the locker room, but not before stopping to look around. He applauded right back at those applauding him and saluting him with one final chant.\n\n\"Ra-fa! Ra-fa!\"\n\nSpain's Rafael Nadal celebrates scoring a point during his first round match of the French Open tennis tournament against Germany's Alexander Zverev at the Roland Garros stadium in Paris, Monday, May 27, 2024. "storyUri": "eng-9598845", "eventUri": "eng-9598845", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Paris"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "France"}}}, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-05-11", "textStart": 1484, "textEnd": 1490}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-01", "textStart": 2256, "textEnd": 2262}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-06-03", "textStart": 2884, "textEnd": 2890}], "sentiment": 0.2313725490196079, "wgt": 206, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8148589529", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "18:19:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T18:19:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T18:18:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/14-time-champion-rafael-nadal-loses-in-the-french-opens-first-round-to-alexander-zverev/article_d4333372-4eaa-59f2-9bb3-d6c07a40bca6.html", "title": "14-time champion Rafael Nadal loses in the French Open's first round to Alexander Zverev", "body": "Spain's Rafael Nadal leaves the court after losing against Germany's Alexander Zverev during their first round match of the French Open tennis tournament at the Roland Garros stadium in Paris, Monday, May 27, 2024.\n\nPARIS (AP) -- The noise was loud and relentless, a chorus of thousands of belting out \" Ra-fa! Ra-fa! \" whenever their guy found the occasional moment of brilliance of the sort he has conjured up so often at the French Open and elsewhere through the years.\n\nThe 15,000 or so on hand roared their support when Rafael Nadal stepped out into Court Philippe Chatrier on Monday. When the 14-time champion at Roland Garros approached the net for the prematch coin toss. When he took his swings during the warmup. And, especially, when he whipped his trademark topspin lefty forehand or chopped his two-fisted cross-court backhand or placed a volley perfectly to claim a point.\n\nThe problem for Nadal, and for his fans, is that there were not nearly enough such points for him on this afternoon-into-evening match against Alexander Zverev. Not enough vintage play to allow his nearly 38-year-old, oft-injured body to claim one more victory, no matter how much the folks in the stands tried to will that to happen. And so he lost 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3 in the first round of the French Open to Zverev in what might turn out to be Nadal's last match at the clay-court tournament he dominated for so long.\n\n\"If it's the last time that I played here,\" Nadal said, \"I am at peace with myself.\"\n\nIt is the first time in his long and illustrious career that Nadal has been beaten in two consecutive matches on clay courts -- he lost to Hubert Hurkacz at the Italian Open on May 11 -- and the first time he has dropped a match earlier than the fourth round at the French Open.\n\nHe had indicated 2024 likely would be his last season before retirement, but he said Saturday that he is not 100% sure he won't play again at the French Open. And he reiterated that after Monday's defeat, only his fourth in 116 career matches at the place.\n\n\"It's difficult for me to talk,\" said the Spaniard, whose 1 1/2-year-old son, Rafael Jr., sat on his mother's lap in the stands. \"I don't know (if) it's going to be the last time I am here. I am not 100% sure.\"\n\nWhile Nadal said it's doubtful that he will enter Wimbledon, which he won twice and starts on July 1, he did note that he hopes to return to Roland Garros later that month, when the Paris Olympics' tennis competition will be held at the French Open's site.\n\nWhen Monday's match ended, in anticlimactic fashion, with the 22-time Grand Slam champion simply unable to play at his usual level after 1 1/2 years of hip and abdominal injuries, he thanked the crowd for the \"incredible the amount of energy\" it provided throughout the 3 hours, 5 minutes of play. The match was played with the retractable roof shut, and the shouts of his two-syllable nickname echoed.\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3, has been limited to 16 matches and an 8-8 record since the start of last year. His infrequent play dropped his ranking to No. 275, and he was unseeded for the French Open for the first time; indeed, he'd never been anything worse than the No. 6 seed in 18 previous appearances going back to his days as a teenager.\n\nThat is why Nadal ended up facing the No. 4-seeded Zverev, the runner-up at the 2020 U.S. Open, a gold medalist at the Tokyo Olympics and the only man to reach the semifinals in Paris each of the past three years.\n\nNadal's other losses at Roland Garros came against Robin Soderling in 2010 and against Novak Djokovic in 2015 and 2021.\n\nDjokovic, owner of 24 major championships and the man Nadal played against more than any other, sat in the stands Monday, as did younger stars Iga Swiatek and Carlos Alcaraz. Also there: Nadal's uncle, Toni, who used to be his coach. Not surprisingly, it was difficult to spot so much as a single empty beige chair anywhere in the arena on what many realized could be a historic occasion.\n\nHere and there, when Nadal was able to come up with the goods and get the better of his opponent, he would yell \"Vamos!\" and throw that celebratory uppercut that became so familiar, from the days of muscle shirts and Capri pants to Monday's look of sky-blue sleeves and standard-length white shorts. His numerous and vocal supporters would respond in kind, thrusting their fists in the air right along with him or shaking their red-and-yellow Spanish flags or clapping to the beat of a drum.\n\nIf Nadal put a ball into the net, or sailed one wide or long, the groans of disappointment filled the chilly air. Between points, especially when he was trying to navigate a difficult spot, it was so quiet that a pigeon's coos were audible from a corner of the stadium.\n\nNadal began shakily, with a misplayed drop shot and a double-fault contributing to getting broken at love. He got broken again to end the first set.\n\nThe 6-foot-6 (1.98-meter) Zverev is a talented player, one coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open. The 27-year-old German leverages every bit of his long legs and considerable wingspan to cover the court well and unleash tough-to-corral groundstrokes.\n\nAs he plays in Paris, he is awaiting Friday's start of a trial in a Berlin court related to accusations of domestic abuse made by an ex-girlfriend. Zverev does not need to be present at the court and has said he won't be there.\n\nOn Monday, there were two stretches, albeit brief, where Nadal looked as though he might be able to find enough muscle memory to make this a close contest.\n\nIn the second set, right after he flubbed a backhand and hung his head, he faced a pair of break points that would have put Zverev up 3-1. Nadal escaped, using a 116 mph (187 kph) ace and a 117 mph (188 kph) service winner to hold, before breaking for a 3-2 lead.\n\nRoars.\n\nNot so fast. Nadal served for that set at 5-4, but Zverev broke at love, then was superior in the ensuing tiebreaker.\n\nAt the start of the third set, Nadal again erased a pair of break points, then broke for a 2-0 lead with a trademark on-the-run forehand. He pumped his fists, gritted his teeth and screamed, \"Vamos!\"\n\nMore roars.\n\nOnce more, though, Nadal failed to sustain that level, and soon it was 2-all. Zverev later broke to lead 5-3, and that essentially was that.\n\n\"The amount of feelings I had on this amazing court during my entire tennis career is amazing. But now I'm 28,\" Nadal said, then paused and corrected himself with a chuckle: \"Well, no, 38. I would love to be 28!\"\n\nAddressing the fans directly, Nadal said: \"The feelings that you made me feel here are unbelievable. I really hope to see you again, but I don't know. Merci beaucoup.\"\n\nAnd with that, he gathered his bags and headed to the locker room, but not before stopping to look around and applaud right back at those applauding him and saluting him with one final chant.\n\n\"Ra-fa! Ra-fa!\"\n\nAP tennis: https://apnews.com/hub/tennis", "source": {"uri": "eagletribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Eagle-Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "howard_fendrich@eagletribune.com", He had hip surgery during the 2023 French Open, the first time he missed it since winning his debut there as a teenager.\n\n\"My body has been a jungle for two years. You don't know what to expect,\" Nadal said. \"I wake up one day and I (felt like I had) a snake biting me. Another day, a tiger.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3, has been limited to 16 matches and an 8-8 record since the start of last year. He got broken again to end the first set.\n\nThe 6-foot-6 (1.98-meter) Zverev is a talented player coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open. The 27-year-old German leverages every bit of his long legs and considerable wingspan to cover the court well and unleash tough-to-corral groundstrokes.\n\nAs he plays in Paris, he is awaiting Friday's start of a trial in a Berlin court related to accusations of domestic abuse made by an ex-girlfriend. Zverev does not need to be present at the court and has said he won't be there.\n\nOn Monday, there were two stretches, albeit brief, where Nadal looked as though he might be able to find enough muscle memory to make this a close contest.\n\nIn the second set, right after he flubbed a backhand and hung his head, Nadal faced a pair of break points that would have put Zverev up 3-1. Nadal escaped, using a 116 mph (187 kph) ace and a 117 mph (188 kph) service winner to hold, before breaking for a 3-2 lead.\n\nRoars.\n\nNot so fast. He pumped his fists, gritted his teeth and screamed, \"Vamos!\"\n\nMore roars.\n\nOnce more, though, Nadal failed to sustain it and soon was back at 2-all. Zverev broke to lead 5-3, and that essentially was that. Nadal said his body felt as well as it has in a while during practice, and he finally could move without limitations, but he hasn't been competing enough lately.\n\n\"To hold your level (with) this amount of energy, this amount of concentration,\" he explained, \"you need to be playing often.\"\n\nAddressing the fans directly, Nadal said: \"The feelings that you made me feel here are unbelievable. I really hope to see you again, but I don't know. Merci beaucoup.\"\n\nAnd with that, he gathered his bags and headed to the locker room, but not before stopping to look around.
