It is the place I love the most.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 next week, showed all his trademark fighting qualities in a gripping match, but only managed to convert two of 11 break points against an inspired opponent.\n\n\"The first round wasn't ideal,\" he admitted, before saying he \"hoped\" to be back at Roland Garros later this summer for the Paris Olympics but would almost certainly skip Wimbledon.\n\n\"It will be difficult playing on grass considering that right after Wimbledon are the Olympic Games.\"\n\nIt was only Nadal's fifth tournament since January 2023 after suffering a hip injury and then a muscle tear, arriving in Paris a lowly 275th in the world rankings.\n\n\"It's hard to say about the future,\" he added. \"I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. The body is feeling better than it did two months ago.\"\n\nNadal was unseeded for the draw and vulnerable to a difficult opening round.\n\nGerman Zverev, who lifted the Rome Open title last month, proved too strong despite the fans desperately attempting to raise Nadal to past glories.\n\nThe 27-year-old banished the memories of the duo's last meeting, when he left Chatrier court on a wheelchair after injuring his ankle during their 2022 French Open semi-final.\n\nHis reward for becoming just the third player to defeat Nadal at Roland Garros -- after Novak Djokovic and Robin Soderling -- is a match against either David Goffin or home wildcard Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard.\n\n- Zverev's fast start -\n\nZverev started the match strongly with a break to love in the opening game, going on to wrap up the first set with relative ease.\n\nNadal was much improved from his most recent outing, when he was well beaten by Hubert Hurkacz in the Rome second round, but failed to serve out the second set when leading 5-4.\n\nZverev then came out on top in a tense tie-break as a Nadal return found the net.\n\nThe Spaniard again broke first in the third set to lead 2-0, much to the delight of the 15,000 spectators in attendance, including Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz, Swiatek and Manchester City footballer Rodri.\n\nBut Zverev quickly hit back once more, before breaking for a 4-3 lead with a wonderful passing winner.\n\nHe secured victory on his first match point as Nadal blazed a forehand off target, potentially ending the most dominant career at a single event in Grand {"uri": "2024-05-370032001", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "18:27:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T18:27:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T18:27:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "http://accesswdun.com/article/2024/5/1244910/14-time-champion-nadal-ousted-in-1st-round-of-french-open", "title": "14-time champion Nadal ousted in 1st round of French Open", "body": "PARIS -- The noise was loud and relentless, a chorus of thousands of belting out \" Ra-fa! Ra-fa! \" whenever their guy found the occasional moment of brilliance of the sort he has conjured up so often at the French Open and elsewhere through the years.\n\nThe 15,000 or so on hand roared their support when Rafael Nadal stepped out into Court Philippe Chatrier on Monday. When the 14-time champion at Roland Garros approached the net for the prematch coin toss. When he took his swings during the warmup. And, especially, when he whipped his trademark topspin lefty forehand or chopped his two-fisted cross-court backhand or placed a volley perfectly to claim a point.\n\nThe problem for Nadal, and for his fans, is that there were not nearly enough such points for him on this afternoon-into-evening match against Alexander Zverev. Not enough vintage play to allow his nearly 38-year-old, oft-injured body to claim one more victory, no matter how much the folks in the stands tried to will that to happen. And so he lost 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3 in the first round of the French Open to Zverev in what might turn out to be Nadal's last match at the clay-court tournament he dominated for so long.\n\n\"If it's the last time that I played here,\" Nadal said, \"I am at peace with myself.\"\n\nIt is the first time in his long and illustrious career that Nadal has been beaten in two consecutive matches on clay courts -- he lost to Hubert Hurkacz at the Italian Open on May 11 -- and the first time he has dropped a match earlier than the fourth round at the French Open.\n\nHe had indicated 2024 likely would be his last season before retirement, but he said Saturday that he is not 100% sure he won't play again at the French Open. And he reiterated that after Monday's defeat, only his fourth in 116 career matches at the place.\n\n\"It's difficult for me to talk,\" said the Spaniard, whose 1 1/2-year-old son, Rafael Jr., sat on his mother's lap in the stands. \"I don't know (if) it's going to be the last time I am here. I am not 100% sure.\"\n\nWhile Nadal said it's doubtful that he will enter Wimbledon, which he won twice and starts on July 1, he did note that he hopes to return to Roland Garros later that month, when the Paris Olympics' tennis competition will be held at the French Open's site.\n\nWhen Monday's match ended, in anticlimactic fashion, with the 22-time Grand Slam champion simply unable to play at his usual level after 1 1/2 years of hip and abdominal injuries, he thanked the crowd for the \"incredible the amount of energy\" it provided throughout the 3 hours, 5 minutes of play. The match was played with the retractable roof shut, and the shouts of his two-syllable nickname echoed.\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3, has been limited to 16 matches and an 8-8 record since the start of last year. His infrequent play dropped his ranking to No. 275, and he was unseeded for the French Open for the first time; indeed, he'd never been anything worse than the No. 6 seed in 18 previous appearances going back to his days as a teenager.\n\nThat is why Nadal ended up facing the No. 4-seeded Zverev, the runner-up at the 2020 U.S. Open, a gold medalist at the Tokyo Olympics and the only man to reach the semifinals in Paris each of the past three years.\n\nNadal's other losses at Roland Garros came against Robin Soderling in 2010 and against Novak Djokovic in 2015 and 2021.\n\nDjokovic, owner of 24 major championships and the man Nadal played against more than any other, sat in the stands Monday, as did younger stars Iga Swiatek and Carlos Alcaraz. Also there: Nadal's uncle, Toni, who used to be his coach. Not surprisingly, it was difficult to spot so much as a single empty beige chair anywhere in the arena on what many realized could be a historic occasion.\n\nHere and there, when Nadal was able to come up with the goods and get the better of his opponent, he would yell \"Vamos!\" and throw that celebratory uppercut that became so familiar, from the days of muscle shirts and Capri pants to Monday's look of sky-blue sleeves and standard-length white shorts. His numerous and vocal supporters would respond in kind, thrusting their fists in the air right along with him or shaking their red-and-yellow Spanish flags or clapping to the beat of a drum.\n\nIf Nadal put a ball into the net, or sailed one wide or long, the groans of disappointment filled the chilly air. Between points, especially when he was trying to navigate a difficult spot, it was so quiet that a pigeon's coos were audible from a corner of the stadium.\n\nNadal began shakily, with a misplayed drop shot and a double-fault contributing to getting broken at love. He got broken again to end the first set.\n\nThe 6-foot-6 (1.98-meter) Zverev is a talented player, one coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open. The 27-year-old German leverages every bit of his long legs and considerable wingspan to cover the court well and unleash tough-to-corral groundstrokes.\n\nAs he plays in Paris, he is awaiting Friday's start of a trial in a Berlin court related to accusations of domestic abuse made by an ex-girlfriend. Zverev does not need to be present at the court and has said he won't be there.\n\nOn Monday, there were two stretches, albeit brief, where Nadal looked as though he might be able to find enough muscle memory to make this a close contest.\n\nIn the second set, right after he flubbed a backhand and hung his head, he faced a pair of break points that would have put Zverev up 3-1. Nadal escaped, using a 116 mph (187 kph) ace and a 117 mph (188 kph) service winner to hold, before breaking for a 3-2 lead.\n\nRoars.\n\nNot so fast. Nadal served for that set at 5-4, but Zverev broke at love, then was superior in the ensuing tiebreaker.\n\nAt the start of the third set, Nadal again erased a pair of break points, then broke for a 2-0 lead with a trademark on-the-run forehand. He pumped his fists, gritted his teeth and screamed, \"Vamos!\"\n\nMore roars.\n\nOnce more, though, Nadal failed to sustain that level, and soon it was 2-all. Zverev later broke to lead 5-3, and that essentially was that.\n\n\"The amount of feelings I had on this amazing court during my entire tennis career is amazing. But now I'm 28,\" Nadal said, then paused and corrected himself with a chuckle: \"Well, no, 38. I would love to be 28!\"\n\nAddressing the fans directly, Nadal said: \"The feelings that you made me feel here are unbelievable. I really hope to see you again, but I don't know. Merci beaucoup.\"\n\nAnd with that, he gathered his bags and headed to the locker room, but not before stopping to look around and applaud right back at those applauding him and saluting him with one final chant.", "source": {"uri": "accesswdun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Access WDUN"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Zverev", "type": "wiki", {"uri": "2024-05-369760544", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "13:34:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T13:34:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T13:32:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/tennis/2024/05/27/rafael-nadal-vs-alexander-zverev-french-open-live-score1/", "title": "Rafael Nadal vs Alexander Zverev live: French Open score and latest first-round updates", "body": "2:31PM\n\nNadal* 0-2 Zverev\n\nThat's age for ya. Little drop shot from Zverev, not perfect and it sits up a bit. In his prime, Rafa would have hared over there, slid, and hit a winner. But today, he just gives it up when six or eight yards away, knowing that it would be a waste of energy.\n\nNadal wins the first two points of that game. When he can stand and deliver he still looks mighty but the court coverage is going to be the issue. If Sascha can play the man not the legend here, he should win with plenty in hand.\n\n2:26PM\n\nNadal 0-1 Zverev*\n\nNadal is up against is straight away. Zverev aggressive, direct, moving the Spanish veteran around and he's been very dominant there. Before you know it, it's 0-40 and, not that the great man needed telling, but he knows he's in a huge fight. Zverev takes the first of the three break points at his disposal.\n\n2:21PM\n\nNadal in a powder blue\n\nshirt with white shorts, his opponent in a shirt with a yellow front and white back. It's Nadal to serve first.\n\n2:18PM\n\nRoof a factor?\n\nA few boos ring out among the cheers as Alexander Zverev enters the stadium. The closed roof clearly favours Zverev, both because Nadal is the world's best windy-weather player (his heavy spin cuts through the breeze) and because Zverev has arguably the best serve in the game right now, which will only be enhanced by the lack of any wind to disrupt his ball-toss. He is landing a mind-boggling 74 per cent of his first serves this season, and unless Nadal gets in his head, I'd expect that figure to climb above 80 today.\n\n2:17PM\n\nThe great man is out on court\n\nTo a rapturous reception, as you might imagine, and this could be a fantastic occasion. By the way, it's Alan Tyers here to talk you through the action.\n\n2:10PM\n\nThe last dance for Nadal in Paris?\n\nHello and welcome to coverage from the French Open in what could be Rafael Nadal's final match at Roland Garros.\n\nThe 14-time champion begins his campaign against Alexander Zverev, which is the standout match in the first round.\n\n\"It's not ideal the first match, because I feel competitive to have this match later in the tournament, but it's how it is,\" Nadal said.\n\n\"I need to be ready since the beginning. Let's see.\"\n\nThe meeting will bring back contrasting memories for both players of the last time they met, in a French Open semi-final in 2022, when Nadal went on to win yet another title in Paris, the last of his 22 Grand Slam victories.\n\nZverev was forced to retire from that match with an ankle injury. He underwent surgery and ended up missing the rest of the season with another injury, but he returned last year to reach his third consecutive French Open semi-final.\n\nWith some of the other top players such as Novak Djokovic, Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz, struggling with injuries of late, this could be Zverev's chance to finally win a Grand Slam.\n\nThe German might not have wanted to meet Nadal so early in the tournament but he was happy to have the chance to take him on again.\n\n\"I really wanted to play him here. I did not want to play him in the first round. I wanted to play him in the semi-finals, finals, a later stage of the tournament,\" Zverev said.\n\n\"But at the end of the day, he's not seeded, it is how it is, and I think we're both prepared for a tough battle.\"\n\nAny plans to pay tribute to Nadal if he loses have been scuppered because he has said this might not necessarily be his final appearance at the tournament.\n\n\"As you can imagine, we had something planned for him. But ... because he doesn't know if it's going to be his last Roland Garros or not, he wants to leave the door open maybe to come back next year as a player. So we are not going to push him, obviously, to do anything,\" Mauresmo said.\n\n\"It's his decision when he wants to have a proper ceremony, a proper goodbye, a proper farewell. So we're not going to do it this year. That's his wish,\" she continued. \"And even though we were ready to push the button if something happens, we obviously are going to respect what he wants and make sure we are ready whenever he feels he wants to do it. {"uri": "8146001382", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "00:55:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T00:55:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T00:54:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.timesfreepress.com/news/2024/may/25/rafael-nadal-not-so-sure-this-will-be-his-last/", "title": "Rafael Nadal not so sure this will be his last French Open", "body": "PARIS -- Rafael Nadal smiled. He joked. He sounded upbeat. He has been playing well and feeling better in practice. He is eager to get going at Roland Garros after dealing for so long with hip and abdominal problems.\n\nOh, and then there's this little tidbit he dropped during a news conference Saturday, just before the start of the second major tennis tournament of the year: This French Open might not turn out to be the 14-time champion's last appearance, after all, at his favorite event, one he called \"magical.\"\n\nBecause of his age -- the Spaniard turns 38 on June 3 -- and his injuries, not to mention his past statements about figuring 2024 would be his last year on the ATP Tour, everyone from fellow players to fans to members of the media have been assuming it will be his farewell appearance at the clay court Grand Slam event.\n\nAsked whether that's accurate, Nadal grinned and replied: \"Don't assume that.\"\n\n\"It's a big, big chance that it's going to be my last Roland Garros,\" Nadal said. \"But if I have to tell you it's 100% my last Roland Garros? Sorry, but I will not. Because I cannot predict what's going on.\"\n\nHe missed much of the past two seasons because of health problems, including hip surgery that forced him to sit out the French Open a year ago, his first absence in the event since he made his debut as a teenager. He is just 7-4 in 2024, and he expressed a bit of doubt after a lopsided loss at the Italian Open two weeks ago -- he called it a \"disaster\" on Saturday -- as to whether he would even enter the competition in Paris.\n\nHe did show up, though, and trained in front of loud, supportive crowds during the week leading up to competition. Because his ranking is so low after such little activity -- once No. 1, he is currently No. 276 -- Nadal did not get the benefit of a seeding and was drawn to face No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev in a showdown that will be the focus on Monday, the second day of main draw play.\n\n\"Ideally, I would have liked to play him in the later stage of the tournament, but it is how it is now. He is unseeded this year; I am seeded,\" Zverev said. \"You know, it's a tough draw, but it's a tough draw for both of us. We'll see how it goes.\"\n\nNadal said he can move more confidently than he has lately and gets the sense he can play with anyone now, a sensation that has been fleeting for a while.\n\n\"I probably will say is the first week since I come back playing tennis that I am able to run the proper way without having a lot of limitations,\" he said. \"That encourages me.\"\n\nZverev is coming off a title in Rome and might be a popular pick as the most talented current player without a Grand Slam singles trophy. He was the runner-up at the 2020 U.S. Open and was at the top of his game two years ago at the French Open, when he took on Nadal in the semifinals but had to stop after tearing ligaments in his right ankle and was taken out of Court Philippe Chatrier in a wheelchair.\n\nWhen Zverev's brother, former player Mischa, informed him of the draw's outcome on Thursday, Zverev said he figured it was a joke. It was very much real, and Zverev said he can't go into Monday's match thinking about facing a diminished Nadal.\n\n\"For me, in my mind, I'm going to play peak Rafa Nadal. That's what I expect him to be. I expect him to be at his absolute best,\" Zverev said. \"I expect him to play the best tennis he's played in a long time on this court.\"\n\nAt the 2022 French Open, Nadal wound up winning his 22nd major championship -- only Novak Djokovic, the No. 1 seed, has more Grand Slam men's singles titles with 24 -- while playing on a left foot that hurt so much he needed nerve-numbing injections. So competing at something less than perfect health is nothing new to him.\n\nHe hurt his hip during a second-round loss at the Australian Open in January 2023 and later had an operation. A comeback this January was stalled by a tear in a hip muscle near that original injury. A recurrence of an abdominal issue hampered Nadal after that.\n\nSo while Nadal has often intimated retirement is beckoning, he said Saturday that he doesn't \"want to close, 100%, the door,\" because he is enjoying playing tennis, he likes traveling with his wife and young son and, he added, \"I was not able to explore yet the proper way how I will be able to play, being in, again, more or less healthy conditions, playing without limitation.\"\n\nHe asked Saturday for a halt to questions about his future while he figures things out. About a possible return to the French Open. About how much longer he will be on tour.\n\n\"Give me some time,\" Nadal said. \"Maybe in one month and a half, I'll say, 'OK, it's enough. I can't keep going.' But today, in some way, I cannot guarantee that that's going to be the last one.\"", "source": {"uri": "timesfreepress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "timesfreepress.com"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-05-370347865", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "04:46:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T04:46:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T04:40:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.news.com.au/sport/tennis/rafael-nadals-son-steals-the-show-in-adorable-french-open-scenes/news-story/1d00ae7d90409c23cc9ca6ae99c38e6b", "title": "Rafael Nadal's son steals the show in adorable French Open scenes", "body": "Some were some familiar faces in the crowd for what could well have been Rafael Nadal's last match at the French Open overnight.\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3, went down 6-3 7-6 (7/5) 6-3 to world number four Alexander Zverev, suffering only his fourth loss in 116 matches at Roland Garros since his 2005 title-winning debut.\n\n\"I really hope to see you again -- but I don't know,\" the 14-time French Open champion said after the demoralising loss to Zverev.\n\nA look at the crowd packed into Court Phillipe Chartier told the story.\n\nLongtime rival Novak Djokovic and tournament favourite Carlos Alcaraz were in attendance, as was Nadal's parents, wife Maria 'Xisca' Perello and their young son.\n\nNadal and Perello welcomed their son in October 2022, reportedly naming him Rafael Nadal Junior.\n\nAnd 'Baby Rafa' well and truly stole the show in the French Open crowd as he watched his dad play on a court he dominated for two decades.\n\nTennis fans couldn't get enough of Nadal's son, who captured the heart viewers with his many glorious facial expressions during the match.\n\nRafa junior played with a mini version of Nadal's Babolat tennis racquet as he sat with his mum.\n\nNadal was spotted swinging his son around and playing with him in wholesome scenes after the match.\n\nThe Tennis Letter account wrote on X: \"Rafa Nadal playing with Baby Rafa is the cutest thing you'll see all week. Pure love, nothing else.\"\n\nIt was the first time he had been defeated in Paris in the opening round and will again lead to questions over his long-term future in the sport.\n\n\"It is difficult for me to talk, I don't know if it's the last time I'll be here in front of all of you,\" he said.\n\n\"Honestly, I am not sure. If it is, then you have been amazing. The feelings I have today are difficult to describe in words. It is the place I love the most.\"\n\nHe added: \"It's hard to say about the future. I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. The body is feeling better than it did two months ago.\n\n\"Maybe in two months I say it's enough. That is something I don't feel yet.\"\n\nNadal may not return for the 2025 French Open but he still plans to play the Olympics in the city in July.\n\n\"I hope to be back here for the Olympics, that motivates me. I really hope to be well prepared,\" he said to loud cheers.\n\nPlagued by injuries, which had limited him to just four events since January last year, former world number one Nadal is now 275 in the rankings and was unseeded in Paris.\n\nHowever, he insisted on the eve of the tournament that he was \"100 per cent keeping the door open\" on his future in a sport which has brought him 22 Grand Slam titles.\n\nNadal was broken to love in his opening service game and he was left to regret his inability to convert two break points in the fourth game.\n\nNadal saved two set points in the ninth game but surrendered the opener after 50 minutes when he buried a loose forehand into the net.\n\nIt was only the fourth opening set he had lost at Roland Garros. Nadal broke for the first time in the match to lead 3-2 in the second set but couldn't back up the advantage and handed the break back to three-time semi-finalist Zverev as he served for the set.\n\nA tense tie-breaker followed which the German claimed, buoyed by stretching to 5-3 on the back of a gruelling 19-shot rally.\n\nHowever, Zverev again roared back to level at 2-2 before a besieged Nadal had to save four break points in a 13-minute fifth game to stay in contention.\n\nThe effort was too much and a composed Zverev was soon 4-3 up and the match was over when Nadal fired a forehand wide and long.\n\n\"The amount of feelings I had on this court throughout my career, I didn't think I would be here almost 38 with all of the success. It has been a very beautiful process,\" he before he left to a standing ovation.\n\nNadal all but rules out playing Wimbledon\n\nNadal virtually ruled himself out of a final appearance at Wimbledon this year, saying it will not be \"smart\" to do so before the Olympics.\n\n\"I can't confirm anything, but I don't think it's smart after everything my body has been through,\" said Nadal.\n\n\"It will be difficult playing on grass considering that right after Wimbledon are the Olympic Games.\"\n\nNadal has twice been a Wimbledon champion, winning the title in 2008 and 2010 but also enduring some of his toughest moments at the All England Club.\n\nHe last played the tournament in 2022 when he was forced to withdraw before his semi-final against Nick Kyrgios with an abdomen strain.", {"uri": "8146281748", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "07:08:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T07:08:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T07:04:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.nwaonline.com/news/2024/may/26/dont-assume-this-is-nadals-final-french-open/", "title": "'Don't assume' this is Nadal's final French Open", "body": "PARIS -- Rafael Nadal smiled. He joked. He sounded upbeat. He's been playing well and feeling better in practice. He is eager to get going at Roland Garros after dealing for so long with hip and abdominal problems.\n\nOh, and then there's this little tidbit he dropped during a pre-tournament news conference Saturday: This French Open might not turn out to be the 14-time champion's last appearance, after all, at his favorite event, one he called \"magical.\"\n\nBecause of his age -- he turns 38 on June 3 -- and his injuries, not to mention past statements about figuring 2024 would be his last year on tour, everyone from other players to fans to the media has been assuming it will be his farewell appearance at the French Open.\n\nAsked whether that's accurate, Nadal grinned and replied: \"Don't assume that.\"\n\n\"It's a big, big chance that it's going to be my last Roland Garros,\" Nadal said. \"But if I have to tell you it's 100% my last Roland Garros? Sorry, but I will not. Because I cannot predict what's going on.\"\n\nThe Spaniard missed much of the last two seasons because of health problems, including hip surgery that forced him to sit out the French Open a year ago, his first absence there since he made his debut as a teenager. He is just 7-4 in 2024, and he expressed a bit of doubt after a lopsided loss at the Italian Open two weeks ago -- he called it a \"disaster\" on Saturday -- as to whether he would even enter the clay-court tournament in Paris at all.\n\nBut he did show up and has been training in front of loud, supportive crowds this week. Because his ranking is so low after such little activity -- once No. 1, he is No. 276 currently -- Nadal did not get the benefit of a seeding and was drawn to face No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev in a showdown that will be the focus on Monday, Day 2 of the tournament.\n\n\"Ideally, I would have liked to play him in the later stage of the tournament, but it is how it is now. He is unseeded this year; I am seeded,\" Zverev said. \"You know, it's a tough draw, but it's a tough draw for both of us. We'll see how it goes.\"\n\nNadal said he can move more confidently than he has been and gets the sense he can play with anyone now, a sensation that has been fleeting for a while.\n\n\"I probably will say is the first week since I come back playing tennis that I am able to run the proper way without having a lot of limitations,\" he said. \"That encourages me.\"\n\nZverev is coming off a title in Rome and might be a popular pick as the most talented player yet to win a Grand Slam trophy. He was the runner-up at the 2020 U.S. Open and was at the top of his game two years ago at Roland Garros, when he took on Nadal in the semifinals but had to stop after tearing ligaments in his right ankle and was taken out of Court Philippe Chatrier with a wheelchair.\n\nWhen Zverev's brother, former player Mischa, informed him of the draw's outcome on Thursday, Zverev said he figured it was a joke.\n\nAnd Zverev -- whose ongoing court case related to accusations of domestic abuse by a former girlfriend will resume with a hearing in his native Germany next week -- said he can't go into Monday's match thinking about facing a diminished Nadal.\n\n\"For me, in my mind, I'm going to play peak Rafa Nadal. That's what I expect him to be. I expect him to be at his absolute best,\" Zverev said. \"I expect him to play the best tennis he's played in a long time on this court.\"\n\nNadal wound up winning his 22nd major championship at the 2022 French Open while playing on a left foot that hurt so much he needed nerve-numbing injections. So competing at something less than perfect health is nothing new.\n\nHe hurt his hip during a second-round loss at the Australian Open in January 2023, and later had an operation. A comeback this January was stalled by a tear in a hip muscle near that original injury. A recurrence of an abdominal issue hampered Nadal later this season.\n\nAnd while Nadal has often intimated retirement is beckoning, he said Saturday that he doesn't \"want to close, 100%, the door,\" because he is enjoying playing tennis, he likes traveling with his wife and young son and, he added, \"I was not able to explore yet the proper way how I will be able to play, being in, again, more or less healthy conditions, playing without limitation.\"\n\nHe asked Saturday for a halt to questions about his future while he figures things out. About a possible return to the French Open. About how much longer he will be on tour.\n\n\"Give me some time,\" Nadal said. \"Maybe in one month and a half, I'll say, 'OK, it's enough. I can't keep going.' But today, in some way, I cannot guarantee that that's going to be the last one.\"\n\nSpain's Rafael Nadal arrives for a training session at the Roland Garros stadium, Saturday, May 25, 2024 in Paris. {"uri": "8148574938", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "18:06:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T18:06:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T18:06:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://bdnews24.com/sport/11c69e4a0484", "title": "Nadal goes down fighting against Zverev in earliest French Open exit", "body": "French Open - Roland Garros, Paris, France - May 27, 2024 Spain's Rafael Nadal reacts as he leaves the court after losing his first round match against Germany's Alexander Zverev REUTERS/Stephanie Lecocq\n\nRafa Nadal crashed to his earliest exit at the French Open on Monday after a 6-3 7-6(5) 6-3 first-round defeat by fourth seed Alexander Zverev, with fans wondering if the 14-times champion will return to the Grand Slam he has ruled for two decades.\n\nThe 22-times major champion, who won the Musketeers' Cup for the first time in 2005 and last raised the trophy in 2022 before a serious hip injury derailed his career, had previously said this year could be his final one on the tour.\n\nHaving returned to the tournament that he skipped in 2023 and refusing to confirm any farewells ahead of his opener, Nadal showed flashes of top form again on Court Philippe Chatrier but the 37-year-old ultimately went down fighting.\n\n\"I'm not 100% sure if it's the last time but I enjoyed it, the crowd were amazing during the whole week of preparation and today,\" Nadal said as the crowd rose to their feet.\n\n\"The feelings today are difficult to describe with words but it's special to feel the love in the place I love the most.\n\n\"I enjoy playing a lot and travelling with the family. The body is feeling better than two months ago. Maybe in two months I say it's enough. But it's something I don't feel yet.\"\n\nVictory meant Zverev became only the third man to beat Nadal at Roland Garros, after Novak Djokovic and Robin Soderling, with the German also banishing memories of his retirement due to an ankle injury when the duo last met in the 2022 semi-finals.\n\n\"I don't know what to say... thank you Rafa from all of the tennis world, it's such a great honour,\" Zverev said.\n\n\"I've watched Rafa play all my childhood and I was lucky enough to play him twice on this beautiful court.\"\n\nNadal was broken by in-form Rome champion Zverev in the opening game and surrendered his serve again late on to drop the first set in unfavourable conditions for him with the roof closed due to heavy rain earlier.\n\nFaced with the prospect of only his fourth Roland Garros defeat in 116 matches, Nadal made a positive start to the next set as he leapt and pumped his fists after holding for 2-2 and broke for the first time with a delicate drop.\n\nThe crowd began to sense a comeback as Nadal went ahead 4-2 with some vintage shots on both flanks but the steely Zverev hit back in the 10th game and saved two breakpoints before doubling his advantage by edging a high-octane tiebreak.\n\nWatched on by his great rival Djokovic and a host of other current players, Nadal surged to a 2-0 lead in the third set but squandered it as Zverev drew level and dealt another body blow in the seventh game.\n\nThe boisterous crowd tried their best to roar Nadal on but Zverev held his nerve to clinch a famous victory that could well prove to be the springboard {"uri": "8148686771", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "19:59:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T19:59:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T19:58:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://nationnews.com/2024/05/27/nadal-loses-on-possible-french-open-farewell/", "title": "Nadal loses on possible French Open farewell - nationnews.com", "body": "Rafael Nadal lost in the French Open singles for only the fourth time in 116 matches (Getty Imaes)\n\nRafael Nadal's return to the French Open - and possible farewell - ended at the first hurdle as the 14-time winner lost to Alexander Zverev.\n\nThe 22-time Grand Slam champion was beaten 6-3 7-6 (7-5) 6-3 by the in-form German fourth seed.\n\nNadal has become synonymous with Roland Garros but, in front of a partisan crowd, he could not replicate the level which has made him almost unbeatable on the Paris clay.\n\nThe 37-year-old indicated when he missed last year's French Open that the 2024 season could be his final one on tour.\n\nHe has also said he does not know if this will be his final time at the clay-court major - but it remains a \"big chance\" it will be.\n\nNadal arrived on Court Philippe Chatrier - the scene of many of the finest moments of his career - to a thunderous reception from a packed stadium.\n\nWhile nowhere near his scintillating best, the former world number one showed flashes of the brilliance that has made him so loved, but not enough to stringently test Zverev.\n\nIt was only Nadal's fourth defeat in 116 singles matches at Roland Garros and Zverev became the third man - after Robin Soderling in 2009 and Novak Djokovic in 2015 and 2021 - to beat him there.\n\n\"I don't know if it'll be the last time I'm going to be here in front of you. If it is I have enjoyed it,\" Nadal said in an on-court speech.\n\n\"The crowd have been amazing the whole week. For me it's so special to feel the love of the people the way I have felt.\"\n\nWith some fans crying in the stands, Nadal departed to another standing ovation as the crowd showed their appreciation for the tournament's finest champion.\n\nAnticipation for Nadal's return had been frenzied all day, with fans of the iconic champion - easily identified by Spanish red and yellow flags and 'Gracias Rafa' T-shirts - milling around the arena as soon as the gates opened.\n\nAfter a dismal defeat by Hubert Hurkacz in Rome last month, Nadal had not even been sure if he would be ready to compete here.\n\nIn a bullish pre-tournament news conference, he said he quickly found the motivation to return and felt his practice session showed he could \"play against anyone\".\n\nPractice is very different to a match, of course. Nadal knew that and knew he faced a monumental task against Zverev.\n\nWith the 275th-ranked Nadal unseeded at Roland Garros for the first time, having barely played because of injury in the past 18 months, it left him vulnerable to facing a leading player when the draw was made.\n\nZverev is considered one of the finest players not to have won a major title and, being a strong clay-courter, stands a good chance of finally joining the pantheon of Grand Slam winners over the next fortnight.\n\nHe reached the 2022 French Open semi-finals, retiring against Nadal after a nasty fall which led to a serious ankle injury, and tuned up this year by winning the Rome title earlier this month.\n\nThe way in which the 27-year-old played against Nadal reiterated why he is among the favourites.\n\nZverev has insisted a court case over domestic abuse allegations will not distract him. Zverev has denied the charges, with a hearing set to begin on Friday in Germany. His career record at the clay-court Grand Slam tournament is now 112-4.\n\nThe match was played with the retractable roof shut at Court Philippe Chatrier on Monday, and the loud cheers for Nadal from most in the capacity crowd of about 15,000 echoed throughout.\n\nNadal, who owns 22 major trophies in all, turns 38 on June 3 and he has been dealing with hip and abdominal injuries since January 2023, limiting him to 15 matches and an 8-7 record since the start of last year. His infrequent play dropped his ranking to No. 275 and he was unseeded for the French Open for the first time.\n\nThat is why he ended up facing the No. 4-seeded Zverev, the runner-up at the 2020 U.S. Open, a gold medalist at the Tokyo Olympics and the only man to reach the semifinals in Paris each of the past three years.\n\nNadal has indicated 2024 likely would be his last season before retirement but he said Saturday that he is not 100% sure he won't play again at the French Open. {"uri": "8148627768", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "18:56:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T18:56:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T18:56:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/rafael-nadal-swept-alexander-zverev-174325555.html", "title": "Rafael Nadal swept by Alexander Zverev in possible French Open farewell", "body": "Rafael Nadal lost in the French Open first round for the first time in what may have been his last match at the tournament he has won a record 14 times.\n\nNo. 4 seed Alexander Zverev of Germany swept Nadal 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3 on Monday.\n\n\"I don't know (if) it's going to be the last time that I'm going to be here in front of all of you,\" Nadal said in an on-court interview. \"Honestly, I'm not 100% sure, but if it's last time, I enjoy it, no?\"\n\nThe 37-year-old Nadal, unseeded because he missed most of the last year and a half due to injuries, said before the tournament that there was \"a big, big chance\" it will be his last French Open.\n\nFRENCH OPEN DRAWS: Men | Women | Broadcast Schedule\n\nNadal said Saturday that he would need time after the tournament to decide about returning to the event in 2025.\n\n\"Maybe in two months I say it's enough, I can't give anything else, no?\" Nadal said after Monday's match. \"But it's something I don't feel yet. I have some goals in front. I hope to be back on this court for the (Paris) Olympics. That motivates me. That's going to be another chance, and I really hope to be well prepared.\"\n\nZverev, who won the last top-level tour event before the French Open, broke Nadal at love in the opening game, then again to secure the first set.\n\nNadal broke Zverev to go up 3-2 in the second, then was broken at love while serving for the set.\n\nNadal won the first two games of the third set before Zverev closed it out. Zverev made 77 percent of his first serves, saved nine of 11 break points and had 44 winners to 30 unforced errors.\n\n\"Today is not my moment,\" he said. \"It's Rafa's moment.\"\n\nNadal dropped to 112-4 in his French Open career and has now lost back-to-back matches on clay for the first time since he made his ATP Tour match debut in April 2002.\n\nHe entered the French Open with a 5-3 record in clay-court matches this season after missing nearly all of 2023.\n\n\"The last two years I have been working and going through probably the toughest process in my tennis career with the dream to come back here, no?\" he said. \"At least I did. I mean, I lost, but that's part of the business.\"\n\nFor the Paris Olympics, Nadal is eligible to use an injury protected ranking of No. 9 to get into the singles draw.\n\nNo. 3 seed Carlos Alcaraz of Spain said Sunday that he and Nadal plan to play doubles together at the Olympics \"if everything goes well.\"\n\nNadal said the Olympics are his \"main goal\" and that it would be \"difficult\" to play Wimbledon next month because it would require going from clay courts to grass courts and then back to clay courts for the Olympics.\n\n\"Give me two months till Olympics, and then let's see if I am able to keep going or I say, OK, guys, it's more than enough,\" Nadal said. \"Let's see. I mean, today is not a moment to analyze all these kind of things. It's a moment just to keep going, accept the moment, and let's see what's going on.\"\n\nEarlier Monday, top seed Iga Swiatek swept 148th-ranked Frenchwoman Leolia Jeanjean 6-1, 6-2 to reach a second-round match with fellow four-time Grand Slam champion Naomi Osaka on Wednesday.\n\nWho will qualify for Paris Olympics in tennis? {"uri": "2024-05-369977335", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "17:15:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T17:15:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T17:05:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240527-nadal-defeated-in-likely-french-open-farewell-1", "title": "Nadal defeated in likely French Open farewell", "body": "Paris (AFP) - Rafael Nadal's record-breaking French Open career came to its likely end on Monday when the 14-time champion slumped to a demoralising first round defeat against Alexander Zverev before he admitted: \"I really hope to see you again -- but I don't know.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3, went down 6-3, 7-6 (7/5), 6-3 to world number four Zverev, suffering only his fourth loss in 116 matches at Roland Garros since his 2005 title-winning debut.\n\nIt was the first time he had been defeated in Paris in the opening round and will again lead to questions over his long-term future in the sport.\n\n\"It is difficult for me to talk, I don't know if it's the last time I'll be here in front of all of you,\" he said.\n\n\"Honestly, I am not sure. If it is, then you have been amazing. The feelings I have today are difficult to describe in words. It is the place I love the most.\"\n\nHe added: \"It's hard to say about the future. I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. The body is feeling better than it did two months ago.\n\n\"Maybe in two months I say it's enough. That is something I don't feel yet.\"\n\nNadal may not return for the 2025 French Open but he still plans to play the Olympics in the city in July.\n\n\"I hope to be back here for the Olympics, that motivates me. I really hope to be well prepared,\" he said to loud cheers.\n\nPlagued by injuries, which had limited him to just four events since January last year, former world number one Nadal is now 275 in the rankings and was unseeded in Paris.\n\nHowever, he insisted on the eve of the tournament that he was \"100% keeping the door open\" on his future in a sport which has brought him 22 Grand Slam titles.\n\n'Thank you Rafa'\n\n\"I don't know what to say. Thank you Rafa from all of the tennis world. It is such a great honour,\" said Zverev.\n\n\"I've watched Rafa play all my childhood and I was lucky enough to play him two times on this beautiful court. Today is not my moment, it is Rafa's moment.\"\n\nIn a repeat of the 2022 semi-final, which Nadal won when Zverev quit with ankle ligament damage, the Spaniard had his chances.\n\nHe was a break of serve up in the second and third sets, only to be pinned back on both occasions by his in-form 27-year-old opponent.\n\nHowever, a relentless Zverev broke six times from 18 opportunities and fired 44 winners to Nadal's 34.\n\nChants of \"Rafa, Rafa\" had loudly echoed under the roof of Court Philippe Chatrier which was shut tight against the torrential rain sweeping across the grounds and bringing havoc to the schedule.\n\nThey subsided to silence when Nadal was broken to love in his opening service game and he was left to regret his inability to convert two break points in the fourth game.\n\nNadal saved two set points in the ninth game but surrendered the opener after 50 minutes when he buried a loose forehand into the net.\n\nIt was only the fourth opening set he had lost at Roland Garros.\n\nNadal broke for the first time in the match to lead 3-2 in the second set but couldn't back up the advantage and handed the break back to three-time semi-finalist Zverev as he served for the set.\n\n'Beautiful process'\n\nA tense tie-breaker followed which the German claimed, buoyed by stretching to 5/3 on the back of a gruelling 19-shot rally.\n\nNadal dug deep and with the likes of Novak Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz and Iga Swiatek having watched from the packed stands, he broke and held for 2-0 in the third set.\n\nHowever, Zverev again roared back to level at 2-2 before a besieged Nadal had to save four break points in a 13-minute fifth game to stay in contention.\n\nThe effort was too much and a composed Zverev was soon 4-3 up and the match was over when Nadal fired a forehand wide and long.\n\n\"The amount of feelings I had on this court throughout my career, I didn't think I would be here almost 38 with all of the success. {"uri": "8145835694", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-25", "time": "20:40:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-25T20:40:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-25T20:39:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/sports/rafael-nadal-addresses-retirement-plans-on-eve-of-2024-french-open-5657225", "title": "Rafael Nadal Addresses Retirement Plans on Eve of 2024 French Open", "body": "It had long been assumed that Rafael Nadal, the legendary Spaniard tennis player who won 22 Grand Slam single titles, would be hanging up his racket in the not-so-distant future. Based on Nadal's past comments, his recent injury history and the fact that he's competing in the 2024 French Open after his injury caused him to miss last year's tournament, it was speculated that Roland Garros could be his final sendoff, similar to Serena Williams taking a final bow at the 2022 U.S. Open.\n\nHowever, Nadal, on the eve of the French Open -- which he's won a record 14 times -- pushed back on that notion that this appearance at Roland Garros would be his final. During a pre-event press conference, Nadal was asked if he had decided that this would be his final French Open.\n\n\"Don't assume that,\" Nadal responded, before noting that physically he feels better than he did weeks ago at the Italian Open, when he lost in straight sets in the second round.\n\n\"It's a big chance it's going to be my last Roland Garros. But if I have to tell you it's 100 percent my last Roland Garros, sorry but I will not because I cannot predict what's going on ... In some way, I don't want to close 100 percent the door.\"\n\nNadal then cited that he still enjoys playing tennis and he cherishes being able to travel with his family. He also said that before, when the speculation arose that he was close to calling it a career, he wasn't able to explore playing tennis without limitation.\n\n\"Today, in some way I cannot guarantee that it's going to be the last one. But, of course, there's a big chance,\" admitted Nadal to reporters.\n\nThe speculation all stems from Nadal's own comments exactly one year ago when a hip flexor injury caused him to miss the 2023 French Open -- his first time not competing at Roland Garros since being a 17-year-old in 2004.\n\n\"My goal and my ambition is to try to stop and give myself an opportunity to enjoy next year,\" Nadal said in May 2023. \"It's probably going to be my last year in a professional tour.\n\n\"My idea and my motivation is to try to enjoy and say goodbye to all of the tournaments that have been important for me in my tennis career this year.\"\n\nInjuries caused Nadal to not only miss the 2023 French Open, but he also missed last year's Wimbledon and U.S. Open. He played just three matches in the entire calendar year, with none coming after January's Australian Open, and he underwent hip surgery in June 2023. The inactivity by Nadal caused him to drop out of the top 10 rankings for the first time since April 2005, thus ending the longest top 10 streak in ATP history. Nadal, who began the year as the No. 2 player in the world ended it ranked No. 670.\n\nHe returned to play at the Brisbane International in the first week of January and had a promising start, knocking off 2020 U.S. Open champion Dominic Thiem and then 2023 Australian Open doubles champion Jason Kubler in the first two rounds. However, injury struck again, and that same surgically operated hip flared up in his next match, which he would lose to Jordan Thompson. Nadal would lose more than just the match, as the injury would cause him to miss the year's first major Down Under at the Australian Open.\n\nNadal made his way back to the court in April in his native Spain where he fell in the second round of the Barcelona Open in straight sets. The next week he played in the Madrid Open where he won his first three matches before losing in the fourth round, also in straight sets. His final event before heading to Roland Garros was the Italian Open where he lost in the second round, again in straight sets. So, he is entering the 2024 French Open without having won a match in the quarterfinals or later of any tournament since Wimbledon in July 2022.\n\nDespite a rough last few years, Nadal is focusing on the present because, as he said, he can't predict what the future will hold. His immediate future is facing Alexander Zverev in the first round of the 2024 French Open on Monday. Nadal and Zverev have played 10 times previously, with Nadal holding a 7-3 edge, including a 5-1 record on clay, which is what Roland Garros consists of.\n\nNadal owns a record 14 French Open titles, which is as many as the two men with next-most combined in Max Decugis (eight) and Bjorn Borg (six). His 14 championships at Roland Garros are the same number as the legendary Pete Sampras has titles at all four majors combined. Nadal holds an astounding 112-3 record at the French Open, or a 97.4 percent win rate, and his 22 Grand Slam championships are second most amongst men, trailing only Novak Djokovic's 24.", "source": {"uri": "8145539561", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-25", "time": "15:16:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-25T15:16:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-25T15:12:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/rafael-nadal-says-might-not-120504773.html", "title": "Rafael Nadal says he is feeling better and this might not be his last French Open", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Rafael Nadal smiled. He joked. He sounded upbeat. He's been playing well and feeling better in practice. He is eager to get going at Roland Garros after dealing for so long with hip and abdominal problems.\n\nOh, and then there's this little tidbit he dropped during a pre-tournament news conference Saturday: This French Open might not turn out to be the 14-time champion's last appearance, after all, at his favorite event, one he called \"magical.\"\n\nBecause of his age -- he turns 38 on June 3 -- and his injuries, not to mention past statements about figuring 2024 would be his last year on tour, everyone from other players to fans to the media has been assuming it will be his farewell appearance at the French Open.\n\nAsked whether that's accurate, Nadal grinned and replied: \"Don't assume that.\"\n\n\"It's a big, big chance that it's going to be my last Roland Garros,\" Nadal said. \"But if I have to tell you it's 100% my last Roland Garros? Sorry, but I will not. Because I cannot predict what's going on.\"\n\nThe Spaniard missed much of the last two seasons because of health problems, including hip surgery that forced him to sit out the French Open a year ago, his first absence there since he made his debut as a teenager. He is just 7-4 in 2024, and he expressed a bit of doubt after a lopsided loss at the Italian Open two weeks ago -- he called it a \"disaster\" on Saturday -- as to whether he would even enter the clay-court tournament in Paris at all.\n\nBut he did show up and has been training in front of loud, supportive crowds this week. Because his ranking is so low after such little activity -- once No. 1, he is No. 276 currently -- Nadal did not get the benefit of a seeding and was drawn to face No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev in a showdown that will be the focus on Monday, Day 2 of the tournament.\n\n\"Ideally, I would have liked to play him in the later stage of the tournament, but it is how it is now. He is unseeded this year; I am seeded,\" Zverev said. \"You know, it's a tough draw, but it's a tough draw for both of us. We'll see how it goes.\"\n\nNadal said he can move more confidently than he has been and gets the sense he can play with anyone now, a sensation that has been fleeting for a while.\n\n\"I probably will say is the first week since I come back playing tennis that I am able to run the proper way without having a lot of limitations,\" he said. \"That encourages me.\"\n\nZverev is coming off a title in Rome and might be a popular pick as the most talented player yet to win a Grand Slam trophy. He was the runner-up at the 2020 U.S. Open and was at the top of his game two years ago at Roland Garros, when he took on Nadal in the semifinals but had to stop after tearing ligaments in his right ankle and was taken out of Court Philippe Chatrier with a wheelchair.\n\nWhen Zverev's brother, former player Mischa, informed him of the draw's outcome on Thursday, Zverev said he figured it was a joke.\n\nAnd Zverev -- whose ongoing court case related to accusations of domestic abuse by a former girlfriend will resume with a hearing in his native Germany next week -- said he can't go into Monday's match thinking about facing a diminished Nadal.\n\n\"For me, in my mind, I'm going to play peak Rafa Nadal. That's what I expect him to be. I expect him to be at his absolute best,\" Zverev said. \"I expect him to play the best tennis he's played in a long time on this court.\"\n\nNadal wound up winning his 22nd major championship at the 2022 French Open while playing on a left foot that hurt so much he needed nerve-numbing injections. So competing at something less than perfect health is nothing new.\n\nHe hurt his hip during a second-round loss at the Australian Open in January 2023, and later had an operation. A comeback this January was stalled by a tear in a hip muscle near that original injury. A recurrence of an abdominal issue hampered Nadal later this season.\n\nAnd while Nadal has often intimated retirement is beckoning, he said Saturday that he doesn't \"want to close, 100%, the door,\" because he is enjoying playing tennis, he likes traveling with his wife and young son and, he added, \"I was not able to explore yet the proper way how I will be able to play, being in, again, more or less healthy conditions, playing without limitation.\"\n\nHe asked Saturday for a halt to questions about his future while he figures things out. About a possible return to the French Open. About how much longer he will be on tour.\n\n\"Give me some time,\" Nadal said. \"Maybe in one month and a half, I'll say, 'OK, it's enough. I can't keep going.' But today, in some way, I cannot guarantee that that's going to be the last one.\"\n\n___\n\nHoward Fendrich has been the AP's tennis writer since 2002. {"uri": "8148780858", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "21:51:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T21:51:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T21:50:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.tennis365.com/french-open/alexander-zverev-gives-rafael-nadal-advice-after-french-open-win", "title": "Alexander Zverev gives Rafael Nadal 'unbelievable' verdict as he gives retirement advice", "body": "Alexander Zverev described his French Open first round match against Rafael Nadal as 'special', as he admitted he 'didn't know how to act' when he won the match.\n\nNadal was beaten 6-3 7-6(5) 6-3 by Zverev, who will now be seen as one of the favourites to lift the French Open title after an impressive performance against the 'King of Clay'.\n\nZverev will now join a list of just four players who have beaten Nadal on Court Philippe Chatrier, but he conceded his emotions were mixed as he tried to comprehend the magnitude of the match he had been a part of.\n\nNadal refused to confirm that had been his final match at the French Open, where he is a 14-time champion, but there is a good chance that the last entry on his Roland Garros scoresheet will be a defeat against Zverev.\n\n\"It was special, it was definitely special,\" admitted Zverev as he spoke to the media after a match that will be remembered one of the most memorable in his career.\n\n\"I didn't know how to act in certain moments, especially at the end of the match.\n\n\"There is uncertainty over whether he wants to come back and play next year. He's definitely going to be back for the Olympics, but just for Roland Garros, there is uncertainty.\n\n\"I would say the improvement he has made over the last few months and the difference in level he played today was unbelievable.\n\n\"I really felt like it was a very good match and if he stays healthy, he will continue to play better. Then he will be seeded again and that makes it a lot easier for him, for sure.\"\n\nNadal was persuaded afterwards by tournament director Amelie Mauresmo to say a few words to the crowd.\n\n\"I don't know if it's gonna be my last time here in front of you, not 100 per cent - but if it is I enjoyed it,\" he said.\n\n\"The feelings that I have are difficult to describe, it's so special to feel the love of the people in the place I love the most.\n\n\"I have been going through a very tough two years in terms of injuries and I went through a process with the dream of being back at Roland Garros.\n\n\"The first round was not the dream one but I was competitive and had my chances. It's difficult to say what's going on in the future, a big percentage that I won't be back but I can say 100 per cent I am enjoying playing and having fun.\n\n\"Maybe in two months I'll say it's enough, but it's something I don't want yet and I want to be back on this court for the Olympics.\n\n\"I never could imagine when I was a kid that I would be here at almost 38 with all the success I had here. I really hope to see you again - but I don't know.\"\n\nMeanwhile, tennis legend Boris Becker gave his verdict on Zverev's performance as he suggested Nadal should be optimistic about what is to come in the final months of his career after an improved display against the German.\n\n\"Sascha was the better player right from the start,\" Becker told Eurosport. \"He broke Nadal's first service game straight away and never let up. For me, the second set was decisive when Nadal was ahead and then lost the tie-break. It was clear then that Zverev would be the winner.\n\n\"I believe that Rafa will still play the Olympics at Roland Garros, but I don't think he'll play the French Open again in 2025.\n\n\"Of course, he has emotions and probably had a sleepless night because he didn't know whether it would be the last time. He wanted to say goodbye well. Then his opponent was Zverev, against whom he can lose even on a good day. That's why it was emotionally very difficult for Nadal.\n\n\"Sascha started with a deep return and then worked his way into the rallies. The longer the rallies became over the course of the match, the better Zverev got. That's unusual against Nadal - and he's the king of Paris. He dominates the baseline and the centre of the court because he can then send his opponent running. It was the other way round today due to Zverev's positioning.\"", "source": {"uri": "tennis365.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Tennis365.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kevin_palmer@tennis365.com", {"uri": "8148458190", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "16:28:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T16:28:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T16:28:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://metro.co.uk/2024/05/27/rafael-nadal-suffers-french-open-first-round-heartbreak-controversial-rival-2-20918475/", "title": "Rafael Nadal suffers French Open first-round heartbreak to controversial rival", "body": "Rafael Nadal suffered a gut-wrenching first-round defeat at the 2024 French Open on Monday to controversial fourth-seed Alexander Zverev.\n\nIt was widely expected that the 37-year-old was playing Roland-Garros for the final time before retirement - but he has since suggested that he may play again - with tournament organisers cancelling a farewell ceremony after his recent U-turn.\n\nNadal is the most successful player in French Open history, registering 14 men's singles titles, but headed to this year's Grand Slam event unseeded for the first time and has now suffered just his fourth defeat on the Paris clay since 2005.\n\nThe 22-time Grand Slam champion has massively struggled with injury in the last 18 months and hasn't played much, seeing his ranking drop - and he was handed a nightmare opening match against Zverev - a controversial player who is set for a trial over domestic abuse allegations, which he strongly denies.\n\nThere were audible gasps in the crowd when the draw was made as Nadal was picked to face one of the toughest possible opponents he could get - and those shocked fans had a right to be worried as Zverev beat him 6-3 7-6 6-3.\n\nThe atmosphere on Philippe-Chatrier at the start of the match was electric with fans desperate to see Nadal in action for one of the last times in Paris - and the volume only went up when the roof was closed - but there was a spell of silence as Zverev set up a triple break-point opportunity in the first game of the first set.\n\nZverev successfully converted his first break point and then held to lead 2-0 before Nadal produced his own hold to stop the rot - and then clocked up two break points of his own in game three - but his opponent managed to save them both to maintain a 3-1 lead, much to the frustration of the Nadal-loving crowd.\n\nNadal was refusing to give up, though, living up to his nickname of 'The King of Clay' to race into a quick 40-love lead before making it 3-2. But Zverev went into this match expecting 'peak Rafael Nadal' and was fully prepared for the Spanish veteran to be operating at a high level, going 40-love up himself for a 4-2 lead.\n\nThe duo traded service games for 5-3 - leaving Zverev just one game away from taking the first set - and he clocked up three set points on Nadal's serve in game nine to clinch it 6-3 as the crowd on court Philippe-Chatrier went totally silent.\n\nIn the second set, both players held in their opening two service games for 2-2, with Nadal knocking up a break point in game five and converting it with a beautiful drop shot to raise the roof as spectators got behind the 37-year-old.\n\nNadal held to open up a 4-2 lead and another trade of service games saw Nadal one game away from levelling up the match. He appeared to get complacent, though, as Zverev held and then went 40-love up on Nadal's serve in game 10, registering his third break of the match to level up the second set at 5-5.\n\nThat put the fire back in Nadal's belly as he knocked up two chances to break back, only for Zverev to save both of them, with the set eventually going to a tie-break as the German came out on top 7-5 to open up a two-set lead.\n\nNadal looked to keep the match alive as he held in game one of the third set and then broke Zverev to lead 2-0. But Zverev was not letting his lead slip away in a hurry as he responded with an instant break back and held to level it up at 2-2.\n\nNadal was then firmly on the ropes as he denied Zverev the double break four times, with both players producing holds to take it to 3-3. The German stayed patient, though, and eventually got his fifth break of the match to lead 4-3.\n\nThat led to passionate screams of 'Rafa, Rafa, Rafa' from the Philippe-Chatrier crowd as the looked to inspire the Spaniard into an unlikely comeback but he was ultimately unable to register one as Zverev closed out the match in straight sets.\n\nIt was widely expected that 2024 would be the final time Rafael Nadal would play the French Open given his public comments, but ahead of his opening match, he has appeared to suggest it may not be his last dance after all.\n\n'In terms if that's going to be my last Roland Garros, it's a long answer, but I think I need to answer that, because we're going to avoid future questions since the beginning - so I'm going to do it,' Nadal said.\n\n'As I said, it's a big, big chance that it's going to be my last Roland Garros, but if I have to tell you it's 100 per cent my last Roland Garros, sorry, but I will not, because I cannot predict what's going on. I hope you understand.\n\n'Myself, I have been going through a long process of recovery with a very difficult injury, almost two years of suffering, a recovering process that seems like I feel better now.\n\n'I am not a guy that reacts because I lost there or I lost in the other place, no? I react about my personal feelings, and my personal feelings are better now than one month and a half ago, without a doubt.\n\n'So in some way I don't want to close, 100 per cent, the door, because of a very simple thing. First thing, I am enjoying playing tennis. Second thing, I am travelling with the family. They are enjoying and I am enjoying sharing all this process with them.\n\n'And the third thing, I was not able to explore yet the proper way how I will be able to play in more or less healthy conditions, playing without limitation.\n\n'So give me some time. Maybe in one month and a half I say, 'okay it's enough, I can't keep going', but today in some way I cannot guarantee that that's going to be the last one. But of course it's a big chance.'\n\nWorld No.1 Iga Swiatek, the heavy favourite for the women's singles trophy, kicked off her title defence in style with a 6-1 6-2 win over Leolia Jeanjean.\n\nSwiatek headed into Roland-Garros in impressive form, beating world No.2 Aryna Sabalenka and world No.3 Coco Gauff in Rome to clinch the Italian Open title.\n\nAnd the Polish superstar barely broke a sweat in her first French Open match to set up an exciting clash with four-time Grand Slam winner Naomi Osaka in Paris.\n\n'It feels like home here,' Swiatek said after her victory over Jeanjean. 'Hopefully, I'm going to be here as long as possible.\n\n'I think it's too early [to be called Queen of clay]. I'm really proud of my achievements and this has always been my favourite surface.\n\n'I'm just at the beginning but I will try to take some lessons from [Rafael Nadal] on being a good person and a good player.'\n\nJannik Sinner is one of the favourites for the French Open men's singles title but arrived in Paris with a hip injury.\n\nHe moved well in a 6-3 6-3 6-4 opening win over Christopher Eubanks, though, and only looked somewhat troubled while he was serving out the match.\n\nAhead of his second-round battle with Richard Gasquet, Sinner said: 'The hip is good, I am very happy. The general shape is not at 100 per cent yet so we try to build every day.'\n\nNovak Djokovic gets started against French wildcard Pierre-Hugues Herbert on Tuesday as he begins his quest to clinch a historic 25th Grand Slam singles title.\n\nBritish No.1 Katie Boulter also plays her opening match on Tuesday, with an interesting battle against former world No.2 Paula Badosa.\n\nMORE : Enzo Maresca and Kieran McKenna show clubs promoted to Premier League face fight to keep managers", "source": {"uri": "metro.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Metro"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-370009293", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "17:56:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T17:56:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T17:46:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/french-open-news-rafael-nadal-teases-olympics-participation-roland-garros", "title": "Rafael Nadal teases Olympics participation after Roland Garros loss", "body": "Rafael Nadal had a nightmare draw in what could have been the 22-time Grand Slam champion's last match at Roland Garros -- a place where the Spanaird has won a record 14 titles. Nadal drew world No. 4 Sasha Zverev in the first-round; the German was coming off a title at the Italian Open and is eyeing his first Grand Slam title in a wide open field.\n\nThat's especially true after Zverev beat Nadal 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3 at the French Open on Monday, dashing the hopes of a deep run for the tournament's most successful athlete. And although the 37-year-old clay court specialist wouldn't confirm or deny whether he would play in France next year, he is hoping to be back on these courts for the 2026 Summer Olympics in just two months.\n\n\"Body is feeling a bit better than two months ago. Maybe in two months I say it's enough,\" Nadal said in a rare post-match interview for the losing player. \"I hope to be back on this court for the Olympics. That motivates me.\"\n\nHe added: \"I don't know if it's going to be last time I'm going to be here in front of you. I am not 100% sure, but if it is the last time, I enjoyed it. The crowd have been amazing in the whole week of preparation. The feelings that I have today are difficult to describe in words, but for me, it's so special to feel the love from the people in the place I love the most.\n\n\"It's a big percentage that I will not be back here playing at Roland Garros, but I've enjoyed it a lot. I'm traveling with the family, having fun and the body is feeling a little bit better than two months ago.\"\n\nWhat Rafael Nadal achieved at Roland Garros will never be matched\n\nDespite a disappointing ending for one of the sport's most prolific players, Nadal will go down as the best clay court player ever -- and his 14 titles at the French Open will never be matched.\n\nSince he began competing in 2003, Nadal has ridiculously lost just four matches at the tournament, including Monday's defeat to Zverev. His record at Roland Garros stands at an outrageous 112-4.\n\n\"I never could imagine when I was a kid that I will be here with almost 28 [years of age] - 38, I would love to be 28,\" Nadal said to the crowd at the end. \"I couldn't have dreamed it. It's been a beautiful process, all the memories have been different, but nonetheless special. The feelings that you make me feel here are unforgettable, thanks very much from the bottom of my heart.\"\n\nNadal reportedly told Roland Garros finalist Alex Corretja last week that his body was \"feeling pain free for the first time in two years,\" which certainly opens the door to him continuing to compete in 2025. But that is a long way away.\n\nIt will be intriguing to see if Nadal will compete in one more French Open in 2025 -- and maybe get a better draw if so. But first, the tennis world will be holding its collective breath hoping that a legend of the sport will be back in Paris come July.", "source": {"uri": "clutchpoints.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-05-370021628", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "18:13:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T18:13:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T17:52:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/14-time-champion-rafael-nadal-loses-in-the-french-opens-first-round-to-alexander-zverev/article_f2cc83e0-465a-5df1-9667-b282bcbcf280.html", "title": "14-time champion Rafael Nadal loses in the French Open's first round to Alexander Zverev", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- The noise was loud and relentless, a chorus of thousands of belting out \" Ra-fa! Ra-fa! \" whenever their guy found the occasional moment of brilliance of the sort he has conjured up so often at the French Open and elsewhere through the years.\n\nThe 15,000 or so on hand roared their support when Rafael Nadal stepped out into Court Philippe Chatrier on Monday. When the 14-time champion at Roland Garros approached the net for the prematch coin toss. When he took his swings during the warmup. And, especially, when he whipped his trademark topspin lefty forehand or chopped his two-fisted cross-court backhand or placed a volley perfectly to claim a point.\n\nThe problem for Nadal, and for his fans, is that there were not nearly enough such points for him on this afternoon-into-evening match against Alexander Zverev. Not enough vintage play to allow his nearly 38-year-old, oft-injured body to claim one more victory, no matter how much the folks in the stands tried to will that to happen. And so he lost 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3 in the first round of the French Open to Zverev in what might turn out to be Nadal's last match at the clay-court tournament he dominated for so long.\n\n\"If it's the last time that I played here,\" Nadal said, \"I am at peace with myself.\"\n\nIt is the first time in his long and illustrious career that Nadal has been beaten in two consecutive matches on clay courts -- he lost to Hubert Hurkacz at the Italian Open on May 11 -- and the first time he has dropped a match earlier than the fourth round at the French Open.\n\nHe had indicated 2024 likely would be his last season before retirement, but he said Saturday that he is not 100% sure he won't play again at the French Open. And he reiterated that after Monday's defeat, only his fourth in 116 career matches at the place.\n\n\"It's difficult for me to talk,\" said the Spaniard, whose 1 1/2-year-old son, Rafael Jr., sat on his mother's lap in the stands. \"I don't know (if) it's going to be the last time I am here. I am not 100% sure.\"\n\nWhile Nadal said it's doubtful that he will enter Wimbledon, which he won twice and starts on July 1, he did note that he hopes to return to Roland Garros later that month, when the Paris Olympics' tennis competition will be held at the French Open's site.\n\nWhen Monday's match ended, in anticlimactic fashion, with the 22-time Grand Slam champion simply unable to play at his usual level after 1 1/2 years of hip and abdominal injuries, he thanked the crowd for the \"incredible the amount of energy\" it provided throughout the 3 hours, 5 minutes of play. The match was played with the retractable roof shut, and the shouts of his two-syllable nickname echoed.\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3, has been limited to 16 matches and an 8-8 record since the start of last year. His infrequent play dropped his ranking to No. 275, and he was unseeded for the French Open for the first time; indeed, he'd never been anything worse than the No. 6 seed in 18 previous appearances going back to his days as a teenager.\n\nThat is why Nadal ended up facing the No. 4-seeded Zverev, the runner-up at the 2020 U.S. Open, a gold medalist at the Tokyo Olympics and the only man to reach the semifinals in Paris each of the past three years.\n\nNadal's other losses at Roland Garros came against Robin Soderling in 2010 and against Novak Djokovic in 2015 and 2021.\n\nDjokovic, owner of 24 major championships and the man Nadal played against more than any other, sat in the stands Monday, as did younger stars Iga Swiatek and Carlos Alcaraz. Also there: Nadal's uncle, Toni, who used to be his coach. Not surprisingly, it was difficult to spot so much as a single empty beige chair anywhere in the arena on what many realized could be a historic occasion.\n\nHere and there, when Nadal was able to come up with the goods and get the better of his opponent, he would yell \"Vamos!\" and throw that celebratory uppercut that became so familiar, from the days of muscle shirts and Capri pants to Monday's look of sky-blue sleeves and standard-length white shorts. His numerous and vocal supporters would respond in kind, thrusting their fists in the air right along with him or shaking their red-and-yellow Spanish flags or clapping to the beat of a drum.\n\nIf Nadal put a ball into the net, or sailed one wide or long, the groans of disappointment filled the chilly air. Between points, especially when he was trying to navigate a difficult spot, it was so quiet that a pigeon's coos were audible from a corner of the stadium.\n\nNadal began shakily, with a misplayed drop shot and a double-fault contributing to getting broken at love. He got broken again to end the first set.\n\nThe 6-foot-6 (1.98-meter) Zverev is a talented player, one coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open. The 27-year-old German leverages every bit of his long legs and considerable wingspan to cover the court well and unleash tough-to-corral groundstrokes.\n\nAs he plays in Paris, he is awaiting Friday's start of a trial in a Berlin court related to accusations of domestic abuse made by an ex-girlfriend. Zverev does not need to be present at the court and has said he won't be there.\n\nOn Monday, there were two stretches, albeit brief, where Nadal looked as though he might be able to find enough muscle memory to make this a close contest.\n\nIn the second set, right after he flubbed a backhand and hung his head, he faced a pair of break points that would have put Zverev up 3-1. Nadal escaped, using a 116 mph (187 kph) ace and a 117 mph (188 kph) service winner to hold, before breaking for a 3-2 lead.\n\nRoars.\n\nNot so fast. Nadal served for that set at 5-4, but Zverev broke at love, then was superior in the ensuing tiebreaker.\n\nAt the start of the third set, Nadal again erased a pair of break points, then broke for a 2-0 lead with a trademark on-the-run forehand. He pumped his fists, gritted his teeth and screamed, \"Vamos!\"\n\nMore roars.\n\nOnce more, though, Nadal failed to sustain that level, and soon it was 2-all. Zverev later broke to lead 5-3, and that essentially was that.\n\n\"The amount of feelings I had on this amazing court during my entire tennis career is amazing. But now I'm 28,\" Nadal said, then paused and corrected himself with a chuckle: \"Well, no, 38. I would love to be 28!\"\n\nAddressing the fans directly, Nadal said: \"The feelings that you made me feel here are unbelievable. I really hope to see you again, but I don't know. Merci beaucoup.\"\n\nAnd with that, he gathered his bags and headed to the locker room, but not before stopping to look around and applaud right back at those applauding him and saluting him with one final chant.\n\n\"Ra-fa! Ra-fa!\"\n\nAP tennis: https://apnews.com/hub/tennis", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": It will be the third match on the No.1 court at Stade Roland Garros following two women's singles matches.\n\nNadal heads into the game on the back of a 5-3 win-loss record on clay, including two second-round exits in Madrid and Rome and a run to the fourth round in Madrid. He only returned to action in Barcelona last month in a bid to gear up for the most cherished event of his career.\n\nMeanwhile, Zverev lifted the Italian Open title last week after a third-round exit in Madrid Masters.
