{"uri": "8149441287", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "08:44:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T08:44:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T08:43:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.tennis365.com/tennis-news/rafael-nadal-pundits-french-open-last-match-retirement-alexander-zverev", "title": "Rafael Nadal: Former stars believe Spaniard may not have played his last French Open match", "body": "Former tennis stars Mats Wilander, Alex Corretja and Tim Henman all think there is a chance Rafael Nadal could return to play the French Open again in 2025.\n\nThe trio believe Nadal will be encouraged by his performance in his defeat to Alexander Zverev at Roland Garros, with Henman declaring the Spaniard \"can still do some damage.\"\n\nNadal was beaten 6-3, 7-6(5), 6-3 by Zverev in a highly competitive opening round contest at the 2024 French Open on Monday in what may turn out to be his last match at Roland Garros.\n\nThe 37-year-old tennis icon had his chances against the world No 4, having served for the second set, led 2-0 in the third set and had 11 break points in total.\n\nThe 14-time French Open champion revealed he has most likely played at the Paris Grand Slam for the final time, but he also left the door open to returning next year.\n\nRead More: Rafael Nadal's 4 French Open losses: Alexander Zverev 3rd man to beat Spaniard at Roland Garros\n\nFollowing the match, Corretja, a former world No 2 and two-time Roland Garros finalist, gave his thoughts on his countryman's tennis future.\n\n\"I spoke to him a couple of months ago and he was sure he wouldn't be back,\" he told Eurosport. \"But then I spoke to him a week ago, and he said to me it's the first time I've been practising here at Roland Garros that I feel no pain.\n\n\"He said he felt so good on the court and that his tennis is growing and doesn't see any reason why he can't come back at least one more time.\n\n\"But he also said, it depends how I play. If I play awful against Zverev, maybe I won't come back. But the way he played, I believe he will think, why not come back?\"\n\nWilander, a seven-time Grand Slam champion, feels the upcoming Paris Olympics could be a great farewell tournament for Nadal, but suggested he still has a lot left to offer.\n\n\"Obviously the Olympics are huge and for him to have the chance to play here on Phillipe Chatrier is amazing and could be an unbelievable end to his career,\" said the former world No 1.\n\n\"But I agree with Alex, he's too competitive, he's playing too good. I think he beats 90% of the draw today. There's only a few guys that would beat him playing this well.\n\n\"And Zverev was the worst opponent possible in the first round, worse that playing Djokovic, worse than playing Alcaraz. Also the circumstances, it's indoor, cold outside, the ball doesn't travel.\n\n\"So I think all that, and still being so close, it's all positive for Rafa. And with that passion, why not [come back]? He knows how to win big matches on this court.\"\n\nFormer world No 4 Henman lauded Nadal's mental approach to the sport and expressed his hope that the 22-time Grand Slam champion will continue playing.\n\n\"Uncle Toni said to him when he was a six-year-old you try your best on every shot on every point and you run after every ball until it's bounced twice. He obviously took that on board for his professional career,\" he reflected.\n\n\"There have been times when he's been frustrated with a shot or with the umpire but it's never affected him on the next point.\n\n\"That mental strength, mental fortitude is one the strongest attributes in all of sport and to see him out there playing with that passion and belief is so special for everyone to see. I'd love to see him back out there because Rafa Nadal can still do some damage.\"\n\nRead More: Rafael Nadal reacts to Novak Djokovic and Carlos Alcaraz watching his French Open defeat\n\nSix-time Major winner Boris Becker, however, feels Nadal has played his last match at the French Open.\n\n\"I believe that Rafa will still play the Olympics at Roland Garros,\" Becker said. \"But I don't think he'll play the French Open again in 2025.\n\n\"Of course he has emotions and probably had a sleepless night because he didn't know whether it would be the last time. He wanted to say goodbye well.\n\n\"Then his opponent was Zverev, against whom he can lose even on a good day. That's why it was emotionally very difficult for Nadal.\"", "source": {"uri": "tennis365.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Tennis365.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "ewan_west@tennis365.com", "name": {"uri": "8145861683", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-25", "time": "21:15:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-25T21:15:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-25T21:13:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/sports/nadal-wont-100-close-door-on-magical-fr-1828856.html", "title": "Nadal Wont 100% Close Door On magical French Open - UrduPoint", "body": "Paris, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 26th May, 2024) Rafael Nadal said Saturday that he is likely appearing at the French Open for the final time but cautioned it was \"not 100%\" certain, describing the tournament where he has been champion 14 times as a \"magical place\".\n\n\"It's a big, big chance that this is going to be my last Roland Garros, but if I have to tell you it's 100% my last Roland Garros, sorry, but I will not, because I cannot predict what's going on. I hope you understand,\" said the Spaniard.\n\nNadal, who will celebrate his 38th birthday on June 3, faces world number four Alexander Zverev in the first round in Paris on Monday.\n\nThe Spanish legend has racked up 112 wins in 115 matches at the tournament since his title-winning 2005 debut when he was just 19.\n\nHe has 22 Grand Slam titles -- second only to Novak Djokovic's 24 on the all-time men's list -- but his career has been plagued by injuries.\n\nNadal has played just four tournaments since January last year after suffering a hip injury and then a muscle tear.\n\nAs a result, his ranking has slumped to 276 in the world and he comes into the French Open unseeded.\n\n\"I have been going through a long process of recovery with a very difficult injury, almost two years of suffering, but I feel better now,\" he added.\n\n\"I have fewer limitations than three, four weeks ago, without a doubt.\"\n\nNadal had to sit out the 2023 French Open through injury.\n\nThe year before he won his 14th title but revealed that he could only play with daily pain-killing injections in his feet.\n\n\"So give me some time. Maybe in one month and a half I say, okay, it's enough, I can't keep going, but today in some way I cannot guarantee that that's going to be the last one.\n\n\"I feel competitive in training. Maybe not in an official match, but when I enter the court, I feel like I can beat anyone,\" he said.\n\nNadal holds a 7-3 winning record over Zverev.\n\nFive of those victories came on clay including a semi-final triumph at Roland Garros in 2022 when the German was forced to quit with ankle ligament damage.\n\nIn Paris so far this week, Nadal has practised in front of packed courts.\n\nHe hit with fellow former champion Stan Wawrinka who described Nadal as \"strong as ever\".\n\nFifth-ranked Daniil Medvedev, who trained with him on Thursday, said he was happy not to face him in the first round.\n\n\"This place is magical for me. If in the bottom of my heart, I didn't have any hope to have success here and to create a beautiful thing this year, I would not be here in front of you guys,\" added Nadal.\n\n\"So I still have the motivation and a small, at least is a small hope to play well.\"\n\nAnd if 2024 turns out to be Nadal's French Open farewell?\n\n\"I just can say thanks to all the love I received from all the players, from the organisers, from the tournaments, from all the community of tennis and sport.\n\n\"I feel very proud that probably I leave a positive legacy there.\"\n\nFrench veteran Gael Monfils, who is also 37 and first played Nadal in 2005, said: \"we should enjoy it as much as we can\".\n\n\"I wonder if we're not going back to traditional tournaments as they were played a long time ago, because the last 20 years are not run-of-the-mill normal years,\" added Monfils of two decades dominated by Nadal, Novak Djokovic and the now-retired Roger Federer.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8148723783", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "20:41:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T20:41:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T20:40:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.odt.co.nz/sport/other-sport/nadal-exits-french-open-farewell-defeat", "title": "Nadal exits French Open in farewell-like defeat", "body": "You are not permitted to download, save or email this image. Visit image gallery to purchase the image.\n\nRafael Nadal exited what could be his last French Open to an outpouring of love and support with a first-round defeat by Alexander Zverev, wishing to be back at Roland Garros for the Paris 2024 Olympics.\n\n\"I hope to see you again, but I don't know,\" Nadal told an ecstatic crowd after crashing to a straight sets loss, 6-3 7-6(5) 6-3, against fourth seed Alexander Zverev on Monday (local time).\n\n\"There's a big percentage I will not be back here but I am not 100% sure. I hope to be back on this court for the Olympics, that motivates me.\"\n\nIt will the third time since his debut at Roland Garros in 2005, that Nadal, whose body has been martyred by 23 years of professional tennis and who left the tournament with a crushed foot after his record-improving 14th title two years ago, does not get to celebrate his June 3 birthday in Paris when he'll turn 38.\n\nThe French, who tend to arrive on court Philippe Chatrier fashionably late on the back of a long lunch, skipped coffee and digestif to fill the arena before the king, racket in hand as usual, stepped onto the court to deafening roars.\n\nOn a rainy day in Paris, organisers closed the roof, adding to the intimacy of the moment.\n\nOn a court he knows like no one else, Nadal struggled to find his mark early on, netting a routine drop shot and serving a double fault to give Zverev the opening game.\n\nThe German, who after winning the Rome Masters was the worst possible draw for Nadal, kept his foot on the gas pedal to take the first set even if the Mallorcan showed glimpses of his best with a couple of spinning forehand winners down the line.\n\n\"Rafa! Rafa!\" went the crowd, again, as world number ones Iga Swiatek and Novak Djokovic, as well as fellow Spaniard Carlos Alcaraz, joined the party.\n\nNadal served for the set but Zverev levelled and forced a tiebreak, which he comfortably won.\n\nThere was another break for Nadal in the third set, and some 'I-can-still-do-it' fist pumps after a few jaw-dropping winners, but two years after Zverev left their semi-final match on a wheelchair with a broken foot, the German was too good this time.\n\nNever far from physical issues in his glittering career, Nadal missed almost all of 2023 with a hip problem and his comeback earlier this year was stalled by a muscle tear, before small niggles affected his preparation for the claycourt major.\n\n\"My body has been a jungle for two years. You don't know what to expect. I wake up one day and I find a snake biting me. Another day a tiger,\" Nadal told a packed press conference following his earliest exit from Roland Garros.\n\n\"I've been fighting with all the things that I went through. But the dynamic is positive the last few weeks. I felt ready. I think tomorrow I'll be ready to play again if I have to. But I will not have to.\n\n\"So that's the thing. Now, I need to prepare myself, I need to clear my ideas and see what's the new calendar to try to be ready for Olympics. I can't say anything today, but my main goal now is to play the Olympics.\"\n\nNadal will be eyeing his third gold medal after triumphing in singles in the 2008 Beijing Games and doubles eight years later in Rio. He had expressed doubts about his fitness ahead of Roland Garos.\n\nThe 22-Grand-Slam winner said it would be unwise to prepare for the grasscourt season that follows with a potentially difficult transition back to clay for the Olympics.\n\n\"It looks difficult, honestly. For me now I can't confirm what's going on, but it looks difficult to make a transition to grass, having the Olympics again on clay,\" Nadal said.\n\n\"I need to talk with the team. I need to analyse so many facts. But I don't think it's going to be smart after all the things that happened to my body to make a big transition to a completely different surface and then come back to clay.\n\n\"Today I feel that's not a good idea, but I can't confirm. But my feelings is even if I'm booked in Wimbledon because I had to, I don't think it's a positive idea right now.\"\n\nIn other first round matches, Australian Open champion Jannik Sinner, seeded second, barely broke sweat as he downed American Chris Eubanks in straight sets, just like former runner-up Stefanos Tsitsipas did with Hungarian journeyman Marton Fucsovics.\n\nIn the women's matches, Swiatek, gunning for a fourth title in Paris, kicked off her campaign with a 6-1 6-2 demolition of French qualifier Leolia Jeanjean.\n\nSwiatek has now won her last 15 matches in the French capital following her back-to-back wins in 2022 and 2023.\n\nCoco Gauff also made a strong start, dispatching German Julia Avdeeva 6-1 6-1 for her 50th Grand Slam match victory.\n\nThe 20-year-old American, who won the US Open last year to break her Grand Slam duck, is looking to claim her first French Open title after losing the 2022 final in Paris.", "source": {"uri": "odt.co.nz", "dataType": Check out what's clicking on Foxnews.com.\n\nRafael Nadal has owned the clay court at Roland Garros throughout his career, but in what could be his final appearance in the French Open, he lost in the first round in straight sets.\n\nAlexander Zverev, the No. 4-ranked men's tennis player in the world, took down the Spanish legend that is Nadal, 6-3, 7-6, 6-3, to move on to the second round.\n\nNadal, 37, was unsure if he would be competing in the tournament last month as he's continuously battled injuries while trying to extend his illustrious career, which includes 22 Grand Slam titles. He's won the French Open 14 times, owning an outstanding career record of 112-4 after the loss to Zverev.\n\nCLICK HERE FOR MORE SPORTS COVERAGE ON FOXNEWS.COM\n\nZverev is just the third tennis player ever to beat Nadal at Roland Garros, as Novak Djokovic did it twice - both in the final in 2015 and 2021 - and Robin S\u00f6derling in 2009 in the fourth round.\n\nThe emotions for Nadal were understandably high after the match, as the crowd roared despite his quick exit.\n\nRAFAEL NADAL, 37, DISMISSES NOTION THIS IS HIS LAST FRENCH OPEN: 'DON'T ASSUME THAT'\n\n\"It's difficult for me to talk,\" he said after saluting the crowd in French. \"I don't know if it's going to be the last time that I'm going to be here in front of all of you. Honestly, I'm not 100% sure. But if it's the last time, I enjoyed it.\n\n\"The crowd has been amazing during the whole week of preparation and today. Yeah, the feelings I have today are difficult to describe in words. But, for me, it's so special to feel the love from people in the place I love the most.\"\n\nWhile Zverev dominated the match as a whole, there were vintage \"Rafa\" moments throughout, including an incredible forehand on the run after a Zverev overhand that should've resulted in a point. Instead, Nadal shot it back down the line and the crowd roared with the lefty having a chance to come back as the third set was tied 3-3 at the time.\n\nZverev was a gentleman after the match as well, giving Nadal his flowers as he explained the emotions for him going into the match.\n\n\"To be honest, I don't know what to say,\" the 27-year-old Zverev began. \"First of all, thank you, Rafa, from all of the tennis world. It's such a great honor. I've watched Rafa play all my childhood, and I was lucky enough to play Rafa when I became professional. I was lucky enough to play him two times on this beautiful court.\n\n\"Today is not my moment - it's Rafa's moment.\"\n\nNadal has battled \"body limitations,\" as he called it, due to knee, feet, ankle, abdomen and wrist problems. They caused him to miss 11 major tournaments throughout his career. {"uri": "2024-05-370060014", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "19:10:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T19:10:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T18:29:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://weeklyvoice.com/french-open-zverev-sends-nadal-into-sunset-with-win-in-first-round-blockbuster-ld/", "title": "French Open: Zverev sends Nadal into sunset with win in first-round blockbuster (Ld)", "body": "Paris, May 27 (VOICE) Only time will tell whether people have witnessed him playing for the final time, but fans rose to cheer Rafael Nadal after a spectacular match against Alexander Zverev, who caused a huge upset by beating the 14-time winner in the men's singles first round of the French Open 2024 here on Monday.\n\nFourth-seeded Zverev handed Nadal a 6-3, 7-6(5), 6-3 defeat on Monday afternoon, the 27-year-old German becoming the first man to defeat Nadal before the fourth round at Roland Garros and joining Robin Soderling and Novak Djokovic as the third man to defeat Nadal on the Parisian clay courts.\n\nNadal found moments of his vintage best tennis, especially with his trademark forehand passing shot. But Zverev's booming serve, aggressive forehand, and calm under pressure proved too much to overcome after three hours and five minutes.\n\n\"To be honest I don't know what to say,\" Zverev said on court after his win, before handing the mic to the Spanish legend.\n\n\"First of all, thank you, Rafa, from all of the tennis world. It's such a great honour. I've watched Rafa play all my childhood, and I was lucky enough to play Rafa when I became a pro, I was lucky enough to play him two times on this beautiful court. Today is not my moment, it's Rafa's moment,\" Zverev was quoted as saying by the official Roland Garros website.\n\nThere was so much excitement for the match that Novak Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz, and WTA No. 1 Iga Swiatek all sat in the stands to take in the action. The encounter was very tightly contested for a straight-sets match, but for every moment in which Nadal seemed to seize the momentum -- rallying the raucous crowd fully behind him -- Zverev found an answer to retake control.\n\nNadal, ranked 275 at the moment, had never played Roland-Garros unseeded, and never faced a top-10 player in the first round. He had also never lost consecutive matches on his beloved clay, but Zverev changed all that with a command performance.\n\nNadal, who fell to 112-4 lifetime at Roland-Garros with the loss, gave his faithful fans plenty to cheer about across the contest, but it was three-time semi-finalist Zverev who held the heavier hand in the key moments as he notched his second clay-court victory over the 22-time Grand Slam champion, and improved to 29-8 lifetime at Porte d'Auteuil.\n\nThunderous chants rang through the bowels of Chatrier with regularity during the pair's 11th meeting, Nadal's feverish fans doing their best to raise the closed roof that covered the court for the entirety of the match. Determined Zverev kept Nadal's faithful from getting too unruly in the early going, however, as he broke Nadal in the first game of the match before wrestling the opening set with a second break of serve at the 50-minute mark, 6-3.\n\nThe second and third sets followed a different path to a similar end.\n\nNadal charged to life in the fourth game of set two, saving a pair of break points for 2-2 and breaking for 3-2 as chants of \"Rafa! Rafa!\" could be heard echoing across the grounds.\n\nUrged on by the faithful, the Spaniard clung to the lead for a spell, but couldn't ward off his determined adversary, who broke at love for 5-5 and eventually claimed a tense tiebreak to take a 2-0 lead.\n\nThere were chances galore for Nadal, which is a testament to just how far he has come since making his return to the tour in April in Barcelona. Though defeated, he left us to wonder what might have been had he had a few more weeks to prepare.\n\nBut Monday's match was Zverev's for the taking, and he braved the magnitude of the contest with aplomb, rising to the occasion and matching the legendary Spaniard whenever the situation called for it.\n\nFaced with another deficit in the third set, Zverev wrestled control from Nadal once again, rallying from 2-0 down, winning six of the final seven games to close out his victory in three hours and five minutes.\n\nIt was a brilliant contest, full of drama, quality, and tension. The only shame, of course, is that such a high-profile contest happened so early in the Paris fortnight. After the match, Nadal was sent off properly by the fans, who chanted his name for several minutes before he took the microphone to address them, and his future plans.\n\n\"The amount of feelings that I had on this amazing court during all my tennis career is just unbelievable,\" Nadal said. \"I never dreamed I would be here at almost 38 years old, with all the success I had here, winning so many times - it is something that I never dreamt of.\n\n\"For me, it's difficult to say what will happen in the future. It's a big percentage that I won't be back at Roland-Garros, but I can't say 100 percent. I enjoy playing here, I like traveling with the family, and my body is feeling a little bit better than it did two months ago.\"", "source": {"uri": "weeklyvoice.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8148675696", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "19:46:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T19:46:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T19:45:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/nadal-out-of-possible-last-french-open-swiat-1829480.html", "title": "Nadal Out Of Possible Last French Open, Swiatek Through - UrduPoint", "body": "Paris, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 28th May, 2024) Rafael Nadal's illustrious French Open career came to a likely end with his first ever defeat in the opening round by Alexander Zverev on Monday, after Iga Swiatek made a winning start in her bid for a fourth title.\n\nNadal matched world number four Zverev for long periods on a packed Court Philippe Chatrier, but slipped to a 6-3, 7-6 (7/5), 6-3 loss as he was beaten for just the fourth time in 116 matches at the tournament.\n\nThis year's event was expected to be the 14-time champion's farewell to Roland Garros, but he had since insisted he could not confirm \"100 percent\" it would be his last appearance.\n\n\"If it is (the last time), then you have been amazing,\" Nadal told an adoring crowd under the Chatrier roof.\n\n\"The feelings I have today are difficult to describe in words. It is the place I love the most.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 next week, showed all his trademark fighting qualities in a gripping match, but only managed to convert two of 11 break points against an inspired opponent.\n\n\"It's hard to say about the future,\" he added. \"I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. The body is feeling better than it did two months ago.\"\n\nNadal was unseeded for the draw and vulnerable to a difficult opening round.\n\nGerman Zverev, who lifted the Rome Open title last month, proved too strong despite the fans desperately attempting to raise Nadal to past glories.\n\nThe 27-year-old banished the memories of the duo's last meeting, when he left Chatrier court on a wheelchair after injuring his ankle during their 2022 French Open semi-final.\n\nHis reward for becoming just the third player to defeat Nadal at Roland Garros -- after Novak Djokovic and Robin Soderling -- is a match against either David Goffin or home wildcard Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard.\n\n- Zverev's fast start -\n\nZverev started the match strongly with a break to love in the opening game, going on to wrap up the first set with relative ease.\n\nZverev then came out on top in a tense tie-break as a Nadal return found the net.\n\nThe Spaniard again broke first in the third set to lead 2-0, much to the delight of the 15,000 spectators in attendance, including Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz, Swiatek and Manchester City footballer Rodri.\n\nBut Zverev quickly hit back once more, before breaking for a 4-3 lead with a wonderful passing winner.\n\nHe secured victory on his first match point as Nadal blazed a forehand off target, potentially ending the most dominant career at a single event in Grand Slam history.\n\n\"I'm really happy to be back. Feel like I'm playing really good tennis so hoping to be here as long as possible,\" said Swiatek.\n\nThe 20-year-old goes on to face Slovenian qualifier Tamara Zidansek for a place in the last 32.\n\nMarketa Vondrousova, also a former Roland Garros runner-up and the reigning Wimbledon champion, eased past Rebeka Masarova of Spain in straight sets.\n\nTunisian eighth seed Ons Jabeur booked {"uri": "8148518046", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "17:16:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T17:16:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T17:15:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.skysports.com/tennis/news/12110/13143952/rafael-nadal-fourteen-time-champion-suffers-first-round-defeat-to-alexander-zverev-at-french-open", "title": "Rafael Nadal: Fourteen-time champion suffers first round defeat to Alexander Zverev at French Open", "body": "Rafael Nadal did not want a French Open leaving party, but he got one anyway as he bowed out to Alexander Zverev in the first round at Roland Garros; you can watch Andy Murray in action at the Stuttgart Open, exclusively live on Sky Sports Tennis from June 10-16\n\nRafael Nadal lost in the first round of the French Open to Alexander Zverev 6-3 7-6 (7-5) 6-3 in what could be his last match at Roland Garros.\n\nIt is the first time in his long and illustrious career that Nadal has been beaten in two consecutive matches on clay courts and the first time he has lost a match earlier than the fourth round at the French Open.\n\nThe 14-time champion, known as the 'King of Clay', was roared on by family, friends and rivals at the scene of his greatest triumphs.\n\nHaving returned to the tournament he skipped in 2023 and refused to confirm any farewells ahead of his opener, Nadal showed flashes of top form again on Court Philippe Chatrier but the 37-year-old ultimately went down fighting.\n\nNadal was persuaded afterwards by tournament director Amelie Mauresmo to say a few words to the crowd.\n\n\"I don't know if it's gonna be my last time here in front of you, not 100 per cent - but if it is I enjoyed it,\" he said.\n\n\"The feelings that I have are difficult to describe, it's so special to feel the love of the people in the place I love the most.\n\n\"I have been going through a very tough two years in terms of injuries and I went through a process with the dream of being back at Roland Garros.\n\n\"The first round was not the dream one but I was competitive and had my chances. It's difficult to say what's going on in the future, a big percentage that I won't be back but I can say 100 per cent I am enjoying playing and having fun.\n\n\"Maybe in two months I'll say it's enough, but it's something I don't want yet and I want to be back on this court for the Olympics.\n\n\"I never could imagine when I was a kid that I would be here at almost 38 with all the success I had here. I really hope to see you again - but I don't know.\"\n\nVictory meant Zverev became only the third man to beat Nadal at Roland Garros, after Novak Djokovic and Robin Soderling, with the German banishing memories of his retirement due to an ankle injury when the duo last met in the 2022 semi-finals.\n\nThe 22-time Grand Slam champion, who won the Musketeers' Cup for the first time in 2005 and last raised the trophy in 2022 before a serious hip injury derailed his career, has previously said this year could be his final one on the tour.\n\nThe seats behind the players' boxes were crammed with current stars including Carlos Alcaraz - Nadal's heir apparent\n\n- long-time rival Novak Djokovic and women's No 1 and three-time champion Iga Swiatek.\n\nAlso in attendance were Nadal's wife Xisca, who rarely watches his matches, baby son Rafael Jr and uncles Toni - his former coach - and Miguel Angel, the ex-Spain footballer.\n\nManchester City midfielder Rodri, no stranger to titles himself, was another famous face in the crowd.\n\nA slow start cost Nadal a break in the opening game which he never retrieved, while Zverev was too strong in the tie-break and held his nerve down the final straight.\n\nHis celebrations were low key as Nadal sent a forehand wide on match point, before Chatrier rose, possibly for one last time, to salute their hero.\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3, came into the French Open unseeded for the first time and saw his career record at the clay-court Grand Slam tournament fall to 112-4.\n\nHis three other losses came against Soderling in 2010 and twice against Djokovic in 2015 and 2021.\n\nItalian world No 2 Jannik Sinner looked fully recovered from his injury problems as he saw off American Christopher Eubanks 6-3 6-3 6-4.\n\nSinner, the Australian Open champion, withdrew from the Madrid Open and missed Rome with a hip injury, but was back on form at Roland Garros as Eubanks exited at the first hurdle for the second successive year.\n\n\"The hip is good, I'm glad that my team and myself, we were working very hard to be on court as soon as possible,\" Sinner said. \"For sure, the general shape is not at 100 per cent yet, so we try to build every day.\"\n\nThe Italian broke twice in the opening set to lead 4-1 before Eubanks broke back but Sinner saw out the set with another break, and needed just one break in each of the next two sets to take his place in the second round.\n\n\"Honestly, I'm just happy to be back on court, I was injured, so I'm very happy to be back here,\" Sinner said.\n\n\"It's a very special tournament for me, it was the first time in a quarter-final of a grand slam, so I have some great memories.\"\n\nDjokovic, who returned to the top of the rankings in September, now needs to at least reach the final to have any chance of staying there.\n\nThe 37-year-old Serb, who said he has \"low expectations and high hopes\" of defending his title in Paris, faces French wild card Pierre-Hugues Herbert in his first-round match on Tuesday.\n\nIn the run-up to the third Grand Slam of 2024 - Wimbledon - you can watch all of the biggest tennis stars in action live on Sky Sports as they compete {"uri": "2024-05-370013237", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "18:02:24", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T18:02:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T17:50:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-clay-king-rafael-nadal-exits-french-open-in-opening-round-for-first-time-zverev-prevails-5994629.html", "title": "Sports News | 'Clay King' Rafael Nadal Exits French Open in Opening Round for First Time, Zverev Prevails", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on Sports at LatestLY. The former World No. 1 Nadal suffered his first-ever first-round defeat at Roland Garros.\n\nParis [France], May 27 (ANI): Paris [France], May 27 (ANI): Rafael Nadal, the 14-time French Open champion, gave his all in what might be his final appearance in the French Open but fell prey to the sharp forehand aggressive play of Alexander Zverev as he lost 3-6, 6-7(4), 3-6 in the blockbuster opening round clash on Monday.\n\nNadal, the former World No. 1, suffered a first-round defeat at Roland Garros. This is the first time that he made an exit in the first round.\n\nAlso Read | On Which Channel ICC T20 World Cup 2024 Will Be Telecast Live in India? How to Watch Free Live Streaming Online of Men's Twenty20 WC?.\n\nSpectators at the Court Philippe-Chatrier witnessed vintage Nadal moments as he played some of his best tennis, especially with his trademark forehand passing shot in a three-hour-and-five-minute match.\n\nZverev's powerful serve, forceful forehand, and composure under duress proved to be too much to overcome. Talk among tennis fans of this intriguing matchup - a replay of their Paris semifinal from two years back when they played for almost three hours before Zverev was forced to withdraw due to a terrible ankle injury - began as soon as the draw was announced at Roland Garros.\n\nAlso Read | IPL 2024 Award Winners List: Orange Cap, Purple Cap and Recipients of Other Honours After KKR vs SRH Final.\n\nWTA No. 1 Iga Swiatek, Carlos Alcaraz, and 24-time Grand Slam champion Novak Djokovic all sat in the stands to watch the exciting match.\n\nThe match was won in straight sets but every time Nadal appeared to have the upper hand and get the boisterous audience behind him, Zverev came up with a countermove to regain the upper hand.\n\nRain forced the match to be played indoors on Court Philippe-Chatrier, where Zverev served heavily and hit a sharp forehand to prevent Nadal from establishing the lead in rallies.\n\nZverev started his highly anticipated first-round Roland Garros blockbuster against Rafael Nadal with aggressive play to take a 6-3 lead.\n\nEarly in the second set, Nadal faced two break points and was well behind at the Court Philippe-Chatrier. However, he managed to escape difficulty and invoked his finest tennis memories to secure a service break. The boisterous crowd erupted in applause for the 37-year-old who was all over the court.\n\nHowever, Zverev maintained his composure and responded when Nadal served to tie the game. The German then took a dominating advantage by playing almost the whole tie-break from the lead.\n\nThe 22-time Grand Slam champion Nadal dug deeper to come out of trouble, he conjured memories of his very best tennis to claim a service break.\n\nIn an attempt to get back into the match, Nadal gave the audience big fist pumps and played some scorching forehand passing shots multiple times during the match. However, the King of Clay suffered his first-ever first-round defeat at Roland Garros.\n\n\"To be honest I don't know what to say. First of all, thank you Rafa from all of the tennis world. It's such a great honour. I've watched Rafa play all my childhood and I was lucky enough to play Rafa when I became a professional. I was lucky enough to play him two times on this beautiful court. I don't know what to say. Today is not my moment, it's Rafa's moment, so thank you,\" Zverev said in his on-court interview, as quoted by ATP.\n\nOn the same court, the two faced off in the semi-finals two years ago. Before the second set had ended, and more than three hours into the match, Zverev sustained a terrible ankle injury that sidelined him for the remainder of the 2022 season. It looked like a duel made to be remembered. Afterwards, Nadal won his fourteenth Coupe des Mousquetaires.\n\nNadal struggled with a couple of injuries over the past couple of years and had a tally of 5-3 record this clay-court season heading into the French Open 2024.\n\nBefore this match, the Spaniard hadn't competed on Court Philippe-Chatrier since winning there in 2022. "eng-9598845", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-05-27", "textStart": 162, "textEnd": 168, "freq": 2}], "sentiment": -0.01960784313725494, "wgt": 186, {"uri": "8146850054", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "16:06:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T16:06:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T16:05:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5519552/2024/05/26/rafael-nadal-alexander-zverev-french-open-preview/", "title": "\"You're playing the statue\": Alexander Zverev faces Nadal, and his aura", "body": "PARIS, France -- Officially, the French Open started today (Sunday May 26). Fans streamed through the gates, packing Roland Garros, lining up for crepes and champagne and Aperol spritzes. Grand slam champions played -- Alcaraz, Osaka, Ostapenko -- and came away with victories, even Osaka, who nearly gave away her match twice, squandering a 4-0 lead in the third set before beating Lucia Bronzetti 6-1, 4-6, 7-5. The defending champion, Novak Djokovic arrived.\n\nAnd yet it all felt like a prelude, a kind overture before the real business of the competition takes place, as though there will be two events happening during, just as there were during what was likely Serena Williams' final U.S. Open in 2022. There was the run of an all-time great, however long it might last, and then the business of a championship, two narratives that didn't figure to coalesce, then or now.\n\nWhen Rafael Nadal is in the draw here, it does not truly start until he takes the court. The lines were 40-deep to get into Court Suzanne Lenglen even on Saturday afternoon, before the tournament began in earnest.\n\nThere were similar queues to get a solo picture with the 10-foot steel statue of Nadal which stands just east of Court Philippe-Chatrier.\n\nHis name is on nearly everyone's lips, uber tennis fans and Uber drivers alike. If that latter court is his living room, then the grounds at Roland Garros are his estate.\n\nUnfortunately, tomorrow (Monday) brings the very real threat of Nadal getting kicked off his property by sundown, possibly for the last time, by arguably the most in-form clay-courter, and most controversial player, in tennis right now.\n\nThat would be Alexander Zverev, winner of the Italian Open last Sunday, ranked fourth in the world, facing a trial on charges of domestic abuse later this week (he denies them).\n\nZverev is a big and fast prototype of new-age 2020s tennis. How does someone 6ft 6in (198cm) tall, with the build of an NBA shooting guard, move that effortlessly across a tennis court, especially after tearing three ligaments in his ankle, against Nadal of all people, in their semi-final here two years ago?\n\n\"On paper, is not the best draw,\" Nadal said Saturday, with a gallows humour-style smile. \"What can I do? That's the draw. Just try to be ready for it.\"\n\nNadal, who has won this tournament 14 times, was ready two years ago, playing the best tennis of this twilight period of his career that has now likely entered its sunset. He'd won the year's first Grand Slam in Australia and, after some bumps during the clay-court season, he was rounding into his usual Roland Garros form, despite having to get painkilling injections in his foot before each match.\n\nBut Zverev was giving him fits until that violent ankle-roll. They had played for three hours and still hadn't finished the second set, with Nadal leading 7-6, 6-6 on a sweaty, humid afternoon where the roof was closed because of thunderstorms. He was getting so many balls back on a day when the slow, heavy conditions and Zverev's quickness and seemingly endless arms made it difficult for Nadal to pound the ball through the court like he's done since 2005.\n\nEver since then, Zverev has wanted another shot at playing Nadal at Roland Garros -- though not in the first round, more like a semifinal or a final.\n\nThe idea of playing Nadal on this clay sends chills through the spines of so many players. Not Zverev, because that is the way his brain works and because he knows how his weapons have long caused the Spaniard serious problems. He had won three of their past four meetings before that 2022 semi-final.\n\n\"I didn't want my last memory of me playing against Rafa to be me leaving the court on a wheelchair,\" Zverev said Saturday.\n\nZverev said he had just finished what he described as a terrific practice with Andrey Rublev when his brother, Misha, who is one of his coaches, arrived with news of the draw. He thought Misha was punking him, then quickly realized he wasn't.\n\n\"You never want to play Rafa at Roland Garros. I don't think anyone would like to play Rafa in the first round here,\" world No 9 Stefanos Tsitsipas says. \"He can still find a way to make it work on Philippe-Chatrier.\"\n\nFor nearly two decades, Nadal has made the bulk of his living on a single maneuver -- hunting for any chance he can find to hit that bull-whip forehand across the court into a right-handed player's backhand. The shot -- so heavy, so much topspin -- strikes the ground and takes off to eye level for most players. It nearly drove Roger Federer mad in the late 2000s, so much so that he remodelled his entire backhand.\n\nZverev, though, has a better backhand than forehand, and he is so tall he can still get on top of a ball spitting at him like a snake from Nadal's racket. He can't do it every time, and it's not as though he is able to neutralize Nadal's version of the cruise missile. But he can do it enough to extend rallies longer than a lot of other players can.\n\nFactor in Nadal's injuries - hip surgery, abdominal muscle strains - that have taken some of the punch out of his best shot, and this looks like an ugly afternoon for the soon to be 38-year-old, even if he said he has felt better this week than he has all spring, since this latest comeback began last month in Barcelona.\n\n\"I wanted to have that process months ago and start with the feeling that I have today in Monte Carlo, but you can't manage what you can't manage,\" Nadal said. \"Things went like this, and here we are.\"\n\nYes, here they are, in a place that Nadal has described as \"magical\" for him, where his presence looms so large, where nearly every player who isn't playing or practising when he is will have their eyes fixed on this match, And like most of the 15,000 fans packing the stadium, and the tens of thousands more watching on the big screens across the Roland Garros grounds, they will be pulling for him.\n\n\"I'm going to be rooting for Rafa, sorry,\" said Iga Swiatek, the women's world No 1, a self-described Nadal freak.\n\nAnd this is where maybe the biggest challenges will come for Zverev -- dealing with a hostile crowd, and having to constantly remind himself to play the ball and the version of the man that is standing on the other side of the net, rather than the statue standing outside, so to speak, as impossible as that might seem.\n\n\"You are playing the statue,\" he acknowledges. \"For me, in my mind, I'm going to play peak Rafa Nadal. That's what I expect him to be. I expect him to be at his absolute best. I expect him to play the best tennis he's played in a long time on this court.\n\n\"There's always been discussion. In 2022, I remember he came into Roland Garros not winning Monte Carlo, not winning Madrid, not winning Rome. He came into this tournament, and everybody was like, 'Oh, he's a big question mark, he's this and that'. He came and dominated the entire tournament.\"\n\nYes, and no.\n\nFelix Auger-Aliassime took him to five sets in the round of 16 that year. He and Novak Djokovic had a four-set battle in the quarterfinal that was a few points away from going to a fifth. Nadal is now two years older, significantly more banged up, and as he put it, just starting to feel like he can play without worrying about the consequences each shot will have on his body.\n\nFor his part, Zverev is playing some of the best tennis of his life, and certainly the best since coming back from that ankle injury early last year.\n\nHis serve, always a massive shot but prone to cracking in tight spots, is getting into the territory of Hubert Hurkacz, currently the best server in men's tennis, according to the advanced tennis statistics compiled by TennisViz, which rates shots on speed and placement. His forehand is among the best of the French Open's top 16 seeds by those same metrics. He is moving as though he was never injured.\n\nNadal and his camp know what he is up against, but he's not ready to give up yet.\n\nHe even suggested on Saturday that this French Open might not be his last. He promised earlier in the month he would not have bothered to come to this tournament at all if his body prevented him from dreaming of what might be possible, that his career sunset might somehow end up being one of those giant, bright orange fireballs that gleam as it drops toward the horizon.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": However, the second set saw the former World No. 1 showcase his resilience, pushing Zverev to the limit. Let's see.\"\n\nThe meeting will bring back contrasting memories for both players of the last time they met, in a French Open semi-final in 2022, when Nadal went on to win yet another title in Paris, the last of his 22 Grand Slam victories.\n\nZverev was forced to retire from that match with an ankle injury. He underwent surgery and ended up missing the rest of the season with another injury, but he returned last year to reach his third consecutive French Open semi-final.\n\nWith some of the other top players such as Novak Djokovic, Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz, struggling with injuries of late, this could be Zverev's chance to finally win a Grand Slam.\n\nThe German might not have wanted to meet Nadal so early in the tournament but he was happy to have the chance to take him on again.\n\n\"I really wanted to play him here. I did not want to play him in the first round. I wanted to play him in the semi-finals, finals, a later stage of the tournament,\" Zverev said. \"But at the end of the day, he's not seeded, it is how it is, and I think we're both prepared for a tough battle.\"\n\nWorld number two Sinner makes his return to action after sitting out the Italian Open following a hip injury at the Madrid Open, and takes on American Christopher Eubanks.\n\nIga Swiatek begins her title defence against French qualifier Leolia Jeanjean, and the Polish world number one comes to Paris on the back of title wins in Madrid and Rome.\n\nAmerican third seed Coco {"uri": "2024-05-369628222", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "11:33:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T11:33:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T10:18:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.aol.com/possibly-last-french-open-appearance-101830750.html", "title": "In possibly his last French Open appearance, Rafael Nadal prepares to take on Alexander Zverev in round one", "body": "In possibly his last French Open appearance, Rafael Nadal prepares to take on Alexander Zverev in round one\n\nSam Joseph, CNN\n\nMay 27, 2024 at 12:18 PM\n\nIt might be the last dance for the 'King of Clay.'\n\nIn what could be his final French Open appearance ever, Rafael Nadal is set to take on world No. 4 Alexander Zverev in the first round of the tournament on Monday.\n\nRegarded as the greatest clay court player ever, the 37-year-old Nadal has struggled with injuries across the last three seasons and said last year that he expected 2024 to be his final campaign on the ATP Tour.\n\nHow to watch\n\nNadal and Zverev are currently scheduled in the third match of the day on Court Philippe Chatrier - Roland Garros' showpiece venue - and the contest is slated to begin around 8:30 a.m. ET, per the ATP Tour.\n\nUS viewers will be able to watch the entirety of the match on the Tennis Channel. NBC and streaming service Peacock begin their Monday coverage of the French Open at 11 a.m. ET.\n\nEuropean viewers can catch the action on Eurosport, which like CNN is owned by Warner Bros. Discovery.\n\nA tough path to 15\n\nNadal has won Roland Garros 14 times - the most of any player by a comfortable margin - and possesses an incredible 112-3 record at the tournament.\n\n\"You win it five times, that's a lot,\" tennis great Boris Becker recently told CNN Sport. \"You win it 10 times, it's impossible. Nadal's won it 14 times. I don't know any other record in any other sport that equals that.\"\n\nCurrently blocking his path towards an unthinkable 15th title though is former world No. 2 Zverev, widely tipped as one of the favorites to win the tournament in Paris.\n\nThe German is a proficient clay court player and is fresh off winning his sixth Masters 1000 title in Rome earlier this month. He has struggled against Nadal in the past, however, holding a 3-7 record against the legendary Spaniard. The last meeting between the pair came in the French Open semifinals in 2022, where Zverev suffered an ankle injury that sidelined him for the rest of the year.\n\nThough speculation remains rampant that this could be the last time Nadal appears at Roland Garros as an active player, the 22-time grand slam singles champion told the media that he was not willing to close the door on competing in 2025.\n\n\"It's a big, big chance that it's going to be my last Roland Garros, but if I have to tell you it's 100 percent my last Roland Garros, sorry, but I will not because I cannot predict what's going on - I hope you understand,\" he said ahead of the tournament.\n\nFor more CNN news and newsletters create an account at CNN.com", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sam_joseph@aol.com", "name": "Sam Joseph", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Zverev", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Alexander Zverev"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clay_court", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Clay court"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Rafael Nadal"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_Open", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "French Open"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ATP_Tour", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "ATP Tour"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN", "type": "org", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "CNN"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros._Discovery", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Warner Bros. {"uri": "8148499279", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "17:01:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T17:01:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T17:00:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://cyprus-mail.com/2024/05/27/nadal-knocked-out-by-zverev-on-possible-french-open-farewell/", "title": "Nadal knocked out by Zverev on possible French Open farewell", "body": "Rafa Nadal crashed to his earliest exit at the French Open on Monday after a 6-3 7-6(5) 6-3 first-round defeat by fourth seed Alexander Zverev, with fans wondering if the 14-times champion will return to the Grand Slam he has ruled for two decades.\n\nThe 22-times major champion, who won the Musketeers' Cup for the first time in 2005 and last raised the trophy in 2022 before a serious hip injury derailed his career, had previously said this year could be his final one on the tour.\n\nHaving returned to the tournament that he skipped in 2023 and refusing to confirm any farewells ahead of his opener, Nadal showed flashes of top form again on Court Philippe Chatrier but the 37-year-old ultimately went down fighting.\n\n\"I'm not 100% sure if it's the last time but I enjoyed it, the crowd were amazing during the whole week of preparation and today,\" Nadal said as the crowd rose to their feet.\n\n\"The feelings today are difficult to describe with words but it's special to feel the love in the place I love the most.\n\n\"I enjoy playing a lot and travelling with the family. The body is feeling better than two months ago. Maybe in two months I say it's enough. But it's something I don't feel yet.\"\n\nVictory meant Zverev became only the third man to beat Nadal at Roland Garros, after Novak Djokovic and Robin Soderling, with the German also banishing memories of his retirement due to an ankle injury when the duo last met in the 2022 semi-finals.\n\n\"I don't know what to say... thank you Rafa from all of the tennis world, it's such a great honour,\" Zverev said.\n\n\"I've watched Rafa play all my childhood and I was lucky enough to play him twice on this beautiful court.\"\n\nNadal was broken by in-form Rome champion Zverev in the opening game and surrendered his serve again late on to drop the first set in unfavourable conditions for him with the roof closed due to heavy rain earlier.\n\nFaced with the prospect of only his fourth Roland Garros defeat in 116 matches, Nadal made a positive start to the next set as he leapt and pumped his fists after holding for 2-2 and broke for the first time with a delicate drop.\n\nThe crowd began to sense a comeback as Nadal went ahead 4-2 with some vintage shots on both flanks but the steely Zverev hit back in the 10th game and saved two breakpoints before doubling his advantage by edging a high-octane tiebreak.\n\nWatched on by his great rival Djokovic and a host of other current players, Nadal surged to a 2-0 lead in the third set but squandered it as Zverev drew level and dealt another body blow in the seventh game.\n\nThe boisterous crowd tried their best to roar Nadal on but Zverev held his nerve to clinch a famous victory that could well prove to be the springboard {"uri": "8147729103", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "08:17:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T08:17:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T08:17:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.news18.com/sports/rafael-nadal-bidding-to-avoid-early-french-open-exit-8905503.html", "title": "Rafael Nadal Bidding to Avoid Early French Open Exit - News18", "body": "Rafael Nadal has only played four tournaments since January 2023 after suffering a hip injury and then a muscle tear.\n\nRafael Nadal admits he will be facing \"one of the toughest opponents possible\" when he plays Alexander Zverev in the French Open first round on Monday.\n\nThis year's event was expected to be the 14-time champion's farewell to Roland Garros, but he has since insisted he could not confirm \"100 percent\" it would be his last appearance.\n\nNadal has only played four tournaments since January 2023 after suffering a hip injury and then a muscle tear.\n\nAlso Read: Grayson Murray's Parents Say Tour Winner Died of Suicide\n\nThat left him unseeded for the draw and vulnerable to a difficult opening round at a tournament where he has only lost three of his 115 matches.\n\nWorld number four Zverev arrives in Paris as one of the favourites for the title after winning the Rome Open earlier this month.\n\n\"Of course on paper it is not the best draw,\" Nadal said ahead of the match on Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\n\"I play against one of the toughest opponents possible, and at the same time, he came here winning the last event and it's a Masters 1000.\n\n\"It's not a small one. So what can I do? That's the draw. Just try to be ready for it.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 in a week's time, has shown flashes of his best form in the clay-court swing, but was thrashed 6-1, 6-3 by Poland's Hubert Hurkacz in the second round of his last outing in Rome.\n\nHe boasts a 7-3 winning record over Zverev ahead of their first meeting since the 2022 French Open semi-finals, when the German left the court in a wheelchair near the end of the second set after injuring his ankle.\n\n\"I am not anxious. No, I am focused on trying to play well. That's it,\" said Nadal.\n\n\"Maybe I go there and I repeat the disaster of Rome. It's a possibility, of course. I don't want to hide that.\n\n\"But in my mind, is do something different and play much better and give myself a chance to play competitive.\"\n\n- 'Didn't want' to play Nadal -\n\nZverev did not play again in 2022 after that ankle injury but has climbed the rankings again in recent months.\n\nThe 27-year-old has long been touted as a future Grand Slam champion but remains without one of tennis' four biggest titles.\n\nClay is his strongest surface, though, and he has reached the semi-finals in each of the last three years at Roland Garros.\n\nThe men's draw looks far more open than usual, with doubts surrounding Nadal's fitness and Novak Djokovic having endured a turbulent start to the year.\n\n\"I can guarantee you Novak didn't want to play Rafa in the first round and (Carlos) Alcaraz didn't want to play, Jannik (Sinner) didn't want to play him,\" admitted Zverev.\n\n\"I don't want to play him in the first round, but it is how it is. He has been out injured. He hasn't played a lot of tennis. His ranking is where it is. Of course it's not ideal, but at the same time, you know, there is nothing you can do.\n\n\"Everybody now is excited for a tough battle and tough first round. I think he's excited and I'm excited for it.\"\n\nFrench Open organisers were prepared to stage a tribute ceremony to Nadal to honour his career but the Spaniard was reluctant to endorse such a celebration.\n\n\"We were ready to press the button on it,\" admitted tournament director Amelie Mauresmo.\n\n\"But it's Rafa who manages his timing, we follow what he wants. We wouldn't want to put him in an uncomfortable position.\"\n\nAlso on Monday, women's world number one Iga Swiatek starts her bid for a fourth French Open crown against home player Leolia Jeanjean.\n\nVictory for the top seed will give her a second round clash with fellow four-time Grand Slam title winner Naomi Osaka.\n\nMen's Australian Open champion Jannik Sinner, former Roland Garros runner-up Stefanos Tsitsipas and women's US Open title-holder Coco Gauff all get their campaigns under way on Court Suzanne Lenglen.", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8147791916", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "09:01:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T09:01:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T08:59:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/sports/tennis-news/french-open-rafael-nadal-farewell-ceremony-cancelled-13775535.html", "title": "French Open: Why farewell ceremony for Rafael Nadal was cancelled? And why is he unseeded?", "body": "Rafael Nadal will start his French Open campaign against Alexander Zverev. AP\n\nRafael Nadal will not be getting a farewell ceremony at Roland Garros this year. The tournament organisers had planned a farewell ceremony for the record 14-time winner but they have now shunned the idea because he has said this might not necessarily be his final appearance at the tournament.\n\nTournament director Am\u00e9lie Mauresmo said Sunday, Day 1 of the clay-court Grand Slam event, that Nadal let officials know he didn't want to close the door on a return before he told the world that at a pre-tournament news conference.\n\n\"As you can imagine, we had something planned for him. But &mldr; because he doesn't know if it's going to be his last Roland Garros or not, he wants to leave the door open maybe to come back next year as a player. So we are not going to push him, obviously, to do anything,\" Mauresmo said.\n\n\"It's his decision when he wants to have a proper ceremony, a proper goodbye, a proper farewell. So we're not going to do it this year. That's his wish,\" she continued. \"And even though we were ready to push the button if something happens, we obviously are going to respect what he wants and make sure we are ready whenever he feels he wants to do it. Later this year; next year; anytime he wants.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3 and has said previously he expects this to be his last season, will face No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev in the first round on Monday. The match is scheduled to be third in the main stadium, Court Philippe Chatrier, and could start at around 6 PM IST.\n\nHere are some answers to questions about Nadal and Zverev:\n\nWhy are top players like Nadal and Zverev meeting in the first round?\n\nDespite having such a dominant record at the French Open, Nadal was not seeded and so could have been placed anywhere in the bracket and been stuck playing anyone at all, even the very best opponents. Because of injuries, including a surgically repaired hip and problematic abdominal muscle, Nadal has competed little the past two seasons, going only 7-4 in 2024, and so someone who has been ranked No. 1 and spent more than a decade inside the top 10 is now outside the top 250.\n\nWhy isn't Nadal seeded?\n\nThis is Nadal's first Grand Slam tournament without a seeding since the 2005 Australian Open. The top 32 players in the men's and women's draws are seeded, and the seedings are based on the ATP and WTA rankings, which take into account the most recent 52 weeks of results. In theory, Mauresmo could have opted to circumvent the rules and go ahead and award a seeding to Nadal based on his past performances in Paris. But that was never really considered, she said, in part because \"giving protection to some players\" would result in \"a lot of other issues and problems,\" and because \"it also has to be OK with other Grand Slams and everything.\"\n\nWhat difference do seedings make?\n\nPlayers who are seeded, such as Zverev, are guaranteed to avoid going up against another seeded player any earlier than the third round of a Grand Slam tournament, which have 128-player fields and require seven victories to earn a championship.\n\nWhat do other players think?\n\nPlayers tend to agree with Mauresmo's decision, with several saying they believe the seeding system should remain the way it currently is (Wimbledon used to seed players according to their results on grass courts, but has strictly followed the rankings since 2021). \"The way that the seedings work, I think it's appropriate. In this case, it's unfortunate how that happened, but I don't know how you gauge where someone should and shouldn't be seeded based on past or previous success,\" said three-time major champion Andy Murray. \"It'd be quite hard to do that.\"\n\nWho is Alexander Zverev?\n\nHe is a leading player in men's tennis, one who is coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open, won a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics and was the 2020 U.S. Open runner-up. He reached the semifinals at the French Open each of the past three years, including in 2022, when he played Nadal at that stage but had to stop after tearing ligaments in his right foot during the match. Zverev, a 27-year-old from Germany, is about to face a court proceeding that starts next week in Berlin related to accusations of physically abusing an ex-girlfriend. He does not need to be in court and said he will not be. \"At the end of the day, I do believe in the German system. I do believe in the truth, as well. I have to be certain that, you know, I do know what I did, I do know what I didn't do,\" Zverev said. \"That's, at the end of the day, what's going to come out, and I have to trust in that.\"\n\nWhy is Zverev allowed to play during his ongoing court case?\n\nMauresmo was asked Sunday about Zverev's status and replied: \"As long as the trial isn't finished and there isn't a decision, he's considered innocent and so that's why he's allowed to be part of the draw.\"", "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Firstpost"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": I hope to be back on this court for the Olympics, that motivates me.\"\n\nIt will the third time since his debut at Roland Garros in 2005, that Nadal, whose body has been martyred by 23 years of professional tennis and who left the tournament with a crushed foot after his record-improving 14th title two years ago, does not get to celebrate his June 3 birthday in Paris.\n\nThe French, who tend to arrive on court Philippe Chatrier fashionably late on the back of a long lunch, skipped coffee and digestif to fill the arena before the king, racquet in hand as usual, stepped onto the court to deafening roars.\n\nSpain's Nadal stuck to his routine, avoiding the lines and crossing them with his right foot, sprinting to the baseline during warm-up and positioning his two bottles diagonally aimed at the court.\n\nOn a rainy day in Paris, organisers closed the roof, adding to the intimacy of the moment.\n\nOn a court he knows like no one else, Nadal struggled to find his mark early on, netting a routine drop shot and serving a double fault to give Zverev the opening game.\n\nThe German, who after winning the Rome Masters was the worst possible draw for Nadal, kept his foot on the gas pedal to take the first set even if the Mallorcan showed glimpses of his best with a couple of spinning forehand winners down the line.\n\nAs soon as Zverev eased the pressure, however, Nadal converted his first break point to take a 3-2 lead in the second set.\n\n\"Rafa! Rafa!\" went the crowd, again, as world number ones Iga Swiatek and Novak Djokovic, as well as fellow Spaniard Carlos Alcaraz, joined the party.\n\nNadal served for the set but Zverev levelled and forced a tiebreak, which he comfortably won.\n\nThere was another break for Nadal in the third set, and some 'I-can-still-do-it' fist pumps after a few jaw-dropping winners, but two years after Zverev Tennis legend unsure about future", "body": "Let's get this part out of the way: Rafael Nadal did not announce his retirement after exiting the French Open in the first round.\n\nNothing else, though, is entirely clear about what comes next for the owner of 22 Grand Slam titles. He turns 38 in a week and has been dealing with injuries for quite some time.\n\n\"I don't know,\" Nadal acknowledged, \"what's going to happen in the next few months.\"\n\nHe probably won't be back at the tournament where he's collected a record 14 trophies, but write that in pencil, because he would not completely rule out the possibility in the days leading up to, or the moments immediately following, the 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3 loss to Alexander Zverev at Roland Garros on Monday that gave the Spaniard the first losing streak of his career on clay courts.\n\nHe probably won't enter Wimbledon, because it just doesn't seem like a good idea to switch to grass right now, although he would not completely rule that out, either.\n\nAs for the Paris Olympics, which will hold the tennis competition at Roland Garros starting in two months? He probably will be there, but -- hey, here's a twist -- he wouldn't completely commit to that.\n\nSo in sum, all we really know about what the future holds for Nadal is that we don't really know a thing about what the future holds for him. Which, of course, is OK, because he is allowed to do whatever he wants, whenever he wants, however he wants.\n\n\"Obviously,\" Zverev observed, \"there are uncertainties.\"\n\nObviously.\n\n\"That's why I am not saying I am retiring today,\" said Nadal, whose 1 1/2-year-old child, Rafael Jr., sat on his mother's lap at Court Philippe Chatrier on Monday. \"In terms of what's driving me ... I'm a simple guy. I enjoy what I do. I am passionate about sport, I am passionate about competition. I like to practice, I like to play tennis. I'm in a different moment of my personal life, too, traveling with my son, wife. I am enjoying these moments that will not come back.\"\n\nSo, basically, why force himself to stop? Why not try to see how much more his body can take?\n\nWhy not hope to stay out there, doing what he's done so well for so long, and maybe just give himself and his family -- particularly his kid, still too young to remember what is happening yet -- some memories to hold onto one day?\n\n\"If I keep enjoying doing what I am doing and I feel myself competitive and healthy enough to enjoy, I want to keep going for a while,\" Nadal explained. \"I don't know for how long, but I want to keep going for a while, because they are having fun, I am having fun, and I need to see -- I need to give myself a little bit longer ... to see if my level is growing and my body is holding, and then let's make a decision.\"\n\nMakes perfect sense.\n\nEspecially considering what both opponents took away from this latest performance, which was hardly up to Nadal's career-long standards but did include the occasional patch of play that might have been good enough to get past a lesser obstacle than Zverev.\n\nThe 27-year-old German is, after all, ranked No. 4, was the runner-up at the U.S. Open four years ago and the gold medalist at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago. Plus, he is coming off a clay title at the Italian Open and has been a semifinalist at Roland Garros each of the past three years.\n\n\"I mean, I was not that far,\" Nadal said. \"That's my feeling.\"\n\nZverev's assessment: \"If he stays healthy, he's going to continue playing better.\"\n\nNadal sounded as though he agreed with that. He also asked for some time to make up his mind.\n\n\"Give me two months 'til the Olympics, and then let's see if I am able to keep going or I say, 'OK, guys, it's more than enough.' Let's see,\" Nadal said Monday evening, after only his fourth loss in 116 French Open matches. \"I mean, today is not a moment to analyze all these kind of things.\"", "source": {"uri": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.arnnewscentre.ae/news/sports/nadal-knocked-out-in-french-open-first-round/", "title": "Nadal knocked out in French Open first round", "body": "Fourteen-time champion Rafael Nadal crashed to his earliest exit at the French Open after a 6-3 7-6 6-3 first-round defeat by fourth seed Alexander Zverev.\n\nThe Spaniard, who entered the tournament on the back of a series of injuries, had never lost in the first round at Roland Garros.\n\nHaving returned to the tournament that he skipped in 2023 and refusing to confirm any farewells ahead of his opener, Nadal showed flashes of top form again on Court Philippe Chatrier but the 37-year-old ultimately went down fighting.\n\nVictory meant Zverev became only the third man to beat Nadal at Roland Garros, after Novak Djokovic and Robin Soderling, with the German banishing memories of his retirement due to an ankle injury when the duo last met in the 2022 semi-finals.\n\nNadal was broken by in-form Rome champion Zverev in the opening game and surrendered his serve again late on to drop the first set in unfavourable conditions for him with the roof closed due to heavy rain.\n\nFaced with the prospect of only his fourth Roland Garros defeat in 116 matches, Nadal made a positive start to the next set as he leapt and pumped his fists after holding for 2-2 and broke for the first time with a delicate drop.\n\nThe crowd began to sense a comeback as Nadal went ahead 4-2 with some vintage shots on both flanks but the steely Zverev hit back in the 10th game and saved two breakpoints before doubling his advantage by edging a high-octane tiebreak.\n\nWatched on by his great rival Djokovic and a host of other current players, Nadal surged to a 2-0 lead in the third set but squandered it as Zverev drew level and dealt another body blow in the seventh game.\n\nThe boisterous crowd tried their best to roar Nadal on but Zverev held his nerve to clinch a famous victory that {"uri": "8148989474", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "02:35:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T02:35:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T02:33:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news/235087/nadal-eyes-olympics-but-not-wimbledon-after-likely-french-open-farewell/", "title": "Nadal eyes Olympics but not Wimbledon after likely French Open farewell", "body": "PARIS: Rafael Nadal's record-breaking French Open career came to its likely end on Monday when the 14-time champion slumped to a demoralising defeat against Alexander Zverev before he revealed his journey to the Paris Olympics in July will not take a detour to Wimbledon.\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3, went down 6-3, 7-6 (7/5), 6-3 in the first round to world number four Zverev, suffering only his fourth loss in 116 matches at Roland Garros since his 2005 title-winning debut.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nIt was the first time he had been defeated in Paris in the opening round and will again lead to questions over his long-term future in the sport.\n\n\"I don't know if it's the last time I'll be here in front of all of you,\" he said.\n\nSPONSORED CONTENT Electrifying windows of opportunity in Sabah - The right policies, collaborations, and strategies can turn emerging opportunities into victories for all parties in Sabah. CHIEF Minister Datuk Seri Panglima Hajiji Noor's 2021 Hala Tuju Sabah Maju Jaya Plan and the Sabah Economic Development and Investment Authority (SEDIA) have laid out a road map to an exciting future for all Sabahans, with a target of increasing Sabah's income levels and GDP per capita from about RM 23,000 to about RM 40,000 by 2030. Read more \"If it is, then you have been amazing. The feelings I have today are difficult to describe in words. It is the place I love the most.\"\n\nHe added: \"It's hard to say about the future. I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. The body is feeling better than it did two months ago.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\n\"Maybe in two months I say it's enough. That is something I don't feel yet.\"\n\nNadal may not return for the 2025 French Open but he still plans to play the Olympics at Roland Garros in July.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nNadal, an Olympic singles gold medallist in Beijing in 2008 and doubles champion at the Rio Games, later told reporters: \"That's my main goal now.\n\n\"I need to prepare myself the proper way to try to arrive healthy and well-prepared.\"\n\nHe won't make the rankings cut for the Olympics, but as a Grand Slam winner he would be eligible for a spot reserved for major winners.\n\nPlagued by injuries, which had limited him to just four events since January last year, former world number one Nadal is now 275 in the rankings and was unseeded in Paris.\n\n\"My body has been a jungle for two years. You don't know what to expect. You know, I wake up one day and I found a snake biting me. Another day a tiger,\" said Nadal of his recent battles with a hip injury.\n\nIn his career, he has had to skip 11 Grand Slams. That is certain to become 12 next month when he is likely to skip Wimbledon where he was champion in 2008 and 2010.\n\n\"It looks difficult to make a transition to grass, having the Olympics again on clay,\" he said.\n\n\"I don't think it's going to be smart after all the things that happened to my body now make a big transition to a completely different surface and then come back immediately to clay. I don't think it's a positive idea right now.\"\n\n- 'Thank you Rafa' -\n\nZverev said it had been \"a great honour\" to play Nadal on 11 occasions in their careers.\n\n\"I've watched Rafa play all my childhood and I was lucky enough to play him two times on this beautiful court. Today is not my moment, it is Rafa's moment,\" said the German star.\n\nIn a repeat of the 2022 semi-final, which Nadal won when Zverev quit with ankle ligament damage, the Spaniard had his chances.\n\nHe was a break of serve up in the second and third sets, only to be pinned back on both occasions by his in-form 27-year-old opponent.\n\nHowever, a relentless Zverev broke six times from 18 opportunities and fired 44 winners to Nadal's 34.\n\nChants of \"Rafa, Rafa\" had loudly echoed under the roof of Court Philippe Chatrier which was shut tight against the torrential rain sweeping across the grounds and bringing havoc to the schedule.\n\nThey subsided to silence when Nadal was broken to love in his opening service game and he was left to regret his inability to convert two break points in the fourth game.\n\nNadal saved two set points in the ninth game but surrendered the opener after 50 minutes when he buried a loose forehand into the net.\n\nIt was only the fourth opening set he had lost at Roland Garros.\n\nNadal broke for the first time in the match to lead 3-2 in the second set but couldn't back up the advantage and handed the break back to three-time semi-finalist Zverev as he served for the set.\n\nA tense tie-breaker followed which the German claimed, buoyed by stretching to 5/3 on the back of a gruelling 19-shot rally.\n\nNadal dug deep and with the likes of Novak Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz and Iga Swiatek having watched from the packed stands, he broke and held for 2-0 in the third set.\n\nHowever, Zverev again roared back to level at 2-2 before a besieged Nadal had to save four break points in a 13-minute fifth game to stay in contention.\n\nThe effort was too much and a composed Zverev was soon 4-3 up and the match was over when Nadal fired a forehand wide and long.\n\nStay up-to-date by following Daily Express's Telegram channel.\n\nDaily Express Malaysia\n\n* Follow us on Instagram and join our Telegram and/or WhatsApp {"uri": "8146396024", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "08:56:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T08:56:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T08:55:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.newsofbahrain.com/sports/99525.html", "title": "Nadal won't '100% close door' on 'magical' French Open | THE DAILY TRIBUNE | KINGDOM OF BAHRAIN", "body": "AFP | Riyadh, Saudi Arabia\n\nThe Daily Tribune - www.newsofbahrain.com\n\nRafael Nadal said yesterday that he is likely appearing at the French Open for the final time but cautioned it was \"not 100%\" certain, describing the tournament where he has been champion 14 times as a \"magical place\".\n\n\"It's a big, big chance that this is going to be my last Roland Garros, but if I have to tell you it's 100% my last Roland Garros, sorry, but I will not, because I cannot predict what's going on.\n\nI hope you understand,\" said the Spaniard.\n\nNadal, who will celebrate his 38th birthday on June 3, faces world number four Alexander Zverev in the first round in Paris on Monday.\n\nThe Spanish legend has racked up 112 wins in 115 matches at the tournament since his title-winning 2005 debut when he was just 19.\n\nHe has 22 Grand Slam titles -- second only to Novak Djokovic's 24 on the all-time men's list -- but his career has been plagued by injuries.\n\nNadal has played just four tournaments since January last year after suffering a hip injury and then a muscle tear.\n\nAs a result, his ranking has slumped to 276 in the world and he comes into the French Open unseeded.\n\n\"I have been going through a long process of recovery with a very difficult injury, almost two years of suffering, but I feel better now,\" he added.\n\n\"I have fewer limitations than three, four weeks ago, without a doubt.\" Nadal had to sit out the 2023 French Open through injury.\n\nThe year before he won his 14th title but revealed that he could only play with daily pain-killing injections in his feet. 'Positive legacy' \"In some ways I don't want to close the door 100%.\n\nI am enjoying playing tennis. I am travelling with the family. They are enjoying,\" added Nadal on his reluctance to call time on his career.\n\n\"So give me some time. Maybe in one month and a half I say, okay, it's enough, I can't keep going, but today in some way I cannot guarantee that that's going to be the last one.\n\nBut of course it's a big chance.\"\n\nNadal arrives in Paris having yet to make a clay-court quarter-final this season. In Rome, he was defeated in the second round. \"I feel competitive in training.\n\nMaybe not in an official match, but when I enter the court, I feel like I can beat anyone,\" he said.
