{"uri": "8149142998", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "05:09:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T05:09:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T05:09:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.rappler.com/sports/tennis-match-results-rafael-nadal-alexander-zverev-french-open-may-27-2024/", "title": "Paris darling Rafael Nadal exits French Open in farewell-like early defeat", "body": "Tennis living legend Rafael Nadal hints at entering the last stages of his illustrious career after suffering his earliest defeat ever in the French Open: a first-round loss to Alexander Zverev\n\nRafael Nadal exited what could be his last French Open to an outpouring of love and support with a first-round defeat by Alexander Zverev, 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3, wishing to be back at Roland Garros for the Paris 2024 Olympics.\n\n\"I hope to see you again, but I don't know,\" Nadal told an ecstatic crowd after his straight-sets loss on Monday (Tuesday, May 28, Manila time).\n\n\"There's a big percentage I will not be back here but I am not 100% sure. I hope to be back on this court for the Olympics, that motivates me.\"\n\nIt will the third time since his debut at Roland Garros in 2005, that Nadal, whose body has been martyred by 23 years of professional tennis and who left the tournament with a crushed foot after his record-improving 14th title two years ago, does not get to celebrate his June 3 birthday in Paris.\n\nThe French, who tend to arrive on court Philippe Chatrier fashionably late on the back of a long lunch, skipped coffee and digestif to fill the arena before the king, racket in hand as usual, stepped onto the court to deafening roars.\n\nSpain's Nadal stuck to his routine, avoiding the lines and crossing them with his right foot, sprinting to the baseline during warm-up and positioning his two bottles diagonally aimed at the court.\n\nOn a rainy day in Paris, organizers closed the roof, adding to the intimacy of the moment.\n\nOn a court he knows like no one else, Nadal struggled to find his mark early on, netting a routine drop shot and serving a double fault to give Zverev the opening game.\n\nThe German, who after winning the Rome Masters was the worst possible draw for Nadal, kept his foot on the gas pedal to take the first set even if the Mallorcan showed glimpses of his best with a couple of spinning forehand winners down the line.\n\nAs soon as Zverev eased the pressure, however, Nadal converted his first break point to take a 3-2 lead in the second set.\n\n\"Rafa! Rafa!\" went the crowd, again, as world number ones Iga Swiatek and Novak Djokovic, as well as fellow Spaniard Carlos Alcaraz, joined the party.\n\nNadal served for the set but Zverev leveled and forced a tiebreak, which he comfortably won.\n\nThere was another break for Nadal in the third set, and some 'I-can-still-do-it' fist pumps after a few jaw-dropping winners, but two years after Zverev left their semi-final match on a wheelchair with a broken foot, the German was too good this time.\n\nThere was a sense of anticipation on the morning of the Nadal vs Zverev clash as Swiatek, gunning for a fourth title here, kicked off her campaign with a 6-1, 6-2 demolition of French qualifier Leolia Jeanjean.\n\nSwiatek has now won her last 15 matches in Paris following her back-to-back wins in 2022 and 2023.\n\nCoco Gauff also made a strong start, dispatching German Julia Avdeeva 6-1 6-1 for her 50th Grand Slam match victory.\n\nThe 20-year-old American, who won the U.S. Open last year to break her Grand Slam duck, is looking to claim her first French Open title after losing the 2022 final in Paris.\n\nSixth seed Maria Sakkari crashed out of the first round as Russian-born Varvara Gracheva, who now represents France, came back from a set down to secure a 3-6 6-4 6-3 victory.\n\nIn the men's draw, Russian fifth seed Daniil Medvedev, who suffered a shock first-round exit at last year's French Open, ensured a longer stay at Roland Garros this time around with a 6-3 6-4 5-7 6-3 win over Germany's Dominik Koepfer.\n\nMedvedev had leaned on his serve and a slew of shots to comfortably grab the first two sets before a determined Koepfer suddenly stepped up his game.\n\nKoepfer came back from a early break down in the third set where Medvedev's bid to force a tiebreaker was thwarted when the German broke serve to grab the set.\n\nKoepfer then double-faulted to gift the Russian a break to open the fourth set but got back on serve at 3-3 only for Medvedev to close out the day's final match on Court Simonne-Mathieu by winning the next three games.\n\nIn other men's action, Australian Open champion Jannik Sinner, seeded second, downed American Chris Eubanks in straight sets, just like former runner-up Stefanos Tsitsipas did with Hungarian journeyman Marton Fucsovics. - Rappler.com", "source": {"uri": "rappler.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Rappler"}, {"uri": "8149572504", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "10:04:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T10:04:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T10:03:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://wtop.com/sports/2024/05/analysis-all-we-know-about-rafael-nadals-future-is-that-we-really-know-nothing-at-all/", "title": "Analysis: All we know about Rafael Nadal's future is that we really know nothing at all - WTOP News", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Let's get this part out of the way: Rafael Nadal did not announce his retirement after exiting the French Open in the first round.\n\nNothing else, though, is entirely clear about what comes next for the owner of 22 Grand Slam titles. He turns 38 in a week and has been dealing with injuries for quite some time.\n\n\"I don't know,\" Nadal acknowledged, \"what's going to happen in the next few months.\"\n\nHe probably won't be back at the tournament where he's collected a record 14 trophies, but write that in pencil, because he would not completely rule out the possibility in the days leading up to, or the moments immediately following, the 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3 loss to Alexander Zverev at Roland Garros on Monday that gave the Spaniard the first losing streak of his career on clay courts.\n\nHe probably won't enter Wimbledon, because it just doesn't seem like a good idea to switch to grass right now, although he would not completely rule that out, either.\n\nAs for the Paris Olympics, which will hold the tennis competition at Roland Garros starting in two months? He probably will be there, but -- hey, here's a twist -- he wouldn't completely commit to that.\n\nSo in sum, all we really know about what the future holds for Nadal is that we don't really know a thing about what the future holds for him. Which, of course, is OK, because he is allowed to do whatever he wants, whenever he wants, however he wants.\n\n\"Obviously,\" Zverev observed, \"there are uncertainties.\"\n\nObviously.\n\n\"That's why I am not saying I am retiring today,\" said Nadal, whose 1 1/2-year-old child, Rafael Jr., sat on his mother's lap at Court Philippe Chatrier on Monday. \"In terms of what's driving me ... I'm a simple guy. I enjoy what I do. I am passionate about sport, I am passionate about competition. I like to practice, I like to play tennis. I'm in a different moment of my personal life, too, traveling with my son, wife. I am enjoying these moments that will not come back.\"\n\nSo, basically, why force himself to stop? Why not try to see how much more his body can take?\n\nWhy not hope to stay out there, doing what he's done so well for so long, and maybe just give himself and his family -- particularly his kid, still too young to remember what is happening yet -- some memories to hold onto one day?\n\n\"If I keep enjoying doing what I am doing and I feel myself competitive and healthy enough to enjoy, I want to keep going for a while,\" Nadal explained. \"I don't know for how long, but I want to keep going for a while, because they are having fun, I am having fun, and I need to see -- I need to give myself a little bit longer ... to see if my level is growing and my body is holding, and then let's make a decision.\"\n\nMakes perfect sense.\n\nEspecially considering what both opponents took away from this latest performance, which was hardly up to Nadal's career-long standards but did include the occasional patch of play that might have been good enough to get past a lesser obstacle than Zverev.\n\nThe 27-year-old German is, after all, ranked No. 4, was the runner-up at the U.S. Open four years ago and the gold medalist at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago. Plus, he is coming off a clay title at the Italian Open and has been a semifinalist at Roland Garros each of the past three years.\n\n\"I mean, I was not that far,\" Nadal said. \"That's my feeling.\"\n\nZverev's assessment: \"If he stays healthy, he's going to continue playing better.\"\n\nNadal sounded as though he agreed with that. He also asked for some time to make up his mind.\n\n\"Give me two months 'til the Olympics, and then let's see if I am able to keep going or I say, 'OK, guys, it's more than enough.' Let's see,\" Nadal said Monday evening, after only his fourth loss in 116 French Open matches. \"I mean, today is not a moment to analyze all these kind of things.\"\n\nHoward Fendrich has been the AP's tennis writer since 2002. Find his stories at https://apnews.com/author/howard-fendrich and write to him at hfendrich@ap.org\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. I have less limitations than three, four weeks ago, without a doubt,\" Nadal Saturday at Roland Garros. \"I am having a good week of practices. I probably will say this is the first week since I came back playing tennis that I am able to run the proper way without having a lot of limitations. That encourages me.\n\n\"In the practices, without a doubt I improved. Especially in terms of movements. So I don't feel the limitations that I felt in Rome in terms of running to both sides, so that's a lot for me.\"\n\nAfter missing 2023 due to his hip, Nadal returns to Chatrier Monday to face Rome Masters winner Alexander Zverev.\n\n\"Of course on the paper is not the best draw,\" Nadal said with a smile. \"I play against one of the toughest opponents possible, and at the same time, he came here winning the last event and it's a Masters 1000. It's not a small one. So just, yeah, what can I do? That's the draw. Just try to be ready for it.\"\n\nNadal added that this might not be his final French Open.\n\n\"As I said, it's a big, big chance that going to be my last Roland Garros, but if I have to tell you it's 100% my last Roland Garros, sorry, but I will not, because I cannot predict what's going on. I hope you understand.\n\n\"So in some way I don't want to close 100% the door, because a very simple thing. First thing, I am enjoying playing tennis. Second thing, I am traveling with the family. They are enjoying. I am enjoying sharing all this process with them.\"\n\nRegardless, Nadal will have to first deal with Zverev before anything.\n\n\"I feel very proud that probably I leave a positive legacy there,\" Nadal added. \"Not only about tennis. Probably about like human person, no? So that's more important than any result at the end of the day, because the results are there, you know. {"uri": "8147806481", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "09:09:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T09:09:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T09:08:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.sapeople.com/sport/when-is-rafael-nadal-playing-sasha-zverev-in-a-potential-french-open-farewell/", "title": "When is Rafael Nadal playing Sasha Zverev in a potential French Open farewell?", "body": "Roland Garros legend Rafael Nadal could be playing his final French Open match on Monday 27 May.\n\nRoland Garros legend Rafael Nadal could be playing his final French Open match on Monday 27 May. Here are all the details.\n\nThe French Tennis Federation had intended to hold a ceremony to celebrate the career of Rafael Nadal at Roland Garros this year. Still, those plans have been put on hold after the legendary Spaniard said this might not necessarily be his final appearance at the French Open. Nadal has won it 14 times. Tournament director Am\u00e9lie Mauresmo said Sunday, Day 1 of the clay-court Grand Slam event, that Nadal let officials know he didn't want to close the door on a return\n\n\"As you can imagine, we had something planned for him. But ... because he doesn't know if it's going to be his last Roland Garros or not, he wants to leave the door open maybe to come back next year as a player. So we are not going to push him, obviously, to do anything,\" Mauresmo said.\n\n\"It's his decision when he wants to have a proper ceremony, a proper goodbye, a proper farewell. So we're not going to do it this year. That's his wish,\" she continued. \"And even though we were ready to push the button if something happens, we obviously are going to respect what he wants and make sure we are ready whenever he feels he wants to do it. Later this year; next year; anytime he wants.\"\n\nUnseeded Nadal, who turns 38 on June 3, previously said he expects this to be his last season on the pro circuit after battling injuries for the better part of the previous 18 months. He faces No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev in the first round on Monday 27 May. {"uri": "8148430588", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "16:07:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T16:07:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T16:06:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/05/28/sports/nadal-bidding-to-avoid-early-french-open-exit/1948708", "title": "Nadal bidding to avoid early French Open exit", "body": "Paris - Rafael Nadal admits he will be facing \"one of the toughest opponents possible\" when he plays Alexander Zverev in the French Open first round on Monday (Tuesday in Manila).\n\nThis year's event was expected to be the 14-time champion's farewell to Roland Garros, but he has since insisted he could not confirm \"100 percent\" it would be his last appearance.\n\nNadal has only played four tournaments since January 2023 after suffering a hip injury and then a muscle tear.\n\nSpain's Rafael Nadal takes part in a practice session during the French Open tennis tournament on Court Philippe-Chatrier at the Roland Garros Complex in Paris on May 25, 2024. AFP PHOTO\n\nThat left him unseeded for the draw and vulnerable to a difficult opening round at a tournament where he has only lost three of his 115 matches.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nWorld number four Zverev arrives in Paris as one of the favorites for the title after winning the Rome Open earlier this month.\n\n\"Of course on paper it is not the best draw,\" Nadal said ahead of the match on Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"I play against one of the toughest opponents possible, and at the same time, he came here winning the last event and it's a Masters 1000.\n\n\"It's not a small one. So what can I do? That's the draw. Just try to be ready for it.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 in a week's time, has shown flashes of his best form in the clay-court swing, but was thrashed 6-1, 6-3 by Poland's Hubert Hurkacz in the second round of his last outing in Rome.\n\nHe boasts a 7-3 winning record over Zverev ahead of their first meeting since the 2022 French Open semi-finals, when the German left the court in a wheelchair near the end of the second set after injuring his ankle.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"I am not anxious. No, I am focused on trying to play well. That's it,\" said Nadal.\n\n\"Maybe I go there and I repeat the disaster of Rome. It's a possibility, of course. I don't want to hide that.\n\n\"But in my mind, is do something different and play much better and give myself a chance to play competitive.\"\n\nZverev did not play again in 2022 after that ankle injury but has climbed the rankings again in recent months.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe 27-year-old has long been touted as a future Grand Slam champion but remains without one of tennis' four biggest titles.\n\nClay is his strongest surface, though, and he has reached the semi-finals in each of the last three years at Roland Garros.\n\nThe men's draw looks far more open than usual, with doubts surrounding Nadal's fitness and Novak Djokovic having endured a turbulent start to the year.\n\n\"I can guarantee you Novak didn't want to play Rafa in the first round and (Carlos) Alcaraz didn't want to play, Jannik (Sinner) didn't want to play him,\" admitted Zverev.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"I don't want to play him in the first round, but it is how it is. He has been out injured. He hasn't played a lot of tennis. His ranking is where it is. Of course it's not ideal, but at the same time, you know, there is nothing you can do.\n\n\"Everybody now is excited for a tough battle and tough first round. I think he's excited and I'm excited for it.\"\n\nFrench Open organisers were prepared to stage a tribute ceremony to Nadal to honour his career but the Spaniard was reluctant to endorse such a celebration.\n\n\"We were ready to press the button on it,\" admitted tournament director Amelie Mauresmo.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"But it's Rafa who manages his timing, we follow what he wants. We wouldn't want to put him in an uncomfortable position.\"\n\nAlso on Monday, women's world number one Iga Swiatek starts her bid for a fourth French Open crown against home player Leolia Jeanjean.\n\nVictory for the top seed will give her a second round clash with fellow four-time Grand Slam title winner Naomi Osaka.\n\nMen's Australian Open champion Jannik Sinner, former Roland Garros runner-up Stefanos Tsitsipas and women's US Open title-holder Coco Gauff all get their campaigns under way on Court Suzanne Lenglen.\n\nAdvertisement", "source": {"uri": "manilatimes.net", {"uri": "8148530927", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "17:27:22", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T17:27:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T17:26:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://thepeninsulaqatar.com/article/27/05/2024/nadal-out-of-possible-last-french-open-swiatek-through", "title": "Nadal out of possible last French Open, Swiatek through", "body": "Paris: Rafael Nadal's illustrious French Open career came to a likely end with his first ever defeat in the opening round by Alexander Zverev on Monday, after Iga Swiatek made a winning start in her bid for a fourth title.\n\nNadal matched world number four Zverev for long periods on a packed Court Philippe Chatrier, but slipped to a 6-3, 7-6 (7/5), 6-3 loss as he was beaten for just the fourth time in 116 matches at the tournament.\n\nThis year's event was expected to be the 14-time champion's farewell to Roland Garros, but he had since insisted he could not confirm \"100 percent\" it would be his last appearance.\n\n\"If it is (the last time), then you have been amazing,\" Nadal told an adoring crowd under the Chatrier roof.\n\n\"The feelings I have today are difficult to describe in words. It is the place I love the most.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 next week, showed all his trademark fighting qualities in a gripping match, but only managed to convert two of 11 break points against an inspired opponent.\n\n\"The first round wasn't ideal,\" he admitted, before saying he \"hoped\" to be back at Roland Garros later this summer for the Paris Olympics.\n\n\"It's hard to say about the future. I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. The body is feeling better than it did two months ago.\"\n\nIt was only Nadal's fifth tournament since January 2023 after suffering a hip injury and then a muscle tear, arriving in Paris a lowly 275th in the world rankings.\n\nThat left him unseeded for the draw and vulnerable to a difficult opening round.\n\nGerman Zverev, who lifted the Rome Open title last month, proved too strong despite the fans desperately attempting to raise Nadal to past glories.\n\nThe 27-year-old banished the memories of the duo's last meeting, when he left Chatrier court on a wheelchair after injuring his ankle during their 2022 French Open semi-final.\n\nHis reward for becoming just the third player to defeat Nadal at Roland Garros -- after Novak Djokovic and Robin Soderling -- is a match against either David Goffin or home wildcard Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard.\n\nZverev's fast start\n\nZverev started the match strongly with a break to love in the opening game, going on to wrap up the first set with relative ease.\n\nNadal was much improved from his most recent outing, when he was well beaten by Hubert Hurkacz in the Rome second round, but failed to serve out the second set when leading 5-4.\n\nZverev then came out on top in a tense tie-break as a Nadal return found the net.\n\nThe Spaniard again broke first in the third set to lead 2-0, much to the delight of the 15,000 spectators in attendance, including Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz, Swiatek and Manchester City footballer Rodri.\n\nBut Zverev quickly hit back once more, before breaking for a 4-3 lead with a wonderful passing winner.\n\nHe secured victory on his first match point as Nadal blazed a forehand off target, potentially ending the most dominant career at a single event in Grand Slam history.\n\nSwiatek makes strong start\n\nPoland's Iga Swiatek celebrates after winning her women's singles match against France's Leolia Jeanjean on Court Philippe-Chatrier on day two of the French Open tennis tournament at the Roland Garros Complex in Paris on May 27, 2024. (Photo by Alain Jocard / AFP)\n\nWomen's world number one Swiatek raced to a 6-1, 6-2 victory against French qualifier Leolia Jeanjean after just 61 minutes on Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nThe Pole will next face fellow four-time major champion Naomi Osaka on Wednesday.\n\n\"I'm really happy to be back. Feel like I'm playing really good tennis so hoping to be here as long as possible,\" said Swiatek.\n\nThe 22-year-old Pole is aiming to become the first woman to win three straight Roland Garros titles since Justine Henin in 2007, and only the second ever after Serena Williams to win the Madrid, Rome and French Opens in the same year.\n\nAustralian Open champion Jannik Sinner started his title tilt with a confident 6-3, 6-3, 6-4 win over Wimbledon quarter-finalist Christopher Eubanks.\n\nThe Italian second seed, who withdrew from the Madrid Open and missed the Rome Open with a hip injury, set up a second-round meeting with French veteran Richard Gasquet.\n\n\"The hip is good, I'm very happy,\" said Sinner.\n\nFormer finalist Stefanos Tsitsipas beat Marton Fucsovics of Hungary 7-6 (9/7), 6-4, 6-1.\n\nWomen's third seed Coco Gauff, the current US Open title-holder and who lost the 2022 French Open final to Swiatek, raced through in just 52 minutes by crushing Russian Julia Avdeeva 6-1, 6-1.\n\nThe 20-year-old goes on to face Slovenian qualifier Tamara Zidansek for a place in the last 32.\n\nMarketa Vondrousova, also a former Roland Garros runner-up and the reigning Wimbledon champion, eased past Rebeka Masarova of Spain in straight sets.\n\nTunisian eighth seed Ons Jabeur booked her place in round two with a comfortable win over US wildcard Sachia Vickery.", Compatriot Alex Corretja reveals chat", "body": "Rafael Nadal aims to return for the Paris Olympics, keeping fans hopeful\n\nFormer World No.2 Alex Corretja reckons that legendary Spanish tennis player Rafael Nadal may reconsider his French Open future after his opening round exit on Monday. Corretja revealed insights from his recent conversations with Nadal, indicating a significant shift in the 22-time Grand Slam champion's outlook. The 37-year-old Spaniard, who missed nearly all of 2023 due to injuries, was defeated in straight sets by fourth-seed German Alexander Zverev.\n\nZverev became only the third player to beat Nadal on the Parisian clay. In what could have been his final match at the tournament he dominated for almost two decades, Nadal exhibited flashes of his former brilliance. He has openly expressed his ambition to return to Roland Garros for this year's Paris Olympics. Additionally, Nadal has given his fans a glimmer of hope that he might extend his career a bit longer.\n\n\"I spoke to him a couple of months ago and he was sure he wouldn't be back (at the French Open),\" Corretja told Eurosport. \"But then I spoke to him a week ago, and he said to me it's the first time I've been practising here at Roland Garros that I feel no pain. He said he felt so good on the court and that his tennis is growing and doesn't see any reason why he can't come back at least one more time.\n\nNadal, who holds an astonishing 14 French Open titles, appears to be buoyed by his improved physical condition and promising practice sessions. Yet, he remains cautiously optimistic about his prospects. \"But he also said, it depends how I play. If I play awful against Zverev, maybe I won't come back. But the way he played, I believe he will think why not come back.\"\n\nWilander said the prospect of him playing at the Olympics was exciting. Nadal's level of tennis during his French Open defeat by Alexander Zverev on Monday was high enough to secure victory against the majority of players in the draw, according to former Roland Garros champion Mats Wilander.\n\n\"Obviously the Olympics are huge and for him to have the chance to play here on Philippe Chatrier is amazing and could be an unbelievable end to his career,\" Wilander told Eurosport. \"I think he beats 90% of the draw today. There's only a few guys that would beat him playing this well. And Zverev was the worst opponent possible in the first round, worse than playing (Novak) Djokovic, worse than playing (Carlos) Alcaraz.\"", "source": {"uri": "indiatoday.in", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8148598931", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "18:28:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T18:28:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T18:27:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/nadal-out-of-possible-last-french-open-swiatek-through/article_1d5c1244-35c8-5da0-bb06-7ac8471700e0.html", "title": "Nadal out of possible last French Open, Swiatek through", "body": "Alexander Zverev displayed why he is among the title favourites\n\nRafael Nadal's illustrious French Open career came to a likely end with his first ever defeat in the opening round by Alexander Zverev on Monday, after Iga Swiatek made a winning start in her bid for a fourth title.\n\nNadal matched world number four Zverev for long periods on a packed Court Philippe Chatrier, but slipped to a 6-3, 7-6 (7/5), 6-3 loss as he was beaten for just the fourth time in 116 matches at the tournament.\n\nThis year's event was expected to be the 14-time champion's farewell to Roland Garros, but he had since insisted he could not confirm \"100 percent\" it would be his last appearance.\n\n\"If it is (the last time), then you have been amazing,\" Nadal told an adoring crowd under the Chatrier roof.\n\n\"The feelings I have today are difficult to describe in words. It is the place I love the most.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 next week, showed all his trademark fighting qualities in a gripping match, but only managed to convert two of 11 break points against an inspired opponent.\n\n\"The first round wasn't ideal,\" he admitted, before saying he \"hoped\" to be back at Roland Garros later this summer for the Paris Olympics.\n\n\"It's hard to say about the future. I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. The body is feeling better than it did two months ago.\"\n\nIt was only Nadal's fifth tournament since January 2023 after suffering a hip injury and then a muscle tear, arriving in Paris a lowly 275th in the world rankings.\n\nThat left him unseeded for the draw and vulnerable to a difficult opening round.\n\nGerman Zverev, who lifted the Rome Open title last month, proved too strong despite the fans desperately attempting to raise Nadal to past glories.\n\nThe 27-year-old banished the memories of the duo's last meeting, when he left Chatrier court on a wheelchair after injuring his ankle during their 2022 French Open semi-final.\n\nHis reward for becoming just the third player to defeat Nadal at Roland Garros -- after Novak Djokovic and Robin Soderling -- is a match against either David Goffin or home wildcard Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard.\n\n- Zverev's fast start -\n\nZverev started the match strongly with a break to love in the opening game, going on to wrap up the first set with relative ease.\n\nNadal was much improved from his most recent outing, when he was well beaten by Hubert Hurkacz in the Rome second round, but failed to serve out the second set when leading 5-4.\n\nZverev then came out on top in a tense tie-break as a Nadal return found the net.\n\nMore from this section Federal Election Commission: Sen. Menendez paid $2M to Paul Hastings law firm, defense attorneys 'Poor weather conditions' cancels remainder of Bethpage Air Show at Jones Beach Diversity courses are 'obviously discriminatory' against white people and a 'big issue' in the UK - Jeremy Carl\n\nThe Spaniard again broke first in the third set to lead 2-0, much to the delight of the 15,000 spectators in attendance, including Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz, Swiatek and Manchester City footballer Rodri.\n\nBut Zverev quickly hit back once more, before breaking for a 4-3 lead with a wonderful passing winner.\n\nHe secured victory on his first match point as Nadal blazed a forehand off target, potentially ending the most dominant career at a single event in Grand Slam history.\n\n- Swiatek makes strong start -\n\nWomen's world number one Swiatek raced to a 6-1, 6-2 victory against French qualifier Leolia Jeanjean after just 61 minutes on Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nThe Pole will next face fellow four-time major champion Naomi Osaka on Wednesday.\n\n\"I'm really happy to be back. Feel like I'm playing really good tennis so hoping to be here as long as possible,\" said Swiatek.\n\nThe 22-year-old Pole is aiming to become the first woman to win three straight Roland Garros titles since Justine Henin in 2007, and only the second ever after Serena Williams to win the Madrid, Rome and French Opens in the same year.\n\nAustralian Open champion Jannik Sinner started his title tilt with a confident 6-3, 6-3, 6-4 win over Wimbledon quarter-finalist Christopher Eubanks.\n\nThe Italian second seed, who withdrew from the Madrid Open and missed the Rome Open with a hip injury, set up a second-round meeting with French veteran Richard Gasquet.\n\n\"The hip is good, I'm very happy,\" said Sinner.\n\nFormer finalist Stefanos Tsitsipas beat Marton Fucsovics of Hungary 7-6 (9/7), 6-4, 6-1.\n\nWomen's third seed Coco Gauff, the current US Open title-holder and who lost the 2022 French Open final to Swiatek, raced through in just 52 minutes by crushing Russian Julia Avdeeva 6-1, 6-1.\n\nThe 20-year-old goes on to face Slovenian qualifier Tamara Zidansek for a place in the last 32.\n\nMarketa Vondrousova, also a former Roland Garros runner-up and the reigning Wimbledon champion, eased past Rebeka Masarova of Spain in straight sets.\n\nTunisian eighth seed Ons Jabeur booked her place in round two with a comfortable win over US wildcard Sachia {"uri": "8146715233", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "13:51:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T13:51:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T13:51:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/Sports/489315/Why-did-the-French-Open-cancel-a-farewell-ceremony-for-Rafael-Nadal-And-why-is-he-unseeded-", "title": "Why did the French Open cancel a farewell ceremony for Rafael Nadal? And why is he unseeded? - Sports", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- The French tennis federation put off holding a ceremony to celebrate Rafael Nadal at Roland Garros this year, because he has said this might not necessarily be his final appearance at the tournament he has won a record 14 times.\n\nTournament director Am\u00e9lie Mauresmo said Sunday, Day 1 of the clay-court Grand Slam event, that Nadal let officials know he didn't want to close the door on a return before he told the world that at a pre-tournament news conference.\n\n\"As you can imagine, we had something planned for him. But ... because he doesn't know if it's going to be his last Roland Garros or not, he wants to leave the door open maybe to come back next year as a player. So we are not going to push him, obviously, to do anything,\" Mauresmo said.\n\n\"It's his decision when he wants to have a proper ceremony, a proper goodbye, a proper farewell. So we're not going to do it this year. That's his wish,\" she continued. \"And even though we were ready to push the button if something happens, we obviously are going to respect what he wants and make sure we are ready whenever he feels he wants to do it. Later this year; next year; anytime he wants.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3 and has said previously he expects this to be his last season, will face No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev in the first round on Monday.\n\nHere are some answers to questions about Nadal and Zverev:\n\nWhy are top players like Nadal and Zverev meeting in the first round?\n\nDespite having such a dominant record at the French Open, Nadal was not seeded and so could have been placed anywhere in the bracket and been stuck playing anyone at all, even the very best opponents. Because of injuries, including a surgically repaired hip and problematic abdominal muscle, Nadal has competed little the past two seasons, going only 7-4 in 2024, and so someone who has been ranked No. 1 and spent more than a decade inside the top 10 is now outside the top 250.\n\nWhy isn't Nadal seeded?\n\nThis is Nadal's first Grand Slam tournament without a seeding since the 2005 Australian Open. The top 32 players in the men's and women's draws are seeded, and the seedings are based on the ATP and WTA rankings, which take into account the most recent 52 weeks of results. In theory, Mauresmo could have opted to circumvent the rules and go ahead and award a seeding to Nadal based on his past performances in Paris. But that was never really considered, she said, in part because \"giving protection to some players\" would result in \"a lot of other issues and problems,\" and because \"it also has to be OK with other Grand Slams and everything.\"\n\nWhat difference do seedings make?\n\nPlayers who are seeded, such as Zverev, are guaranteed to avoid going up against another seeded player any earlier than the third round of a Grand Slam tournament, which have 128-player fields and require seven victories to earn a championship.\n\nWhat do other players think?\n\nPlayers tend to agree with Mauresmo's decision, with several saying they believe the seeding system should remain the way it currently is (Wimbledon used to seed players according to their results on grass courts, but has strictly followed the rankings since 2021). \"The way that the seedings work, I think it's appropriate. In this case, it's unfortunate how that happened, but I don't know how you gauge where someone should and shouldn't be seeded based on past or previous success,\" said three-time major champion Andy Murray. \"It'd be quite hard to do that.\"\n\nWho is Alexander Zverev?\n\nHe is a leading player in men's tennis, one who is coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open, won a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics and was the 2020 U.S. Open runner-up. He reached the semifinals at the French Open each of the past three years, including in 2022, when he played Nadal at that stage but had to stop after tearing ligaments in his right foot during the match. Zverev, a 27-year-old from Germany, is about to face a court proceeding that starts next week in Berlin related to accusations of physically abusing an ex-girlfriend. He does not need to be in court and said he will not be. \"At the end of the day, I do believe in the German system. I do believe in the truth, as well. I have to be certain that, you know, I do know what I did, I do know what I didn't do,\" Zverev said. \"That's, at the end of the day, what's going to come out, and I have to trust in that.\"\n\nWhy is Zverev allowed to play during his ongoing court case?\n\nMauresmo was asked Sunday about Zverev's status and replied: \"As long as the trial isn't finished and there isn't a decision, he's considered innocent and so that's why he's allowed to be part of the draw.\"\n\n___\n\nHoward Fendrich has been the AP's tennis writer since 2002. {"uri": "8149620457", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "10:32:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T10:32:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T10:31:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/Sports/489535/Analysis-All-we-know-about-Rafael-Nadal-s-future-is-that-we-really-know-nothing-at-all", "title": "Analysis: All we know about Rafael Nadal's future is that we really know nothing at all - Sports", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Let's get this part out of the way: Rafael Nadal did not announce his retirement after exiting the French Open in the first round.\n\nNothing else, though, is entirely clear about what comes next for the owner of 22 Grand Slam titles. He turns 38 in a week and has been dealing with injuries for quite some time.\n\n\"I don't know,\" Nadal acknowledged, \"what's going to happen in the next few months.\"\n\nHe probably won't be back at the tournament where he's collected a record 14 trophies, but write that in pencil, because he would not completely rule out the possibility in the days leading up to, or the moments immediately following, the 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3 loss to Alexander Zverev at Roland Garros on Monday that gave the Spaniard the first losing streak of his career on clay courts.\n\nHe probably won't enter Wimbledon, because it just doesn't seem like a good idea to switch to grass right now, although he would not completely rule that out, either.\n\nAs for the Paris Olympics, which will hold the tennis competition at Roland Garros starting in two months? He probably will be there, but -- hey, here's a twist -- he wouldn't completely commit to that.\n\nSo in sum, all we really know about what the future holds for Nadal is that we don't really know a thing about what the future holds for him. Which, of course, is OK, because he is allowed to do whatever he wants, whenever he wants, however he wants.\n\n\"Obviously,\" Zverev observed, \"there are uncertainties.\"\n\nObviously.\n\n\"That's why I am not saying I am retiring today,\" said Nadal, whose 1 1/2-year-old child, Rafael Jr., sat on his mother's lap at Court Philippe Chatrier on Monday. \"In terms of what's driving me ... I'm a simple guy. I enjoy what I do. I am passionate about sport, I am passionate about competition. I like to practice, I like to play tennis. I'm in a different moment of my personal life, too, traveling with my son, wife. I am enjoying these moments that will not come back.\"\n\nSo, basically, why force himself to stop? Why not try to see how much more his body can take?\n\nWhy not hope to stay out there, doing what he's done so well for so long, and maybe just give himself and his family -- particularly his kid, still too young to remember what is happening yet -- some memories to hold onto one day?\n\n\"If I keep enjoying doing what I am doing and I feel myself competitive and healthy enough to enjoy, I want to keep going for a while,\" Nadal explained. \"I don't know for how long, but I want to keep going for a while, because they are having fun, I am having fun, and I need to see -- I need to give myself a little bit longer ... to see if my level is growing and my body is holding, and then let's make a decision.\"\n\nMakes perfect sense.\n\nEspecially considering what both opponents took away from this latest performance, which was hardly up to Nadal's career-long standards but did include the occasional patch of play that might have been good enough to get past a lesser obstacle than Zverev.\n\nThe 27-year-old German is, after all, ranked No. 4, was the runner-up at the U.S. Open four years ago and the gold medalist at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago. Plus, he is coming off a clay title at the Italian Open and has been a semifinalist at Roland Garros each of the past three years.\n\n\"I mean, I was not that far,\" Nadal said. \"That's my feeling.\"\n\nZverev's assessment: \"If he stays healthy, he's going to continue playing better.\"\n\nNadal sounded as though he agreed with that. He also asked for some time to make up his mind.\n\n\"Give me two months 'til the Olympics, and then let's see if I am able to keep going or I say, 'OK, guys, it's more than enough.' Let's see,\" Nadal said Monday evening, after only his fourth loss in 116 French Open matches. \"I mean, today is not a moment to analyze all these kind of things.\"\n\n___\n\nHoward Fendrich has been the AP's tennis writer since 2002. {"uri": "8147325893", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "02:13:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T02:13:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T02:12:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/tennis/nadal-vs-zverev-last-match-french-open-2022-semifinal-revisit-details-ankle-injury-roland-garros-paris-score/article68219576.ece", "title": "What happened when Nadal last faced Zverev at French Open", "body": "Fourteen-time French Open champion Rafael Nadal is set to take on fourth-seeded German Alexander Zverev in the first round at Roland Garros, Paris on Monday.\n\nIt is the first time Nadal and Zverev will face each other since the semifinal of the same Major from two years ago.\n\nNadal had entered that contest after a 6-2, 4-6, 6-2, 7-6(4) win over arch-rival Novak Djokovic while Zverev had beaten rising star Carlos Alcaraz 6-4, 6-4, 4-6, 7-6(7) in the quarterfinals.\n\nIn an exciting semifinal contest that lasted more than three hours before the abrupt ending, Zverev missed four set points during the first set tiebreak against Nadal. Still, Zverev continued to make life tough for the Spaniard until the German rolled his right ankle in the final point of the 12th game of the second set.\n\nZverev twisted his ankle as he tried to retrieve a shot and had to be taken off the Court Philippe-Chatrier in a wheelchair.\n\nAfter several minutes off court, he returned to the arena on crutches to concede the match while trailing 7-6(8), 6-6.\n\nNadal went on to beat Casper Ruud in the final to clinch a record-extending 14th title in Paris.\n\nThis time too, Zverev is in top form after clinching the Italian Open title. {"uri": "8147132637", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "21:26:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T21:26:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T21:25:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.nwitimes.com/sports/professional/other/nadal-french-open-clay-tennis-atp-major/article_cdb203b2-f703-51d2-b6af-6ed2735d285e.html", "title": "French Open cancels farewell ceremony for Nadal", "body": "PARIS -- The French tennis federation put off holding a ceremony to celebrate Rafael Nadal at Roland Garros this year, because he has said this might not necessarily be his final appearance at the tournament he has won a record 14 times.\n\nTournament director Am\u00e9lie Mauresmo said Sunday, Day 1 of the clay-court Grand Slam event, that Nadal let officials know he didn't want to close the door on a return before he told the world that at a pre-tournament news conference.\n\n\"As you can imagine, we had something planned for him. But ... because he doesn't know if it's going to be his last Roland Garros or not, he wants to leave the door open maybe to come back next year as a player. So we are not going to push him, obviously, to do anything,\" Mauresmo said.\n\n\"It's his decision when he wants to have a proper ceremony, a proper goodbye, a proper farewell. So we're not going to do it this year. That's his wish,\" she continued. \"And even though we were ready to push the button if something happens, we obviously are going to respect what he wants and make sure we are ready whenever he feels he wants to do it. Later this year; next year; anytime he wants.\"\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3 and has said previously he expects this to be his last season, will face No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev in the first round on Monday. The match is scheduled to be third in the main stadium, Court Philippe Chatrier, and could start at around 3:30 p.m. local time (9:30 a.m. EDT).\n\nHere are some answers to questions about Nadal and Zverev:\n\nWhy are top players like Nadal and Zverev meeting in the first round?\n\nDespite having such a dominant record at the French Open, Nadal was not seeded and so could have been placed anywhere in the bracket and been stuck playing anyone at all, even the very best opponents. Because of injuries, including a surgically repaired hip and problematic abdominal muscle, Nadal has competed little the past two seasons, going only 7-4 in 2024, and so someone who has been ranked No. 1 and spent more than a decade inside the top 10 is now outside the top 250.\n\nWhy isn't Nadal seeded?\n\nThis is Nadal's first Grand Slam tournament without a seeding since the 2005 Australian Open. The top 32 players in the men's and women's draws are seeded, and the seedings are based on the ATP and WTA rankings, which take into account the most recent 52 weeks of results. In theory, Mauresmo could have opted to circumvent the rules and go ahead and award a seeding to Nadal based on his past performances in Paris. But that was never really considered, she said, in part because \"giving protection to some players\" would result in \"a lot of other issues and problems,\" and because \"it also has to be OK with other Grand Slams and everything.\"\n\nWhat difference do seedings make?\n\nPlayers who are seeded, such as Zverev, are guaranteed to avoid going up against another seeded player any earlier than the third round of a Grand Slam tournament, which have 128-player fields and require seven victories to earn a championship.\n\nWhat do other players think?\n\nPlayers tend to agree with Mauresmo's decision, with several saying they believe the seeding system should remain the way it currently is (Wimbledon used to seed players according to their results on grass courts, but has strictly followed the rankings since 2021). \"The way that the seedings work, I think it's appropriate. In this case, it's unfortunate how that happened, but I don't know how you gauge where someone should and shouldn't be seeded based on past or previous success,\" said three-time major champion Andy Murray. \"It'd be quite hard to do that.\"\n\nWho is Alexander Zverev?\n\nHe is a leading player in men's tennis, one who is coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open, won a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics and was the 2020 U.S. Open runner-up. He reached the semifinals at the French Open each of the past three years, including in 2022, when he played Nadal at that stage but had to stop after tearing ligaments in his right foot during the match. Zverev, a 27-year-old from Germany, is about to face a court proceeding that starts next week in Berlin related to accusations of physically abusing an ex-girlfriend. He does not need to be in court and said he will not be. \"At the end of the day, I do believe in the German system. I do believe in the truth, as well. I have to be certain that, you know, I do know what I did, I do know what I didn't do,\" Zverev said. \"That's, at the end of the day, what's going to come out, and I have to trust in that.\"\n\nWhy is Zverev allowed to play during his ongoing court case?\n\nMauresmo was asked Sunday about Zverev's status and replied: \"As long as the trial isn't finished and there isn't a decision, he's considered innocent and so that's why he's allowed to be part of the draw.\"\n\nAP Sports Week in Pictures: Caitlin Clark's debut, Fury on the ropes and golf's winning shot Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 {"uri": "8149240451", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "06:30:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T06:30:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T06:28:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/tennis/french-open/i-hope-to-see-you-again-but-i-dont-know-says-rafael-nadal-after-french-open-exit/articleshow/110487379.cms", "title": "I hope to see you again, but I don't know, says Rafael Nadal after French Open exit | Tennis News - Times of India", "body": "PARIS: Rafael Nadal returned the love to Court Philippe-Chatrier, where the packed house chanted 'Rafa, Rafa, Rafa' for three-hours of his Roland Garros first-round match, as if to remind their 14-time champion of who he was.\n\nA stirring love song that echoed across the grounds well after that final forehand landed long.\n\n\"The feelings you make me feel here are just unforgettable,\" Nadal told the stands, where everyone, including fellow pros Novak Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz and Iga Swiatek, stood.\"Thank you so much from the bottom of my heart; I hope to see you again, but I don't know.\"\n\nNadal, tennis' 22-time major winner, went down 3-6, 6-7 (5), 3-6 to the fourth-seeded Alexander Zverev on a wet, cold day in Paris. To be sure Nadal had his chances, 11 opportunities to break the German's serve in the match.\n\nNadal will return to Roland Garros in a couple of months to play the Olympics, but he was unsure of his plans thereafter. The door is ajar.\n\n\"I still have some goals,\" Nadal said. \"I hope to be back on this court at the Olympics.\"\n\nNadal, playing in a pastel blue-green tee, said he was getting better, felt better with every passing day, leading into Roland Garros.\n\n\"At the end, I was ready to build my game and my confidence day by day, but I never had those days of competition, because I faced a very tough opponent. Probably today I needed him not playing a great match,\" Nadal said. \"I played at a good level in all ways, comparing to the way that I was playing the weeks before.\"\n\n\"Of course, disappointed for losing, but in terms of (how my) body is feeling, happy that I finished healthy, I had a tough battle out there. And I was ready for a little bit more,\" the 37-year-old said.\n\n\"If it's the last time that I played here, I'm at peace with myself,\" Nadal said, smiling. \"I tried everything to be ready for this tournament. The last two years, I have been working and going through probably the toughest process in my tennis career with the dream to come back here. At least I did. {"uri": "8150170743", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "16:18:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T16:18:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T16:17:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/05/29/sports/nadal-out-of-possible-last-french-open/1948768", "title": "Nadal out of possible last French Open", "body": "(UPDATE) PARIS -- Rafael Nadal's illustrious French Open career came to a likely end with his first ever defeat in the opening round by Alexander Zverev on Monday, after Iga Swiatek made a winning start in her bid for a fourth title.\n\nNadal matched world number four Zverev for long periods on a packed Court Philippe Chatrier, but slipped to a 6-3, 7-6 (7/5), 6-3 loss as he was beaten for just the fourth time in 116 matches at the tournament.\n\nThis year's event was expected to be the 14-time champion's farewell to Roland Garros, but he had since insisted he could not confirm \"100 percent\" it would be his last appearance.\n\n\"If it is (the last time), then you have been amazing,\" Nadal told an adoring crowd under the Chatrier roof.\n\n\"The feelings I have today are difficult to describe in words. It is the place I love the most.\"\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nNadal, who turns 38 next week, showed all his trademark fighting qualities in a gripping match, but only managed to convert two of 11 break points against an inspired opponent.\n\n\"The first round wasn't ideal,\" he admitted, before saying he \"hoped\" to be back at Roland Garros later this summer for the Paris Olympics but would almost certainly skip Wimbledon.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"It will be difficult playing on grass considering that right after Wimbledon are the Olympic Games.\"\n\nIt was only Nadal's fifth tournament since January 2023 after suffering a hip injury and then a muscle tear, arriving in Paris a lowly 275th in the world rankings.\n\n\"It's hard to say about the future,\" he added. \"I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. The body is feeling better than it did two months ago.\"\n\nNadal was unseeded for the draw and vulnerable to a difficult opening round.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nGerman Zverev, who lifted the Rome Open title last month, proved too strong despite the fans desperately attempting to raise Nadal to past glories.\n\nThe 27-year-old banished the memories of the duo's last meeting, when he left Chatrier court on a wheelchair after injuring his ankle during their 2022 French Open semifinal.\n\nHis reward for becoming just the third player to defeat Nadal at Roland Garros -- after Novak Djokovic and Robin Soderling -- is a match against either David Goffin or home wildcard Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard.\n\nZverev's fast start\n\nAdvertisement\n\nZverev started the match strongly with a break to love in the opening game, going on to wrap up the first set with relative ease.\n\nNadal was much improved from his most recent outing, when he was well beaten by Hubert Hurkacz in the Rome second round, but failed to serve out the second set when leading 5-4.\n\nZverev then came out on top in a tense tie-break as a Nadal return found the net.\n\nThe Spaniard again broke first in the third set to lead 2-0, much to the delight of the 15,000 spectators in attendance, including Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz, Swiatek and Manchester City footballer Rodri.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBut Zverev quickly hit back once more, before breaking for a 4-3 lead with a wonderful passing winner.\n\nHe secured victory on his first match point as Nadal blazed a forehand off target, potentially ending the most dominant career at a single event in Grand Slam history.\n\nSwiatek makes strong start\n\nWomen's world number one Swiatek raced to a 6-1, 6-2 victory against French qualifier Leolia Jeanjean after just 61 minutes on Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe Pole will next face fellow four-time major champion Naomi Osaka on Wednesday.\n\n\"I'm really happy to be back. Feel like I'm playing really good tennis so hoping to be here as long as possible,\" said Swiatek.\n\nThe 22-year-old Pole is aiming to become the first woman to win three straight Roland Garros titles since Justine Henin in 2007, and only the second ever after Serena Williams to win the Madrid, Rome and French Opens in the same year.\n\nAustralian Open champion Jannik Sinner started his title tilt with a confident 6-3, 6-3, 6-4 win over Wimbledon quarterfinalist Christopher Eubanks.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe Italian second seed, who withdrew from the Madrid Open and missed the Rome Open with a hip injury, set up a second-round meeting with French veteran Richard Gasquet.\n\nDaniil Medvedev had lost in the first round on five of his previous seven Roland Garros appearances, but made no mistake this time, seeing off Dominik Koepfer in four sets.\n\nFormer finalist Stefanos Tsitsipas beat Marton Fucsovics of Hungary 7-6 (9/7), 6-4, 6-1.\n\nWomen's third seed Coco Gauff, the current US Open title-holder and who lost the 2022 French Open final to Swiatek, raced through in just 52 minutes by crushing Russian Julia Avdeeva 6-1, 6-1.\n\nBut sixth-seeded Greek Maria Sakkari bowed out in the first round for the second straight year with a three-set loss to Varvara Gracheva.\n\nMarketa Vondrousova, also a former Roland Garros runner-up and the reigning Wimbledon champion, eased past Rebeka Masarova of Spain in straight sets.\n\nTunisian eighth seed Ons Jabeur booked her place in round two with a comfortable win over US wildcard Sachia Vickery.", "source": {"uri": From Australia, China and the United States, Rafael Nadal fans descended on a chilly and damp Roland Garros on Monday, hoping to inspire their \"superhero\" to victory at the French Open.\n\nIn the end, however, many were reduced to tears as the 14-time champion slumped to a straight-sets defeat to Alexander Zverev in the first round, likely signalling the end of the 38-year-old's Grand Slam adventure in Paris.\n\n\"Personally, I'm very sad, he's Rafa, a legend,\" Mateo Castro, a 41-year-old French fan, told AFP with tears in his eyes. \"It's hard to see him go.\"\n\nMichael Lundell, another Nadal fan who had travelled from Genoa to Paris to watch the match, was also in tears.\n\n\"I was crying, because I don't think there has ever been another role model like him before in sports,\" said the 43-year-old.\n\nALSO READ: Nadal defeated in likely French Open farewell\n\n\"It was a great match, I saw Rafael Nadal with an exceptional level again,\" said Gregory Dubus, a 50-year-old French fan.\n\n\"I've been following Nadal since 2005, his first victory here at Roland Garros, and to see him here, maybe in his last match was exciting.\"\n\nLike many fans at Roland Garros on Monday, there was a feeling that they were witnessing the end of an era.\n\n\"A player like Rafa, you never want him to retire, he's a humble player, with an exceptional attitude on the court and in life, nobody wants him to stop,\" added Dubus.\n\nBefore the start of the match, fans had hailed a player dubbed a \"superhero\".\n\nALSO READ: Nadal keeps his clay dream alive as he battles past Cachin\n\n\"You always have to keep the faith in Rafa, he will win,\" Hazel, a 28-year-old fan who had flown in from China for a second straight year after being left disappointed when message \"Welcome back my super hero\".\n\nBefore Wednesday, Nadal had only lost three times in 115 matches at the tournament since his title-winning debut as a 19-year-old in 2005.\n\nHe said at the weekend that there was a chance this may be his last French Open but insisted he was still keeping the door \"100 percent open\" on continuing his career.\n\n\"You see a lot of 'Thank you Rafa' {"uri": "8147573151", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "06:27:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T06:27:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T06:26:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://leadership.ng/nadal-bidding-to-avoid-early-french-open-exit/", "title": "Nadal Bidding To Avoid Early French Open Exit", "body": "Rafael Nadal admits he will be facing \"one of the toughest opponents possible\" when he plays Alexander Zverev in the French Open first round on Monday.\n\nThis year's event was expected to be the 14-time champion's farewell to Roland Garros, but he has since insisted he could not confirm \"100 per cent\" it would be his last appearance.\n\nNadal has only played four tournaments since January 2023 after suffering a hip injury and then a muscle tear.\n\nThat left him unseeded for the draw and vulnerable to a difficult opening round at a tournament where he has only lost three of his 115 matches.\n\nWorld No 4 Zverev arrives in Paris as one of the favourites for the title after winning the Rome Open earlier this month.\n\n\"Of course on paper it is not the best draw,\" Nadal said ahead of the match on Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\n\"I play against one of the toughest opponents possible, and at the same time, he came here winning the last event and it's a Masters 1000.\n\n\"It's not a small one. So what can I do? That's the draw. Just try to be ready for it.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 in a week's time, has shown flashes of his best form in the clay-court swing, but was thrashed 6-1, 6-3 by Poland's Hubert Hurkacz in the second round of his last outing in Rome.\n\nHe boasts a 7-3 winning record over Zverev ahead of their first meeting since the 2022 French Open semifinals, when the German left the court in a wheelchair near the end of the second set after injuring his ankle.\n\n\"I am not anxious. No, I am focused on trying to play well. That's it,\" said Nadal.\n\n\"Maybe I go there and I repeat the disaster of Rome. It's a possibility, of course. I don't want to hide that.\n\n\"But in my mind, is to do something different and play much better and give myself a chance to play competitive.\"\n\nZverev did not play again in 2022 after that ankle injury but has climbed the rankings again in recent months.\n\nThe 27-year-old has long been touted as a future Grand Slam champion but remains without one of tennis' four biggest titles.\n\nClay is his strongest surface, though, and he has reached the semifinals in each of the last three years at Roland Garros.\n\nThe men's draw looks far more open than usual, with doubts surrounding Nadal's fitness and Novak Djokovic having endured a turbulent start to the year.\n\n\"I can guarantee you Novak didn't want to play Rafa in the first round and (Carlos) Alcaraz didn't want to play, Jannik (Sinner) didn't want to play him,\" admitted Zverev.", "source": {"uri": "leadership.ng", "dataType": "news", "title": "Leadership"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-370697341", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "10:27:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T10:27:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T10:00:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/sports/national_sports/analysis-all-we-know-about-rafael-nadals-future-is-that-we-really-know-nothing-at/article_b95fd76e-fd7d-55f2-a4bb-0a62abdc258f.html", "title": "Analysis: All we know about Rafael Nadal's future is that we really know nothing at all", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Let's get this part out of the way: Rafael Nadal did not announce his retirement after exiting the French Open in the first round.\n\nNothing else, though, is entirely clear about what comes next for the owner of 22 Grand Slam titles. He turns 38 in a week and has been dealing with injuries for quite some time.\n\n\"I don't know,\" Nadal acknowledged, \"what's going to happen in the next few months.\"\n\nHe probably won't be back at the tournament where he's collected a record 14 trophies, but write that in pencil, because he would not completely rule out the possibility in the days leading up to, or the moments immediately following, the 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3 loss to Alexander Zverev at Roland Garros on Monday that gave the Spaniard the first losing streak of his career on clay courts.\n\nHe probably won't enter Wimbledon, because it just doesn't seem like a good idea to switch to grass right now, although he would not completely rule that out, either.\n\nAs for the Paris Olympics, which will hold the tennis competition at Roland Garros starting in two months? He probably will be there, but -- hey, here's a twist -- he wouldn't completely commit to that.\n\nSo in sum, all we really know about what the future holds for Nadal is that we don't really know a thing about what the future holds for him. Which, of course, is OK, because he is allowed to do whatever he wants, whenever he wants, however he wants.\n\n\"Obviously,\" Zverev observed, \"there are uncertainties.\"\n\nObviously.\n\n\"That's why I am not saying I am retiring today,\" said Nadal, whose 1 1/2-year-old child, Rafael Jr., sat on his mother's lap at Court Philippe Chatrier on Monday. \"In terms of what's driving me ... I'm a simple guy. I enjoy what I do. I am passionate about sport, I am passionate about competition. I like to practice, I like to play tennis. I'm in a different moment of my personal life, too, traveling with my son, wife. I am enjoying these moments that will not come back.\"\n\nSo, basically, why force himself to stop? Why not try to see how much more his body can take?\n\nWhy not hope to stay out there, doing what he's done so well for so long, and maybe just give himself and his family -- particularly his kid, still too young to remember what is happening yet -- some memories to hold onto one day?\n\n\"If I keep enjoying doing what I am doing and I feel myself competitive and healthy enough to enjoy, I want to keep going for a while,\" Nadal explained. \"I don't know for how long, but I want to keep going for a while, because they are having fun, I am having fun, and I need to see -- I need to give myself a little bit longer ... to see if my level is growing and my body is holding, and then let's make a decision.\"\n\nMakes perfect sense.\n\nEspecially considering what both opponents took away from this latest performance, which was hardly up to Nadal's career-long standards but did include the occasional patch of play that might have been good enough to get past a lesser obstacle than Zverev.\n\nThe 27-year-old German is, after all, ranked No. 4, was the runner-up at the U.S. Open four years ago and the gold medalist at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago. Plus, he is coming off a clay title at the Italian Open and has been a semifinalist at Roland Garros each of the past three years.\n\n\"I mean, I was not that far,\" Nadal said. \"That's my feeling.\"\n\nZverev's assessment: \"If he stays healthy, he's going to continue playing better.\"\n\nNadal sounded as though he agreed with that. He also asked for some time to make up his mind.\n\n\"Give me two months 'til the Olympics, and then let's see if I am able to keep going or I say, 'OK, guys, it's more than enough.' Let's see,\" Nadal said Monday evening, after only his fourth loss in 116 French Open matches. \"I mean, today is not a moment to analyze all these kind of things.\"\n\nHoward Fendrich has been the AP's tennis writer since 2002. Probably yes, but I don't want to say 100%.\n\n\"I don't want to close the door. This place is magical for me. I may say yes in a couple of months, but I feel better than a month and a half ago.\n\n\"I am enjoying and feel competitive in training. I can play against anyone and I don't feel worse than others. That gives me hope. I progressed since Rome, especially in terms of movement. I can run without limitations now.\n\n\"I'm not anxious, I'm focused on trying to play. Maybe I will repeat the disaster of Rome but in my mind I'm going to give myself a chance to be competitive here. The answer will be on Monday.\"\n\nThe 14-time French Open champion will face No 4 seed Alexander Zverev in a highly-anticipated opening round showdown.\n\nRead More: Boris Becker's warning for Alexander Zverev ahead of French Open showdown with Rafael Nadal\n\nThe great Spaniard, who will turn 38 during the event, has played just four tournament since January 2023 -- when he sustained a serious hip injury at the Australian Open that required surgery.\n\nFederer, who won 16 of 40 matches in his amazing rivalry with Nadal, gave his thoughts on his fellow icon's hopes at the French Open.\n\n\"Can he have a great Roland Garros? I think so. The day of rest between the rounds is exactly what he needs. Then there are the five sets and that is another question that he himself cannot answer,\" the Swiss said on French television.\n\n\"But he had such an advantage in his best period that I still think he is capable of having a great Roland Garros. I don't want to put pressure on him, although he can handle that too.\n\n\"The issue is not his level of play, from afar I have the impression that his biggest problem is recovery.\"\n\nThe 20-time Grand Slam champion, who called time on his own career in 2022, also spoke about the possibility of Nadal retiring after Roland Garros.\n\n\"I know how I felt at the end, but maybe it's a little different because I wasn't playing. What I see is someone who really tries to be on the court,\" Federer explained.\n\n\"If he says 'ciao', he will do it on a court and not on his couch, and I love that because he is very far from being 100%. It is such a personal decision that he has to choose. How he wants to do it, based on his body, as he honestly says.\n\n\"I don't know anything, but I would like it to end as he has decided, with his family and his team. I would like him to continue on the circuit a little longer than people believe.\n\n\"I have heard many things, that the end could be during this Roland Garros or after the Olympic Games or that he will still be here next year, which I really hope. "Rafael Nadal comments on Novak Djokovic being in stands for his potential RG farewell", "body": "Nadal addresses Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz and Iga Swiatek coming to watch his French Open match versus Alexander Zverev.\n\nRafael Nadal said he didn't notice Novak Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz and Iga Swiatek in the stands during his French Open match versus Alexander Zverev but noted that he was \"happy\" to hear that some of his biggest rivals came to watch what may have been his last appearance at Roland Garros.\n\nOn Monday, record 14-time French Open champion Nadal kicked off and concluded his Roland Garros run after No. 4 seed Zverev handed him a 6-3 7-6 (5) 6-3 first-round loss.\n\nSince this was believed to be Nadal's last French Open appearance, the stands at Court Suzanne Lenglen were packed and it didn't feature only regular tennis fans but also some of the biggest tennis names.\n\nDjokovic coming to watch Nadal's farewell drew lots of attention and many positive reactions, while Alcaraz and Swiatek being in the stands was also notable but not surprising considering that both grew up watching and idolizing the Spanish 22-time Grand Slam champion.\n\nThere were some other well-known professional tennis players in the stands, including 2022 WTA Finals champion Caroline Garcia and former world No. 11 Alize Cornet, who is also retiring after the French Open.\n\n\"I mean, I didn't see them, but I think in some way it's normal, no?\" Nadal said.\n\n\"I think if that's the last time that I'm going to be playing here and if I know that Novak is the last time playing in Wimbledon or in Australia and I was there or... I mean, these kind of rivals or young players that are here like Carlos that probably they watch me on TV the most of his years that they are living (smiling), it's normal that in some way they are interested to see how this is going to be, and especially in this particular place with all the history that I had behind, no?\n\n\"But yeah, I mean, happy that that happens, you know, because that means that I had a positive legacy here and positive legacy for my career, no? And that's it.\"\n\nMoments after losing to Zverev, Nadal briefly addressed the crowd on the court. {"uri": "8146252211", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "06:38:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T06:38:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T06:34:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://wfin.com/fox-sports/rafael-nadal-37-dismisses-notion-this-is-his-last-french-open-dont-assume-that/", "title": "Rafael Nadal, 37, dismisses notion this is his last French Open: 'Don't assume that' - WFIN Local News", "body": "Rafael Nadal has missed each of the last four grand slams but is making his return to the French Open, where he plays his best.\n\nThe 37-year-old has dominated the clay his entire career, and 14 of his 22 grand slam wins have come at Roland Garros, including his most recent just two years ago.\n\nInjuries hampered his 2023 season, and he was out for almost a full year, dropping out of the top 10 in the world rankings for the first time in nearly 20 years before finally returning to the Brisbane Invitational in December.\n\nCLICK HERE FOR MORE SPORTS COVERAGE ON FOXNEWS.COM\n\nAnother injury, though, forced him to miss the Australian Open, and age may finally be catching up to Nadal.\n\nIt wasn't that long ago he was dominating. His 2022 French Open victory was his second consecutive grand slam, as he had won the Australian Open for the second time earlier that year.\n\nNadal will turn 38 June 3, the day before the Open's quarterfinals begin, and he's hinted this year could be his last. But on Saturday, he kept the door open.\n\nPlayers, fans and the media have been assuming it will be his farewell appearance at the French Open.\n\nAsked whether that's accurate, Nadal channeled Felix Unger.\n\n\"Don't assume that. It's a big, big chance that it's going to be my last Roland Garros,\" Nadal said. \"But if I have to tell you it's 100% my last Roland Garros? Sorry, but I will not. Because I cannot predict what's going on.\"\n\nCOCO GAUFF, UPSET WITH 'CURRENT STATE' OF FLORIDA GOVERNMENT, SAYS IT'S A 'CRAZY TIME' TO BE A BLACK RESIDENT\n\nIn the first round, the Spaniard drew Alexander Zverev, the No. 4 player in the world who went toe-to-toe with Nadal in the 2022 French Open semifinal before a gruesome ankle injury forced Zverev to miss the rest of the season.\n\nWhile Nadal has often intimated retirement is beckoning, he said Saturday he doesn't \"want to close, 100%, the door,\" because he is enjoying playing tennis, he likes traveling with his wife and young son and, he added, \"I was not able to explore yet the proper way how I will be able to play, being in, again, more or less healthy conditions, playing without limitation.\"\n\nHe asked Saturday for a halt to questions about his future while he figures things out.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\n\"Give me some time,\" Nadal said. \"Maybe in one month and a half, I'll say, 'OK, it's enough. I can't keep going.' But today, in some way, I cannot guarantee that that's going to be the last one.\"\n\nNadal and Zverev will take the court on Monday at 6 a.m. ET.\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.",
