{"uri": "8148543023", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "17:38:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T17:38:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T17:37:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/aikenstandard/sports/rafael-nadal-loses-in-the-french-opens-first-round-to-alexander-zverev/article_540db53f-80e6-544b-bdee-03a979ddce65.html", "title": "Rafael Nadal loses in the French Open's first round to Alexander Zverev", "body": "PARIS (AP) -- Rafael Nadal lost in the first round of the French Open to Alexander Zverev 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3 on Monday in what might turn out to be the 14-time Roland Garros champion's last match at his favorite tournament.\n\nNadal has indicated 2024 likely would be his last season before retirement, but he said Saturday that he is not 100% sure he won't play again at the French Open. And he reiterated that after Monday's defeat, only his fourth in 116 career matches at the place.\n\nWhen it ended, in anticlimactic fashion, with 22-time Grand Slam champion Nadal simply unable to play at his usual level after 1 1/2 years of hip and abdominal injuries, he thanked the raucous Court Philippe Chatrier crowd for the \"incredible the amount of energy\" it provided throughout the 3 hours, 5 minutes of play.\n\n\"It's difficult for me to talk. I don't know (if) it's going to be the last time I am here. I am not 100% sure,\" said Nadal, whose 1 1/2-year-old son, Rafael Jr., sat on his mother's lap in the stands. \"If it's the last time, I enjoyed it.\"\n\nIt is the first time in his long and illustrious career that Nadal has been beaten in two consecutive matches on clay courts and the first time he has dropped a match earlier than the fourth round at the French Open.\n\nThe match was played with the retractable roof shut, and the loud chants of \"Ra-fa!\" from most in the capacity crowd of about 15,000 echoed.\n\nToday's Top Headlines SRS walking tours revisit former town of Ellenton 'Thank you for my freedom': Aiken parade marks Memorial Day weekend List of alleged broken promises by Weeping Willows developer continues to grow Late Burnettown mayor Hector Rodriguez recognized at Memorial Day ceremony SRMC welcomes largest class of summer interns Today's events for May 27 Aiken man accused of committing bank fraud regarding wealthy Aiken woman's will Curry and Larlee win member-guest at Palmetto St. Paul to hold final celebration concert featuring pipe organ and voices Grayson Murray dies at age 30 a day after withdrawing from Colonial, PGA Tour says\n\nNadal turns 38 on June 3 and he has been dealing with hip and abdominal injuries since January 2023, limiting him to 15 matches and an 8-7 record since the start of last year. His infrequent play dropped his ranking to No. 275 and he was unseeded for the French Open for the first time.\n\nThat is why he ended up facing the No. 4-seeded Zverev, the runner-up at the 2020 U.S. Open, a gold medalist at the Tokyo Olympics and the only man to reach the semifinals in Paris each of the past three years.\n\nNadal's other losses at Roland Garros came against Robin Soderling in 2010 and against Novak Djokovic in 2015 and 2021.\n\n\"To be honest, I don't know what to say. First of all: Thank you, Rafa, from all of the tennis world,\" Zverev said. \"It's such a great honor. I've watched Rafa play all my childhood, and I was lucky enough to play Rafa when I became a professional. ... Today is not my moment. {"uri": "8146345957", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "08:09:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T08:09:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T08:08:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.sportsmole.co.uk/tennis/french-open/preview/preview-alexander-zverev-vs-rafael-nadal-prediction-form-head-to-head_544553.html", "title": "Preview: Alexander Zverev vs. Rafael Nadal - prediction, form, head-to-head", "body": "Roland-Garros' favourite son commences what is expected to be an emotional French Open last dance on Monday, as 14-time champion Rafael Nadal meets Alexander Zverev in a blockbuster first-round tie.\n\nWhile the revered Spaniard is engaging on his farewell tour, Zverev is now hitting the heights that he threatened to hit before his devastating injury in his most recent encounter with Nadal.\n\nMatch preview\n\n\u00a9 Reuters\n\nVery rarely is Zverev not the headline act on the court these days - whether it be for his undeniable talent with the racquet in his hand or controversies outside of the arena - but the German will be under no illusions that the Roland-Garros crowd will be rooting against him on Monday.\n\nZverev arrives on the French clay amid the backdrop of his trial for alleged domestic abuse - which starts on May 31 and runs until mid-July - but the 27-year-old vehemently denies the accusations and does not have to appear in person, meaning that his French Open participation remains unaffected.\n\nClose but no cigar has been Zverev's French Open story for the past three years, having reached the semi-finals in 2021, 2022 and 2023 without ever advancing to the championship match, while his Australian Open run back in January also ended at the semi-final stage to Daniil Medvedev.\n\nHowever, the 2020 US Open runner-up may feel that he has no better shot at Grand Slam glory owing to high-profile injuries and other celebrated names losing their way, and his form in the lead-up to the second major of the year is certainly befitting that of a potential French Open champion.\n\nIndeed, the fourth seed stormed to Italian Open glory earlier this month - his sixth Masters title overall and a first since the 2021 Cincinnati Open - and his record for the year reads a praiseworthy 28 wins and nine defeats before he attempts to bring the curtain down on Nadal's Roland-Garros adventure.\n\n\u00a9 Reuters\n\nRemaining coy on his future with the press ahead of Monday's unmissable tie, Nadal refused to rule out the possibility of prolonging his French Open adventure until 2025 or later, but the upcoming edition is widely expected to be the Spaniard's swansong on his beloved Roland-Garros clay.\n\nNo man can boast as many as Nadal's unrivalled 14 French Open singles crowns during a streak of dominance lasting nearly 20 years, having conquered Roland-Garros on his very first foray in 2005 and sweeping aside countless foes ever since, but just seeing the 37-year-old in a major draw again brings about a hearty smile.\n\nMost recently hoisting the Coupe des Mousquetaires aloft in 2022, Nadal has been absent from the last four Grand Slam events on account of his cruel injury problems, although he was scheduled to make his eagerly-anticipated major comeback at the 2024 Australian Open before a muscular issue reared its ugly head.\n\nThe 37-year-old, who turns 38 on June 3, has since been soaking up adulation in Barcelona, Madrid and Rome - reaching the last 16 in the Spanish capital and earning a notable scalp over Alex de Minaur along the way - but he was seen off with consummate ease by Hubert Hurkacz in the Italian Open second round.\n\nFormerly as low as world number 664, Nadal - using a protected ranking to enter Roland-Garros 2024 - has since risen almost 400 places to 275th on the globe, and a second-round showdown against either David Goffin or Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard will be the prize should he avoid a fate he is yet to suffer at the French Open - a first-round exit.\n\nHead To Head\n\nFrench Open (2022) - Semi-finals: Nadal wins 7-6[8] 6-6 ret.\n\nItalian Open (2021) - Quarter-finals: Nadal wins 6-3 6-4\n\nMadrid Open (2021) - Quarter-finals: Zverev wins 6-4 6-4\n\nParis Masters (2020) - Semi-finals: Zverev wins 6-4 7-5\n\nATP Finals (2019) - Round robin: Zverev wins 6-2 6-4\n\nItalian Open (2018) - Final: Nadal wins 6-1 1-6 6-3\n\nDavis Cup (2018) - Round robin: Nadal wins 6-1 6-4 6-4\n\nMonte-Carlo Masters (2017) - Last 16: Nadal wins 6-1 6-1\n\nAustralian Open (2017) - Third round: Nadal wins 4-6 6-3 6-7[5] 6-3 6-2\n\nIndian Wells Masters (2016) - Fourth round: Nadal wins 6-7[8] 6-0 7-5\n\nZverev and Nadal's mouthwatering Monday matchup is a repeat of their 2022 French Open semi-final, where the 14-time champion was edging a tight contest before his German foe rolled his ankle and let out a blood-curdling cry of anguish; it was announced afterwards that he had sustained torn ligaments and required season-ending surgery.\n\nNadal's victory on retirement was his seventh success from 10 previous battles against Zverev, whom he also bested in straight sets in the 2021 Italian Open quarters, prior to which the reigning Rome champion had earned three triumphs on the bounce against his more experienced foe.\n\nBefore Nadal's body began to fail him, the 22-time major winner prevailed in each of his first five battles against Zverev, most notably a five-set Australian Open thriller in 2017 and a three-set Italian Open final in 2018, which remains their solitary meeting with a trophy on the line.\n\nWe say: Zverev to win in three sets\n\nThis was a particularly painful prediction to type out. While Nadal's unparalleled French Open achievements, unprecedented love for clay and unrivalled support from the Roland-Garros crowd all work in his favour, the form book is just too hard to ignore on this occasion.\n\nThe veteran Spaniard is also yet to be tested in a best-of-five battle in the 2024 season, but we cannot envisage him taking an in-form Zverev to the distance, and the German fourth seed should storm to the success that may close Nadal's French Open chapter for good.\n\nID:544553:1false2false3false:QQ:: from db desktop :LenBod:collect7983:Previews by emailClick here to get Sports {"uri": "8150262008", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "17:25:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T17:25:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T17:24:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.khmertimeskh.com/501496292/nadal-suffers-likely-farewell-defeat-swiatek-advances/", "title": "Nadal suffers likely farewell defeat, Swiatek advances - Khmer Times", "body": "PARIS - Rafael Nadal's glorious French Open career very likely came to an end as the 14-time champion suffered his first ever opening-round-defeat on Monday, losing to Alexander Zverev in three straight sets.\n\nWomen's defending champion Iga Swiatek kicked off her campaign in style in an earlier action at the Philippe-Chatrier Court as she dismissed French qualifier Leolia Jeanjean 6-1, 6-2 to extend her winning streak at Roland Garros to 15 matches.\n\nFourth-seeded Zverev handed Nadal a 6-3, 7-6(5), 6-3 defeat in the most mouthwatering clash of the first round, maybe also the most remarkable one of this stage in the tournament's 134-year history.\n\nThe 27-year-old German became the first man to defeat Nadal before the fourth round at Roland-Garros and joined Robin Soderling and Novak Djokovic as the third man to defeat Nadal on the Parisian clay.\n\n\"To be honest I don't know what to say,\" Zverev said on court after his win, before handing the mic to the Spanish legend. \"First of all, thank you Rafa, from all of the tennis world. It's such a great honour. I've watched Rafa play all my childhood, and I was lucky enough to play Rafa when I became a pro.\"\n\nNadal, ranked 275 at the moment, had never played Roland-Garros unseeded, and never faced a top-10 player in the first round.\n\n\"I had my chances but it was not enough against a great player like Sascha,\" Nadal said after the match.\n\nZverev's aggressive play set the tone in the first set. The two-time ATP Finals champion took the action to his opponent, hitting 15 winners compared to five for Nadal in the opener.\n\nNadal faced two break points early in the second set to fall into a deep deficit despite chants of \"Rafa! Rafa!\" in and outside the stadium. After digging out of trouble, he conjured memories of his very best tennis to claim a service break and lead by 3-2.\n\nBut his rival responded quickly with another break before claiming a tense tiebreak to take a two-set lead.\n\nAfter Nadal missed a final shot on match point, Zverev gave a muted celebration out of respect for the 22-time major champion. They enjoyed a warm greeting at the net.\n\nFor now, Nadal will look to continue testing himself against the best players in the world, with plans to be back in Paris for the 2024 Olympic Games.\n\nWorld No.1 Swiatek opened her title defence with a trademark performance, thriving as the frontrunner to dispatch local underdog Jeanjean in just one hour.\n\nThe Pole had arrived at Roland-Garros on a 12-match winning streak off the back of collecting WTA 1000 titles in Madrid and Rome.\n\n\"It feels like home here,\" the three-time champion said.\n\nReigning Australian Open champion Jannik Sinner also clinched a straight-set victory as the Italian beat American Christopher Eubanks 6-3, 6-3, 6-4 to progress.\n\nHome favourite Varvara Gracheva produced the biggest upset of the first round so far as the world No.88 came from a set down to defeat No.6 seed Maria Sakkari 3-6, 6-4, 6-3.\n\nSakkari is the first Top 10 seed to fall through the first two days of the tournament. {"uri": "8149683762", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "11:10:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T11:10:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T11:10:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.tennis365.com/tennis-news/will-rafael-nadal-play-wimbledon-french-open-2024-tennis-retirement", "title": "Rafael Nadal makes honest Wimbledon confession after his French Open exit", "body": "Rafael Nadal admitted he does not think it would be \"a good idea\" to play at Wimbledon following his 2024 French Open defeat to Alexander Zverev.\n\nThe tennis legend feels making the transition from clay to grass, and then back to clay for the Paris Olympics, would be difficult and potentially risky given his injury issues.\n\nNadal was defeated 6-3, 7-6(5), 6-3 by world No 4 Zverev in the first round of the French Open on Monday in his first Grand Slam match since the 2023 Australian Open.\n\nThe 22-time Grand Slam champion reached the semi-finals at Wimbledon in 2022 in his last appearance at the All England Club. The former world No 1 was forced to pull out ahead of his semi-final match with Nick Kyrgios due to an abdominal tear.\n\nThe 37-year-old Spaniard won Wimbledon in 2008 and 2010, while he was also a runner-up at the grass-court Grand Slam in 2006, 2007 and 2011.\n\nThe 2024 Wimbledon Championships will be held from July 1-14, while the tennis event at the 2024 Olympics will run from July 27 to August 4. The Olympics will be staged on the clay courts of Stade Roland Garros.\n\nRead More: Rafael Nadal: Former stars believe Spaniard may not have played his last French Open match\n\nSpeaking in his press conference after his match with Zverev at Roland Garros, Nadal was asked if he intends to play at Wimbledon.\n\n\"It looks difficult, honestly,\" Nadal said. \"I can't confirm what's going on, but it looks difficult to make the transition to grass, having the Olympics again on clay.\n\n\"I cannot confirm anything, I have to talk with the team to analyse so many facts.\n\n\"But I don't think it's going to be smart after all the things that happened to my body to make a big transition to a completely different surface and then come back immediately to clay. Today I feel that's not a good idea.\"\n\nThe 14-time French Open champion also spoke further about his tennis future, having left the door open to extending his career beyond 2024.\n\n\"I'm a simple guy,\" the Mallorcan explained. \"For me, the feeling of coming back home with the personal satisfaction to do all that's in my hands to make things work well, give myself everything, that's the only way I understand my life.\n\n\"That's why I'm not saying I'm retiring today. In the end, it's about not having the feeling in one year or one year and a half that I didn't give myself a real chance, because [as soon as] I started to become a little healthier, I stopped.\n\n\"In terms of what's the force driving me, I'm a simple guy, I enjoy what I do. I am passionate about sport, about competition, I like to practise, I like to play tennis.\n\n\"I'm in a different moment of my personal life too, travelling with my son and my wife. I'm enjoying these moments that will not come back.\n\n\"If I keep enjoying what I'm doing and feel that I'm competitive and healthy enough to enjoy it, I want to keep going for a while, I don't know how long.\n\n\"I need to see. I need to give myself a little longer to see if my level is growing, how my body is holding, and then let's make a decision.\n\n\"But give me two months to the Olympics and then let's see if I can They captioned the video \"Family First.\" Rafael Nadal's Wife Maria Parello and Son Rafael Jr Steal Spotlight at French Open 2024.\n\nThe unseeded 14-time French Open winner lost to Alexander Zverev in the first round of his favourite grand slam. {"uri": "8147131859", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "21:25:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T21:25:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T21:24:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/sports/professional/other/nadal-french-open-clay-tennis-atp-major/article_4c2e2ab5-1d65-55a8-84fb-c2238e21a692.html", "title": "French Open cancels farewell ceremony for Nadal", "body": "PARIS -- The French tennis federation put off holding a ceremony to celebrate Rafael Nadal at Roland Garros this year, because he has said this might not necessarily be his final appearance at the tournament he has won a record 14 times.\n\nTournament director Am\u00e9lie Mauresmo said Sunday, Day 1 of the clay-court Grand Slam event, that Nadal let officials know he didn't want to close the door on a return before he told the world that at a pre-tournament news conference.\n\n\"As you can imagine, we had something planned for him. But ... because he doesn't know if it's going to be his last Roland Garros or not, he wants to leave the door open maybe to come back next year as a player. So we are not going to push him, obviously, to do anything,\" Mauresmo said.\n\n\"It's his decision when he wants to have a proper ceremony, a proper goodbye, a proper farewell. So we're not going to do it this year. That's his wish,\" she continued. \"And even though we were ready to push the button if something happens, we obviously are going to respect what he wants and make sure we are ready whenever he feels he wants to do it. Later this year; next year; anytime he wants.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Thunderstorms with flash flooding and wind hit McDowell on Saturday Jaden Dalton becomes McDowell's newest Eagle Scout Gym Rats: McDowell's girls and boys basketball players competitive this spring in conditioning Mountain Athletic Conference releases all-conference teams for spring 2024 McDowell student receives prestigious award Former McDowell High School counselor charged with sex acts on a student makes court appearance Marion police chief: No robbery occurred at First Citizens Bank Memorial Day weekend car show set for Saturday McDowell County Schools will implement new dual-enrollment program this fall Proposed McDowell budget leaves tax rate unchanged Morganton woman dies after a rock was thrown through her windshield, troopers say Downtown Marion's Spillway Bridge closes its doors If passed as law, would 'unmasking bill' criminalize mask-wearing for health reasons? Republicans say no, others remain worried. Jeff and Harold Grindstaff take Week 2 of Friday night tournament on Lake James NCHSAA releases 2024 baseball and softball playoff brackets\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3 and has said previously he expects this to be his last season, will face No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev in the first round on Monday. The match is scheduled to be third in the main stadium, Court Philippe Chatrier, and could start at around 3:30 p.m. local time (9:30 a.m. EDT).\n\nHere are some answers to questions about Nadal and Zverev:\n\nWhy are top players like Nadal and Zverev meeting in the first round?\n\nDespite having such a dominant record at the French Open, Nadal was not seeded and so could have been placed anywhere in the bracket and been stuck playing anyone at all, even the very best opponents. Because of injuries, including a surgically repaired hip and problematic abdominal muscle, Nadal has competed little the past two seasons, going only 7-4 in 2024, and so someone who has been ranked No. 1 and spent more than a decade inside the top 10 is now outside the top 250.\n\nWhy isn't Nadal seeded?\n\nThis is Nadal's first Grand Slam tournament without a seeding since the 2005 Australian Open. The top 32 players in the men's and women's draws are seeded, and the seedings are based on the ATP and WTA rankings, which take into account the most recent 52 weeks of results. In theory, Mauresmo could have opted to circumvent the rules and go ahead and award a seeding to Nadal based on his past performances in Paris. But that was never really considered, she said, in part because \"giving protection to some players\" would result in \"a lot of other issues and problems,\" and because \"it also has to be OK with other Grand Slams and everything.\"\n\nWhat difference do seedings make?\n\nPlayers who are seeded, such as Zverev, are guaranteed to avoid going up against another seeded player any earlier than the third round of a Grand Slam tournament, which have 128-player fields and require seven victories to earn a championship.\n\nWhat do other players think?\n\nPlayers tend to agree with Mauresmo's decision, with several saying they believe the seeding system should remain the way it currently is (Wimbledon used to seed players according to their results on grass courts, but has strictly followed the rankings since 2021). \"The way that the seedings work, I think it's appropriate. In this case, it's unfortunate how that happened, but I don't know how you gauge where someone should and shouldn't be seeded based on past or previous success,\" said three-time major champion Andy Murray. \"It'd be quite hard to do that.\"\n\nWho is Alexander Zverev?\n\nHe is a leading player in men's tennis, one who is coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open, won a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics and was the 2020 U.S. Open runner-up. He reached the semifinals at the French Open each of the past three years, including in 2022, when he played Nadal at that stage but had to stop after tearing ligaments in his right foot during the match. Zverev, a 27-year-old from Germany, is about to face a court proceeding that starts next week in Berlin related to accusations of physically abusing an ex-girlfriend. He does not need to be in court and said he will not be. \"At the end of the day, I do believe in the German system. I do believe in the truth, as well. I have to be certain that, you know, I do know what I did, I do know what I didn't do,\" Zverev said. \"That's, at the end of the day, what's going to come out, and I have to trust in that.\"\n\nWhy is Zverev allowed to play during his ongoing court case?\n\nMauresmo was asked Sunday about Zverev's status and replied: \"As long as the trial isn't finished and there isn't a decision, he's considered innocent and so that's why he's allowed to be part of the draw.\"\n\nAP Sports Week in Pictures: Caitlin Clark's debut, Fury on the ropes and golf's winning shot Tags Dcc Wire Lee-national {"uri": "2024-05-369941790", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "16:34:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T16:34:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T16:29:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.france24.com/en/sport/20240527-king-of-clay-nadal-knocked-out-by-zverev-in-possible-french-open-farewell", "title": "'King of Clay' Nadal knocked out by Zverev in possible French Open farewell", "body": "The 22-time Grand Slam champion showed flashes of his old self as he mounted a spirited challenge on Court Philippe Chatrier, carried by a raucous crowd that included his old rival Novak Djokovic. But his towering opponent was too steep a mountain to climb for the ageing Spaniard, whose career twilight has been blighted by injury.\n\nNadal had played only four tournaments since January 2023 after undergoing hip surgery and then suffering a muscle tear. He arrived in Paris ranked a lowly 276th in the world, on the back of a straight sets humbling in Rome at the hands of Poland's Hubert Hurkacz.\n\nFears of an equally undignified exit at Roland Garros appeared to materialise when Nadal lost his opening serve game to love. But the Spaniard quickly recovered, throwing his heart into a close-fought battle that did justice to his extraordinary career.\n\nEarlier on, there was a deafening roar as the players walked onto court and the master of ceremonies gave a rundown of Nadal's 14 French Open titles, starting with his maiden win in 2005 as a long-haired, sleeveless teenager.\n\nThe hair thinned out over the years, and the outfits got tamer, but Rafa remained the indisputable 'King of Clay' for close to two decades.\n\n'I didn't want to play Rafa'\n\nThe unenviable task of drawing the curtain on Nadal's French Open career fell to Zverev, the German 4th seed who left this same court in a wheelchair after twisting his ankle when they last met in the semi-finals two years ago.\n\n\"I can guarantee you Novak (Djokovic) didn't want to play Rafa in the first round and (Carlos) Alcaraz didn't want to play, Jannik (Sinner) didn't want to play him,\" Zverev said ahead of the match. \"I don't want to play him in the first round, but it is how it is.\"\n\nZverev arrived in Paris as one of the favourites for the title after winning the Rome Open earlier this month. The 27-year-old has long been touted as a future Grand Slam champion but remains without one of tennis' four biggest titles.\n\nWith the likes of Djokovic, Sinner and Alcaraz all recovering from injuries, this may be Zverev's best chance yet, and on his preferred surface too.\n\nThe lanky German was in ruthless form as he stormed to an early lead against Nadal, saving two break points at 3-1 in the opening set. The Spaniard saved two set points on his own serve at 3-5 but gave up the opener on the third when he buried a loose forehand into the net.\n\nTellingly, Zverev had hit 15 winners to Nadal's five.\n\nA tighter contest, the second set saw Nadal save two break points to go to 2-2, celebrating his winning forehand with a leap, punch and scream of \"Vamos\". He then broke for first time to lead 3-2 courtesy of a pinpoint drop shot with Zverev stranded at the back of the court.\n\nNadal was then broken to love in the 10th game as he served for the set. He then saved one set point in a tense tie-break, only for Zverev to claim the set when the Spaniard netted a service return.\n\n'Forever the greatest'\n\nNadal's fans had descended en masse on a chilly and damp Roland Garros, hoping to carry their hero to an unlikely win. Many lined up for a selfie at the \"Rafa monument\", a stainless steel sculpture three metres high and almost five metres wide, located near the entrance to the stadium.\n\n\"I wouldn't have missed this day for the world,\" said 45-year-old Andr\u00e8s, posing for a picture with his friends from Alicante in Spain, each of them sporting a \"Gracias Rafa\" (Thank you Rafa) T-shirt.\n\n\"Rafa is a model to us, an example of modesty, of courage and fighting spirit,\" he added. \"He is forever the greatest, whatever happens today.\"\n\nAndr\u00e8s still harboured hopes of seeing Nadal back in Paris next year. He added: \"A part of Roland Garros will be missing once he is gone.\"\n\nThis was expected to be Nadal's final appearance at the French Open, but the Spaniard has been more cryptic about his future since arriving in Paris, telling reporters he could not confirm \"100 percent\" this would be his farewell to Roland Garros.\n\n\"Maybe the last one, maybe not,\" he told a packed press conference on Saturday. \"I hope to be clear. I don't want to create a big confusion, but I'm enjoying what I am doing.\"\n\nFrench Open organisers were prepared to stage a tribute ceremony to Nadal to honour his career, but the Spaniard was reluctant to endorse such a celebration.\n\n\"We were ready to press the button on it,\" admitted tournament director Am\u00e9lie Mauresmo. \"But it's Rafa who manages his timing, we follow what he wants.\"", "source": {"uri": "france24.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "France 24"}, "authors": [{"uri": "benjamin_dodman@france24.com", "name": "Benjamin Dodman", "type": "author", "isAgency": The Spaniard lost to Alexander Zverev, 6-3 7(7)-6(5) 6-3, in a match which had the likes of Novak Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz and Iga Swiatek at the stands.\n\nAfter the match, an emotional Nadal was applauded by fans, and he waved back at him, acknowledging their support.\n\nIt turned out to be a one-sided affair as Zverev broke Nadal in the opening game, and the veteran surrendered his serve again late on to lose the first set. Nadal began the second set on a strong note, and got a 4-2 lead. But the German fought back in the 10th game, saving two breakpoints before doubling his advantage by winning a thrilling tiebreak.\n\nThen in the third set, he took a 2-0 lead, but again gave it away as Zverev sealed a win.\n\nSpeaking after the match, he said, \"The amount of energy.. It's difficult for me to talk. I don't know if it's gonna be the last time here in front of all of you. I'm not sure. But if it's the last time I enjoyed it. The crowd was amazing during the whole week of preparation. Today the feelings I have are difficult to describe in words. For me it is so special to feel the love of the people in the place I love the most.\"\n\n\"I enjoy playing a lot and traveling with my family. The body is feeling better than 2 months ago. Maybe in 2 months I say it's enough. But it's something I don't feel yet. I hope to be back on this court for the Olympics. That motivates me. That's going to be another chance,\" he added.\n\nMeanwhile, Zverev said, \"Thank you Rafa from all of the tennis world. It is such a great honour. {"uri": "2024-05-371164351", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "17:24:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T17:24:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T17:18:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.worldtennismagazine.com/archives/23235", "title": "We Haven't Seen The Last of Rafael Nadal (And Neither Has Paris) - World Tennis Magazine", "body": "Rafael Nadal's almost unmatched tennis career was born at Roland Garros and has been largely defined by Roland Garros, but the 2024 edition of the tournament will likely not be where Nadal's career will come to a close.\n\nWhen Nadal announced that the 2024 season would likely be his last on tour, many wisely predicted that he would play his final match at the French Championships, the tournament that he has won an incredible 14 times - more than double the number of times that six-time champion Bjorn Borg won the title. Many great champions have a hard time letting go of their competitive careers and Nadal himself was cagey and evasive when confronted in conversations that the 2024 French Open would be his final event. As author and former New York Times tennis writer Christopher Clarey wrote in his Substack email article, Nadal \"has been resisting the word retirement like it is a break point.\" Earlier this year, the Laver Cup even announced that Nadal would be a member of Team Europe in its September event, perhaps indicating that Nadal would have a farewell in the team event like his greatest rival Roger Federer did in 2022.\n\nIn his post-match comments after his straight-sets first-round loss to No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev, Nadal seemed determined to return to Paris this summer to his favorite clay courts and compete for Spain in the Olympic Games. The International Tennis Federation, which oversees the Olympic tennis competition, confirmed via a social post on X (formerly Twitter) that Nadal's ATP protected ranking of No. 9 could be used to gain entry into the Olympic Games, also played at Roland Garros. He could also be paired in doubles with his Spanish heir apparent Carlos Alcaraz. When asked if would consider another trip to play at Wimbledon in July, Nadal begged off saying that playing on the grass courts at the All England Club would not be wise if he wanted to play again on the clay at the Olympic Games.\n\nSo Nadal's first-round loss to Zverev looks only to be the closing bookend to his career at the French Championships, which he won in his first visit there in 2005 as a 19-year-old. As Clarey wrote, \"Nadal's straight-set defeat to Alexander Zverev at the French Open did not quite feel like a full-circle moment....But full circle would also imply the end, and though the understandable assumption has been that this is Nadal's farewell tour it is beginning to seem much more like a warmup act for the farewell tour.\" And Clarey, perhaps more than anybody outside of Nadal's family and his close inner circle, would know best as he has meticulously written and researched Nadal for his upcoming book \"The Warrior.\"\n\nWe will see him again.\n\nOh, and did we {"uri": "2024-05-370681756", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "10:15:11", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T10:15:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T10:09:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/05/28/sport/rafael-nadal-wimbledon-paris-olympics-spt-intl/index.html", "title": "Rafael Nadal says playing Wimbledon is 'not a good idea' as he looks to prioritize Paris Olympics", "body": "CNN --\n\nRafael Nadal has cast further doubt on his participation at Wimbledon this year, saying it is \"not a good idea\" as he looks to prioritize the Summer Olympics on the Roland Garros clay.\n\nThe 22-time grand slam champion was eliminated in the first round of the French Open by Alexander Zverev on Monday and said Paris 2024 is now the \"main goal\" for the summer.\n\nThe transition from clay to grass is the most difficult surface change on the tennis calendar. Wimbledon gets underway on July 1, with the Olympic tennis tournament starting less than a month later on July 27.\n\n\"It looks difficult,\" Nadal, who won singles gold at Beijing 2008, said of his Wimbledon prospects. \"Honestly, I can't confirm what's going on, but for me, now it looks difficult to make the transition to grass, having the Olympics again on clay.\n\n\"So I cannot confirm anything, I need to talk with the team, I need to analyze so many facts, but I don't think it's going to be smart after all the things that happened to my body to now make a big transition to a completely different surface and then come back immediately to clay.\n\n\"Today, I feel that's not a good idea. I can't confirm, but my feeling is, even if I am booked in Wimbledon because I had to, I don't think it's a positive idea right now.\"\n\nNadal is also set to play in the doubles at Paris 2024 with Carlos Alcaraz.\n\nThe 37-year-old has struggled with injury since the 2023 Australian Open and was forced to miss the vast majority of last season as he tried to get his body ready for one last year on tour.\n\nAfter previously announcing that 2024 would likely be his last year in professional tennis, Nadal opened the door to a possible return in 2025 after his defeat to Zverev, saying he is \"not 100% sure\" the loss was his final appearance at Roland Garros.\n\nBut given his injury struggles over the last 18 months, Nadal admitted that, even if prioritizes being fit for the Olympics, there is no guarantee he will be.\n\n\"I cannot tell you if I will be or won't be in one month and a half,\" Nadal said. \"My body has been a jungle for two years and you don't know what to expect. I wake up one day and I found a snake biting me; another day, a tiger.\n\nNadal won singles gold at Beijing 2008.\n\nBehrouz Mehri/AFP/Getty Images\n\n\"It's been a big fight with all of the things I went through, but the dynamic is positive the last few weeks. I felt ready. I think tomorrow I will be ready to play again if I had to - but I will not have to,\" he laughed. \"I need to clear my ideas now and see what the new calendar is for me to be ready for the Olympics.\n\n\"I can't say anything today, but my main goal now is to play the Olympics that are going to be here, so I need to prepare myself the proper way: to try to arrive here healthy and well prepared - and then let's see.\"", "source": {"uri": "cnn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNN"}, "authors": [{"uri": "matias_grez@cnn.com", "name": "Matias Grez", "type": "author", "isAgency": {"uri": "8147130077", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "21:22:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T21:22:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T21:21:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/sports/professional/other/nadal-french-open-clay-tennis-atp-major/article_5badb897-58ec-5ad0-8c40-95dced89b288.html", "title": "French Open cancels farewell ceremony for Nadal", "body": "PARIS -- The French tennis federation put off holding a ceremony to celebrate Rafael Nadal at Roland Garros this year, because he has said this might not necessarily be his final appearance at the tournament he has won a record 14 times.\n\nTournament director Am\u00e9lie Mauresmo said Sunday, Day 1 of the clay-court Grand Slam event, that Nadal let officials know he didn't want to close the door on a return before he told the world that at a pre-tournament news conference.\n\n\"As you can imagine, we had something planned for him. But ... because he doesn't know if it's going to be his last Roland Garros or not, he wants to leave the door open maybe to come back next year as a player. So we are not going to push him, obviously, to do anything,\" Mauresmo said.\n\n\"It's his decision when he wants to have a proper ceremony, a proper goodbye, a proper farewell. So we're not going to do it this year. That's his wish,\" she continued. \"And even though we were ready to push the button if something happens, we obviously are going to respect what he wants and make sure we are ready whenever he feels he wants to do it. Later this year; next year; anytime he wants.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Man crashes vintage replica hot rod into Waterloo library moments after purchase East High School student to spend her summer as part of a world-renowned drum and bugle corps Wells gives $1 million to Le Mars daycare center UPDATED: Sioux City officers doubted fatal shooting suspect was intoxicated Sioux City sues marina manager for breach of contract 2 students, driver hurt in Le Mars school bus crash Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for May 20, 2024 South Sioux City senior who has been homeless, finds home at school Live updates: Omaha metro floods, power outages close schools, businesses Samuel J. Chadwick Much of Siouxland cleans up after heavy rainstorm, gusty winds and golf ball-sized hail Man linked to missing Nebraska girl faces federal charges in Sioux City Sioux City West High School Graduates 2024 Sioux City North High School Graduates 2024 Heelan's James Cleary named Rotary Club's Student of the Year; nine students honored during the year\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3 and has said previously he expects this to be his last season, will face No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev in the first round on Monday. The match is scheduled to be third in the main stadium, Court Philippe Chatrier, and could start at around 3:30 p.m. local time (9:30 a.m. EDT).\n\nHere are some answers to questions about Nadal and Zverev:\n\nWhy are top players like Nadal and Zverev meeting in the first round?\n\nDespite having such a dominant record at the French Open, Nadal was not seeded and so could have been placed anywhere in the bracket and been stuck playing anyone at all, even the very best opponents. Because of injuries, including a surgically repaired hip and problematic abdominal muscle, Nadal has competed little the past two seasons, going only 7-4 in 2024, and so someone who has been ranked No. 1 and spent more than a decade inside the top 10 is now outside the top 250.\n\nWhy isn't Nadal seeded?\n\nThis is Nadal's first Grand Slam tournament without a seeding since the 2005 Australian Open. The top 32 players in the men's and women's draws are seeded, and the seedings are based on the ATP and WTA rankings, which take into account the most recent 52 weeks of results. In theory, Mauresmo could have opted to circumvent the rules and go ahead and award a seeding to Nadal based on his past performances in Paris. But that was never really considered, she said, in part because \"giving protection to some players\" would result in \"a lot of other issues and problems,\" and because \"it also has to be OK with other Grand Slams and everything.\"\n\nWhat difference do seedings make?\n\nPlayers who are seeded, such as Zverev, are guaranteed to avoid going up against another seeded player any earlier than the third round of a Grand Slam tournament, which have 128-player fields and require seven victories to earn a championship.\n\nWhat do other players think?\n\nPlayers tend to agree with Mauresmo's decision, with several saying they believe the seeding system should remain the way it currently is (Wimbledon used to seed players according to their results on grass courts, but has strictly followed the rankings since 2021). \"The way that the seedings work, I think it's appropriate. In this case, it's unfortunate how that happened, but I don't know how you gauge where someone should and shouldn't be seeded based on past or previous success,\" said three-time major champion Andy Murray. \"It'd be quite hard to do that.\"\n\nWho is Alexander Zverev?\n\nHe is a leading player in men's tennis, one who is coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open, won a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics and was the 2020 U.S. Open runner-up. He reached the semifinals at the French Open each of the past three years, including in 2022, when he played Nadal at that stage but had to stop after tearing ligaments in his right foot during the match. Zverev, a 27-year-old from Germany, is about to face a court proceeding that starts next week in Berlin related to accusations of physically abusing an ex-girlfriend. He does not need to be in court and said he will not be. \"At the end of the day, I do believe in the German system. I do believe in the truth, as well. I have to be certain that, you know, I do know what I did, I do know what I didn't do,\" Zverev said. \"That's, at the end of the day, what's going to come out, and I have to trust in that.\"\n\nWhy is Zverev allowed to play during his ongoing court case?\n\nMauresmo was asked Sunday about Zverev's status and replied: \"As long as the trial isn't finished and there isn't a decision, he's considered innocent and so that's why he's allowed to be part of the draw.\"\n\nAP Sports Week in Pictures: Caitlin Clark's debut, Fury on the ropes and golf's winning shot 0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 {"uri": "2024-05-368897451", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "17:13:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T17:13:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T12:24:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.bworldonline.com/sports/2024/05/26/597495/no-guarantee-its-nadals-last-french-open/", "title": "No guarantee it's Nadal's last French Open", "body": "PARIS -- Fourteen-time French Open champion Rafael Nadal said there was still a chance this year's tournament in Paris may not be his last, in comments ahead of his tough opener against fourth seed Alexander Zverev.\n\nThe Spaniard, who turns 38 next month, skipped last year's tournament due to a hip injury that needed surgery and has said he expects to retire at the end of 2024. But he wasn't ready to repeat those words on Saturday.\n\n\"If I have to tell you it's 100 percent my last Roland Garros, sorry but I will not, because I cannot predict what's going on. I hope you understand,\" Mr. Nadal told a packed press conference.\n\n\"I don't want to close 100 percent the door, because it's a very simple thing. First, I'm enjoying playing tennis,\" he said, adding that he was \"more or less healthy .. and playing without limitation.\"\n\n\"Maybe in one month and a half I'll say 'OK, it's enough, I can't keep going.' But today I cannot guarantee that it's going to be the last one.\"\n\nMr. Nadal skipped the Australian Open in January with a muscle problem, and the 22-times Grand Slam champion had raised doubts about his fitness for the year's second major with lingering issues in Barcelona, Madrid and Rome. \"I'm feeling better. That's the truth,\" Mr. Nadal added, appearing more cheerful than he has in recent months.\n\nMr. Nadal turned his attention to Monday's clash with Mr. Zverev, a rematch of the 2022 semifinal when the German retired after an ankle injury.\n\n\"It's a super-tough first round,\" he said.\n\nMaybe I go there and I repeat the disaster of Rome. It's a possibility. I don't want to hide that,\" Nadal said, referring to a second-round defeat by Hubert Hurkacz in the Italian capital this month.\n\n\"But in my mind is something different, play much better and give myself a chance to be competitive... I didn't play this level of opponents, being competitive since a super-long time.\n\n\"So all these questions I understand that you're making to me I'm asking to myself too. But the answer is going to be on Monday, no? That's it.\n\n\"The rest of the things are just talking and talking, and in the end don't matter. It's about my feelings and my feelings are better. I want to enjoy that match.\" - Reuters", "source": {"uri": "bworldonline.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "BusinessWorld"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The conditions in the day, with less humidity, will allow the ball to not get heavy, a factor that could work in Nadal's favor. His powerful forehand, a signature move, could inflict much more damage under these conditions.\n\nThis was evident in the Madrid Masters last month, where Nadal played his first three matches in the afternoon and comfortably claimed victories in all, including one against world No. 10 Alex de Minaur. appearance after  French Open exit", "body": "Rafael Nadal has outlined his future plans as he prepares to retire from tennis at the end of 2024.\n\nThe 37-year-old suffered a first-round defeat to Alexander Zverev in what was likely his final French Open match, and revealed afterwards that he could miss Wimbledon in July.\n\nHaving previously hinted that 2024 could be his last year in tennis, Nadal's Roland Garros exit brought about emotional scenes as fans saluted his legacy at the tournament where he is a 14-time champion.\n\nIn a post-match speech to the Paris crowd, the Spaniard admitted he is unlikely to return to the clay court major.\n\nHe said: \"It's probably a big percentage that I will not be back playing here at Roland Garros, but I can't say 100 per cent.\"\n\nDespite casting doubt over his long-term future in the sport, Nadal shared his hopes of making another appearance on his favourite court in this summer's Paris Olympics, taking place at Roland Garros.\n\nHowever, the tennis legend admitted that his Paris dream could mean that he is forced to sacrifice taking part in Wimbledon, which starts on July 1.\n\nHaving struggled with persistent hip injuries since the beginning of 2023, Nadal explained that he is reluctant to switch to grass from clay, and then back again in time for the Olympics in August.\n\nWhen asked if he would compete in SW19, the 22-time Grand Slam champion told his post-match press conference: \"It looks difficult, honestly.\n\n\"I can't confirm what's going on, but it looks difficult to make the transition to grass, having the Olympics again on clay.\n\n\"I cannot confirm anything, I have to talk with the team to analyse so many facts.\n\n\"But I don't think it's going to be smart after all the things that happened to my body to make a big transition to a completely different surface and then come back immediately to clay. Today I feel that's not a good idea.\"\n\nWith Nadal a two-time Wimbledon winner, having tasted victory in London in both 2008 and 2010, this news will no doubt come as a disappointment to fans.\n\nBut they may well be slightly more understanding of the decision after hearing his exciting plans for his Roland Garros return in the summer.\n\nThe Beijing 2008 gold medallist is set to play Olympic doubles for Spain alongside reigning Wimbledon champion Carlos Alcaraz.\n\nNadal previously discussed the possibility on the Madrid Open's official podcast IGUALES in April, saying: \"I think if we're both fit enough, why not?\n\n\"We could have the chance to form a great team and aspire to great things. It'd be good for both of us. I think it'd also be good for the Spanish team, so we'll see how things progress.\"\n\nAnd Alcaraz, who was in the crowd for his compatriot's defeat to Zverev, confirmed the proposal after his first round French Open victory over J.J Wolf.\n\nHe revealed: \"If everything goes well, we are going to play doubles here.\"\n\nShould the budding partnership produce a positive result, it may well force Nadal to reconsider his earlier suggestion of retirement, having revealed that the decision is not yet set in stone.\n\nThe all-time great admitted: \"I don't know what's going to happen in the next few months. I need to finish all this process.\n\n\"My mindset was ready until Olympics and then I need to check how I feel in different ways in terms of personal motivation, body feelings, and then in terms of {"uri": "8148477084", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "16:44:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T16:44:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T16:42:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/tennis/french-open/fourteen-time-champion-rafael-nadal-knocked-out-in-french-open-first-round/articleshow/110473017.cms", "title": "Fourteen-time champion Rafael Nadal knocked out in French Open first round | Tennis News - Times of India", "body": "NEW DELHI: Rafa Nadal experienced his earliest exit from the French Open on Monday, falling 6-3, 7-6(5), 6-3 in the first round to fourth seed Alexander Zverev. This unexpected defeat has left fans questioning whether the 14-time champion will return to the Grand Slam he has dominated for two decades.\n\nThe 22-time major champion, who first claimed the Musketeers' Cup in 2005 and last lifted the trophy in 2022 before a serious hip injury disrupted his career, had hinted that this year might be his final one on the tour.\n\nHaving returned to the tournament that he skipped in 2023 and refusing to confirm any farewells ahead of his opener, Nadal showed flashes of top form again on Court Philippe Chatrier but the 37-year-old ultimately went down fighting.\n\nVictory meant Zverev became only the third man to beat Nadal at Roland Garros, after Novak Djokovic and Robin Soderling, with the German banishing memories of his retirement due to an ankle injury when the duo last met in the 2022 semi-finals.\n\nNadal was broken by in-form Rome champion Zverev in the opening game and surrendered his serve again late on to drop the first set in unfavourable conditions for him with the roof closed due to heavy rain.\n\nFaced with the prospect of only his fourth Roland Garros defeat in 116 matches, Nadal made a positive start to the next set as he leapt and pumped his fists after holding for 2-2 and broke for the first time with a delicate drop.\n\nThe crowd began to sense a comeback as Nadal went ahead 4-2 with some vintage shots on both flanks but the steely Zverev hit back in the 10th game and saved two breakpoints before doubling his advantage by edging a high-octane tiebreak.\n\nWatched on by his great rival Djokovic and a host of other current players, Nadal surged to a 2-0 lead in the third set but squandered it as Zverev drew level and dealt another body blow in the seventh game.\n\nThe boisterous crowd tried their best to roar Nadal on but Zverev held his nerve to clinch a famous victory that could well prove to be the springboard he needs to push for an elusive first Grand Slam title.\n\n(With inputs from {"uri": "2024-05-368104751", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-25", "time": "16:46:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-25T16:46:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-25T16:40:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport/article/2024/may/25/maybe-not-rafael-nadal-goes-cryptic-before-uncertain-french-open-tennis", "title": "'Maybe, maybe not': Nadal goes cryptic before uncertain French Open", "body": "With top seeds struggling or recently injured, the men's draw is hard to call while Swiatek has few serious rivals\n\nAs Rafael Nadal expressed his satisfaction at being able to return to Roland Garros once again, a flurry of laughter circled the room. This coming fortnight could be a truly significant moment, the 14-time champion's final appearance in Paris, and one that could well end with his first-round meeting against Alexander Zverev. In reality, though, not even Nadal has a clue if this is the end.\n\n\"Maybe the last one; maybe not,\" said Nadal, smiling. \"But let's explore. I hope to be clear. I don't want to create a big confusion, but I'm enjoying what I am doing. Sorry, but I am feeling competitive in the practices.\"\n\nNadal had been moved to explain why he could not be 100% certain that this would be his final appearance at the French Open, despite his own comments this year, after a recent awkward moment. After his farewell ceremony at the Madrid Open, Italian Open organisers had planned their own surprise event, but Nadal quickly left the court after his dire loss to Hubert Hurkacz and did not return.\n\nLater, he noted that he wasn't even sure that it would be his last appearance there. The French Tennis Federation may be well served to temper any plans for a grand farewell.\n\nA month ago in Barcelona, Nadal's future seemed grim. The 37-year-old had competed in just one tournament in the prior 15 months and he was still struggling physically in the days before the Madrid Open, unsure if his body would let him perform properly. But since then, he has been able to train and compete for four weeks without any significant physical problems.\n\nWith many hours spent on the court, Nadal has felt himself progressing. He said he is competitive with top players in practice matches and, as of this week, has finally been able to move with freedom. \"In some way I don't want to close 100% the door, because of a very simple thing,\" said Nadal.\n\n\"First thing, I am enjoying playing tennis. Second thing, I am travelling with the family. They are enjoying. I am enjoying sharing all this process with them. And third thing, I was not able to explore yet the proper way how I will be able to play being in more or less healthy conditions again, playing without limitation.\"\n\nIn a perfect world, this is a process that would have happened a few months earlier, allowing Nadal an opportunity to find his feet throughout the clay season before Roland Garros. But time is not on his side and Zverev, the fourth seed, awaits.\n\n\"It's a super tough first round,\" said Nadal. \"Maybe I repeat the disaster of Rome. It's a possibility, of course. I don't want to hide that. But in my mind is to do something different and play much better and give myself a chance to play competitively.\"\n\nBeyond Nadal, the men's draw is looking like the most open grand slam tournament in years. While Novak Djokovic, the top seed, is struggling badly with motivation and form, Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz, seeded second and third, arrived in Paris recovering from injuries. Among the rest of the field, whoever is healthy, bold and ready to produce their best tennis may be rewarded with the tournament of their life.\n\nAfter years of order in men's tennis and unpredictability in women's, their roles have reversed. This year, Iga Swiatek returns to Roland Garros as the overwhelming favourite, seeking her third consecutive French Open title and a fourth in her last five appearances. Swiatek has dominated the clay season, becoming the first player to win the Madrid-Rome double as a four-week format.\n\nIn both finals, Swiatek had to hold off Aryna Sabalenka, the world No 2 and clear second favourite, and their rivalry continues to grow. While the Madrid Open final was an instant classic, decided on a final-set tie-break after Sabalenka missed three match points, Rome was perhaps a better example of how difficult it is to hang with Swiatek in slower clay court conditions.\n\nElena Rybakina, the fourth seed, is clearly another contender after defeating Swiatek in the semi-finals of Stuttgart and narrowly losing a spectacular battle with Sabalenka in Madrid, but she appears to be struggling with her immune system recently as she has been unable to remain healthy. Coco Gauff, seeded third, has found her form in recent weeks but her 1-10 record against Swiatek is a monumental obstacle now she has been drawn in the Pole's half.\n\nBeyond the top four, the Americans Danielle Collins and Madison Keys stand as more peripheral contenders after their brilliant recent performances. Still, while there are numerous players performing at an extremely high level, it remains to be seen if anyone can slow down this era of dominance that Swiatek continues to establish in Paris.", {"uri": "8147159451", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "22:04:54", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T22:04:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T22:03:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://magicvalley.com/sports/professional/other/nadal-french-open-clay-tennis-atp-major/article_c78ddc69-4e9a-53bf-a18c-52de42de0dad.html", "title": "French Open cancels farewell ceremony for Nadal", "body": "PARIS -- The French tennis federation put off holding a ceremony to celebrate Rafael Nadal at Roland Garros this year, because he has said this might not necessarily be his final appearance at the tournament he has won a record 14 times.\n\nTournament director Am\u00e9lie Mauresmo said Sunday, Day 1 of the clay-court Grand Slam event, that Nadal let officials know he didn't want to close the door on a return before he told the world that at a pre-tournament news conference.\n\n\"As you can imagine, we had something planned for him. But ... because he doesn't know if it's going to be his last Roland Garros or not, he wants to leave the door open maybe to come back next year as a player. So we are not going to push him, obviously, to do anything,\" Mauresmo said.\n\n\"It's his decision when he wants to have a proper ceremony, a proper goodbye, a proper farewell. So we're not going to do it this year. That's his wish,\" she continued. \"And even though we were ready to push the button if something happens, we obviously are going to respect what he wants and make sure we are ready whenever he feels he wants to do it. Later this year; next year; anytime he wants.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... More choices: Food truck square opens in Twin Falls Jerome Pizza Factory rising to the occasion 6 people killed, 10 others injured in Idaho Falls when pickup crashes into passenger van Death Notices Blaine, Camas and Cassia County 2024 unofficial results are in Death Notices Dixon, Hartgen, Lanting fall in primaries; unofficial primary election results Gooding, Jerome and Lincoln County 2024 unofficial results are in Kimberly sweeps SCIC baseball, softball MVP awards Jerome's Autumn Allen leads Great Basin Conference baseball, softball honorees Death Notices Minidoka, Twin Falls County unofficial results are in Rosters set for 46th annual District IV Shrine Game Twin Falls County Most Wanted Kimberly's Peyton Bair qualifies for 2nd straight NCAA Outdoor Track & Field Championships\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3 and has said previously he expects this to be his last season, will face No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev in the first round on Monday. The match is scheduled to be third in the main stadium, Court Philippe Chatrier, and could start at around 3:30 p.m. local time (9:30 a.m. EDT).\n\nHere are some answers to questions about Nadal and Zverev:\n\nWhy are top players like Nadal and Zverev meeting in the first round?\n\nDespite having such a dominant record at the French Open, Nadal was not seeded and so could have been placed anywhere in the bracket and been stuck playing anyone at all, even the very best opponents. Because of injuries, including a surgically repaired hip and problematic abdominal muscle, Nadal has competed little the past two seasons, going only 7-4 in 2024, and so someone who has been ranked No. 1 and spent more than a decade inside the top 10 is now outside the top 250.\n\nWhy isn't Nadal seeded?\n\nThis is Nadal's first Grand Slam tournament without a seeding since the 2005 Australian Open. The top 32 players in the men's and women's draws are seeded, and the seedings are based on the ATP and WTA rankings, which take into account the most recent 52 weeks of results. In theory, Mauresmo could have opted to circumvent the rules and go ahead and award a seeding to Nadal based on his past performances in Paris. But that was never really considered, she said, in part because \"giving protection to some players\" would result in \"a lot of other issues and problems,\" and because \"it also has to be OK with other Grand Slams and everything.\"\n\nWhat difference do seedings make?\n\nPlayers who are seeded, such as Zverev, are guaranteed to avoid going up against another seeded player any earlier than the third round of a Grand Slam tournament, which have 128-player fields and require seven victories to earn a championship.\n\nWhat do other players think?\n\nPlayers tend to agree with Mauresmo's decision, with several saying they believe the seeding system should remain the way it currently is (Wimbledon used to seed players according to their results on grass courts, but has strictly followed the rankings since 2021). \"The way that the seedings work, I think it's appropriate. In this case, it's unfortunate how that happened, but I don't know how you gauge where someone should and shouldn't be seeded based on past or previous success,\" said three-time major champion Andy Murray. \"It'd be quite hard to do that.\"\n\nWho is Alexander Zverev?\n\nHe is a leading player in men's tennis, one who is coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open, won a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics and was the 2020 U.S. Open runner-up. He reached the semifinals at the French Open each of the past three years, including in 2022, when he played Nadal at that stage but had to stop after tearing ligaments in his right foot during the match. Zverev, a 27-year-old from Germany, is about to face a court proceeding that starts next week in Berlin related to accusations of physically abusing an ex-girlfriend. He does not need to be in court and said he will not be. \"At the end of the day, I do believe in the German system. I do believe in the truth, as well. I have to be certain that, you know, I do know what I did, I do know what I didn't do,\" Zverev said. \"That's, at the end of the day, what's going to come out, and I have to trust in that.\"\n\nWhy is Zverev allowed to play during his ongoing court case?\n\nMauresmo was asked Sunday about Zverev's status and replied: \"As long as the trial isn't finished and there isn't a decision, he's considered innocent and so that's why he's allowed to be part of the draw.\"\n\nAP Sports Week in Pictures: Caitlin Clark's debut, Fury on the ropes and golf's winning shot 0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Despite a premature exit from the French Open, Nadal remains focused on preparing for the Olympic Games. He shares his thoughts on physical setbacks, possible transitions, and his ultimate goal of winning another gold medal.\n\nRafa Nadal likened his struggles with injury in the last 18 months to being in a jungle as the 14-times French Open champion hoped to return to Roland Garros for the Olympic Games after making a premature exit from the Grand Slam on Monday.\n\nNever far from physical issues in his glittering career, the 37-year-old missed almost all of 2023 with a hip problem and his comeback earlier this year was stalled by a muscle tear, before small niggles affected his preparation for the claycourt major. Nadal crashed to a 6-3 7-6(5) 6-3 defeat by fourth seed Alexander Zverev in Paris and although there were positives, he said he could not predict how his battered body would respond to the demands of the Games in July and August.\n\n\"My body has been a jungle for two years. You don't know what to expect. I wake up one day and I find a snake biting me. Another day a tiger,\" Nadal told a packed press conference following his earliest exit from Roland Garros. \"I've been fighting with all the things that I went through. But the dynamic is positive the last few weeks. I felt ready. I think tomorrow I'll be ready to play again if I have to. But I will not have to.\n\n\"So that's the thing. Now, I need to prepare myself, I need to clear my ideas and see what's the new calendar to try to be ready for Olympics. I can't say anything today, but my main goal now is to play the Olympics.\" Nadal will be eyeing his third gold medal after triumphing in singles in the 2008 Beijing Games and doubles eight years later in Rio.\n\nHe had expressed doubts about his fitness ahead of what is likely his final French Open. \"Today in the match, I felt I was able to move myself much better than in the previous tournaments. But I had a very tough opponent in front of me. He played well,\" Nadal added.\n\n\"I had my chances... I mean, I wasn't that far. That's my feeling. That's probably my truth... I played at a good level in all ways, comparing to the way I was playing the weeks before. So, happy for that. \"Of course disappointed to lose, but in terms of body feelings, I'm happy that I finished healthy and I had a tough battle out there. And I was ready for a little bit more.\"\n\nNadal said it would be unwise to prepare for the grasscourt season that follows with a potentially difficult transition back to clay for the Olympics. \"It looks difficult, honestly. For me now I can't confirm what's going on, but it looks difficult to make a transition to grass, having the Olympics again on clay,\" Nadal said.\n\n\"I need to talk with the team. I need to analyse so many facts. But I don't think it's going to be smart after all the things that happened to my body to make a big transition to a completely different surface and then come back to clay. \"Today I feel that's not a good idea, but I can't confirm. But my feelings is even if I'm booked in Wimbledon because I had to, I don't think it's a positive idea right now.\"\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from {"uri": "8146712978", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "13:50:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T13:50:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T13:49:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.daytondailynews.com/nation-world/why-did-the-french-open-cancel-a-farewell-ceremony-for-rafael-nadal-and-why-is-he-unseeded/4CKBQEDEANCPRMFWM6OTRAHYGQ/", "title": "Why did the French Open cancel a farewell ceremony for Rafael Nadal? And why is he unseeded?", "body": "Tournament director Am\u00e9lie Mauresmo said Sunday, Day 1 of the clay-court Grand Slam event, that Nadal let officials know he didn't want to close the door on a return before he told the world that at a pre-tournament news conference.\n\n\"As you can imagine, we had something planned for him. But ... because he doesn't know if it's going to be his last Roland Garros or not, he wants to leave the door open maybe to come back next year as a player. So we are not going to push him, obviously, to do anything,\" Mauresmo said.\n\n\"It's his decision when he wants to have a proper ceremony, a proper goodbye, a proper farewell. So we're not going to do it this year. That's his wish,\" she continued. \"And even though we were ready to push the button if something happens, we obviously are going to respect what he wants and make sure we are ready whenever he feels he wants to do it. Later this year; next year; anytime he wants.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3 and has said previously he expects this to be his last season, will face No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev in the first round on Monday.\n\nHere are some answers to questions about Nadal and Zverev:\n\nDespite having such a dominant record at the French Open, Nadal was not seeded and so could have been placed anywhere in the bracket and been stuck playing anyone at all, even the very best opponents. Because of injuries, including a surgically repaired hip and problematic abdominal muscle, Nadal has competed little the past two seasons, going only 7-4 in 2024, and so someone who has been ranked No. 1 and spent more than a decade inside the top 10 is now outside the top 250.\n\nThis is Nadal's first Grand Slam tournament without a seeding since the 2005 Australian Open. The top 32 players in the men's and women's draws are seeded, and the seedings are based on the ATP and WTA rankings, which take into account the most recent 52 weeks of results. In theory, Mauresmo could have opted to circumvent the rules and go ahead and award a seeding to Nadal based on his past performances in Paris. But that was never really considered, she said, in part because \"giving protection to some players\" would result in \"a lot of other issues and problems,\" and because \"it also has to be OK with other Grand Slams and everything.\"\n\nPlayers who are seeded, such as Zverev, are guaranteed to avoid going up against another seeded player any earlier than the third round of a Grand Slam tournament, which have 128-player fields and require seven victories to earn a championship.\n\nPlayers tend to agree with Mauresmo's decision, with several saying they believe the seeding system should remain the way it currently is (Wimbledon used to seed players according to their results on grass courts, but has strictly followed the rankings since 2021). \"The way that the seedings work, I think it's appropriate. In this case, it's unfortunate how that happened, but I don't know how you gauge where someone should and shouldn't be seeded based on past or previous success,\" said three-time major champion Andy Murray. \"It'd be quite hard to do that.\"\n\nHe is a leading player in men's tennis, one who is coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open, won a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics and was the 2020 U.S. Open runner-up. He reached the semifinals at the French Open each of the past three years, including in 2022, when he played Nadal at that stage but had to stop after tearing ligaments in his right foot during the match. Zverev, a 27-year-old from Germany, is about to face a court proceeding that starts next week in Berlin related to accusations of physically abusing an ex-girlfriend. He does not need to be in court and said he will not be. \"At the end of the day, I do believe in the German system. I do believe in the truth, as well. I have to be certain that, you know, I do know what I did, I do know what I didn't do,\" Zverev said. \"That's, at the end of the day, what's going to come out, and I have to trust in that.\"\n\nMauresmo was asked Sunday about Zverev's status and replied: \"As long as the trial isn't finished and there isn't a decision, he's considered innocent and so that's why he's allowed to be part of the draw.\"\n\n___\n\nHoward Fendrich has been the AP's tennis writer since 2002. {"uri": "8147128544", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "21:23:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T21:23:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T21:19:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://qctimes.com/sports/professional/other/nadal-french-open-clay-tennis-atp-major/article_c608cd25-2fe5-5bbe-8e4f-6f002d4b181b.html", "title": "French Open cancels farewell ceremony for Nadal", "body": "PARIS -- The French tennis federation put off holding a ceremony to celebrate Rafael Nadal at Roland Garros this year, because he has said this might not necessarily be his final appearance at the tournament he has won a record 14 times.\n\nTournament director Am\u00e9lie Mauresmo said Sunday, Day 1 of the clay-court Grand Slam event, that Nadal let officials know he didn't want to close the door on a return before he told the world that at a pre-tournament news conference.\n\n\"As you can imagine, we had something planned for him. But ... because he doesn't know if it's going to be his last Roland Garros or not, he wants to leave the door open maybe to come back next year as a player. So we are not going to push him, obviously, to do anything,\" Mauresmo said.\n\n\"It's his decision when he wants to have a proper ceremony, a proper goodbye, a proper farewell. So we're not going to do it this year. That's his wish,\" she continued. \"And even though we were ready to push the button if something happens, we obviously are going to respect what he wants and make sure we are ready whenever he feels he wants to do it. Later this year; next year; anytime he wants.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Quad-Cities weather updates: Q-C under severe thunderstorm watch until 9 p.m. Meta named as company considering Davenport for data center; state board OKs incentives Quad-Cities business openings, closings: Disc Replay, Starbucks Orion School Board hears complaints of book being removed from curriculum Hy-Vee responds to concerns over closing Iowa stores, offers measures to ease transition Weather blog: Tornado watch expires for Quad-Cities area Davenport man arrested for May 5 Moline double homicide Will charges be brought in Davenport building collapse? Investigative report to prosecutor Deere announces 190 new layoffs in Waterloo after idling 308 workers in April Man crashes vintage replica hot rod into Waterloo library moments after purchase 'We will find you': Moline police arrest man accused of post-prom double murder Davenport woman accused of double murder moved to Marshall County Jail Quad-Cities business openings, closings: Wolfe It Down, Azteca 3 and more Man shot Friday by East Moline police has died; authorities name man, officers involved Quad City Bank & Trust CEO John Anderson to retire\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3 and has said previously he expects this to be his last season, will face No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev in the first round on Monday. The match is scheduled to be third in the main stadium, Court Philippe Chatrier, and could start at around 3:30 p.m. local time (9:30 a.m. EDT).\n\nHere are some answers to questions about Nadal and Zverev:\n\nWhy are top players like Nadal and Zverev meeting in the first round?\n\nDespite having such a dominant record at the French Open, Nadal was not seeded and so could have been placed anywhere in the bracket and been stuck playing anyone at all, even the very best opponents. Because of injuries, including a surgically repaired hip and problematic abdominal muscle, Nadal has competed little the past two seasons, going only 7-4 in 2024, and so someone who has been ranked No. 1 and spent more than a decade inside the top 10 is now outside the top 250.\n\nWhy isn't Nadal seeded?\n\nThis is Nadal's first Grand Slam tournament without a seeding since the 2005 Australian Open. The top 32 players in the men's and women's draws are seeded, and the seedings are based on the ATP and WTA rankings, which take into account the most recent 52 weeks of results. In theory, Mauresmo could have opted to circumvent the rules and go ahead and award a seeding to Nadal based on his past performances in Paris. But that was never really considered, she said, in part because \"giving protection to some players\" would result in \"a lot of other issues and problems,\" and because \"it also has to be OK with other Grand Slams and everything.\"\n\nWhat difference do seedings make?\n\nPlayers who are seeded, such as Zverev, are guaranteed to avoid going up against another seeded player any earlier than the third round of a Grand Slam tournament, which have 128-player fields and require seven victories to earn a championship.\n\nWhat do other players think?\n\nPlayers tend to agree with Mauresmo's decision, with several saying they believe the seeding system should remain the way it currently is (Wimbledon used to seed players according to their results on grass courts, but has strictly followed the rankings since 2021). \"The way that the seedings work, I think it's appropriate. In this case, it's unfortunate how that happened, but I don't know how you gauge where someone should and shouldn't be seeded based on past or previous success,\" said three-time major champion Andy Murray. \"It'd be quite hard to do that.\"\n\nWho is Alexander Zverev?\n\nHe is a leading player in men's tennis, one who is coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open, won a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics and was the 2020 U.S. Open runner-up. He reached the semifinals at the French Open each of the past three years, including in 2022, when he played Nadal at that stage but had to stop after tearing ligaments in his right foot during the match. Zverev, a 27-year-old from Germany, is about to face a court proceeding that starts next week in Berlin related to accusations of physically abusing an ex-girlfriend. He does not need to be in court and said he will not be. \"At the end of the day, I do believe in the German system. I do believe in the truth, as well. I have to be certain that, you know, I do know what I did, I do know what I didn't do,\" Zverev said. \"That's, at the end of the day, what's going to come out, and I have to trust in that.\"\n\nWhy is Zverev allowed to play during his ongoing court case?\n\nMauresmo was asked Sunday about Zverev's status and replied: \"As long as the trial isn't finished and there isn't a decision, he's considered innocent and so that's why he's allowed to be part of the draw.\"\n\nAP Sports Week in Pictures: Caitlin Clark's debut, Fury on the ropes and golf's winning shot 0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0
