{"uri": "8145696012", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-25", "time": "17:56:35", "dateTime": "2024-05-25T17:56:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-25T17:55:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/tennis/zverev-federer-nadal-french-open-32893078", "title": "Zverev left Roger Federer's ex-coach upset for 'trash talking' Rafael Nadal", "body": "Alexander Zverev was once slammed for allegedly tarnishing Rafael Nadal's reputation with some fiery \"trash talk\".\n\nAs they gear up to face off in the first round of this year's French Open, fans are buzzing with anticipation for another electrifying encounter. The drama traces back to the 2022 semi-finals at Roland Garros, where Zverev, then 27, endured a devastating ankle injury three hours into his battle against Nadal.\n\nThis injury sidelined him for the remainder of the year, while Nadal, a decade older, went on to secure his 14th French Open title and a record-breaking 22nd Grand Slam trophy. Zverev stirred controversy when he expressed to Eurosport that it \"could have been the week\" he clinched his first major title, quickly clarifying he didn't mean to come off as arrogant.\n\nThis sparked a cheeky retort from Ivan Ljubicic, ex-world No.3 and Roger Federer's coach for six years, who mocked Zverev's confidence about his prospects in Paris. \"Nobody wants to sound arrogant but everyone is claiming to have almost won Roland Garros last year,\" Ljubicic quipped on social media in 2023, punctuating his comment with a crying-with-laughter emoji and adding, \"Love it! On with trash talk!\"\n\nDespite the setback, Roland Garros remains Zverev's preferred slam, having reached the semi-finals for three consecutive years. His performance at this year's Australian Open, where he made it to the semi-finals, has largely dispelled concerns over any lingering effects from his 2022 injury, reports the Express.\n\nLjubicic didn't hold back in his critique, especially given that Nadal was leading 7-6(8), 6-6 when their match was abruptly stopped. Zverev, who has clinched three wins out of ten against Nadal, has shown commendable resilience after a severe injury, yet he's still chasing his first major title and the world No.1 spot.\n\nOver the past year, Nadal's form has notably dipped, participating in only one Grand Slam in 2023. His early exit in Melbourne was followed by a series of injuries, sparking rumours of an impending retirement. A difficult draw was always on the cards for Nadal - who returned to his stomping ground with a protected ranking - but even Zverev was shocked by the news.\n\n\"I actually thought [my brother] was joking in the beginning,\" Zverev shared with journalists, reflecting on his initial reaction to the draw. \"But then, yeah, it is what it is. I mean, obviously, to be very honest, I wanted to play Rafa again in my career, in his career, because I didn't want my last memory of me playing against Rafa to be me leaving the court in a wheelchair.\n\n\"Ideally, I would have liked to play him in the latter stage of the tournament. It's a tough draw, but it's a tough draw for both of us. We'll see how it goes on Monday.\"\n\nZverev is tipped to be the favourite in their upcoming clash, but Nadal will be keen to avoid a first-round exit from the French Open for the first time in his career. The Parisian tournament promises to deliver some thrilling moments in the coming weeks, with this match-up already shaping up to be one of the most exciting openers.\n\nDON'T SCRAP REPLAYS!Join our petition to keep the magic of the FA Cup alive!\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp communityand receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. Photograph: Gonzalo Fuentes/Reuters\n\nFourteen-time French Open champion Rafael Nadal said there was still a chance this year's tournament in Paris may not be his last, in comments ahead of his tough opener against fourth seed Alexander Zverev.\n\nThe Spaniard, who turns 38 next month, skipped last year's tournament due to a hip injury that needed surgery and has said he expects to retire at the end of 2024.\n\nBut he wasn't ready to repeat those words on Saturday.\n\n\"If I have to tell you it's 100% my last Roland Garros, sorry but I will not, because I cannot predict what's going on. I hope you understand,\" Nadal told a packed press conference.\n\n\"I don't want to close 100% the door, because it's a very simple thing. First, I'm enjoying playing tennis,\" he said, adding that he was \"more or less healthy .. and playing without limitation\".\n\n\"Maybe in one month and a half I'll say 'OK, it's enough, I can't keep going'. But today I cannot guarantee that it's going to be the last one.\"\n\nNadal skipped the Australian Open in January with a muscle problem, and the 22-times Grand Slam champion had raised doubts about his fitness for the year's second major with lingering issues in Barcelona, Madrid and Rome.\n\n\"I'm feeling better. That's the truth. Not because I'm here,\" Nadal added, appearing more cheerful than he has in recent months.\n\n\"Probably because we did things to try to feel better and we have been working without a stop to keep going with the process, to try to arrive here in a proper way.\"\n\nNadal turned his attention to Monday's clash with Zverev, a rematch of the 2022 semi-final when the German retired after an ankle injury.\n\n\"It's a super-tough first round. Maybe I go there and I repeat the disaster of Rome. It's a possibility. I don't want to hide that,\" Nadal said, referring to a second-round defeat by Hubert Hurkacz in the Italian capital this month.\n\n\"But in my mind is something different, play much better and give myself a chance to be competitive... {"uri": "8145588545", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-25", "time": "16:03:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-25T16:03:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-25T16:02:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://bdnews24.com/sport/03d7a7e395a1", "title": "Nadal says 2024 may not be his last French Open, ahead of Zverev showdown", "body": "The Spaniard, who turns 38 next month, skipped last year's tournament due to a hip injury\n\nFourteen-time French Open champion Rafa Nadal said there was still a chance this year's tournament in Paris may not be his last, in comments ahead of his tough opener against fourth seed Alexander Zverev.\n\nThe Spaniard, who turns 38 next month, skipped last year's tournament due to a hip injury that needed surgery and has said he expects to retire at the end of 2024.\n\nBut he wasn't ready to repeat those words on Saturday.\n\n\"If I have to tell you it's 100% my last Roland Garros, sorry but I will not, because I cannot predict what's going on. {"uri": "8148863876", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "23:45:49", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T23:45:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T23:41:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.nation.com.pk/28-May-2024/nadal-out-of-possible-last-french-open-swiatek-through", "title": "Nadal out of possible last French Open, Swiatek through", "body": "PARIS - Rafael Nadal's illustrious French Open career came to a likely end with his first ever defeat in the opening round by Alexander Zverev on Monday, after Iga Swiatek made a winning start in her bid for a fourth title. Nadal matched world number four Zverev for long periods on a packed Court Philippe Chatrier, but slipped to a 6-3, 7-6 (7/5), 6-3 loss as he was beaten for just the fourth time in 116 matches at the tournament. This year's event was expected to be the 14-time champion's farewell to Roland Garros, but he had since insisted he could not confirm \"100 percent\" it would be his last appearance. \"If it is (the last time), then you have been amazing,\" Nadal told an adoring crowd unde place I love the most.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 next week, showed all his trademark fighting qualities in a gripping match, but only managed to convert two of 11 break points against an inspired opponent. \"The first round wasn't ideal,\" he admitted, before saying he \"hoped\" to be back at Roland Garros later this summer for the Paris Olympics. \"It's hard to say about the future. I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. The body is feeling better than it did two months ago.\"\n\nGerman Zverev proved too strong despite the fans desperately attempting to raise Nadal to past glories. He banished the memories of the duo's last meeting, when he left Chatrier court on a wheelchair after injuring his ankle during their 2022 French Open semi-final. His reward for becoming just the third player to defeat Nadal at Roland Garros -- after Novak Djokovic and Robin Soderling -- is a match against either David Goffin or home wildcard Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard. Women's world No 1 Swiatek raced to a 6-1, 6-2 victory against French qualifier Leolia Jeanjean after just 61 minutes on Court Philippe Chatrier. The Pole will next face fellow four-time major champion Naomi Osaka on Wednesday. Australian Open champion Jannik Sinner started his title tilt with a confident 6-3, 6-3, 6-4 win over Wimbledon quarter-finalist Christopher Eubanks.\n\nThe Italian second seed, who withdrew from the Madrid Open and missed the Rome Open with a hip injury, set up a second-round meeting with French veteran Richard Gasquet. Former finalist Stefanos Tsitsipas beat Marton Fucsovics of Hungary 7-6 (9/7), 6-4, 6-1. Women's third seed Coco Gauff raced through in just 52 minutes by crushing Russian Julia Avdeeva 6-1, 6-1. She will face Slovenian qualifier Tamara Zidansek for a place in the last 32. Marketa Vondrousova eased past Rebeka Masarova of Spain in straight sets. No, I am focused on trying to play well. That's it,\" said Nadal.\n\n\"Maybe I go there and I repeat the disaster of Rome. It's a possibility, of course. I don't want to hide that.\n\n\"But in my mind, is do something different and play much better and give myself a chance to play competitive.\"\n\n- 'Didn't want' to play Nadal -\n\nZverev did not play again in 2022 after that ankle injury but has climbed the rankings again in recent months.\n\nThe 27-year-old has long been touted as a future Grand Slam champion but remains without one of tennis' four biggest titles.\n\nClay is his strongest surface, though, and he has reached the semi-finals in each of the last three years at Roland Garros.\n\nThe men's draw looks far more open than usual, with doubts surrounding Nadal's fitness and Novak Djokovic having endured a turbulent start to the year.\n\n\"I can guarantee you Novak didn't want to play Rafa in the first round and (Carlos) Alcaraz didn't want to play, Jannik (Sinner) didn't want to play him,\" admitted Zverev.\n\n\"I don't want to play him in the first round, but it is how it is.\"\n\n\"I'm really happy to be back. Feel like I'm playing really good tennis so hoping to be here as long as possible,\" said Swiatek.\n\nThe Italian star struck 33 winners and broke Eubanks' serve five times as he set up a second-round meeting with French veteran Richard Gasquet.\n\n\"The hip is good, I'm very happy,\" said Sinner. \"The general shape isn't at 100 percent yet so we're trying to build every day.\"\n\nMarketa Vondrousova, a former Roland Garros runner-up and reigning Wimbledon champion, eased past Rebeka Masarova of Spain in straight sets before rain fell in Paris.\n\nTunisian eighth seed Ons Jabeur also {"uri": "8149673224", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "11:06:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T11:06:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T11:04:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/2952736-rafa-nadals-french-open-farewell-sparks-olympic-hopes", "title": "Rafa Nadal's French Open Farewell Sparks Olympic Hopes | Sports-Games", "body": "Rafa Nadal, despite a strong performance, lost to Alexander Zverev at the French Open. Former champions praise his effort and the possibility of him competing in the Paris Olympics. Nadal's fans were given hope of his return to Roland Garros after he expressed newfound confidence and pain-free play.\n\nRafa Nadal's level of tennis during his French Open defeat by Alexander Zverev on Monday would have earned him victory against the vast majority of players in the draw, according to former Roland Garros champion Mats Wilander. The 37-year-old Spaniard, who missed almost all of 2023 with injuries, went down in straight sets to the fourth-seed German as Zverev became only the third player to beat the 14-time champion on the Parisian clay.\n\nIn what was possibly his last match at the tournament he has dominated for almost two decades, Nadal showed flashes of his former brilliance and has made no secret of targeting a return to Roland Garros for this year's Paris Olympics. He also offered some hope to his legions of fans that he might extend his career a little longer.\n\nWilander said the prospect of him playing at the Olympics was exciting. \"Obviously the Olympics are huge and for him to have the chance to play here on Philippe Chatrier is amazing and could be an unbelievable end to his career,\" Wilander told Eurosport.\n\n\"I think he beats 90% of the draw today. There's only a few guys that would beat him playing this well. And Zverev was the worst opponent possible in the first round, worse than playing (Novak) Djokovic, worse than playing (Carlos) Alcaraz.\" Wilander said the fact the roof on Philippe Chatrier was closed for the match worked against Nadal.\n\n\"The circumstances, it's indoor, cold outside, the ball doesn't travel. So I think all that, and still being so close it's all positive for Rafa and with that passion, why not. He knows how to win big matches on this court,\" the Swede said. Alex Corretja, the former world number two, said he had detected a change in heart from his compatriot Nadal.\n\n\"I spoke to him a couple of months ago and he was sure he wouldn't be back (at the French Open),\" Corretja told Eurosport. \"But then I spoke to him a week ago, and he said to me it's the first time I've been practising here at Roland Garros that I feel no pain. He said he felt so good on the court and that his tennis is growing and doesn't see any reason why he can't come back at least one more time.\n\n\"But he also said, it depends how I play. If I play awful against Zverev, maybe I won't come back. But the way he played, I believe he will think why not come back.\"\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8148081834", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "12:05:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T12:05:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T12:04:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://thesportsrush.com/tennis-news-rafael-nadal-likely-to-sustain-all-time-money-record-even-if-loses-first-round-french-open-2024-novak-djokovic-roger-federer/", "title": "Rafael Nadal Likely to Sustain Major All Time Money Record in Tennis Even if He Loses First Round of French Open 2024; Here's How", "body": "Oct 11, 2020; Paris, France; Rafael Nadal (ESP) poses with the trophy after his match against Novak Djokovic (SRB) on day 15 at Stade Roland Garros. Mandatory Credit: Susan Mullane-USA TODAY Sports\n\nWhether or not Rafael Nadal is the GOAT can be debated. However, there is absolutely no doubt that Nadal will always have a special place in the sport for winning a Grand Slam 14 times, a tournament which has never been won by legends like Pete Sampras, Andy Murray, Boris Becker and Stefan Edberg. And as a result of this incredible achievement, the Spaniard collected almost $27 million in prize money.\n\nThese 14 victories at Roland Garros are responsible for the Raging Bull to win nearly 20% of his entire career earnings from just one tournament. The Mallorca native emerged as an elite player on the ATP Tour during the 2005 season.\n\nLifting the French Open 2005 trophy was the most surreal moment for the youngster. With the virtue of defeating Mariano Puerta 6-7, 6-3, 6-1, 7-5, the southpaw took home $1,064,800 (approx.).\n\nNadal made sure that no one could dub his 2005 title win a \"fluke\" by lifting the La Coupe des Mousquetaires for another 3 years in a row. The sum total of the prize money he earned for the 2006, 2007, and 2008 victories was $4,084,400 (approx.).\n\nAfter suffering a shocking loss in 2009, Nadal turned to his winning ways from 2010 onwards. It seemed as if his first loss in Paris in almost five years hurt him deeply, as he would go on to win at the Court Philippe-Chatrier for 5 years on the trot. Winning the Grand Slam from 2010-2014 allowed him to collect $9,434,044 in his kitty.\n\nDue to the several injuries he sustained in 2015 and 2016, Rafa had a dip in his production. However, he managed to silence his naysayers by winning the French Open four times in a row. The 2022 edition was the latest French Open that Nadal won. His earnings in each of those years were - $2,352,414 (2017), $2,592,475 (2018), $2,710,315 (2019), $1,894,332 (2020), and $2,290,354 (2022), as per Perfect Tennis.\n\nRemarkably, Rafael Nadal is the player to have won the most amount of prize money from one tournament. Nadal is easily ahead of Novak Djokovic, who has won the Australian Open 10 times.\n\nThe Spaniard has also earned more than double of what Roger Federer did for winning Wimbledon 8 times. It is astounding more so because the French Open is the lowest-paying out of the 4 Grand Slams in tennis.\n\nRoger Federer won more Wimbledon titles than any other player ever - 8 times. In total, these 8 victories accumulate $11,507,580 in prize money. While the amount is still astronomical, it is worth noting that there is an almost $15 million difference compared to Rafael Nadal's French Open title-winning years' amount.\n\nNovak Djokovic won the Australian Open 10 times - 9 of them being in the 2010s and 2020s - and earned a whopping $22,927,935. Despite the Happy Slam giving the highest prize money out of three events, Djoko's figure is still almost $4 million less than Nadal's above-mentioned amount.\n\nSo even if Rafael Nadal loses his first round match against Alexander Zverev on Monday at the French Open 2024, it is unlikely that Novak Djokovic breaches this all-time Grand Slam money record at the Australian Open. A tough, expected challenge, which however attracted some criticism towards the tournament director Amelie Mauresmo, who would not have protected Rafa from a very tough first round.\n\nTo respond to the criticism, Mauresmo gave an interview to the French newspaper Le Figaro, in which she talked about the men's draw, obviously focusing on the match between Zverev and Nadal and on the other great match in the first round between Andy Murray and Stan Wawrinka. Amelie explained why Rafael Nadal was not granted top seed status, which would have prevented a challenge against a top player in the first round.\n\n\"We knew that it could happen that we had Nadal against Zverev or Nadal against one of the top players in the world already in the first round. Zverev demonstrated in Rome that he is in excellent form, I imagine that Rafa will not have been happy with the draw, but he is a warrior like no other and knows this court well and the long distance of the five sets there was this semi-final which ended with Zverev's very serious injury,\" she explained.\n\nCriticism has been raised by many for the failure to grant Nadal top seed status. Many fans claimed that an exception could have been made for a 14-time Roland Garros winner.\n\n\"If we could, we would have done it. But protecting him would have solved some problems, but it would have brought many more. Even Wimbledon stopped working like that several years ago. It's sport, everything is possible. There are also other wonderful first rounds like Wawrinka vs. Murray match between these two great veterans, it's another extraordinary match,\" she told.\n\nWe recall Mauresmo talked about to when {"uri": "8148499615", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "17:01:22", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T17:01:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T17:00:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.marca.com/en/tennis/roland-garros-/2024/05/27/6654b69022601d0c1f8b456f.html", "title": "Rafa Nadal bids farewell to Paris as a legend after falling to Zverev", "body": "While only Nadal and his body know if this is a definitive goodbye, all signs seemed to point in that direction.\n\nNadal gave his all to compete in the best possible condition, but it wasn't enough against a superior opponent. With his current ranking of 275, Nadal faces a future of challenging matches against top-ranked players from the very beginning of tournaments.\n\nThe elite level of competition is among the top 32, making it difficult for anyone ranked lower to progress without significant struggle.\n\nZverev's victory makes him only the third player to defeat Nadal at Roland Garros, following Robin Soderling and Novak Djokovic. This was only the second time Nadal lost in his debut match at a major tournament.\n\nThe 15,000 spectators at Philippe Chatrier supported him wholeheartedly. Gone are the days when the crowd was against him, as they were from 2005 to 2008, preferring Roger Federer.\n\nMarc Maury, the tournament's historic announcer, nearly lost his voice recounting all of Nadal's achievements on Parisian soil.\n\nZverev won the first game decisively, exposing Nadal's lack of lateral mobility and struggles with his serve, highlighted by a double fault.\n\nThe heavy ground, a result of rain that forced the match indoors, did not favor Nadal. Despite Zverev's immense talent, his mental fragility remains a concern, despite his 22 titles, including an Olympic gold at the Tokyo Games.\n\nNadal desperately sought to find his rhythm but struggled with his backhand, weakened since his hip surgery.\n\nAfter 13 minutes, he managed to win his first game, which sent the crowd into a frenzy. His supporters, including his father Sebastian, his brothers Miquel Angel, Rafael, and Toni (his mentor), his mother Ana Mar\u00eda, his sister Maribel, and his wife Mery Perello, packed the stands as if it were a final.\n\nNadal's last best-of-five match was in January 2023 against Mackenzie McDonald at the Australian Open, where he ended up injured. Time favored Zverev, who had a chance to close the second set at 2-1 with a break point but failed, allowing Nadal to break his serve and take the lead.\n\nThe second set saw Zverev miss his chance to close, leading to a tiebreak where he eventually prevailed. Only four times in his career had Nadal overcome a two-set deficit, none of which were at nearly 38 years old.\n\nThe last time was at the Australian Open 2022 against Daniil Medvedev, but the miracle did not repeat in Paris.\n\nThe atmosphere resembled a Davis Cup match, with passionate support and tension. A psychological battle ensued as they crossed paths at the net during changeovers, with Nadal insisting on passing last, a ritual his opponent tried to disrupt.\n\nNadal indeed remained competitive and fought valiantly. He saved two break points in the opening game of the third set and briefly led 2-0. However, Zverev's relentless cross-court backhand eventually wore him down.\n\nNadal's last stand saw him fighting for each service game, staying alive until the seventh game of the third set. {"uri": "8148464687", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "16:34:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T16:34:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T16:34:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5521908/2024/05/27/rafael-nadal-alexander-zverev-french-open/", "title": "No miracle on Chatrier: Nadal loses fourth match in 18 years at French Open", "body": "PARIS, France -- There will be no magical run, no age- and injury-defying push into the deep end of the competition.\n\nRafael Nadal, who ruled the red clay of Roland Garros as no one ever imagined someone could, exited the French Open for what is likely his final time early Monday evening, showered with an outpouring of love and admiration he earned during a nearly two-decade reign, over a tournament that became as much a part of his identity as anything in sport has for any athlete.\n\nThe end officially arrived at 6:28, with a final miss off the Spaniard's racket, forced by Alexander Zverev, who prevailed 6-3, 7-6, 6-3.\n\nIn reality it was over far earlier than that, during the first shots of the match when it became clear that, despite all the talk of magic and possibility, this version of Nadal, though still capable of flashes of his old self, was something far different than the one who won 112 of 115 matches and 14 championships here.\n\nMore than 15,000 fans packed into every nook of Court Philippe-Chatrier. A clump of two-dozen that is used to getting choice seats clogged the entryway to the president's box. In the upper reaches of the stadium, they crouched on stairways. In the fancy areas, the luxury suites and club rooms, the bartenders had little to do, their customers too focused on the thing everyone wanted from this day -- the last glimpses of Nadal bull-whipping his forehands, short-hopping volleys off the dirt, and skipping his way into those roof-raising windmill fist-pumps in the court where he had more occasion to do them than anywhere else.\n\nFor more than an hour there wasn't much of any of that, then suddenly there was plenty, a glorious burst of vintage Nadal running around his backhand to blast a forehand and push Zverev deep, perfectly set up for the soft drop shot into the open court. There was an ace down the throat of the court. And here he was, serving at 5-4 to draw even at a set apiece, ready to send the message that he was prepared to \"die on the court,\" as he always put it.\n\nOn Saturday, Nadal had spoken about his biggest concern facing Zverev, the world No. 4 and the the most fit and in-form player at the top of the sport in the first round. He'd been playing well in practice, moving with a freedom he hadn't felt in months, and feeling at moments like he had the level of the best players in the world.\n\nPractice sets, though, are one thing. Making the right decisions and executing the shots under the pressure of a Grand Slam with the eyes of the world watching, knowing the consequences of the slightest misses -- that's something that only comes with the kinds of matches Nadal has not played in nearly two years.\n\nUltimately, that is what doomed him on chilly and dreary afternoon and evening under the roof on Chatrier. In the moments when he'd nearly always found his best tennis and made the right decisions and the most courageous of shots -- when he served to draw even then battled into a do-or-die tiebreaker -- they weren't there.\n\nHe hit serves that became easy chances for Zverev to go on the defensive, and groundstrokes into the middle of the court that Zverev pounded for winners. The big German needed just four points to square up the set at 5-5, then rode his killer serve and jumped on two ill-advised drop shots from Nadal to take a two-set lead and turn the end into a matter of time and details.\n\nWhen Zverev rocketed a backhand service return past a charging Nadal to get the crucial break of serve in the third set, a stadium that had throbbed only minutes before as the Spaniard fought to extend his French Open life just a little longer, fell nearly silent.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8146719234", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "13:56:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T13:56:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T13:55:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/tennis/french-open/rafael-nadal-bidding-to-avoid-early-french-open-exit/articleshow/110442017.cms", "title": "Rafael Nadal bidding to avoid early French Open exit | Tennis News - Times of India", "body": "NEW DELHI: Rafael Nadal acknowledges the formidable challenge that lies ahead as he prepares to face Alexander Zverev in the opening round of the French Open on Monday.\n\nThe 14-time champion recognizes Zverev as one of the most difficult opponents he could potentially encounter at this stage of the tournament.\n\nSpeculation had been rife that this year's French Open would mark Nadal's final appearance at Roland Garros, a place where he has achieved unparalleled success.\n\nHowever, the Spaniard has since clarified that he cannot definitively confirm '100 percent' that this will be his last time competing at the prestigious clay-court event.\n\nSince the beginning of 2023, he has only participated in four tournaments due to a hip injury and a subsequent muscle tear.\n\nThat left him unseeded for the draw and vulnerable to a difficult opening round at a tournament where he has only lost three of his 115 matches.\n\nWorld number four Zverev arrives in Paris as one of the favourites for the title after winning the Rome Open earlier this month.\n\n\"Of course on paper it is not the best draw,\" Nadal said ahead of the match on Court Philippe Chatrier.\n\n\"I play against one of the toughest opponents possible, and at the same time, he came here winning the last event and it's a Masters 1000.\n\n\"It's not a small one. So what can I do? That's the draw. Just try to be ready for it.\"\n\nNadal, who turns 38 in a week's time, has shown flashes of his best form in the clay-court swing, but was thrashed 6-1, 6-3 by Poland's Hubert Hurkacz in the second round of his last outing in Rome.\n\nHe boasts a 7-3 winning record over Zverev ahead of their first meeting since the 2022 French Open semi-finals, when the German left the court in a wheelchair near the end of the second set after injuring his ankle.\n\n\"I am not anxious. No, I am focused on trying to play well. That's it,\" said Nadal.\n\n\"Maybe I go there and I repeat the disaster of Rome. It's a possibility, of course. I don't want to hide that.\n\n\"But in my mind, is do something different and play much better and give myself a chance to play competitive.\"\n\nZverev did not play again in 2022 after that ankle injury but has climbed the rankings again in recent months.\n\nThe 27-year-old has long been touted as a future Grand Slam champion but remains without one of tennis' four biggest titles.\n\nClay is his strongest surface, though, and he has reached the semi-finals in each of the last three years at Roland Garros.\n\nThe men's draw looks far more open than usual, with doubts surrounding Nadal's fitness and Novak Djokovic having endured a turbulent start to the year.\n\n\"I can guarantee you Novak didn't want to play Rafa in the first round and (Carlos) Alcaraz didn't want to play, Jannik (Sinner) didn't want to play him,\" admitted Zverev.\n\n\"I don't want to play him in the first round, but it is how it is. He has been out injured. He hasn't played a lot of tennis. His ranking is where it is. Of course it's not ideal, but at the same time, you know, there is nothing you can do.\n\n\"Everybody now is excited for a tough battle and tough first round. I think he's excited and I'm excited for it.\"\n\nFrench Open organisers were prepared to stage a tribute ceremony to Nadal to honour his career but the Spaniard was reluctant to endorse such a celebration.\n\n\"We were ready to press the button on it,\" admitted tournament director Amelie Mauresmo.\n\n\"But it's Rafa who manages his timing, we follow what he wants. We wouldn't want to put him in an uncomfortable position.\"\n\n(With inputs from AFP)\n\nThe TOI Sports Desk excels in a myriad of roles that capture the essence of live sporting events and deliver compelling content to readers worldwide. {"uri": "2024-05-368050584", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-25", "time": "15:23:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-25T15:23:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-25T15:23:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "http://www.atptour.com/en/news/nadal-roland-garros-2024-preview", "title": "Rafael Nadal's 'encouraging' report ahead of Roland Garros", "body": "Nadal's 'encouraging' report ahead of Roland Garros\n\nRafael Nadal brings positive news to his adoring fans ahead of the Spaniard's first Roland Garros appearance since 2022. Preparing for just his fifth tournament of the year, the 14-time champion has made noticeable physical progress, even since competing in Rome two weeks ago.\n\n\"I am improving in different ways. I have less limitations than three, four weeks ago, without a doubt,\" Nadal said in Saturday's press conference. \"I am having a good week of practices. I probably will say this is the first week since I came back playing tennis that I am able to run the proper way without having a lot of limitations. That encourages me.\n\n\"In the practices, without a doubt I improved. Especially in terms of movements. So I don't feel the limitations that I felt in Rome in terms of running to both sides, so that's a lot for me.\"\n\nThis fortnight is likely to be Nadal's final showing at the season's second major, where he boasts an unrivalled 112-3 match record across 18 appearances. But save the emotional farewell for another day: the former No. 1 in the PIF ATP Rankings cited three important reasons why he continues to relish each moment on Tour.\n\n\"In some way I don't want to close the door 100 per cent, because of a very simple thing,\" Nadal said. \"First thing, I am enjoying playing tennis. Second thing, I am travelling with [my] family. They are enjoying it. I am enjoying sharing all this process with them. And third thing, I was not able to explore yet the proper way of how I will be able to play being in more or less healthy conditions, playing without limitation.\"\n\nWhile Nadal enters Paris in his best physical shape this clay season, luck drew him no favours to begin the tournament. The 22-time major titlist faces fourth seed and Rome champion Alexander Zverev in a blockbuster first-round match. Nadal learned of his place in the draw while indulging in a Spanish board game.\n\n\"I was playing some Parchis and at some point somebody told me the draw. Something that I expected in some way, no? When you are not seeded, anything can happen,\" Nadal said. \"I play against one of the toughest opponents possible, and at the same time, he came here winning the last event and it's a Masters 1000. It's not a small one.\"\n\nNo matter his place in the field of 128, Nadal is glad to be healthy and able to compete at the tournament he has dominated the past two decades.\n\n\"I am grateful that I am able to be in Roland Garros and give myself a chance to play at least one more time here. Maybe the last one, maybe not,\" he said with a laugh. \"It's a big, big chance that it's going to be my last Roland Garros, but if I have to tell you it's 100 per cent my last Roland Garros, sorry, but I will not because I cannot predict what's going on.\"", "source": {"uri": "atptour.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ATP Tour"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The match, lasting 3 hours and 5 minutes, marked Nadal's third-ever loss at the French Open.\n\nThe match began with a shaky start for Nadal, as Zverev quickly seized an early lead by breaking Nadal's serve.\n\nDespite Nadal's attempts to stage a comeback, Zverev maintained control and clinched the first set 6-3.\n\nNadal fought fiercely in the second set, rallying to even the score at 2-2 and thrilling the spectators with his resilience. However, Zverev's powerful serving and strategic gameplay ultimately prevailed, as he secured the second set in a tie-breaker.\n\nUndeterred, Nadal made a spirited effort in the third set, taking an early lead and captivating the spectators with his exceptional play. However, Zverev's consistency and composure proved decisive as he broke Nadal's serve and sealed the match with a 6-3 victory in the third set.\n\nZverev's triumph marked a significant upset in the tournament, ending Nadal's campaign in the first round and sending shockwaves through the tennis world. Despite the defeat, Nadal received a warm ovation from both Zverev and the crowd, acknowledging his enduring legacy at Roland Garros. {"uri": "2024-05-370791943", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "11:48:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T11:48:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T10:09:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.aol.com/rafael-nadal-says-playing-wimbledon-100920238.html", "title": "Rafael Nadal says playing Wimbledon is 'not a good idea' as he looks to prioritize Paris Olympics", "body": "Rafael Nadal says playing Wimbledon is 'not a good idea' as he looks to prioritize Paris Olympics\n\nMatias Grez, CNN\n\nMay 28, 2024 at 12:09 PM\n\nRafael Nadal has cast further doubt on his participation at Wimbledon this year, saying it is \"not a good idea\" as he looks to prioritize the Summer Olympics on the Roland Garros clay.\n\nThe 22-time grand slam champion was eliminated in the first round of the French Open by Alexander Zverev on Monday and said Paris 2024 is now the \"main goal\" for the summer.\n\nThe transition from clay to grass is the most difficult surface change on the tennis calendar. Wimbledon gets underway on July 1, with the Olympic tennis tournament starting less than a month later on July 27.\n\n\"It looks difficult,\" Nadal, who won singles gold at Beijing 2008, said of his Wimbledon prospects. \"Honestly, I can't confirm what's going on, but for me, now it looks difficult to make the transition to grass, having the Olympics again on clay.\n\n\"So I cannot confirm anything, I need to talk with the team, I need to analyze so many facts, but I don't think it's going to be smart after all the things that happened to my body to now make a big transition to a completely different surface and then come back immediately to clay.\n\n\"Today, I feel that's not a good idea. I can't confirm, but my feeling is, even if I am booked in Wimbledon because I had to, I don't think it's a positive idea right now.\"\n\nNadal is also set to play in the doubles at Paris 2024 with Carlos Alcaraz.\n\nThe 37-year-old has struggled with injury since the 2023 Australian Open and was forced to miss the vast majority of last season as he tried to get his body ready for one last year on tour.\n\nAfter previously announcing that 2024 would likely be his last year in professional tennis, Nadal opened the door to a possible return in 2025 after his defeat to Zverev, saying he is \"not 100% sure\" the loss was his final appearance at Roland Garros.\n\nBut given his injury struggles over the last 18 months, Nadal admitted that, even if prioritizes being fit for the Olympics, there is no guarantee he will be.\n\n\"I cannot tell you if I will be or won't be in one month and a half,\" Nadal said. \"My body has been a jungle for two years and you don't know what to expect. I wake up one day and I found a snake biting me; another day, a tiger.\n\n\"It's been a big fight with all of the things I went through, but the dynamic is positive the last few weeks. I felt ready. I think tomorrow I will be ready to play again if I had to - but I will not have to,\" he laughed. \"I need to clear my ideas now and see what the new calendar is for me to be ready for the Olympics.\n\n\"I can't say anything today, but my main goal now is to play the Olympics that are going to be here, so I need to prepare myself the proper way: to try to arrive here healthy and well prepared - and then let's see.\"\n\nFor more CNN news and newsletters create an account at CNN.com", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8147135048", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "21:29:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T21:29:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T21:28:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://lacrossetribune.com/sports/professional/other/nadal-french-open-clay-tennis-atp-major/article_b71db100-8643-5b86-b8fc-4e0a4fc34937.html", "title": "French Open cancels farewell ceremony for Nadal", "body": "PARIS -- The French tennis federation put off holding a ceremony to celebrate Rafael Nadal at Roland Garros this year, because he has said this might not necessarily be his final appearance at the tournament he has won a record 14 times.\n\nTournament director Am\u00e9lie Mauresmo said Sunday, Day 1 of the clay-court Grand Slam event, that Nadal let officials know he didn't want to close the door on a return before he told the world that at a pre-tournament news conference.\n\n\"As you can imagine, we had something planned for him. But ... because he doesn't know if it's going to be his last Roland Garros or not, he wants to leave the door open maybe to come back next year as a player. So we are not going to push him, obviously, to do anything,\" Mauresmo said.\n\n\"It's his decision when he wants to have a proper ceremony, a proper goodbye, a proper farewell. So we're not going to do it this year. That's his wish,\" she continued. \"And even though we were ready to push the button if something happens, we obviously are going to respect what he wants and make sure we are ready whenever he feels he wants to do it. Later this year; next year; anytime he wants.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Steve Cahalan: Owners of Red Pines Bar & Grill open Red Pines Cafe next door Metal braces added to stabilize iconic wooden Riverside Park band shell damaged in 2021 La Crosse wind storm Steve Cahalan: Marcie's Pet Spa in West Salem to relocate, double in size and add new staff Commercial garage in La Crosse sustains heavy fire and smoke damage from Thursday blaze Onalaska man charged with sixth-offense impaired driving, hit-and-run in La Crosse traffic crash New La Crosse School Board members question $53M building referendum approved for November ballots Suspicious death in Trempealeau County now considered a homicide Arrest made in La Crosse as man charged with child pornography possession Kyle Larry Dahl Severe weather warnings expire in region after Altura tornado confirmed WIAA track and field sectionals: Coulee Region state qualifier list Firefighters rescue one person, three pets after responding to Onalaska blaze Steve Cahalan: Gerrard-Hoeschler Realtors sold, NOM Sips & Eats to open Tuesday downtown WIAA Division 1 track and field regionals: Holmen advances in 32 events Memorial Day observances in La Crosse and the greater Coulee Region\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3 and has said previously he expects this to be his last season, will face No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev in the first round on Monday. The match is scheduled to be third in the main stadium, Court Philippe Chatrier, and could start at around 3:30 p.m. local time (9:30 a.m. EDT).\n\nHere are some answers to questions about Nadal and Zverev:\n\nWhy are top players like Nadal and Zverev meeting in the first round?\n\nDespite having such a dominant record at the French Open, Nadal was not seeded and so could have been placed anywhere in the bracket and been stuck playing anyone at all, even the very best opponents. Because of injuries, including a surgically repaired hip and problematic abdominal muscle, Nadal has competed little the past two seasons, going only 7-4 in 2024, and so someone who has been ranked No. 1 and spent more than a decade inside the top 10 is now outside the top 250.\n\nWhy isn't Nadal seeded?\n\nThis is Nadal's first Grand Slam tournament without a seeding since the 2005 Australian Open. The top 32 players in the men's and women's draws are seeded, and the seedings are based on the ATP and WTA rankings, which take into account the most recent 52 weeks of results. In theory, Mauresmo could have opted to circumvent the rules and go ahead and award a seeding to Nadal based on his past performances in Paris. But that was never really considered, she said, in part because \"giving protection to some players\" would result in \"a lot of other issues and problems,\" and because \"it also has to be OK with other Grand Slams and everything.\"\n\nWhat difference do seedings make?\n\nPlayers who are seeded, such as Zverev, are guaranteed to avoid going up against another seeded player any earlier than the third round of a Grand Slam tournament, which have 128-player fields and require seven victories to earn a championship.\n\nWhat do other players think?\n\nPlayers tend to agree with Mauresmo's decision, with several saying they believe the seeding system should remain the way it currently is (Wimbledon used to seed players according to their results on grass courts, but has strictly followed the rankings since 2021). \"The way that the seedings work, I think it's appropriate. In this case, it's unfortunate how that happened, but I don't know how you gauge where someone should and shouldn't be seeded based on past or previous success,\" said three-time major champion Andy Murray. \"It'd be quite hard to do that.\"\n\nWho is Alexander Zverev?\n\nHe is a leading player in men's tennis, one who is coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open, won a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics and was the 2020 U.S. Open runner-up. He reached the semifinals at the French Open each of the past three years, including in 2022, when he played Nadal at that stage but had to stop after tearing ligaments in his right foot during the match. Zverev, a 27-year-old from Germany, is about to face a court proceeding that starts next week in Berlin related to accusations of physically abusing an ex-girlfriend. He does not need to be in court and said he will not be. \"At the end of the day, I do believe in the German system. I do believe in the truth, as well. I have to be certain that, you know, I do know what I did, I do know what I didn't do,\" Zverev said. \"That's, at the end of the day, what's going to come out, and I have to trust in that.\"\n\nWhy is Zverev allowed to play during his ongoing court case?\n\nMauresmo was asked Sunday about Zverev's status and replied: \"As long as the trial isn't finished and there isn't a decision, he's considered innocent and so that's why he's allowed to be part of the draw.\"\n\nAP Sports Week in Pictures: Caitlin Clark's debut, Fury on the ropes and golf's winning shot Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 {"uri": "8145609248", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-25", "time": "16:22:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-25T16:22:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-25T16:21:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/sports/tennis/french-open/rafael-nadal-says-he-is-feeling-better/articleshow/110426163.cms", "title": "Rafael Nadal says he is feeling better | Tennis News - Times of India", "body": "PARIS: Rafael Nadal was in black-and-white practice gear, he was leaning on the grayscale, but that was all the vintage the 14-time Roland Garros champion sparked on an afternoon when the sun was in the shade.\n\nThe 37-year-old's shots were short of signature crackle and his stride was a mite slow.\n\nNadal enters the Paris Grand Slam following an anemic match schedule courtesy a hip injury that kept him off his beloved terre battue last year for the first time after 18 consecutive appearances.The Spaniard played four matches in 2023 and has logged just four tournaments in 2024.\n\nNadal, bidding to finish a storied career on his terms, at the very least end where he started it on the tennis court, will go up against the fourth-ranked German Alexander Zverev in the first round on Monday.\n\nHe'll need to blast off the blocks. So, where exactly is Rafael Nadal, on a competitive scale?\n\nHe is ranked outside the top-250 at No 276, but that, in this case, is just a number against a name. Not a measure of the legend.\n\nNadal, who arrived in Roland Garros more than a week before the start of the fortnight, said he's feeling better than he has in a long time on the tennis court.\n\n\"This is the first week since I come back that I'm able to run the proper way without having a lot of limitations. That has encouraged me,\" said Nadal, who arrived for his pre-championship media interaction in an electric blue tee and a smile to match. \"That does not mean that I'm going to play incredible on Monday, no?\"\n\nThe 22-time major winner, who has a glittering 112-3 win-loss record here, retraced his romance at this spectacularly stylish venue.\n\n\"In some ways this place is magical for me,\" he said. \"So, if, in the bottom of my heart, I don't have any hope to have success here and to create a beautiful thing this year, I will not be here in front of you guys.\"\n\nThat declaration at once lifted the mood in the packed-to-capacity press room. Nobody wants one of the greatest champions this game has seen, one of the fiercest fighters in all sport, limp into the sunset. That would be a travesty.\n\nNadal, who went down to Hubert Hurkacz in the second round in Rome in his last tournament outing, indicated that he's able to push more physically.\n\n\"I don't feel the limitations that I felt in Rome in terms of running,\" he said. \"I'm not thinking in terms of having amazing results here but thinking about giving myself a little bit more room to think about what can happen in the future.\"\n\nThis then, particularly the last three-four months, has got to be Nadal's weightiest fight, chasing as he is a wafer-thin chance on the slippery slope of hope. Battling age and wrestling for time.\n\n\"We did things to try to feel better, and we have been working without a stop to keep progressing, to try to arrive here in a proper way,\" he said.\n\nEach time Nadal threads the needle with his m\u00e9lange of heavily spun groundies on a practice court, he's faced with questions.\n\n\"I didn't play five-set matches since a long time. I haven't played this level of opponents since a long time,\" he said. \"All these questions that you ask me, I'm asking to myself too.\"\n\nZverev, more than a decade younger than his opponent, is up to speed having claimed his biggest title in two years ago in Rome last week\n\nThe German is looking to finish a match he couldn't two years ago when he was wheeled off the court in the middle of their sea-saw semifinal with an ankle injury.\n\n\"I wanted to play Rafa again, because I didn't want the last memory of me playing against Rafa to be me leaving the court on a wheelchair,' the 27-year-old said. \"For me, in my mind, I'm going to play peak Rafa Nadal. I expect him to be at his absolute best. I went all through these processes with the dream to be back here.\n\n'The first round wasn't ideal. I was competitive and I had chances but it was difficult against a player as good as Sasha.\n\n'It's hard to say about the future. I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. {"uri": "8148658394", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "19:26:45", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T19:26:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T19:25:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.usanews.net/breaking/nadal-falls-at-roland-garros-in-a-match-that-tastes-like-a-farewell-i-h159354.html", "title": "Nadal falls at Roland Garros in a match that tastes like a farewell: \"I don't know if it's the last time\"", "body": "He sees himself with dark curls, almost twenty years ago, jogging early in the morning through the Bois de Boulogne and then, at noon, looking out at Roland Garros, sometimes on court 1, or at Suzanne Lenglen, to contemplate to the teenager who wears a tank top and capri pants, that Rafael Nadal who, the wise say, has arrived to mark an era.\n\nSo, Paris is federated.\n\nThe city surrenders to the elegant Swiss who speaks French, English and German, that one-handed backhand Federer whose reign extends over almost all lands: tennis is his except for Paris, a black hole that he will only manage to cover in 2009.\n\nWow, we go back to Nadal from 2005.\n\nThe Manacor\u00ed teenager is like a gladiator or a paranormal phenomenon and, day after day, he devours his rivals.\n\nIt swallows Burgsm\u00fcller, Malisse and Gasquet, the local icon who never takes off (and is still here too). He fights with Grosjean due to the helplessness of the local public, chauvinistic until then: the Parisians had not yet learned to love the Manacor\u00ed. And he passes over Ferrer and over Federer himself before knocking down Mariano Puerta in the final.\n\n19 years later, the chronicler continues jogging through the Bois de Boulogne, but the pace of the race is no longer enough and he does not have long hair either, but rather a shaved skull and a snowy beard.\n\nAnd yet, he acts as if nothing had happened: at noon he looks out at Roland Garros, as excited as he is deluded, and prepares to enjoy this sudden Nadalmania, the wave that has taken over Paris these days.\n\nDreamer?\n\nNadalmania seems to subside three minutes into the match.\n\nThis is the time that Sasha Zverev (27) spends breaking the serve of Rafael Nadal, ten years older than the German.\n\nA drop shot that does not bear fruit, a ball that goes long, a double fault and a bomb from the giant who sports a ponytail mark the painful fate of the long-awaited return, Nadal's return to his promised land: three hours later, Paris bids farewell to his favorite son (6-3, 7-6 (5) and 6-3).\n\n15,000 spectators bundled up in their jackets (including Novak Djokovic and Carlos Alcaraz) and Nadal's sculpture, lying a few meters away, mute and undaunted in the Parisian rain, contemplate the decline of the myth, a 37-year-old autumnal icon whose presentation has never been just:\n\n-Two thousand seven... -speaks the presenter in the proleg\u00f3menos, and sigue contando-: two thousand eight (...), two thousand twelve (...), two thousand twenty-two!\n\nNadal has won so many times in Paris: fourteen editions.\n\n(No one will repeat such a feat, it doesn't hurt to remember it).\n\nRoland Garros had never sold out in the first week. Nadal had never left Paris in the first week. And yet, the man, the myth, sticks to his guns: he tunes up the court, distributes the four towels in the four planters, places the bottles diagonally, never steps on a line as he advances towards his position, sweeps the lines with the inside of his right foot, he wipes away the sweat with his right wristband, he fixes the fold of his pants.\n\nWe will miss him, or perhaps not yet, because the man from Manaco is moving forward, he does not close doors to the future, he thinks he could return to Paris in a year, although here and now he does not seem to have any options against Zverev.\n\nLate in the first set, the chronicler observes deficiencies in the serve (Nadal serves at 175 km/h), lack of depth on the forehand and little repris in his legs: when he gets tired, he cuts the point with a drop shot. He often gets it wrong. Nadal is weighed down by the year and a half of pain and worries, abdominal problems and inactivity.\n\nOn top of that, he has faced the worst of adversaries.\n\n(This is the life of a tennis player when he appears in a Grand Slam like the 275th on the circuit).\n\nZverev is the fourth tennis player in the world but he could be the first, and he is on fire, victorious in Rome and eager for revenge.\n\nIt is also drizzling and the organizers have deployed the retractable roof of the Philippe Chatrier and Nadal and Zverev have been engaged in an infinite match for three hours. The second set had not even closed when the German stumbled on the clay and, gigantically, collapsed, shouting and crying.\n\nHe broke his ankle.\n\nClear path for the Manacor\u00ed, who is projected towards the final against Ruud and, from there, towards his 14th crown in Paris.\n\nIn the present, Zverev has forgotten about that painful episode and now serves at 205 km/h and endures and overcomes Nadal's rallies and accelerates when he considers it necessary. He needs fifty minutes to take over the first set.\n\nThen, the future seems yours.\n\nEspecially, two hours into the match, when the tie break of the second round is set, the one that Nadal fights to the fullest: the power of his serve has risen to 185 km/h, his forehand goes further, he has He managed to break Zverev's serve, even serving to win the set, but he got stuck and ended up compromising.\n\nFor a few moments, timid glimpses of Nadalidad have been illuminated, the same ones that reappear in the third set, again Nadal breaks Zverev's serve, again Zverev returns it.\n\nThe German gives no respite, involved in a hitting and knocking exercise that ruins the illusions of a legend.\n\n-See you soon -despide Roland Garros to Nadal.\n\nSee you soon, because no one knows anything anymore, no one knows what the manacor\u00ed will be doing in a year, nor does he himself know.\n\n-The truth is that I don't know what to say. Today is Rafa's moment -says Zverev.\n\n-It's difficult for me to talk. I don't know if this is the last time I play here. Yes I know I enjoyed it. The chances of him returning are low, but they exist. I hope to be here at the Olympic Games - says Nadal.\n\n(He leaves as quickly as he had done in Barcelona and Rome: the farewell tribute is denied, how can we see goodbye here?).", "source": {"uri": However, he struggled to find a way beyond his opponent - who secured a 6-3 7-6 (7-5) 6-3 success - despite a battling display.\n\nZverev will now play David Goffin or Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard for a spot in the third round. Meanwhile, Nadal was left to bid an emotional farewell to Roland-Garros but refused to confirm whether it was his last appearance at the French Open.\n\nSpeaking after his defeat, the 37-year-old said: \"It is difficult for me to talk, I don't know if it's the last time I'll be here in front of all of you. Honestly, I am not sure. If it is, then you have been amazing. The feelings I have today are difficult to describe in words. It is the place I love the most.\n\n\"I have to congratulate Sasha for this great match. I really wish you all the best in this tournament. 2022 was a tough moment for you so you deserve it.\n\n\"I have been going through a very tough two years in terms of injuries. I went all through these processes with the dream to be back here. The first round wasn't ideal. I was competitive and I had chances but it was difficult against a player as good as Sasha.\n\n\"It's hard to say about the future. I am travelling with my family and I am having fun. The body is feeling better than it did two months ago. Maybe in two months I say it's enough. That is something I don't feel yet. I hope to be back here for the Olympics, that motivates me. I really hope to be well prepared.\n\nWhat is your Rafael Nadal highlight? The feelings you made me feel here are unforgettable, thank you very much from the bottom of my heart. {"uri": "8148373044", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "15:23:58", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T15:23:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T15:23:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.wionews.com/sports/tennis/news-why-french-open-organisers-cancelled-farewell-ceremony-for-rafael-nadal-726026", "title": "Why French Open organisers cancelled farewell ceremony for Rafael Nadal?", "body": "Tournament director Am\u00e9lie Mauresmo revealed Nadal had informed the officials that he did not want to close the door on a potential return to Paris where he has been victorious on 14 occasions\n\nLegendary tennis player Rafael Nadal, currently in the final essay of his illustrious career, will not be getting a farewell ceremony at the French Open, irrespective of his fate at the second major of the year, according to the tournament organisers\n\nTournament director Am\u00e9lie Mauresmo revealed Nadal had informed the officials that he did not want to close the door on a potential return to Paris where he has been victorious on 14 occasions. A farewell ceremony had been planned but it was shunned at the last moment after Nadal's hint.\n\n\"As you can imagine, we had something planned for him. But because he doesn't know if it's going to be his last Roland Garros or not, he wants to leave the door open maybe to come back next year as a player. So we are not going to push him, obviously, to do anything,\" Mauresmo said.\n\nAfter informing the officials, Nadal during a pre-match conference addressed the speculations on his final French Open appearance.\n\nThe Spaniard said while there is a huge chance it could be his last dance, he wasn't 100 per cent sure about it.\n\n\"Honestly, no? I am improving in different ways. I have less limitations that three, four weeks ago, without a doubt. And in terms if this is going to be my last Roland Garros, it's a long answer, but I think I need to answer that, because we're gonna avoid future questions since the beginning so I'm gonna do it,\" said the 22-time Major champion.\n\nAlso read | Reliving Rafael Nadal's 5 greatest wins in French Open finals\n\nNadal has been struggling with injuries for the last two years which has limited his game time. Since January last year, he has only played 15 matches a hip injury and muscle tear have kept him in rehabilitation.\n\nHe returned to action on his favourite surface - clay, playing at Barcelona and Madrid Masters before also giving a go in Rome. However, he was beaten in the second round in Barcelona by Alex de Minaur. The Spaniard took revenge on the Australian in Madrid before being knocked out by Jiri Lehecka in the last 16.\n\nHe was then beaten comfortably by Hubert Hurkacz in the second round of the Rome Open.\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3 and has said previously he expects this to be his last season started off the first round match against Alexander Zverev in the most anticlimactic way by As the Spaniard takes on Alexander Zverev in the opening round, the marquee matchup is being taken in by Novak Djokovic, Carlos Alcaraz and Iga Swiatek.\n\nDefending champions Djokovic and Swiatek both arrived at Roland Garros as World No. 1, with Alcaraz at No. 3 in the PIF ATP Rankings. But there's no doubt that Nadal is the No. 1 attraction in the opening stages of the clay-court Grand Slam this year.\n\nA 14-time champion at the event, Nadal said there is a 'big, big chance' this will be his farewell appearance at the tournament he has owned throughout his career -- though he would not rule out the possibility of a return. Wolf, while Swiatek beat France's Leolia Jeanjean on Court Philippe Chatrier just before Nadal and Zverev took the court.\n\nDjokovic will play his first-round match on Tuesday against Pierre-Hugues {"uri": "8149435863", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "08:41:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T08:41:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T08:39:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.socialnews.xyz/2024/05/28/to-leave-after-first-round-was-not-an-ideal-return-says-nadal-after-shock-roland-garros-exit/", "title": "'To leave after first round was not an ideal return', says Nadal after shock Roland Garros exit", "body": "Paris, May 28 (SocialNews.XYZ) It was an emotional evening at Court Philippe-Chatrier as the 'King of Clay' Rafael Nadal made a shocking first round exit from Roland Garros after losing to Alexander Zverev.\n\nNadal's legacy of record 14 Roland Garros titles is a testament to his sheer quality and industry on clay. At 37, the Spaniard has an illustrious career in tennis to look back at, as he moves closer to retirement which seems imminent, considering his injuries.\n\nEven as Alexander Zverev claimed a straight sets victory over the Spaniard, hearts went out to Nadal who, might as well, played his last match of the Grand Slam ever.\n\n\"It's going to be the last time I'm here in front of all of you. I'm not 100% sure, but if it was the last time, then I must say I enjoyed it. The feelings that I have today are difficult to describe in words. For me, it was special to feel the love of the people in the place that I love the most,\" said Nadal while addressing the spectators in the stadium.\n\n\"I have gone through very tough two years in terms of injuries. I went through that recovery process only to be back at Roland Garros. To leave after the first round was not an ideal return. But I have to accept it. I was competitive and I had my chances. But it was not enough against a great player like Sasha (Alexander Zverev),\" he averred.\n\nHe did give the spectators something to cheer for while mentioning a possible return to Court Philippe-Chatrier for the upcoming Paris 2024 Olympics.\n\n\"What you all have made me feel here, it's unforgettable. I hope to see you again. Merci Beaucoup!\" he conlcuded.", "source": {"uri": "socialnews.xyz", "dataType": "news", "title": "Social News XYZ"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Rafael Nadal"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_Open", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "French Open"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Zverev", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Alexander Zverev"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clay_court", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Clay court"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Tennis"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Grand Slam (tennis)"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Arts/Crafts/Modeling_Compounds", "label": "dmoz/Arts/Crafts/Modeling Compounds", "wgt": 8}, {"uri": "dmoz/Health/Alternative/Alexander_Technique", "label": "dmoz/Health/Alternative/Alexander Technique", "wgt": 9}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Tennis/Social", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Tennis/Social", "wgt": 7}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Roads_and_Highways/Exit_Lists", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Roads and Highways/Exit Lists", "wgt": 8}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Disabled/Mentally_Challenged", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Disabled/Mentally Challenged", "wgt": 8}, {"uri": "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 96}], "image": "https://i0.wp.com/www.socialnews.xyz/wp-content/uploads/2024/05/28/202405283167747.jpg?fit=680%2C680&quality=80&zoom=1&ssl=1?v=1716885640", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9598845", "eventUri": "eng-9598845", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-05-28", "textStart": 7, "textEnd": 13}], "sentiment": 0.1058823529411765, "wgt": 149, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8147127889", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "21:19:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T21:19:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T21:18:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://napavalleyregister.com/sports/professional/other/nadal-french-open-clay-tennis-atp-major/article_819fd360-4a59-557b-8a4c-12343bef6a5c.html", "title": "French Open cancels farewell ceremony for Nadal", "body": "PARIS -- The French tennis federation put off holding a ceremony to celebrate Rafael Nadal at Roland Garros this year, because he has said this might not necessarily be his final appearance at the tournament he has won a record 14 times.\n\nTournament director Am\u00e9lie Mauresmo said Sunday, Day 1 of the clay-court Grand Slam event, that Nadal let officials know he didn't want to close the door on a return before he told the world that at a pre-tournament news conference.\n\n\"As you can imagine, we had something planned for him. But ... because he doesn't know if it's going to be his last Roland Garros or not, he wants to leave the door open maybe to come back next year as a player. So we are not going to push him, obviously, to do anything,\" Mauresmo said.\n\n\"It's his decision when he wants to have a proper ceremony, a proper goodbye, a proper farewell. So we're not going to do it this year. That's his wish,\" she continued. \"And even though we were ready to push the button if something happens, we obviously are going to respect what he wants and make sure we are ready whenever he feels he wants to do it. Later this year; next year; anytime he wants.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Yachts going to BottleRock stuck in Vallejo after bridge failure Horror film explores myths, legends of Napa's Partrick Road How much does it cost to rock in Napa? BottleRock fans discuss this year's ticket prices. Oxbow School arts academy in Napa to close Woman seriously injured in Napa County crash Biagi Bros. president keeps transportation company rolling Future of Napa's Monticello winery splits Corley siblings BottleRock is coming. Who's starring? And how can you get around Napa? Meet Napa family man, rapper and BottleRock musician Sanho Rolling at Napa's last roller rink: The Wheelhouse made memories of disco, friends, fun in the 1970s and '80s Grand jury report: Napa County gang activity increasing, including among youth Vallejo bridge will remain stuck for about a week, blocking BottleRock boats St. Helena police seize concentrated cannabis, vape devices; Calistoga teen arrested BottleRock organizers break down closure, access details around Napa's new Festival La Onda Napa City Council rejects neighbors' appeal of church conversion to day care\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3 and has said previously he expects this to be his last season, will face No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev in the first round on Monday. The match is scheduled to be third in the main stadium, Court Philippe Chatrier, and could start at around 3:30 p.m. local time (9:30 a.m. EDT).\n\nHere are some answers to questions about Nadal and Zverev:\n\nWhy are top players like Nadal and Zverev meeting in the first round?\n\nDespite having such a dominant record at the French Open, Nadal was not seeded and so could have been placed anywhere in the bracket and been stuck playing anyone at all, even the very best opponents. Because of injuries, including a surgically repaired hip and problematic abdominal muscle, Nadal has competed little the past two seasons, going only 7-4 in 2024, and so someone who has been ranked No. 1 and spent more than a decade inside the top 10 is now outside the top 250.\n\nWhy isn't Nadal seeded?\n\nThis is Nadal's first Grand Slam tournament without a seeding since the 2005 Australian Open. The top 32 players in the men's and women's draws are seeded, and the seedings are based on the ATP and WTA rankings, which take into account the most recent 52 weeks of results. In theory, Mauresmo could have opted to circumvent the rules and go ahead and award a seeding to Nadal based on his past performances in Paris. But that was never really considered, she said, in part because \"giving protection to some players\" would result in \"a lot of other issues and problems,\" and because \"it also has to be OK with other Grand Slams and everything.\"\n\nWhat difference do seedings make?\n\nPlayers who are seeded, such as Zverev, are guaranteed to avoid going up against another seeded player any earlier than the third round of a Grand Slam tournament, which have 128-player fields and require seven victories to earn a championship.\n\nWhat do other players think?\n\nPlayers tend to agree with Mauresmo's decision, with several saying they believe the seeding system should remain the way it currently is (Wimbledon used to seed players according to their results on grass courts, but has strictly followed the rankings since 2021). \"The way that the seedings work, I think it's appropriate. In this case, it's unfortunate how that happened, but I don't know how you gauge where someone should and shouldn't be seeded based on past or previous success,\" said three-time major champion Andy Murray. \"It'd be quite hard to do that.\"\n\nWho is Alexander Zverev?\n\nHe is a leading player in men's tennis, one who is coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open, won a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics and was the 2020 U.S. Open runner-up. He reached the semifinals at the French Open each of the past three years, including in 2022, when he played Nadal at that stage but had to stop after tearing ligaments in his right foot during the match. Zverev, a 27-year-old from Germany, is about to face a court proceeding that starts next week in Berlin related to accusations of physically abusing an ex-girlfriend. He does not need to be in court and said he will not be. \"At the end of the day, I do believe in the German system. I do believe in the truth, as well. I have to be certain that, you know, I do know what I did, I do know what I didn't do,\" Zverev said. \"That's, at the end of the day, what's going to come out, and I have to trust in that.\"\n\nWhy is Zverev allowed to play during his ongoing court case?\n\nMauresmo was asked Sunday about Zverev's status and replied: \"As long as the trial isn't finished and there isn't a decision, he's considered innocent and so that's why he's allowed to be part of the draw.\"\n\nAP Sports Week in Pictures: Caitlin Clark's debut, Fury on the ropes and golf's winning shot Tags Dcc Wire Lee-national {"uri": "8147027593", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "19:13:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T19:13:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T19:12:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/nadal-sets-aside-retirement-talk-180353456.html", "title": "Nadal sets aside retirement talk to face Zverev - day two preview", "body": "Rafael Nadal returns to action at his favourite tournament on Monday - but he faces his trickiest French Open opener for many years.\n\nThe Spanish great, a record 14-time champion at Roland Garros, faces fourth seed Alexander Zverev at about 14:00 BST.\n\nIt had seemed like this would be the 37-year-old's final French Open appearance but he said earlier this week he would not \"close the door\" on extending his career.\n\nConsequently, a planned farewell ceremony has been scrapped by tournament organisers.\n\nWomen's top seed and three-time champion Iga Swiatek is also in action as she looks to continue her recent Roland Garros dominance.\n\nMeanwhile, British number one Cameron Norrie begins his tournament against Pavel Kotov, while Harriet Dart takes on Linda Noskova.\n\nNadal has won the French Open more than any other major, with his most recent victory coming in 2022.\n\nGiven his success at Roland Garros, tournament organisers are keen to mark his final appearance.\n\nNadal was widely believed to be retiring at the end of the season, but French Open tournament director Amelie Mauresmo says Nadal told her he is yet to make up his mind.\n\nShe said: \"As you can imagine, we had something planned for him.\n\n\"He wants to leave the door open for him maybe to come back next year as a player. So we're not going to push him obviously to do anything.\n\n\"It's his decision when he wants to have a proper ceremony. So we're not going to do it this year.\"\n\nInjuries have hampered Nadal in recent years and he returns to Paris ranked 275th.\n\nDespite his past success it is a tough first round for him against Italian Open champion Zverev, who many expect to challenge for the title.\n\nHistory suggests that Norrie should get through his opening match.\n\nHe has reached the third round at Roland Garros for the past two years but is yet to go further.\n\nSeeded 32nd, Norrie could face Andy Murray in the second round, providing they both progress through their first-round matches.\n\nBritish number two Dart begins against Czech 27th seed Noskova, looking to win a game in the main draw of the French Open for the first time.\n\nShe has had a difficult start to the year - the 27-year-old contracted food poisoning on her way to Australia and has since had to contend with a number of small injuries.\n\nShe put that behind her to reach her first WTA Tour semi-finals in February, losing to former world number one Karolina Pliskova at the Transylvania Open.\n\n\"This year's been really challenging,\" she said.\n\n\"I have goals to be top 50 by the end of the year. I just need to keep working on my game and the results will take care of themselves.\"\n\nPoland's Swiatek, 22, begins her bid for a fourth French Open title in five years against French qualifier Leolia Jeanjean.\n\nShe heads into the tournament in fine form, after securing back-to-back titles in Madrid and Rome this year.\n\nSwiatek boasts an impressive French Open record, having won 28 of by many as Nadal's swansong at the French Open, which he has clinched a record 14 times and been an absolute master of one of the trickiest surfaces in professional tennis.\n\nNadal's loss to the
