{"uri": "8149619616", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "10:32:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T10:32:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T10:31:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/sports/national/rafael-nadal-says-playing-wimbledon-is-not-a-good-idea-as-he-looks-to-prioritize/article_3d786663-996d-5f95-8103-935790cf74e6.html", "title": "Rafael Nadal says playing Wimbledon is 'not a good idea' as he looks to prioritize Paris Olympics", "body": "(CNN) -- Rafael Nadal has cast further doubt on his participation at Wimbledon this year, saying it is \"not a good idea\" as he looks to prioritize the Summer Olympics on the Roland Garros clay.\n\nThe 22-time grand slam champion was eliminated in the first round of the French Open by Alexander Zverev on Monday and said Paris 2024 is now the \"main goal\" for the summer.\n\nThe transition from clay to grass is the most difficult surface change on the tennis calendar. Wimbledon gets underway on July 1, with the Olympic tennis tournament starting less than a month later on July 27.\n\n\"It looks difficult,\" Nadal, who won singles gold at Beijing 2008, said of his Wimbledon prospects. \"Honestly, I can't confirm what's going on, but for me, now it looks difficult to make the transition to grass, having the Olympics again on clay.\n\n\"So I cannot confirm anything, I need to talk with the team, I need to analyze so many facts, but I don't think it's going to be smart after all the things that happened to my body to now make a big transition to a completely different surface and then come back immediately to clay.\n\n\"Today, I feel that's not a good idea. I can't confirm, but my feeling is, even if I am booked in Wimbledon because I had to, I don't think it's a positive idea right now.\"\n\nNadal is also set to play in the doubles at Paris 2024 with Carlos Alcaraz.\n\nThe 37-year-old has struggled with injury since the 2023 Australian Open and was forced to miss the vast majority of last season as he tried to get his body ready for one last year on tour.\n\nAfter previously announcing that 2024 would likely be his last year in professional tennis, Nadal opened the door to a possible return in 2025 after his defeat to Zverev, saying he is \"not 100% sure\" the loss was his final appearance at Roland Garros.\n\nBut given his injury struggles over the last 18 months, Nadal admitted that, even if prioritizes being fit for the Olympics, there is no guarantee he will be.\n\n\"I cannot tell you if I will be or won't be in one month and a half,\" Nadal said. \"My body has been a jungle for two years and you don't know what to expect. I wake up one day and I found a snake biting me; another day, a tiger.\n\n\"It's been a big fight with all of the things I went through, but the dynamic is positive the last few weeks. I felt ready. I think tomorrow I will be ready to play again if I had to - but I will not have to,\" he laughed. \"I need to clear my ideas now and see what the new calendar is for me to be ready for the Olympics.\n\n\"I can't say anything today, but my main goal now is to play the Olympics that are going to be here, so I need to prepare myself the proper way: to try to arrive here healthy and well prepared - and then let's see.\"\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "2024-05-370245376", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "01:39:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T01:39:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T18:39:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.reuters.com/sports/tennis/nadal-says-olympics-main-goal-after-early-roland-garros-defeat-2024-05-27/", "title": "Nadal says Olympics main goal after early Roland Garros defeat", "body": "PARIS, May 27 (Reuters) - Rafa Nadal likened his struggles with injury in the last 18 months to being in a jungle as the 14-times French Open champion hoped to return to Roland Garros for the Olympic Games after making a premature exit from the Grand Slam on Monday.\n\nNever far from physical issues in his glittering career, the 37-year-old missed almost all of 2023 with a hip problem and his comeback earlier this year was stalled by a muscle tear, before small niggles affected his preparation for the claycourt major.\n\nNadal crashed to a 6-3 7-6(5) 6-3 defeat by fourth seed Alexander Zverev in Paris and although there were positives, he said he could not predict how his battered body would respond to the demands of the Games in July and August.\n\n\"My body has been a jungle for two years. You don't know what to expect. I wake up one day and I find a snake biting me. Another day a tiger,\" Nadal told a packed press conference following his earliest exit from Roland Garros.\n\n\"I've been fighting with all the things that I went through. But the dynamic is positive the last few weeks. I felt ready. I think tomorrow I'll be ready to play again if I have to. But I will not have to.\n\n\"So that's the thing. Now, I need to prepare myself, I need to clear my ideas and see what's the new calendar to try to be ready for Olympics. I can't say anything today, but my main goal now is to play the Olympics.\"\n\nNadal will be eyeing his third gold medal after triumphing in singles in the 2008 Beijing Games and doubles eight years later in Rio.\n\nHe had expressed doubts about his fitness ahead of what is likely his final French Open.\n\n\"Today in the match, I felt I was able to move myself much better than in the previous tournaments. But I had a very tough opponent in front of me. He played well,\" Nadal added.\n\n\"I had my chances... I mean, I wasn't that far. That's my feeling. That's probably my truth... I played at a good level in all ways, comparing to the way I was playing the weeks before. So, happy for that.\n\n\"Of course disappointed to lose, but in terms of body feelings, I'm happy that I finished healthy and I had a tough battle out there. And I was ready for a little bit more.\"\n\nNadal said it would be unwise to prepare for the grasscourt season that follows with a potentially difficult transition back to clay for the Olympics.\n\n\"It looks difficult, honestly. For me now I can't confirm what's going on, but it looks difficult to make a transition to grass, having the Olympics again on clay,\" Nadal said.\n\n\"I need to talk with the team. I need to analyse so many facts. But I don't think it's going to be smart after all the things that happened to my body to make a big transition to a completely different surface and then come back to clay.\n\n\"Today I feel that's not a good idea, but I can't confirm. But my feelings is even if I'm booked in Wimbledon because I had to, I don't think it's a positive idea right now.\"\n\nReporting by Shrivathsa Sridhar in Paris Editing by Christian Radnedge", {"uri": "8150277132", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "17:37:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T17:37:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T17:36:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport/article/2024/may/28/rafael-nadals-mind-has-not-yet-reached-the-end-but-will-his-body-let-him-go-on", "title": "Nadal's mind has not yet reached the end, but will his body let him go on? Tumaini Carayol", "body": "Despite his physical ailments, the Spaniard, 38 in June, feels he is making progress and is pushing for an Olympic appearance in Paris\n\nShortly after his first ever opening-round defeat on Court-Philippe Chatrier, Rafael Nadal arrived at the press conference room for his postmortem in a jovial mood. After a career of dominance at Roland Garros, where he has so often been untouchable even against some of the greatest ever players, he would have been forgiven for feeling a sense of injustice and frustration with a straight-sets loss in the first round to Alexander Zverev. Instead, he felt progress: \"I was not that far,\" he said. \"That's my feeling.\"\n\nNadal's demeanour further underlined what has been increasingly clear over the last few weeks. If this really is the end and retirement is imminent, it will be because his body made the decision, not his mind. It seems clear that the player who turns 38 next week would love to further elongate his career and he is determined to do everything possible to try.\n\nA month ago, Nadal returned to competition in Barcelona and Madrid still unsure about whether he would even make it to Roland Garros. He had good reason to doubt. After the countless physical issues he has suffered, from hip surgery to complications and many unrelated injuries, his ambitions were low. He simply wanted to be sure that his body could physically withstand the load of competing at the highest level across the best of five sets.\n\nBy those parameters, Nadal's presence at Roland Garros was actually a step forward. He made it back to the most important court of his career performing at a decent level, he made life uncomfortable for one of the tournament favourites and he departed still feeling in good physical shape. Nadal felt he could have beaten many other players in this year's field, and a better draw would have allowed him the opportunity to build his form round by round. Roland Garros came too late in his recovery and he was handed a nightmare draw, but it was far easier to accept than being out of the game without a hope of making progress.\n\n\"I cannot tell you if I will be or not will be [ready] in one month and a half, because my body has been a jungle for two years. You don't know what to expect. I wake up one day and I found a snake biting me. Another day a tiger,\" Nadal said, smiling. \"[It] has been a big fight with all the things that I went through, no? But the dynamic is positive the last few weeks. I felt ready. I think tomorrow I will be ready to play again if I have to. But I will not have to.\"\n\nOn the court, being able to train consistently for five weeks has allowed Nadal to gradually improve, and to eventually reach the point where he was able to train without limitations this week for the first time in 15 months. He has also been travelling with his entire family, including his parents, wife and, for the first time, his son. After such a difficult period, he has been able to return to the familiar lifestyle of a tennis player, a sensation that has been energising.\n\nThis has been a fascinating period for farewells and the varying motivations of players late in their careers. Last week, Dominic Thiem, who faced Nadal in consecutive French Open finals in 2018 and 2019, affirmatively contested his final French Open at 30 years old, losing in the qualifying draw. After injuries and burnout, it was unusual and interesting to hear Thiem describe his decision to retire in logical and rational terms. He argued that continuing into his late-30s, like Nadal and his rivals, is still abnormal. \"I had a very intense career,\" said Thiem. \"I don't really feel like I'm 30 or 31, I feel tennis-wise a bit older, to be honest, so that was very intense.\"\n\nDespite his long list of injuries and ailments, Nadal does not appear to have reached that point. He is still determined to commit himself to the work ahead, to push himself to see how far he can go. The looming question over the coming months will be whether his body ultimately scuppers those ambitions. Limiting the risk of injury will also likely mean no Wimbledon. After his recent struggles, the prospect of switching from clay to grass and then back to clay in time for the Olympics in late July is too risky for him to compete on grass.\n\n\"I need to give myself a little bit longer chances to see if my level is growing and my body is holding, and then let's make a decision,\" said Nadal. \"But give me two months till Olympics, and then let's see if I am able to keep going or I say: 'Okay, guys, it's more than enough.' Let's see.\"", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [{"uri": "tumaini_carayol@theguardian.com", "name": "Tumaini Carayol", "type": "author", But Nadal gave the 27-year-old, 10 years his junior and a favourite for the title, a serious match before going down 6-3 7-6 (5) 6-3 in front of an adoring and emotional Philippe Chatrier crowd.\n\nThe Spaniard had told tournament organisers last week that he did not want a farewell ceremony as he would not \"close the door\" on a return to the Paris showpiece.\n\nIt seemed no one had got the memo, though. The seats behind the players' boxes were crammed with current stars including Carlos Alcaraz - Nadal's heir apparent - long-time rival Novak Djokovic and women's number one and three-time champion Iga Swiatek.\n\nAlso in attendance were Nadal's wife Xisca, who rarely watches his matches, baby son Rafael Jr and uncles Toni - his former coach - and Miguel Angel, the ex-Spain footballer.\n\nManchester City midfielder Rodri, no stranger to titles himself, was another famous face in the crowd.\n\nThey were all treated to flashes of the old brilliance; the rat-a-tat volley exchange in the first set, the drop shot from three feet behind the baseline in the second and the flashing forehand winner to clinch a break at the start of the third.\n\nBut a slow start had cost Nadal a break in the opening game which he never retrieved, while Zverev was too strong in the tie-break and held his nerve down the final straight.\n\nSo Nadal's astonishing Roland Garros record now reads played 116, won 112, as {"uri": "8145524291", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-25", "time": "15:00:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-25T15:00:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-25T14:57:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-rafael-nadal-says-he-is-feeling-better-and-this-might-not-be-his-last-french-open-5990082.html", "title": "Sports News | Rafael Nadal Says He is Feeling Better and This Might Not Be His Last French Open | LatestLY", "body": "Paris, May 25 (AP) Rafael Nadal smiled. He joked. He sounded upbeat. He's been playing well and feeling better in practice. He is eager to get going at Roland Garros after dealing for so long with hip and abdominal problems.\n\nOh, and then there's this little tidbit he dropped during a pre-tournament news conference Saturday: This French Open might not turn out to be the 14-time champion's last appearance at his favourite event, after all.\n\nAlso Read | What Happens if KKR vs SRH IPL 2024 Final Match Is Washed Out Due to Rain in Chennai? Is There Any Reserve Day?.\n\nBecause of his age -- he turns 38 on June 3 -- and his injuries and his past statements about figuring 2024 would be his last year on tour, everyone from other players to fans to the media has been assuming it will be his farewell appearance at the French Open.\n\nAsked whether that was accurate, Nadal smiled and replied: \"Don't assume that.\"\n\nAlso Read | KKR vs SRH Head-to-Head Record: Ahead of IPL 2024 Final Clash, Here Are Match Results of Last 3 Kolkata Knight Riders vs Sunrisers Hyderabad Encounters!.\n\n\"It's a big, big chance that it's going to be my last Roland Garros,\" Nadal said. \"But, if I have to tell you it's 100% my last Roland Garros? Sorry, but I will not. Because I cannot predict what's going on.\"\n\nThe Spaniard, who turns 38 on June 3, missed much of the last two seasons because of health problems, including hip surgery that forced him to sit out the French Open a year ago, his first absence there since he made his debut as a teenager. He is just 7-4 in 2024, and there had been some doubt after a lopsided loss at the Italian Open two weeks ago whether he would even enter the clay-court tournament in Paris at all.\n\nBut, he did show up and has been training in front of loud crowds this week. Because his ranking is so low after such little activity -- once No. 1, he was No. 276 this week -- Nadal did not get the benefit of a seeding and was drawn to face No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev in a showdown that will be the focus on Monday, Day 2 of the tournament.\n\n\"Ideally, I would have liked to play him in the later stage of the tournament, but it is how it is now. He is unseeded this year. I am seeded,\" Zverev said. \"You know, it's a tough draw, but it's a tough draw for both of us. We'll see how it goes.\"\n\nNadal said he has been practising well and feels as if he can play with anyone now, a sensation that has been fleeting for a while.\n\n\"I probably will say is the first week since I come back playing tennis that I am able to run the proper way without having a lot of limitations,\" he said. \"That encourages me.\" (AP)\n\n(This is an unedited and auto-generated story {"uri": "8148785691", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "21:58:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T21:58:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T21:58:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.10sballs.com/2024/05/27/tennis-super-star-rafael-nadal-loses-at-roland-garros-2024-by-alix-ramsay/", "title": "Tennis Super Star Rafael Nadal Loses at Roland Garros 2024 by Alix Ramsay - 10sBalls.com * TennisBalls.com", "body": "To steal a line from the Rolling Stones: \"This could be the last time....\" But, like the Rolling Stones, Rafa Nadal does not know.\n\nWhat he knows for sure is that he is out of Roland-Garros, beaten 6-3, 7-6(5), 6-3 by Sascha Zverev in three hours and five minutes. But whether that is the last match he will ever play at the French Open, he is not sure. He plans to be back at the Roland Garros stadium in a couple of months for the Olympics but competing again for the Coupe des Mousquetaires? Probably not. But then again...\n\nAs the draw was announced last Thursday, no one could quite believe that the 14-time champion had been pitted against the world No.4. Of course, Nadal was unseeded - two years spent trying to recover from a serious hip injury has seen his ranking plummet to No.275 - but he could have drawn someone infinitely more beatable. But no. The fates would not have it.\n\nDown in the press room's Brit Alley, the gentleman from the Daily Mail asked: \"can we say there were audible gasps?\" We all nodded. Yes, audible gasps were definitely heard when the draw was published. It made for a headline and a decent intro. But as the news sank in, there was a general feeling of doom. If this was to be Nadal's last match, no one wanted to see him take an absolute pasting from a younger, fitter man. He deserved better than that.\n\nBut then Rafa skipped into the interview room to discuss his situation and his chances. And he was very upbeat: his practice week in Paris had been the best he had felt in two years. He was practising well with everyone and holding his own. He felt he was moving better than he had just the week before. He was having fun travelling with his wife and young son. Life was looking up.\n\nWe listened. We were still doom laden. We thought he was whistling in the dark. And then we saw him play Zverev.\n\nTo get to the nuts and bolts of the match: Nadal started tentatively - he was broken in the opening game - but then he started to play. As the match moved into the second set, there were times when he looked like the real Rafa - the forehand down the line, the baseline belter of a backhand, the serve out wide to set up the deft volley (his volleying is an often-overlooked weapon in his armoury), the stunning winner and the cry of \"Vamos!\" and there were even a couple of aces.\n\nHe served for the second set but was broken to love; he saved break points at the start of the third set and then broke for a 2-0 lead. He was broken back. Broken again to go 4-3 down, he had two chances to break another time but he could not take them; Zverev was not going to let him. And that was that.\n\nThen again, Zverev came to Paris as the champion of Rome and with 13 competitive, clay court matches behind him. Nadal came here with just 11 competitive matches on any surface since the start of the year (only two were on clay). To be fair to Zverev, he played well: he did not let the occasion and the crowd get to him - everyone apart from his team was supporting Nadal - and he stuck to his game plan from start to finish.\n\nZverev was also very gracious at the end. When asked about his win, he looked closer to tears than Nadal and thanked the great champion \"from all of the tennis world\". It was, he said, a great honour to play him but \"this is not my moment; it's Rafa's moment. Let him speak.\" On the second day of the French Open, Zverev did exceedingly well on the court and off it.\n\nAs for Nadal, he was both encouraged by what he had done and, at the same time, disappointed...\n\n\"I went on court with the strange feeling that I'm going to be playing first round in Roland-Garros and I will not be favourite, and that's the true,\" he said.\n\n\"But I went on court with the idea to fight for the match, to put the level, the energy there, and just hope that the opponent don't play at his best, because always first round is tough. I played for moments at, I think, a very good level but in other moments I missed.\n\n\"But that's something that is 100 per cent normal when you are not playing tournaments in a row, when you are not playing these kind of matches since almost two years. It's normal that your level is not [consistently high] because in the end you need to practice this, and the only way to practice this is competing.\"\n\nHis final thoughts were that \"I was not that far; that's my feeling\" and that was better than he could have hoped for a couple of weeks ago. He is making no promises about the future but \"the dynamic is positive the last few weeks\".\n\nThe plan is to let the dust settle on his French Open, clear his head and then see where he is. The only part of his future plans coming into immediate focus is Wimbledon - and that is highly unlikely to be on his agenda. With the progress he has made on clay, the idea of switching to grass and then back to clay for the Olympics does not sound wise. \"I feel that's not a good idea, but I can't confirm,\" he said.\n\nBut coming back here next year? That is still up in the air.\n\n\"At the end, it's about not having the feeling in one year or one year and a half that I didn't give myself a chance, a real chance,\" he said, \"if immediately that I started to become a little bit more healthier, I stop. That's why I am not saying I am retiring today. Give me two months till Olympics, and then let's see if I am able to keep going or I say, okay, guys, it's more than enough. Let's see.\"\n\nWhich brings us back to the Rolling Stones (and they are still going even if some of them are in their 80s):", "source": {"uri": "10sballs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8150490459", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "20:49:16", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T20:49:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T20:48:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/sports/professional/other/nadal-rafael-french-open-tennis-major-atp/article_bf312e84-55e3-58c8-820e-e7168087c784.html", "title": "Nadal doesn't announce retirement, future unclear", "body": "PARIS -- Let's get this part out of the way: Rafael Nadal did not announce his retirement after exiting the French Open in the first round.\n\nNothing else, though, is entirely clear about what comes next for the owner of 22 Grand Slam titles. He turns 38 in a week and has been dealing with injuries for quite some time.\n\n\"I don't know,\" Nadal acknowledged, \"what's going to happen in the next few months.\"\n\nHe probably won't be back at the tournament where he's collected a record 14 trophies, but write that in pencil, because he would not completely rule out the possibility in the days leading up to, or the moments immediately following, the 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3 loss to Alexander Zverev at Roland Garros on Monday that gave the Spaniard the first losing streak of his career on clay courts.\n\nHe probably won't enter Wimbledon, because it just doesn't seem like a good idea to switch to grass right now, although he would not completely rule that out, either.\n\nPeople are also reading... Jaden Dalton becomes McDowell's newest Eagle Scout Gym Rats: McDowell's girls and boys basketball players competitive this spring in conditioning Mountain Athletic Conference releases all-conference teams for spring 2024 McDowell student receives prestigious award Marion police chief: No robbery occurred at First Citizens Bank James Gorst Day held at Eastfield Global Magnet School Former McDowell High School counselor charged with sex acts on a student makes court appearance Proposed McDowell budget leaves tax rate unchanged Downtown Marion's Spillway Bridge closes its doors Mission Hospital McDowell CEO: Our nurses have a deep connection to community Marion couple charged with child abuse appear in court Rotary Club of Marion recognizes Students of the Week McDowell County's Memorial Day service set for Sunday NCHSAA releases 2024 baseball and softball playoff brackets Week two of the Tuesday Night Trail decided by a short margin\n\nAs for the Paris Olympics, which will hold the tennis competition at Roland Garros starting in two months? He probably will be there, but -- hey, here's a twist -- he wouldn't completely commit to that.\n\nSo in sum, all we really know about what the future holds for Nadal is that we don't really know a thing about what the future holds for him. Which, of course, is OK, because he is allowed to do whatever he wants, whenever he wants, however he wants.\n\n\"Obviously,\" Zverev observed, \"there are uncertainties.\"\n\nObviously.\n\n\"That's why I am not saying I am retiring today,\" said Nadal, whose 1 1/2-year-old child, Rafael Jr., sat on his mother's lap at Court Philippe Chatrier on Monday. \"In terms of what's driving me ... I'm a simple guy. I enjoy what I do. I am passionate about sport, I am passionate about competition. I like to practice, I like to play tennis. I'm in a different moment of my personal life, too, traveling with my son, wife. I am enjoying these moments that will not come back.\"\n\nSo, basically, why force himself to stop? Why not try to see how much more his body can take?\n\nWhy not hope to stay out there, doing what he's done so well for so long, and maybe just give himself and his family -- particularly his kid, still too young to remember what is happening yet -- some memories to hold onto one day?\n\n\"If I keep enjoying doing what I am doing and I feel myself competitive and healthy enough to enjoy, I want to keep going for a while,\" Nadal explained. \"I don't know for how long, but I want to keep going for a while, because they are having fun, I am having fun, and I need to see -- I need to give myself a little bit longer ... to see if my level is growing and my body is holding, and then let's make a decision.\"\n\nMakes perfect sense.\n\nEspecially considering what both opponents took away from this latest performance, which was hardly up to Nadal's career-long standards but did include the occasional patch of play that might have been good enough to get past a lesser obstacle than Zverev.\n\nThe 27-year-old German is, after all, ranked No. 4, was the runner-up at the U.S. Open four years ago and the gold medalist at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago. Plus, he is coming off a clay title at the Italian Open and has been a semifinalist at Roland Garros each of the past three years.\n\n\"I mean, I was not that far,\" Nadal said. \"That's my feeling.\"\n\nZverev's assessment: \"If he stays healthy, he's going to continue playing better.\"\n\nNadal sounded as though he agreed with that. He also asked for some time to make up his mind.\n\n\"Give me two months 'til the Olympics, and then let's see if I am able to keep going or I say, 'OK, guys, it's more than enough.' Let's see,\" Nadal said Monday evening, after only his fourth loss in 116 French Open matches. \"I mean, today is not a moment to analyze all these kind of things.\"\n\nAP Sports Week in Pictures: Stanley Cup and NBA playoffs, baseball, soccer and more! It is difficult for me to talk. Honestly I don't know if it will be the last time before you all,\" the 14-time champion said.\n\n\"It is a big percentage I will not be back, but the body is feeling a bit better and I having fun.\n\n\"Maybe in two months I will say enough (and retire), but I hope to be back on this court in two months for the Olympics. That motivates me.\"\n\nHaving only recently returned from a near 18-month absence that has encouraged him to keep going -- and to target more gold.\n\nNadal won singles gold at the 2008 Beijing Olympics and doubles gold at Rio 2016.\n\nThat this year's tennis tournament will be on his favourite court, where he won 14 French Open singles titles, has further tempted him.\n\nHowever, that does mean Wimbledon, where he won in 2008 and 2010, is likely to be sacrificed.\n\nHe has only competed in SW19 once in the last four years -- in 2022 when he had to withdraw through injury ahead of his semi-final with Nick Kyrgios.\n\n\"It looks difficult, honestly, to make a transition to grass, having the Olympics again on clay,\" said Nadal.\n\n\"I'm booked in Wimbledon because I had to, (but) I don't think it's a positive idea right now.\n\n\"I need to talk with the team. I need to analyse so many facts. But I don't think it's going to be smart after all the things that happened to my body to make a big transition to a completely different surface and then come back to clay.\"\n\nNadal, 38 next week, missed most of 2023 with a hip problem and this year's comeback was hampered by a muscle tear, then a series of minor issues affected his Paris preparation.\n\n\"My body has been a jungle for two years. You don't know what to expect. I wake up one day and I find a snake biting me. Another day a tiger,\" Nadal added.\n\n\"I've been fighting with all the things that I went through. But the dynamic is positive the last few weeks. I felt ready. I think tomorrow I'll be ready to play again if I have to. But I will not have to.\n\n\"Now, I need to prepare myself, I need to clear my ideas and see what's the new calendar to try to be ready for Olympics. My main goal now is to play the Olympics.\"\n\nLonger term, sounding much like his old friend and rival Andy Murray who also lost in the first round in Paris, he said he wanted to carry on playing while he was healthy and having fun.\n\nAnd even in defeat on the clay where he had so rarely lost before, he had fun.\n\n\"If it's the last time that I played here, I am at peace with myself,\" Nadal Between a missed drop shot and a forehand error, both players showcased excellent tennis.\n\nNadal's play came in bursts, while Zverev maintained a steady barrage of powerful serves, forehands, and backhands.\n\nUltimately, Nadal lacked the consistency to compete with Zverev. The Rome champion and three-time Roland Garros semifinalist solidified his credentials with a 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3 victory, potentially marking himself as the tournament favorite.", "source": {"uri": "rediff.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Rediff.com India Ltd."}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alexander_Zverev", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Alexander Zverev"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rafael_Nadal", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Rafael Nadal"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_Open", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "French Open"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forehand", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Forehand"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drop_shot", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Drop shot"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tennis", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Tennis"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backhand", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Backhand"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Tennis/Tournaments", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Tennis/Tournaments", "wgt": 10}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Tennis/Social", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Tennis/Social", "wgt": 9}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Pets/Lost_and_Found", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Pets/Lost and Found", "wgt": 11}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Tennis/Organizations", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Tennis/Organizations", "wgt": 8}, {"uri": "dmoz/Sports/Tennis/Juniors", "label": "dmoz/Sports/Tennis/Juniors", "wgt": 8}, {"uri": "news/Sports", "label": "news/Sports", "wgt": 95}], "image": "https://im.rediff.com/sports/2024/may/27zverev.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9598845", "eventUri": "eng-9598845", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.1450980392156862, "wgt": 145, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-05-368794725", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "14:35:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T14:35:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T13:02:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.espn.com/tennis/story/_/id/40206973/2024-french-open-expert-picks-winner-predictions", "title": "Expert picks: Who will win the French Open titles?", "body": "The French Open begins Sunday, and though 14-time champion Rafael Nadal and defending champion Novak Djokovic are both playing, questions abound on whether either will challenge for the title. On the women's side, Iga Swiatek has been looking unstoppable, but can she close the deal? We asked our experts to weigh in.\n\nWho will win the men's singles title?\n\nPam Shriver: Rafa Nadal. I am picking the 14-time champion because for one more time I can pick the greatest clay-court player in history, and because there are too many question marks surrounding the real favorites on the men's side. Carlos Alcaraz, Jannik Sinner and Djokovic all have too many questions to feel comfortable picking any of them.\n\nDo I really think Nadal can win his 15th Roland Garros title? No, but Nadal for 20 years has done countless things I thought not possible. Even with an impossibly hard first-round match versus Alexander Zverev, I still have to write in Nadal's name one more time as my winner. Nadal's first-round opponent is probably your real favorite on paper, before the draw starts.\n\nBrad Gilbert: Feels like the men's field, for the first time in 20 years, is very open, and it's extremely difficult to pick a winner, whereas in past years, Nadal has absolutely dominated. Djokovic hasn't won a tournament in 2024 so far and would normally be the overwhelming favorite at every Slam. Add in the injury concerns for Sinner and Alcaraz, who are hopefully both healthy now.\n\nThe fact that Nadal is unseeded is wild, as is the fact that he is playing Zverev in the first round. I think it will be two tournaments: The first week, we'll see how many top seeds get through, and then a second-week tournament from there. There might be good opportunities for Stefanos Tsitsipas, Casper Ruud and Zverev if he gets through Nadal. I could easily see something very unpredictable happening 17 days from now.\n\nBill Connelly: If you're Zverev, Tsitsipas, Ruud or Holger Rune, or anyone else hoping that the top tier slips up at some point and gives you a shot at an actual Slam title, your odds might be as good right now as they've been in quite a while (or will be moving forward). Now's your chance.\n\nI'm not picking any of those guys, however. If Sinner hadn't hurt his hip, I'd have kept riding that wave. Instead, I'll give this Djokovic guy a shot. I hear he's pretty good in best-of-five matches.\n\nTom Hamilton: This has to be the most open field in a while. Sinner comes into this recovering from his hip injury, Nadal could yet roll back the stone, Djokovic could end up sweeping the field, and then there's Alcaraz, who's recovering from an arm injury. And don't discount the others like Zverev, Andrey Rublev, Rune and Ruud. So having comfortably sat on the fence, I'm going to go with Alcaraz -- if he's fit. If he's not 100%, then I think Djokovic has a brilliant chance, but it could be Ruud's turn as well, in his third attempt here.\n\nD'Arcy Maine: I don't think I've ever had such a tough time predicting a men's champion at a major. There are so many contenders -- and perhaps even more questions about almost all of them. Before the draw came out, I thought Sinner had a decent chance, assuming his hip was at, or near, 100%, but his path to the final might be too much coming off that injury.\n\nSo, I'm instead going to pick Ruud, who has reached the Roland Garros final the past two years. He won the title in Barcelona this year and reached the final in Monte Carlo. He would need to get past Djokovic in the quarters, but he beat him in Monte Carlo for the first time in six tries and now knows he can.\n\nWho will win the women's singles title?\n\nShriver: Swiatek will win her fourth Roland Garros. She is already starting to be compared to Nadal in terms of success in Paris, and given Swiatek won both Madrid and Rome, she is the obvious pick to win her fifth major. Swiatek's idol is Nadal, therefore it's satisfying to pick them both one more time.\n\nConnelly: ESPN BET has Swiatek listed as the betting favorite over the rest of the field combined. If she wins, she'll have as many French Open titles at age 23 as Nadal, aka the greatest clay-courter ever. How on earth are you supposed to pick against that? I can't, anyway.\n\nHamilton: We're in the passing of the baton stage -- from one dominant force in Nadal to the next clay-court champion: Swiatek. As stunning as the Madrid final was, the Rome final was ominous as to how good Swiatek can be. We're starting to see a wonderful rivalry shaping up here between her and Aryna Sabalenka, but Swiatek cuts differently on clay. She finds her zone on this surface, blocking out any distractions and just clocks into a higher gear.\n\nHer opponents will hope someone finds an Elena Rybakina-type performance, similar to when she overcame Swiatek in the semifinals at Stuttgart, but let's face it, Swiatek is the player to beat.\n\nMaine: Swiatek. She had already proved she was the best in the world on clay, but she has separated herself even further this season from the rest of the field. She overcame a very tricky test against Sabalenka in the exceptional Madrid final and then absolutely dismantled the world No. 2 in the Rome final two weeks later. Barring injury, I don't see anyone beating Swiatek -- who seems to get more and more confident with every match she wins -- at Roland Garros this year.", "source": {"uri": "espn.com", "dataType": He underwent surgery and ended up missing the rest of the season with another injury, but he returned last year to reach his third consecutive French Open semi-final.\n\nWith some of the other top players such as Novak Djokovic, Jannik Sinner and Carlos Alcaraz, struggling with injuries of late, this could be Zverev's chance to finally win a Grand Slam.\n\nThe German might not have wanted to meet Nadal so early in the tournament but he was happy to have the chance to take him on again.\n\n\"I really wanted to play him here. {"uri": "2024-05-370002342", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "17:47:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T17:47:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T17:44:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.thenewstribune.com/sports/article288782225.html", "title": "Rafael Nadal ousted in straight sets at Roland Garros", "body": "German Alexander Zverev defeated Rafael Nadal in straight sets at the French Open on Monday, ending what could be the Spaniard's final career appearance at Roland Garros.\n\nZverev defeated the 14-time French champion 6-3, 7-4 (4), 6-3 at Paris to advance to the second round.\n\n\"To be honest I don't know what to say. First of all, thank you Rafa from all of the tennis world. It's such a great honor,\" Zverev said in his on-court interview. \"I've watched Rafa play all my childhood and I was lucky enough to play Rafa when I became a professional. I was lucky enough to play him two times on this beautiful court.\n\n\"I don't know what to say. Today is not my moment, it's Rafa's moment, so thank you.\"\n\nZverev becomes just the third player to defeat Nadal at Roland Garros, joining Novak Djokovic (twice) and Robin Soderling. Nadal, who fell to 112-4 on the clay in France, owns 22 Grand Slam titles but missed last year's French Open dealing with injuries.\n\n\"It's difficult for me to talk. I don't know if it's going to be the last time that I'm going to be here in front of all of you, honestly,\" Nadal said. \"I am not 100 percent sure, but if it's the last time, I enjoyed it.\n\n\"The crowd has been amazing during the whole week of preparation and the feelings that I have today are difficult to describe in words. But for me it's so special to feel the love of the people the way that I felt in the place that I love the most.\"\n\nIn other action Monday, No. 2 seed Jannik Sinner of Italy defeated Christopher {"uri": "8148386844", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "15:34:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T15:34:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T15:33:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/tennis/rafael-nadal-grand-slam-match-wins-two-sets-to-love-down-record-medvedev-youzhny-aus-open-wimbledon/article68221709.ece", "title": "How many Grand Slam matches has Rafael Nadal won from two-sets-to-love down?", "body": "Rafael Nadal is a 22-time Major champion. Ever since the Spaniard won his first Grand Slam at Roland Garris in 2005, he has been one of the players to watch out at the biggest stage every year.\n\nWhen it comes to number of matches at Majors, Nadal has played 357 of them and won 314 times. Many a times, he has come back from really dire situations to end up on the winning side. Three of those happened when he was on the verge of elimination after losing the first two sets.\n\nREAD | How many five-set matches has Rafael Nadal played at French Open?\n\nHere are the three instances when Nadal came from two-sets-to-love down to win a Grand Slam match:-\n\nWimbledon 2006, Round of 64 - Rafael Nadal beat USA's Robert Kendrick 6-7(4), 3-6, 7-6(2), 7-5, 6-4 Nadal in action against USA's Robert Kendrick during Wimbledon Tennis Championships on June 29, 2006. | Photo Credit: AFP\n\nNadal in action against USA's Robert Kendrick during Wimbledon Tennis Championships on June 29, 2006. | Photo Credit: AFP\n\nThe first time Nadal lost the opening two sets in a Grand Slam match was against USA's Robert Kendrick in the second round of Wimbledon in 2006. World No. 237 Kendrick was on his way to defeating then then World No. 2 Nadal after leading 7-6(4), 6-3 but the Spaniard clinched the third set in the tiebreak and completed the comeback by winning the next two 7-5 and 6-4. Nadal eventually lost to Roger Federer in the final of that edition.\n\nWimbledon 2007, Round of 16 - Rafael Nadal beat Russia's Mikhail Youzhny 4-6, 3-6, 6-1, 6-2, 6-2 Nadal returns the ball to Russian Mikhail Youzhny during the 4th round at Wimbledon on July 5, 2007. | Photo Credit: ADRIAN DENNIS\n\nNadal returns the ball to Russian Mikhail Youzhny during the 4th round at Wimbledon on July 5, 2007. | Photo Credit: ADRIAN DENNIS\n\nA year after a scare against Kendrick, Nadal again trailed by two-sets-to-love at the grass Major - this time against Russia's Mikhail Youzhny, the then World No. 13, in the fourth round. However, unlike the match against the American, Nadal won the final three sets fairly easily. Like 2006, Nadal yet again lost to Federer in the summit clash.\n\nAustralian Open 2022, Final - Rafael Nadal beat Russia's Daniil Medvedev 2-6, 6-7(5), 6-4, 6-4, 7-5\n\nNadal's third and most recent comeback from two-sets-to-love down came in the final of the Australian Open in 2022. The Spaniard, who had sat out the second half of the previous season with a foot injury, went on an incredible run to reach the summit clash in Melbourne. It was turning out to be anything but a fairytale when he lost the opening two sets against Daniil Medvedev. He even fell 0-40 down while serving at 2-3 in the third set.\n\nHowever, the Spaniard fought back incredibly to take the third and fourth sets with an identical score of 6-4. Nadal served for the title at 5-4 in the fifth but the Russian broke back. Nadal recovered from that blip and restored his advantage by breaking Medvedev in the very next game and this time, served for the title successfully.\n\nLatest on SportstarHow many Grand Slam matches {"uri": "8150491618", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-28", "time": "20:50:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-28T20:50:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-28T20:49:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://siouxcityjournal.com/sports/professional/other/nadal-rafael-french-open-tennis-major-atp/article_8aca99a7-6cf7-58b3-9b4a-df9f7fd4b4ed.html", "title": "Nadal doesn't announce retirement, future unclear", "body": "PARIS -- Let's get this part out of the way: Rafael Nadal did not announce his retirement after exiting the French Open in the first round.\n\nNothing else, though, is entirely clear about what comes next for the owner of 22 Grand Slam titles. He turns 38 in a week and has been dealing with injuries for quite some time.\n\n\"I don't know,\" Nadal acknowledged, \"what's going to happen in the next few months.\"\n\nHe probably won't be back at the tournament where he's collected a record 14 trophies, but write that in pencil, because he would not completely rule out the possibility in the days leading up to, or the moments immediately following, the 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3 loss to Alexander Zverev at Roland Garros on Monday that gave the Spaniard the first losing streak of his career on clay courts.\n\nHe probably won't enter Wimbledon, because it just doesn't seem like a good idea to switch to grass right now, although he would not completely rule that out, either.\n\nPeople are also reading... Man crashes vintage replica hot rod into Waterloo library moments after purchase East High School student to spend her summer as part of a world-renowned drum and bugle corps Wells gives $1 million to Le Mars daycare center Sioux City sues marina manager for breach of contract UPDATED: Sioux City officers doubted fatal shooting suspect was intoxicated Ceremony marks 175th anniversary of Bruguier's Cabin, Sioux City's oldest structure Friday night Nebraska football home game frustrates high school coaches, administators Sioux City West stuns top-ranked Lewis Central in boys soccer DEAR ABBY: Wealthy in-law 'forgets' promise made to widow Judge dismisses Bertrand defamation against Greenwell, suit continues for school district, ex-employee UPDATED: Leak found in Leif Erikson pool as Riverside aquatic center opens for Memorial Day weekend DEAR ABBY: Relative reveals sordid story to prevent wedding Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for May 28, 2024 Iowa nurse pays $52,560 to settle million-dollar Medicare fraud case Siouxland United FC wins NPSL home opener against TwinStars\n\nAs for the Paris Olympics, which will hold the tennis competition at Roland Garros starting in two months? He probably will be there, but -- hey, here's a twist -- he wouldn't completely commit to that.\n\nSo in sum, all we really know about what the future holds for Nadal is that we don't really know a thing about what the future holds for him. Which, of course, is OK, because he is allowed to do whatever he wants, whenever he wants, however he wants.\n\n\"Obviously,\" Zverev observed, \"there are uncertainties.\"\n\nObviously.\n\n\"That's why I am not saying I am retiring today,\" said Nadal, whose 1 1/2-year-old child, Rafael Jr., sat on his mother's lap at Court Philippe Chatrier on Monday. \"In terms of what's driving me ... I'm a simple guy. I enjoy what I do. I am passionate about sport, I am passionate about competition. I like to practice, I like to play tennis. I'm in a different moment of my personal life, too, traveling with my son, wife. I am enjoying these moments that will not come back.\"\n\nSo, basically, why force himself to stop? Why not try to see how much more his body can take?\n\nWhy not hope to stay out there, doing what he's done so well for so long, and maybe just give himself and his family -- particularly his kid, still too young to remember what is happening yet -- some memories to hold onto one day?\n\n\"If I keep enjoying doing what I am doing and I feel myself competitive and healthy enough to enjoy, I want to keep going for a while,\" Nadal explained. \"I don't know for how long, but I want to keep going for a while, because they are having fun, I am having fun, and I need to see -- I need to give myself a little bit longer ... to see if my level is growing and my body is holding, and then let's make a decision.\"\n\nMakes perfect sense.\n\nEspecially considering what both opponents took away from this latest performance, which was hardly up to Nadal's career-long standards but did include the occasional patch of play that might have been good enough to get past a lesser obstacle than Zverev.\n\nThe 27-year-old German is, after all, ranked No. 4, was the runner-up at the U.S. Open four years ago and the gold medalist at the Tokyo Olympics three years ago. Plus, he is coming off a clay title at the Italian Open and has been a semifinalist at Roland Garros each of the past three years.\n\n\"I mean, I was not that far,\" Nadal said. \"That's my feeling.\"\n\nZverev's assessment: \"If he stays healthy, he's going to continue playing better.\"\n\nNadal sounded as though he agreed with that. He also asked for some time to make up his mind.\n\n\"Give me two months 'til the Olympics, and then let's see if I am able to keep going or I say, 'OK, guys, it's more than enough.' Let's see,\" Nadal said Monday evening, after only his fourth loss in 116 French Open matches. \"I mean, today is not a moment to analyze all these kind of things.\"\n\nAP Sports Week in Pictures: Having only recently returned from a near 18-month absence that has encouraged him to keep going - and to target more gold.\n\nNadal won singles gold at the 2008 Beijing Olympics and doubles gold at Rio 2016. That this year's tennis tournament will be on his favourite court, where he won 14 French Open singles titles, has further tempted him.\n\nHowever, that does mean Wimbledon, where he won in 2008 and 2010, is likely to be sacrificed. He has only competed in SW19 once in the last four years - in 2022 when he had to withdraw through injury ahead of his semi-final with Nick Kyrgios.\n\n\"It looks difficult, honestly, to make a transition to grass, having the Olympics again on clay,\" said Nadal. \"I'm booked in Wimbledon because I had to, [but] I don't think it's a positive idea right now.\n\n\"I need to talk with the team. I need to analyse so many facts. But I don't think it's going to be smart after all the things that happened to my body to make a big transition to a completely different surface and then come back to clay.\"\n\nNadal, 38 next week, missed most of 2023 with a hip problem and this year's comeback was hampered by a muscle tear, then a series of minor issues affected his Paris preparation.\n\n\"My body has been a jungle for two years. You don't know what to expect. I wake up one day and I find a snake biting me. Another day a tiger,\" Nadal added.\n\n\"I've been fighting with all the things that I went through. But the dynamic is positive the last few weeks. I felt ready. I think tomorrow I'll be ready to play again if I have to. But I will not have to.\n\n\"Now, I need to prepare myself, I need to clear my ideas and see what's the new calendar to try to be ready for Olympics. My main goal now is to play the Olympics.\"\n\nLonger term, sounding much like his old friend and rival Andy Murray who also lost in the first round in Paris, he said he wanted to carry on playing while he was healthy and having fun. And even in defeat on the clay where he had so rarely lost before, he had fun.\n\n\"If it's the last time that I played here,\" Nadal said, \"I am at peace with myself.\"", "source": {"uri": "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.tennis365.com/tennis-features/rafael-nadal-olympic-games-record-sets-sights-paris-2024", "title": "Rafael Nadal's Olympic Games record - as he sets sights on Paris 2024", "body": "Rafael Nadal won singles gold at the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing\n\nHave we seen the last of Rafael Nadal at the French Open?\n\nThe 14-time Roland Garros champion is yet to fully commit either way, but it seems more than possible his loss to Alexander Zverev was his final match at the event.\n\nHowever, it might not be the last time he plays on-site at Roland Garros.\n\nThe Spaniard is targeting an Olympic Games spot this summer, with the tennis event at Paris 2024 being held at the same venue where he holds a staggering 112-4 record.\n\nAs he targets more Olympic success, we look back at Nadal's extraordinary record at the Games.\n\nNadal did not play singles at his first Olympics in Athens 20 years ago, focusing on doubles.\n\nBut the Spaniard won gold on his singles debut at the following Games, winning the title at Beijing 2008.\n\nSecond seed at the event - and fresh off consecutive French Open and Wimbledon wins - Nadal eased into the last four, where he beat Novak Djokovic 6-4, 1-6, 6-4 to guarantee a medal.\n\nAnd he claimed the first gold medal of his career in the final, downing Chile's Fernando Gonzalez 6-3, 7-6(2), 6-3 to seal victory.\n\nStruggling with injury, Nadal was forced to pull out of his title defence at London 2012 - though returned to action at the Rio 2016 Games.\n\nThird seed at the Games, Nadal ended the charge of home favourite Thomaz Bellucci in the last eight, though was beaten 5-7, 6-4, 7-6(5) by Juan Martin del Potro in an epic semi-final.\n\nIn a bronze medal playoff shrouded in controversy - with opponent Kei Nishikori taking a lengthy break after the second set - he was beaten by 6-2, 6-7(1), 6-3 as he was forced to settle for fourth.\n\nNadal was just 18 when making his Olympic debut in Athens, playing doubles alongside now-coach Carlos Moya - though the duo lost in straight sets to Brazil's Andre Sa and Flavio Saretta.\n\nFour years later, Nadal was the sixth seed in the doubles draw alongside Tommy Robredo, though this campaign was only marginally better than his previous tilt at doubles glory.\n\nThey beat Sweden's Jonas Bjorkman and Robin Soderling in round one but were then beaten by Australian duo Christopher Guccione and Lleyton Hewitt.\n\nFast forward eight years, and it was an entirely different story.\n\nSeeded sixth alongside frequent partner Marc Lopez, Nadal eased through to the last four - where he and Lopez beat Canada's Daniel Nestor and Vasek Pospisil in two tiebreaks to reach the gold medal match.\n\nAnd the Spaniard memorably claimed the second Olympic gold of his legendary career, battling past Romanian fifth seeds Florin Mergea and Horia Tecau 6-2, 3-6, 6-4.\n\nNadal was meant to play mixed doubles alongside Garbine Muguruza in Rio, but the duo withdrew pre-tournament.\n\nAfter skipping Tokyo 2020 due to injury, Nadal will be looking for a strong Olympic farewell in Paris this summer - potentially making his last Roland Garros appearance.\n\nNadal's comments after his French Open loss send an Olympic-sized statement of intent, as it appears he will skip Wimbledon to prioritize the Games.\n\nCurrently ranked 275th, the 22-time Slam winner is well outside the Olympic entry list cutoff.\n\nBut he is an obvious pick for one of the two Wildcard spots saved for Grand Slam winners, and - should his body be willing - he looks set to play.\n\nAnd all eyes will be on whether he plays doubles as well, with himself and Carlos Alcaraz publicly expressing interest in a blockbuster partnership between the two.", "source": {"uri": "8148500298", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "17:02:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T17:02:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T17:01:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.si.com/tennis/even-in-defeat-rafael-nadal-is-a-champion-at-roland-garros", "title": "Even in Defeat, Rafael Nadal Is a Champion at Roland Garros", "body": "Rafael Nadal fell to Alexander Zverev in the first round of the 2024 French Open. / Clive Mason/Getty Images\n\nHe is a man who needs no introduction. Especially here, where his statue adorns the grounds. But when Rafael Nadal came out today for his first match of the 2024 French Open, the courtside announcer did his thing. Taking a breath, he summoned Nadal by name and then ticked off the years he had won the title.\n\n2005\n\n2006\n\n2007\n\n2008\n\n2010\n\n2011\n\n2012\n\n2013\n\n2014\n\n2017\n\n2018\n\n2019\n\n2020\n\n2022\n\nFourteen in all. It\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s a joke of a tally. The recitation of which enabled a somber occasion to start with some levity.\n\nPresumptively, this was to be Nadal\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s last French Open, his final raging against the dying of the light. He turns 38 next week. His current ranking slums outside the top 250, the kind of grim math that comes when your body doesn\u00e2\u20ac\u2122t let you play\u00e2\u20ac\"much less win\u00e2\u20ac\"many matches.\n\nHe entered the tournament unseeded, jarring in itself. And, the tennis fates did their thing, yielding a first-round opponent of \u00e2\u20ac| Alexander Zverev, the fourth seed, the player who won last week\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s big preview event in Rome, one of the top contenders, the last player at Roland Garros to push Nadal.\n\nSo it was these last dance vibes that came edged with a wince. The Rolling Stones or Elton John can announce a final tour. They may not hit every note. But they also don\u00e2\u20ac\u2122t lose in straight sets to, say, Mumford & Sons.\n\nTickets to the most anticipated match in the history of tennis\u00e2\u20ac\"it's not hyperbole: try and name another\u00e2\u20ac\"fetched $5000 on the secondary markets and brought out both royalty and tennis nobility. Though he plays tomorrow, Novak Djokovic was in the stands. As was Carlos Alcaraz, the betting favorite to win this event. Iga \u00c5\u0161wi\u00c4...tek, the defending women\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s champion, finished her first-round assignation, showered and took a seat.\n\nAs for the match itself \u00e2\u20ac| it played out as expected. Nostalgia and hope are powerful intoxicants. But eventually, they regress to the mean, and talent and time win out.\n\nThere were moments when Nadal did a convincing Nadal impersonation, striking the ball ferociously, picking off volleys, looking like the clay court impresario whose career record at this venue, going into today, was 112\u00e2\u20ac\"3. There were times when he looked like a man in his late 30s\u00e2\u20ac\"playing a fine opponent, more than a decade younger. There were times when he looked fresh, and there were times he looked physically spent, as one would expect from any player who had gone more than 450 days without playing a best-of-five match.\n\nNadal was, inauspiciously, broken to start the match, and Zverev took the first set 6\u00e2\u20ac\"3. Nadal broke Zverev and served for the second, electrifying the crowd. When he failed to close, the deflation was palpable. When he lost the second set in a tiebreaker, this went from an exercise in potentially witnessing history to an exercise in potentially witnessing Nadal\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s final match, at least at the French Open.\n\nThe third set was Nadal's insistence on not going quietly. He got up an early break. He then gave up that early break and fell 6\u00e2\u20ac\"3, 7\u00e2\u20ac\"6, 6\u00e2\u20ac\"3. Respectable? Absolutely. But not the result befitting a 14-time champ.\n\nYou cite the comical, flattering stats, you also have to cite the downers. For the first time in nearly 20 years, Nadal lost in the first round of a clay event. For the first time here, he lost in the first round. For the first time ever, he has now lost back-to-back matches on clay.\u00c2\n\nCredit Zverev for compartmentalizing, ignoring the occasion, locking in mentally, and simply bringing his flagrant talent\u00e2\u20ac\"especially on his backhand\u00e2\u20ac\"to bear. He can now pivot from this momentous match to trying to win his first major, a distinct possibility. (Zverev's appeal of a penalty order issued by a German court stemming from domestic abuse allegations made by his ex-girlfriend goes to trial during the tournament.)\n\nAs for Nadal \u00e2\u20ac| who knows? He called off a retirement ceremony the tournament had planned. It\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s not that he\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s being coy about the endpoint of his unrivaled career. It\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s that, by all accounts, he genuinely doesn\u00e2\u20ac\u2122t know when the ride will end. Ironically his last match might be in Paris in two months, assuming he fulfills his vow to play in the 2024 Olympics.\n\nHe left the court wearing a look of resignation. One that suggested he has played the French Open for the last time. But also\u00e2\u20ac\"a champion to the end\u00e2\u20ac\"that he genuinely thought he could take this match.\u00c2", "source": {"uri": "si.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sports Illustrated"}, {"uri": "8146759708", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "14:36:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T14:36:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T14:35:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/tennis/nadal-unseeded-zverev-domestic-abuse-trial-french-open-2024-amelie-mauresmo-press-conference-roland-garros/article68218716.ece", "title": "French Open 2024: What did tournament director Mauresmo say on Nadal being unseeded; Zverev's domestic abuse trial?", "body": "Despite having a dominant record at the French Open, 14-time champion Rafael Nadal has not been seeded this year and so could have been placed anywhere in the bracket and been stuck playing anyone at all, even the very best opponents.\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3 and has said previously he expects this to be his last season, will face No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev in the first round on Monday.\n\nBecause of injuries, including a surgically repaired hip and problematic abdominal muscle, Nadal has not played much in the past two seasons, going only 7-4 in 2024. So, someone who has been ranked No. 1 and spent more than a decade inside the top 10 is now outside the top 250.\n\nThis is Nadal's first Grand Slam tournament without a seeding since the 2005 Australian Open. The top 32 players in the men's and women's draws are seeded, and the seedings are based on the ATP and WTA rankings, which take into account the most recent 52 weeks of results. In theory, Mauresmo could have opted to circumvent the rules and go ahead and award a seeding to Nadal based on his past performances in Paris. But that was never really considered, she said, in part because \"giving protection to some players\" would result in \"a lot of other issues and problems,\" and because \"it also has to be OK with other Grand Slams and everything.\"\n\nREAD | Why Rafael Nadal will not have a farewell ceremony at Roland Garros this year\n\nPlayers who are seeded, such as Zverev, are guaranteed to avoid going up against another seeded player any earlier than the third round of a Grand Slam tournament, which have 128-player fields and require seven victories to earn a championship.\n\nPlayers tend to agree with Mauresmo's decision, with several saying they believe the seeding system should remain the way it currently is (Wimbledon used to seed players according to their results on grass courts, but has strictly followed the rankings since 2021). \"The way that the seedings work, I think it's appropriate. In this case, it's unfortunate how that happened, but I don't know how you gauge where someone should and shouldn't be seeded based on past or previous success,\" said three-time major champion Andy Murray. \"It'd be quite hard to do that.\"\n\nZverev is coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open, won a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics and was the 2020 U.S. Open runner-up. He reached the semifinals at the French Open each of the past three years, including in 2022, when he played Nadal at that stage but had to stop after tearing ligaments in his right foot during the match.\n\nThe 27-year-old from Germany, is about to face a court proceeding that starts next week in Berlin related to accusations of physically abusing an ex-girlfriend. He does not need to be in court and said he will not be. \"At the end of the day, I do believe in the German system. I do believe in the truth, as well. I have to be certain that, you know, I do know what I did, I do know what I didn't do,\" Zverev said. \"That's, at the end of the day, what's going to come out, and I have to trust in that.\"\n\nMauresmo was asked about Zverev's status and replied: \"As long as the trial isn't finished and there isn't a decision, he's considered innocent and so that's why he's allowed to be part of the draw.\"\n\nLatest on SportstarKKR vs SRH, IPL 2024 Final Live Match in Pictures: Kolkata's bowlers rattle Sunrisers in the PowerPlayLavanya Lakshmi Narayanan _11351KKR vs SRH, IPL 2024 Final: Travis Head, Abhishek Sharma fall inside two oversTeam SportstarKKR vs SRH Live Score, IPL 2024 Final: SRH 21/2 (4 overs); Head falls for golden duck, Starc castles Abhishek Sharma in first overTeam SportstarF1 Monaco Grand Prix Live Updates, Formula One 2024: Leclerc extends lead to Piastri; Sainz, Norris follow behindTeam SportstarFrench Open 2024: What did tournament director Mauresmo say on Nadal being unseeded; Zverev's domestic abuse trial? {"uri": "8148489121", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "16:52:55", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T16:52:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T16:52:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://bleacherreport.com/articles/10122675-rafael-nadal-saluted-by-fans-after-loss-to-zverev-in-possible-french-open-farewell", "title": "Rafael Nadal Saluted by Fans After Loss to Zverev In Possible French Open Farewell", "body": "If this is indeed Rafael Nadal's last French Open, he wasn't going down without a fight.\n\nThe 14-time champion lost 3-6, 6-7(5), 3-6 to fourth-seeded Alexander Zverev on Monday.\n\nThe 37-year-old has played down the idea of bidding adieu to Roland-Garros this summer, but that didn't fully remove the sense a historic chapter for men's tennis is drawing to a close.\n\nTournament organizers didn't do Nadal any favors, making him an unseeded player and pairing him with Zverev straight out of the gate.\n\nThings didn't look good for the southpaw early on. He dropped serve in the opening game of the match and had nine unforced errors to just five winners in the first set.\n\nNadal bounced back in the second and took a 5-3 lead thanks to a service break in the fifth game. Fans were seeing shades of his old self and gaining some hope an instant classic was in store.\n\nThat belief steadily waned as Zverev won the next four games and eventually took the set in the tiebreaker.\n\nWith Nadal down two sets to none, the question became less about whether he could pull off the upset and instead about if his last French Open ever would end in a first-round, straight-set loss.\n\nFor most fans, the occasion was an opportunity to enjoy a legendary star one more time.\n\nIt's anybody's guess as to what the future holds for Nadal, either for the rest of this season or the 2025 Grand Slam calendar. He has logged a relatively light schedule so far in 2024, so his availability for Wimbledon and the U.S. Open isn't assured.\n\nGreat athletes rarely get to exit on their own terms, and that's especially true in such an unforgiving sport such as tennis. The last few years of Roger Federer's career were pretty unremarkable before he walked away altogether.\n\nLosing to Zverev wasn't the way you would've scripted Nadal's farewell, but at least the general certainty over his likely departure allowed everyone to appreciate his legacy at Roland-Garros.", "source": {"uri": "bleacherreport.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Bleacher Report"}, {"uri": "8148643234", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "19:11:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T19:11:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T19:10:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.baltimoresun.com/2024/05/27/armstrong-williams-rafael-nadal-french-open-tennis/", "title": "Armstrong Williams: Witnessing legend Rafael Nadal at French Open a privilege | STAFF COMMENTARY", "body": "Opinion Columnists | Armstrong Williams: Witnessing legend Rafael Nadal at French Open a privilege | STAFF COMMENTARY\n\nI will always cherish the memory of attending my first match Monday at the 2024 Roland Garros tennis tournament, particularly because it was possibly the final French Open match of Rafael Nadal's illustrious career.\n\nThe sun was shining brightly as I took my seat among thousands of enthusiastic tennis fans at the Phillipe-Chartier Court. All of us were eagerly anticipating the match between Nadal and Alexander Zverev.\n\nFirst, we watched Women's Tennis Association No 1 singles player Iga \u015awi\u0105tek commence the defense of her 2023 French Open Title, as she attempts to win the fifth grand slam of her young career at the French Open, entering the tournament on a 12-match winning streak. If she wins the title this year, she will match Justine Henin's three French Open titles in a row.\n\n\"In the current era of women's tennis, no player has achieved so much in such a short space of time, and even \u015awi\u0105tek admits that her success has been a surprise,\" according to a CNN article.\n\nRoland Garros, which is the official name of the French Open, is one of the four Grand Slam tennis tournaments. The tournament, which is named after the renowned French aviator Roland Garros, has a storied past that dates back to 1891. It has been the site of some of the most memorable moments in the history of tennis, and today it saw what might be the final match in the Paris tournament for the 22-time Grand Slam singles title legend.\n\nPhillipe-Chartier Court, the primary court at Roland Garros, is named after the former president of the French Tennis Federation, who played a significant role in the introduction of tennis to the Olympics. The court has been the site of numerous legendary matches. The red clay surface of the court generates an environment that is unparalleled in the tennis world. It hosted a match today that will be cherished for generations.\n\nThe audience erupted in a combination of cheers for Zverev and an emotional ovation for Nadal upon Zverev's victory in the final point. Nadal lost, 6-3, 7-6 (5), 6-3.\n\nWitnessing the sunset of an era was a bittersweet experience. The past few years have been characterized by these moments as a wave of luminaries, including Serena Williams, Roger Federer, and Juan Mart\u00edn del Potro, have retired.\n\nUpon my departure from the stadium on Memorial Day, I was overwhelmed by a profound sense of gratitude for the tournament and the stadium's rich history. Attending Nadal's match was a privilege. {"uri": "8148534868", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-27", "time": "17:31:43", "dateTime": "2024-05-27T17:31:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-27T17:30:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://bleacherreport.com/articles/10122695-rafael-nadal-cant-say-100-that-i-wont-play-in-french-open-again-after-zverev-loss", "title": "Rafael Nadal: Can't Say 100% That I Won't Play in French Open Again After Zverev Loss", "body": "Rafael Nadal's return to the French Open lasted just one match after losing to Alexander Zverev in the first round in straight sets on Monday.\n\nDespite the loss and past teases of retirement, Nadal declined to say after the match whether or not this would be his last time playing at Roland Garros:\n\n\"I went through all this process with the dream to be back here in Roland Garros. For me it is difficult to say what is going on in the future. It is a big percentage that I will not be back playing here, but I cannot say 100 percent. I enjoy playing here. {"uri": "8147134445", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-26", "time": "21:28:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-26T21:28:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-26T21:27:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://heraldcourier.com/sports/professional/other/nadal-french-open-clay-tennis-atp-major/article_89400c48-59b7-52a3-8296-7939adef8e5f.html", "title": "French Open cancels farewell ceremony for Nadal", "body": "PARIS -- The French tennis federation put off holding a ceremony to celebrate Rafael Nadal at Roland Garros this year, because he has said this might not necessarily be his final appearance at the tournament he has won a record 14 times.\n\nTournament director Am\u00e9lie Mauresmo said Sunday, Day 1 of the clay-court Grand Slam event, that Nadal let officials know he didn't want to close the door on a return before he told the world that at a pre-tournament news conference.\n\n\"As you can imagine, we had something planned for him. But ... because he doesn't know if it's going to be his last Roland Garros or not, he wants to leave the door open maybe to come back next year as a player. So we are not going to push him, obviously, to do anything,\" Mauresmo said.\n\n\"It's his decision when he wants to have a proper ceremony, a proper goodbye, a proper farewell. So we're not going to do it this year. That's his wish,\" she continued. \"And even though we were ready to push the button if something happens, we obviously are going to respect what he wants and make sure we are ready whenever he feels he wants to do it. Later this year; next year; anytime he wants.\"\n\nPeople are also reading... Man arrested after driving vehicle with deceased female in rear seat PREP FOOTBALL: Former Abingdon QB Jake Hess is the new head coach at John Battle after four seasons as assistant 2024 GENE \"PAPPY\" THOMPSON FINALIST NO. 1: Taylor Clay, Eastside VHSL Regional Baseball, Softball, Soccer Preview Capsules for Thursday's Games VHSL Regional Preview Capsules for Friday's Baseball and Softball Games LOCALS IN COLLEGE NOTES: Former Abingdon teammates Chase Hungate (Virginia) and Ethan Gibson (Virginia Tech) faced off on Saturday in a baseball game that was an ACC classic New play shines a spotlight on the legendary woman's journey in 'Grandma Gatewood Took a Walk' PREP BASEBALL: Chance Parker scores Lebanon's only run as Pioneers edge Union in pitching duel between Barton, Neff REGION 3D BASEBALL: Abingdon earns walk-off quarterfinal win over Hidden Valley TUESDAY'S PREP ROUNDUP: Eastside wins Cumberland District baseball tourney; Rye Cove (baseball) earns Region 1D tourney bid; Tennessee High girls tennis falls at state; Abingdon boys, girls tennis in region finals; Jack Clem (Richlands) wins tennis gold PREP BASEBALL: Abingdon edges John Battle in Mountain 7 tourney finals as Elijah Parks delivers walk-off hit PREP TRACK & FIELD: Eastside (girls), Patrick Henry (boys) win Region 1D team titles Abingdon and Saltville lead charge in electric vehicle movement REGION 1D BASEBALL: Patrick Henry hammers out hits in 14-5 road win over Eastside PREP SOFTBALL: Braeley McCoy has her moment in the spotlight as Eastside beats Rye Cove for Cumberland tourney title; Twin Springs clinches regional berth\n\nNadal, who turns 38 on June 3 and has said previously he expects this to be his last season, will face No. 4 seed Alexander Zverev in the first round on Monday. The match is scheduled to be third in the main stadium, Court Philippe Chatrier, and could start at around 3:30 p.m. local time (9:30 a.m. EDT).\n\nHere are some answers to questions about Nadal and Zverev:\n\nWhy are top players like Nadal and Zverev meeting in the first round?\n\nDespite having such a dominant record at the French Open, Nadal was not seeded and so could have been placed anywhere in the bracket and been stuck playing anyone at all, even the very best opponents. Because of injuries, including a surgically repaired hip and problematic abdominal muscle, Nadal has competed little the past two seasons, going only 7-4 in 2024, and so someone who has been ranked No. 1 and spent more than a decade inside the top 10 is now outside the top 250.\n\nWhy isn't Nadal seeded?\n\nThis is Nadal's first Grand Slam tournament without a seeding since the 2005 Australian Open. The top 32 players in the men's and women's draws are seeded, and the seedings are based on the ATP and WTA rankings, which take into account the most recent 52 weeks of results. In theory, Mauresmo could have opted to circumvent the rules and go ahead and award a seeding to Nadal based on his past performances in Paris. But that was never really considered, she said, in part because \"giving protection to some players\" would result in \"a lot of other issues and problems,\" and because \"it also has to be OK with other Grand Slams and everything.\"\n\nWhat difference do seedings make?\n\nPlayers who are seeded, such as Zverev, are guaranteed to avoid going up against another seeded player any earlier than the third round of a Grand Slam tournament, which have 128-player fields and require seven victories to earn a championship.\n\nWhat do other players think?\n\nPlayers tend to agree with Mauresmo's decision, with several saying they believe the seeding system should remain the way it currently is (Wimbledon used to seed players according to their results on grass courts, but has strictly followed the rankings since 2021). \"The way that the seedings work, I think it's appropriate. In this case, it's unfortunate how that happened, but I don't know how you gauge where someone should and shouldn't be seeded based on past or previous success,\" said three-time major champion Andy Murray. \"It'd be quite hard to do that.\"\n\nWho is Alexander Zverev?\n\nHe is a leading player in men's tennis, one who is coming off a title on clay at the Italian Open, won a gold medal at the Tokyo Olympics and was the 2020 U.S. Open runner-up. He reached the semifinals at the French Open each of the past three years, including in 2022, when he played Nadal at that stage but had to stop after tearing ligaments in his right foot during the match. Zverev, a 27-year-old from Germany, is about to face a court proceeding that starts next week in Berlin related to accusations of physically abusing an ex-girlfriend. He does not need to be in court and said he will not be. \"At the end of the day, I do believe in the German system. I do believe in the truth, as well. I have to be certain that, you know, I do know what I did, I do know what I didn't do,\" Zverev said. \"That's, at the end of the day, what's going to come out, and I have to trust in that.\"\n\nWhy is Zverev allowed to play during his ongoing court case?\n\nMauresmo was asked Sunday about Zverev's status and replied: \"As long as the trial isn't finished and there isn't a decision, he's considered innocent and so that's why he's allowed to be part of the draw.\"\n\nAP Sports Week in Pictures: Caitlin Clark's debut, Fury on the ropes and golf's winning shot Tags Dcc Wire Lee-national
